150431935.review:
The story is the beating heart of this game, it's like watching a trainwreck in slow motion already knowing that regardless of how many or few people perish it will forever change the course of their lives in a violent manner that none of them could have foreseen. 

Every single aspect of this 9-year one-man-developed game serves to enhance the story. Some things are made explicit, others left subtle and hanging but with all the pieces necessary to draw your own conclusion. The key is in how these details are communicated. They're scattered throughout incidental dialogue we never flash back to, they're present in the environment as recurring motifs and one-off hints alike, and the developer trusts you to put it all together yourself. And its not that kind of "we'll circle back and explain it all in the end in case you didn't figure it out" trust that undermines its own subtlety for the sake of saying "do you see what I did?". You get it, or you don't, but the beauty is that even just the character-drama and story that is made explicit is enough to carry you through the entire 10-11 hour runtime. 

And yes, the gameplay is also very good and lovingly crafted as well.

150046624.review:
The White:
In a broad sense, "yes".  Iconoclasts gets the recommendation; it does a number of things really well.  Visually, it's very well expressed.  Sound design is decent.  Musically, there are some high points, and it builds atmosphere and tone quite well.  I enjoyed the movement and puzzling mechanics, generally.  The sprite work is extremely detailed, and there's a ton of life and thought in the character dialogue (for most of the villains, anyway).

The Black:
I walked away from this game after blazing through ~70% of it back when it came out.  I recall being ticked off about the stealth fight.  I returned to it recently to 100% it.  I offer some critiques with this in mind.  

Turning boss fights into puzzles is an ambitious decision, and I respect it.  The down-side, is that puzzle logic and combat logic often don't mix well.  As a broad analogy, the best chess player in the world probably isn't all that great at chess if someone's taking pot shots at him from across the room with a 9mm.  Having to split focus between survival and discerning an enemy's gimmick is a really quick way to test a player's patience.

The Gray:
For a while I couldn't figure out what Iconoclast's visual style reminded me of.  It's very obvious, particularly late in the game when the sprite work gets massive and (intentionally) unsettling.  It's Metal Slug.  Once that piece "fit", a lot of the game-play and decisions started to make more sense to me.  I still found a number of the fights frustrating for the sake of it, but I understood what I was working with.

I found most dialogue between the protagonists to be irrelevant.  There was a concerted effort to use them to tell an interesting story, and there was a high note or two, but most of it felt pretty flat.  (But that's just like, my opinion man.)

My penultimate thought is that Iconoclasts jumped on the bandwagon of adding a melee "parry" feature to their Metroidvania.  It's incorporated well; it has a lot of versatility.  Still, it's not a trend or a feature I enjoy, and I earnestly wish developers would stop doing it.

My final thought is that the boss rush is not worth your time, and I wouldn't bother with it unless you really want that last acheevo.

149524625.review:
I'm giving it a thumbs up mostly because Steam doesn't allow to vote with "meh", and the game is not bad enough to deem it unplayable.

To start with, this is not really a metroidvania. I personally feel the game could have come out better had it been stage based, but we know the absolute obsession indie devs have with the former genre. Controls feel fine enough for the platforming tasks at hand, and you have a variety of movies to have you guessing what to do. Levels are more focused on puzzle solving with only some needing pure platforming skills, and all bosses are more concerned with pattern recognition than they are with pure skill. For whatever reason, the designer though that "metroidvania" translated to "taunt the player at all points by placing stuff they can see but not reach until endgame" at all points of the levels, which started being more annoying than anything else. Speaking of annoying, the platforming sections have a good deal of waiting to them with things dumb enought like waiting for the electricity to run out so a platform gets into position, or because you need to reset the bar, as charging it was way too convenient or something.

Tying all chests with the crafting system was also a kinda dumb move, as it makes the chets completely uninteresting unless they hapen to have Ether Fuel, the rare material that for lore reasons is scarce, and by dumb reasons is designed as the core piece of all interesting craftable item. The blueprints you find across the game are not good either, as for whatever reason you somehow need to find 3 different blueprints to create 3 versions of the same item, so whatever you find will likely turn to disappointment as it reveals itslef as your third breathing or wrench spinning extension.

The story is all over the place, and the plot basically exists as a result of psychologists apparently not existing in a world where everyone lets their emotions run rampant. Your allies are all horrible, toxic people, who spend most of their time gaslighting you into doing something, and apparently one of them needs to be befriended in order to make the final boss less awkward (and this needs to be done with answers across the game, so fuck you if already going solo, I guess). It tries to add humor every now and then, but falls flat most of the time, and the story morals are as subtle as having the dev poking your from behind with a pencil while asking "do you get it? huh? you get it?" [spoiler]It was particularly funny when you get to meet Mina for the second time, and notice right away that the entirety of the Isi religion exists just to point out that she's gay. By the end, after having like 3 climatic moments and the mood being dark as all heck, the dev breaks it all and makes sure to slam dunk you with the "religions are stupid" message with the final fight, just to make sure you got it in case the pencil poking wasn't enough.[/spoiler]

Not going to stop anyone trying the game. It's enjoyable to play so long as you weren't expecting an actual metroidvania, but yeah... you have been warned. Just don't pay too much attention to the story, and be prepared to roll your eyes whenever your "friends" talk.

149489942.review: This is an incredibly compelling and very fun game. I imagine I'll be coming back to this one again and again.

149459961.review:
Iconoclasts is a decent game. But I struggle to recommend it.

Iconoclasts was developed by one person. That's it. Everything from the music to the pixel art, to the gameplay and story were entirely developed by one person over the course of 9 years. This is an incredibly impressive feat. The amount of work and dedication required to build something of this scale by one person is astounding. But that's about the only thing about Iconoclasts that makes it memorable. It's not that it's bad but it doesn't allow its own strengths to shine and is bogged down by several issues. The fundamental problem of this game is that none of the elements of the game are great, some are boring or bad, others mediocre to pretty good.

The gameplay is decent. It has some cool ideas. You have a gun that you can swap modes on to fire different types of projectiles. There's three modes that you unlock throughout the game. The regular mode shoots projectiles with auto-aim but has very little range. There's a bomb mode that shoots rolling bombs that's used for some cool puzzles. And there's a beam that lets you swap places with whatever it hits. And you also have a wrench that you can use to melee enemies. Speaking of the wrench, it's the most interesting part your kit. You're a mechanic in this game and the wrench lets you interact with different things in the world in cool ways. But it's a prime example of an underdeveloped game mechanic. Very early on your start to use your wrench to open doors. Then you realize you can swing on hanging bolts with your wrench. So naturally, you expect more and more difficult platforming challenges using this mechanic as you advance through the game. But it doesn't really happen. There are a few wrench jumping puzzles, but not nearly enough creative or skillful uses of it to be satisfying. It's not a fault of the game mechanics but one of boring level design. The controls are snappy enough but the platforming and level design are horribly boring. You're often trudging through the same areas over and over and the movement felt too slow. I won't go too far into the tweaks system other than to say it sucks.

Another problem is the combat in this game. The combat is pretty bad. The main issue is that it doesn't feel like combat, it feels like solving a puzzle for each new enemy type as you try to figure out what tool or technique you're supposed to use to beat it. Once you've got that figured out, combat is a piece of cake. But it's also not fun. Fundamentally, I think that's an issue of poor combat mechanics in general. Your movement isn't all that fast, your attack range is pretty low, dealing with enemies involves using the specific technique required for that enemy so you can't exercise too much creativity when you deal with them. None of the enemies are difficult once you know their trick. That goes doubly for bosses. Boss fights are super rinse and repeat, easily predictable, boring encounters. I did struggle with a few of them. That is until I figured out a strategy that worked for each boss. Then it was a joke. There was no chance of me dying. The pace of the boss fights is also slow. Often, you're spending most of your time waiting around for the boss to make a super predictable, slow and telegraphed move that you can punish. Imagine playing Dark Souls with all the bosses on 50% speed. You're never ever at risk of dying once you've figured out their gimmick and seen the only 3 or 4 different attacks and they have. To be fair, the game does try to be creative and it's not a glitchy experience. But it's just flat.

There are also parts of the game where you have to play as other characters, and their controls and mechanics suck.

To summarize the gameplay of this game. There's not much about the gameplay that's actually engaging. The puzzles are easy and often tedious. The combat is easy and often tedious. It's just a terribly flat experience that feels like a waste of time gameplay wise.

So are there any good parts to this game?

Yes there are. The pixel are is amazing. The music is good but not great. But the most interesting thing about this game is the story.

The story is rather dark and pretty disjointed. It's hard for me to call it a great story because it's not. There's a lot of useless exposition on it and the dialogue is mediocre at best. But it's a good story told well enough. And it's genuinely unique. The characters are interesting. The setting is interesting. It's got good twists and turns. But it's far from a great narrative and there's not a satisfying payoff at the end. That being said, there is one moment near the end of the game that I thought was quite an ingenious implementation of gameplay and story. In this moment I had to make a choice that felt more visceral than any choice I've had to make in a video game before. Either do what the game wanted me to do to progress, or exit the game and consider my incomplete playthrough complete. It's really not much of a choice but it was driving home one of the themes of this game really well.

Ultimately, would I recommend this game? No. In 2023 it's not worth the time and effort it takes to play it. But if you want a unique storyline, it is a decent game. 6.5/10

148855795.review:
After getting 100% of the achievements, I can say with certainty that this is one of my absolute favourite games ever made. Yeah, it's really fun, and the boss fights are extremely creative, chaotic and really satisfying to learn, but this is true for several 'metroidvanias'. What really elevates this is the writing.

Without hyperbole, this is my favourite story in a game. It doesn't seem to be for everyone, but each and every character was made with extreme care into their personality, relationships, values, motivations, etc.. If you replay the game you can see so many tiny details that a first-time player would have literally no way of picking out, but they're there anyway. Several characters, notably General Chrome and Royal for me, stole the show each time they appeared and have cemented themselves as some of my favourite characters in fiction.

The narrative itself is just as intricate, and is greatly strengthened by overarching themes that turn it from entertaining to deeply thought-provoking. So much about the nature of religion and human understanding is explored in such a nuanced way that I don't think I'll ever stop thinking about the implications of the ending. I've heard the tone described as unrelentingly dark by some, and it's true that there's a tonal shift towards tragedy near the middle, but I think what it does so well is contrast that darkness with moments of compassion and kindness, making both extremes hit even harder. This world has stakes unlike any I've seen in a video game, and on my first playthrough I genuinely feared for the fates of these characters.

The only criticism I truly understand is the game's aversion to explaining some of its gameplay gimmicks. Several times you'll be thrown into a fight and be completely unable to damage the boss, without any clear signals as to why. You should absolutely try and figure out what the game is trying to teach you first, but don't be ashamed to look up a guide if it's affecting your fun. Other than that, if you have any interest in games that are both story-driven and fun, please give this one a shot.

147382151.review:
I really wanted to be able to recommend this game, and I hate that this has to be my first negative review :(

There’s a lot going for this game: the pixel art and animations are amazing, and the gameplay and UI is extremely well-polished.

That’s kinda where the positives end… my major gripes with this game are

-The story is cryptic and all the characters seem to speak in convoluted code, so much so that I had pretty much no idea what was going on with the plot at any given time. I couldn’t feel for any of the characters (or who was even on my side or not), since they’re motivations were not very well explained

-The music wasn’t really anything special unfortunately :(

-Although it’s a metroidvania, there were no unique upgrades to find, you’re basically just given all your items linearly. The only reason to stray from the main path is to get materials to craft things called “tweaks,” which have little impact on the actual gameplay and aren’t necessary whatsoever

-It’s very hard to tell the weak points of enemies (especially bosses)-it’s almost like the developer assumed that players would already know this information..?

This is really a shame because I love to support indie developers and give them the benefit of the doubt, and there’s no doubt in my mind that the developer is extremely talented and hard-working. It’s just that there’s some areas of the game that are so beautifully polished and some areas that definitely needed more beta testing.

EN REVIEW :

A lot of wasted potential.
Iconoclasts starts off strong with beautiful graphics, a good soundtrack to set the atmosphere, and fairly simple yet dynamic gameplay. Unfortunately, this doesn't last long. The game remains visually appealing, but the platforming oscillates between being okay and unbearable and frustrating. The worst part might be the boss design, which is just atrocious. However, if it were just that, the game could have been passable. The biggest drawback of the game is its story, which feels like it was written by people who didn't know where they were going and, as a result, went nowhere. The dialogues are a pain and give the impression of being written by 10-year-olds. All of this makes the game a chore to play, and I hoped for nothing more than it to end.

With a coherent story, I might have recommended this game, but certainly not in its current state.

CANNOT recommend this enough. i really suck at words and don't know how to articulate reasons for why i think something is Good in a concise way, but i love it so much that i want to leave a review. iconoclasts will be something that sticks with me for a long time.

I got the free code before Phil could and that is all that matters! 

Game's fun, but really linear for a metroidvania, to the point where it barely qualifies as one. Metroidvania is a stupid name anyway, please come up with a better name for this genre, gamers. 

The tower section was incredibly unnecessarily drawn out for no reason, it was like someone converted a Sierra On-Line adventure game into a platforming game. It's really the only thing I disliked about this game, but I loathed that section so much that I broke a baker's dozen PSA 10 Pokemon card slabs with my fists out of my sheer hatred. 

My only other real complaint is the story is overbearing, especially for what looks like a silly cartoon. It would translate better to a different genre, instead of an action game that has to take sometimes long breaks in game play to dump a bunch of text on you. It can be skipped and it's not bad, just out of place and I feel the message could be conveyed with less text.

Worth a play through if you get it cheap because it's mostly fun, the sprites are nicely animated and expressive, the music goes hard, boss battles are cool, and the general game play is fun, but linear (not necessarily a bad thing). I'll just never play it again because the tower was so unenjoyable and it caused my Pokemon card collection to take a significant hit in value.

143485861.review:
Yes, this is a great metroidvania and will hit the spot if you're craving to play one. This is an impressive game for being created, designed, and built by a single person. With that said, the most you can reasonably expect from this game is a good metroidvania just like the many others you've probably played already. If you haven't really played a metroidvania then I hope you have a good time...

I can't say anything that the developer himself or other players haven't said already. Iconoclasts is well balanced around it's bosses attack patterns and your character's movement. There are three difficulties available including a "harder" mode that doesn't pull its punches like the other two modes. You can switch the difficulty at any time, so you can lower the difficulty if it's too much to manage for your skill level. However, the "real" hard mode isn't available until you've cleared the game once- there's a new game+ difficulty where you die after a single hit.

After completing the game, I'm not really feeling up for another run of the game in challenge mode. But if you end up hooked on Iconoclasts then expect dozens of hours trying to master all of the boss fights and maybe even trying to clear the game with faster times.

143317390.review: cute mix of rpg-esque story and metroid. Very charming

143284880.review:
Got this game because of its cute aesthetic and promise of metroidvania platforming gameplay, which this game does absolutely deliver on, and then I found myself bombarded with messy interpersonal stuff, spats between religious ideologies and people yelling at each other because Drama. Granted, these things aren't bad on their own, and cute games can (must, even) be spiced up with a shot of creepy or serious in order to really shine. However, there are lines that must not be crossed.

There I was, platforming through an electric forest, fighting monsters and evil soldiers and ghosts and solving electric-themed block puzzles, and then I come across an empty house. The mechanic lady I was playing as goes into the house. She and the two people in her party (who don't factor into gameplay at all, mechanic lady just carries them in her pocket, guess this game missed a Kickstarter goal or two) begin to go at each other for their opposing religious beliefs. Before it gets toxic (as I had recalled previous cutscenes that went in a similar direction) I skip the cutscene, which is followed with another cutscene where the house is destroyed due to an orbital sat and one of the party members is missing. Mechanic lady looks for the missing party member and the other one (who is mechanic lady's brother, I should add) yells at her because the fact the other party member is missing is apparently that member's fault, and calls mechanic lady a stupid little girl.

And then I thought about this 'stupid little girl' and her massive wrench and her gun and her grenade launcher and the platforming feats she has pulled off and the things she has killed and her cartoony magnet-shaped hair, and stopped playing on the spot.

Granted, I could keep playing while skipping all the cutscenes, and consequently having absolutely no idea what's going on, and knowing that the 'intended experience' is one where this girl endures constant misery inbetween swinging on massive airborne bolts and solving puzzles where she moves blocks using explosions, but I think that I think that editing the content in a piece of media to be enjoyable by default should be up to the people that MAKE the content, not me.

What a disappointment.

143220375.review:
It's refreshing to see a more puzzle and story focused take on a Metroidvania. The plot is very intriguing even though some of the dialogue where the characters talk about their differing ideologies is a bit ham-fisted at times. You can definetly tell that this was a solo passion-project in both the good and bad ways. The tech system isn't all that great since almost all of them aren't really worth it compared to the one that prevents a single instance of damage and you lose any potential benefit upon taking a hit. There are a few ones that offer straight up new abilities such as a dodge but I question why these aren't just permanent upgrades as their ephemeral nature makes them pretty unreliable and questionably useful. 
Despite these shortcomings (in addition to a lot of general jank) I do love this game a lot. The characters and story are very charming, the pixel art is wonderful and the environmental puzzles are great (except for the tower that place stinks).

143197373.review:
6.5/10

Contemplated a while if i should drop this to negative but i am more convinced it is just me that doesn't understand the finer points of this game as this cannot be treated anything like a traditional metroid game. It is quite unique to what i have played in recent memory but not necessary a better one than others. 

First of all there is so much dialogue, events and weird encounters and even more weird bosses you fight than any average metroid-like game. And puzzles. The kind that are so weird that you sometimes don't know what to do, how to even start solving it. Do i need a item that i get later or do some weird trick with the grenade launcher or what. Sometimes you learn of mechanics by watching a YT video when you are so stuck and you go 'huh, didn't know you could do that'. Yes it is one of those games. 

Game page lists these among it's features: 
*Hours of nut-twisting platform action-adventure
*Numerous densely detailed locations filled with fine-tuned action and puzzles
*20+ gear-grinding, screen-filling boss battles stand in your way

Yeah there is a lot of 'nut-twisting' and 'grinding your gears' all right. Thing is this is the kind of stuff that attracts a certain type of people e.g. the kind that want a LONG game that makes you think and really try to absorb the rules of the world. Well i tried playing this in short stings here and there and it worked for quite some time until i realized i am just stuck and don't really have the energy to once again wonder what i have missed this time. It starts to add up as you progress even though in the end the advancement is quite linear. The problems and puzzles you need to solve to go forward in this tunnel though is anything but linear. 

So a careful recommendation it is. Just don't expect this to be really casual in any way in the end. It has a relaxed mode to help with tough fights but puzzles can drain your stamina just the same so be careful what you wish for. It is the Pièce de Résistance of Joakim Sandberg so expect this to be quite an opus and not just a casual weekend snack regardless of which difficulty level you play it on.

143103844.review:
I didn't think Iconoclasts would be a game I would be a huge fan of. Although actually playing it, Iconoclasts is the type of game I would ABSOLUTELY enjoy. I'm a fan of metroidvania platformers. I've played a few Shantae games and The Messenger (underrated game) and enjoyed those quite a lot. So Iconoclasts was on sale and I decided to finally pick it up and play it.

...DAMN this game is much deeper than I thought. I think that's a huge part of why I like it so much. The story is very deep, it was keeping me wanting more. When something major would happen it would genuinely surprise me and hit me super hard, like "Oh shit, that just happened." 

The reason I like The Messenger so much is for it's clever gameplay, fantastic OST, and amazing humor. Although with The Messenger, the story didn't hit me as hard. Iconoclasts does that job a bit better in my opinion, with how the world in the game is structured. And how literal characters die right then and there in the game. It hits hard. Really hard. 

The gameplay is solid! I didn't 100% it because there's a lot of hidden walls and what not I didn't wanna run around finding just for the sake of "completing" it. But I did like the platforming and puzzles quite a lot. I only had to search up what to do ONCE, and it was because I had to backtrack to a different room to find a hidden path in a wall (lol). The abilities too are very clever, I would be using them in way I didn't think would be possible, or "ohhh, I can do that now!".

The music was.. alright. Nothing that I would go out of my way to listen to again, but it was delightful to listen to in game. Not bad by any means, of course. 

Back to the humor side of things, I do like the characters humor quite a lot. With characters like Royal, Mina, Chrome, Agent White, it was a blast reading their dialogue and having fun. And don't even get me started on the One Concern agent dudes too. They'll just be talking about whatever the hell they want sometimes, and it's hilarious to stand by and listen for a while. I think Elro is the opposite of humor, but even he has his own bit of charm. For how seriously he takes things, and.. not so seriously at the same time.

Overall, I like this game quite a lot! It definitely takes a top spot in the games that I've played in 2023. If you like platformers, metroidvanias, all that good stuff, then play this game!

142919986.review: Incredible story! Wish the combat was a bit more wrench focused. Great puzzles! A little bit more structured than a traditional Metroidvania.

142880203.review:
Juegazo!!! ya sea porque no me lo esperaba o porque este Metroidvania es sinónimo de calidad, la verdad es que me ha encantado.
PROS: 
El pixel art es sublime y las animaciones de los personajes están muy cuidadas. 
La historia me ha parecido muy currada y original, a diferencia de otros juegos donde la trama es simplemente un telón de fondo desde el inicio hasta el finalboss. En Iconoclast cada personaje tiene un papel importante en la historia, tienen una personalidad bien diferenciada y me ha sorprendido mucho el toque adulto que tiene el juego (algo que no te esperas en un principio).
La jugabilidad me ha parecido muy fluida y satisfactoria, el personaje se mueve rápido y responde bien, algo muy de agradecer en un metroidvania, donde tenemos que estar desplazándonos de un lugar a otro con frecuencia.
El sistema de combate y las habilidades, así como las mecánicas de los puzzles, se notan trabajados, no es un copia pega de otros juegos.

CONTRAS:
Por otro lado, he de decir que el juego se ve a veces interrumpido por cinemáticas que, aunque interesantes, rompen el ritmo del juego (se pueden saltar). Tendremos habilidades principales para acceder a nuevas zonas y otras secundarias, que a mi parecer tienen poca utilidad, ya que una de las principales características del juego hace que en muchas ocasiones no podamos utilizarlas al recibir daño, con lo cual dejas de depender de ellas rápidamente. En cuanto a los bosses, en varias ocasiones tendremos que averiguar su mecánica particular para vencerlos, la cual no es siempre es obvia y puede llegar a ser frustrante morir varias veces seguidas por no saber lo que tenemos que hacer (una vez sabemos como vencerlos hay que reconocer que mola que se lo hayan currando y no sea simplemente un machacabotones).

El juego me ha llevado unas 14 horas completarlo al 100%, desbloqueando un "modo desafío" y un un "modo boss rush". Los logros no son muchos y no son difíciles de conseguir, requieren algo de habilidad con el mando y paciencia o una guía a mano para localizar los coleccionables.
En definitiva, si te gustan los metroidvanias y el pixel art, este juego no te va a decepcionar!
 9/10

142780570.review:
Apparently this game was made by a single person over the course of 8 years, so it deserve a lot of praise for that alone. However, the more I played the game, the less I enjoyed playing it. The graphics and the music are great. The gameplay is nothing special (pretty average platformer gameplay). The game is unnecessarily long, and the story is unbelievably convoluted and stupid. For a game that you can beat in 10-ish hours, there is a ridiculous amount of text-based exposition that you are fed through cut scenes. You have party members, but they don't really contribute anything (except for the rare instances where your party gets split up and you have to play as a different character). The tweak mechanic doesn't really add anything, and it would be possible to finish the game without getting any of the tweaks at all. Finally, you are locked out of the "true" ending of the game unless you pick the correct dialogue options.

Unless you are a die-hard fan of Metroidvania type games, skip this.

142658735.review: Just beat this game after owning it for a couple of years. This is a metroidvania with some puzzle elements and really challenging bosses. The game does allow you to change the difficulty mid-game (just save and quit to menu and then reload your save). It runs on pretty much any computer and is extremely fun to play. Great graphics, great soundtrack.

142452855.review:
Iconoclasts is a nice 15 to 20 hour character-driven metroidvania. A strange and interesting world that knows how to keep you guessing, well-written characters that are all fighting their own battles, all tied together with charming pixel-art graphics.
The only minor gripe I have is the control scheme. On keyboard it uses the arrow keys plus 'zxcv', but the jump button is neither the up arrow nor the spacebar, which is some kind of cardinal sin. The controls are remappable though, so you can just fix this yourself. Also, some of the more situational functions are on rather awkward button combinations (which can't be remapped), rather than just using an extra button.

142385727.review: Game has it's ups and downs, and I would't put it up against the greats of the genre, but it's a super solid 8/10.  Pick it up if you're a fan of good metroidvanias.  Fair warning the story, while good, is an overall downer.  Though it does end on a happy note.

142384167.review:
Fantastic game that I still think about a year after playing it.

It's a very well designed semi-linear Metroidvania with excellent world building, strong characters, and a lot of story/plot for its length.  Minute-to-minute gameplay is engaging if occasionally a little clunky for certain alternate characters, it's almost always clear where to go next *and* where you can go with your latest skill upgrade.  There's a large variety of environments and battles requiring clever use of skills more than raw player talent.  Graphics are excellent and keep things un-cluttered while still conveying emotion where the story requires it.  The plot is very, very good and gets you invested in the world and its inhabitants, developing both supporting characters and many of the antagonists.  Serious stuff goes down in this game and you will certainly care about it when it does.  10/10, would play again.

142098998.review:
i absolutely loved this game for so long, all the way up until i made one discovery that immediately made me despise it. the game play is amazing, the combat is fun, the boss battles are all different and require unique strategies to get through, the enemy variety is great, and the story is pretty decent. 

unfortunately this game is one of those that decides to punish its players for not knowing something that it never tells them. if you want the "true ending," you apparently have to have made the perfect dialogue choices throughout the entire game, and if you make even a single mistake, it completely locks you out of it, making you have to replay the entire game from the start to fix the mistake you weren't even aware you were making.

now i'm fine with decisions mattering, it makes it so you actually have to think about your actions. but when the game doesn't make it obvious exactly how important said decisions are, it just feels like you're being betrayed. i agree that your dialogue should affect how the characters see you and interact with you, but those effects should only be to the characters the dialogue is for, NOT FOR THE ENDING OF THE ENTIRE GAME. 

im the kind of person who always goes for the true ending or as close to 100% as i can get without spending 30 extra hours finding every collectible, but when you just pull the rug out from under me last second and say i have to restart the whole game, im just not gonna keep playing. the game is a 10/10 in all aspects, but the devs just decide to kick you in the throat in the last second with no explanation and ruins the whole experience for me. i cannot say in good faith that i recommend the game to anybody like me who wants the true ending, because it just straight up says no unless you made the perfect decisions by accident for all of the hours of gameplay, and that just is unfair.

141929140.review: A colorful metroidvania with charming pixel art, challenging puzzles, and a surprisingly dark story, Iconoclasts follows the journey of a rebellious mechanic named Robin as she traverses the world, escaping the clutches of the One Concern and helping everyone along the way. The game has many different locations to explore, each with its own intricate puzzles and secrets. The player uses a large wrench and a blaster with various modes to solve unique puzzles and defeat powerful bosses. The puzzles have a lot of thought put behind them, making the player use specific game mechanics to get through them. The boss fights are unique and challenging, often requiring players to figure out the gimmick behind one and how to use it to their advantage. As Robin continues her journey, she meets new people who become her friends and allies as they assist and travel with her. The story wasn't nearly as lighthearted as I thought it would be, but I consider it to be the game's best part. The characters had in-depth personalities, backgrounds, and personal problems to deal with as they grew as people. The game also has collectibles and a few sidequests to give the player more gameplay beyond the main story. There's even a challenge mode for hardcore players who want a more formidable experience. Overall, Iconoclasts isn't one of the best games I have ever played, but I still consider it a unique experience that metroidvania and indie game fans would enjoy.

141896042.review: One of the best metroidvanias I've played. The gameplay is great, with a good mix of puzzles and bosses. Every boss (of which there are 25 I believe) is completely different, so the combat never becomes stale. The design is gorgeous with top tier pixel art and beautiful music. On top of that all, the story is really captivating and original. 10/10, could not recommend more.

140070956.review: I liked most things about this game- most of the characters, the story, the gameplay, loved the music. I just wish the game weren’t so slow. The characters don’t move very fast (there a couple of hallways that were wayyyy too long for my liking) and then the instances where the dialogue is fixed, it comes pretty slow also. It’s worth not skipping for the story, but it could’ve been faster. By the end of the story I wasn’t up to trudging around for collectibles because it felt like too much of a chore. There also isn’t a ton of metroidvania ability gating to get through the game. A few places to wander around a bit and find a new skill, but most of the backtracking and revisiting old zones is for collectibles. There were 2 areas I didn’t even revisit. 139583316.review:
Iconoclasts is a colorful indie metroidvania that starts out with a pleasant enough story: You're an unlicensed mechanic in a society where those in control want to be the sole source of making thigns function. Your trusty wrench lets you tighten bolts for puzzles, and you get a stungun as well. And eventually a few other gun options. So far, so normal. But by the latter half of the game, the whole thing has taken a very JRPG turn. Things get surprisingly dark, and then keep getting darker for a while. It's an unexpected contrast to the brightly colored SNES-style graphics.

The boss fights - and there are many - I would describe as "tough but fair". Usually it took me an attempt or two to figure out what I was supposed to do, and then another attempt or two to actually pull it off successfully. But every time I died I could blame myself for not dodging properly or shooting the right thing at the right time.

The puzzles were pleasant, naturally many require upgrades that you receive along the course of the story, so you go back and handle them. And clearly there's plenty of hidden nonsense since I went back to try to sweep up all the mapped chests I'd been unable to open before making my final run on the boss, but still finished having found only 81% of the components. A few sections had you control other characters with different control schemes, which I didn't love, but they were generally brief.

All in all, a worthy metroidvania that doesn't waste your time (a bit more backtracking than I'd like notwithstanding), certainly worth a look on sale. Not best ever, but quite solidly good.

139575384.review: I can't even begin to describe how overlooked this game is. The gameplay and puzzles are fun as hell and it feels good to control, the music slaps and fits every area perfectly, not to mention said areas and the characters that inhabit them are made of immaculately crafted pixelart, and the story had me captivated the whole way through. And all of this was made by one dude over the course of 7 years. I could gush about this game all fucking day but nothing I'd say could justify how great it is so all I have left to ask is why the hell is this not in your steam library? Thank you for this godsend of a game Joakim Sandberg, I wish you the best of luck in all of your future projects.

139514546.review: Great game, wish i could play it for the fisrt time again

139327768.review:
This game looks innocent and simple, but it's a trick. This is easily one of the best metroidvanias I've ever played and it deserves way more recognition.
The gameplay and movement is smooth. The progression is perfect as it never gets stale or boring. It's clear that this creator loves building bosses because there are so many boss battles and each one requires a lot more than just blasting away. Many of them require you to puzzle out just how to hit it or which weapon to use and it's always so satisfying when I finally figured it out, which usually only took 2 or 3 tries at most.
The story is what really surprised me though. I thought this would just be a fun romp through another action platformer, but I literally teared up at one point. There is intrigue, mystery, and the brutality of blind belief. I never expected that the main reason I wouldn't be able to put this down would be because I just had to know what happens next.
I really can't praise this game enough. The character design, level design, boss design, and every other aspect of it are so beautiful and colorful without being distracting. 
This also worked flawlessly on my Steam Deck.
There are even a couple of post game bosses that are difficult, but fun. if you can find them.
If you've ever enjoyed a metroidvania and want one with smooth controls and a disturbing, but brilliant story then you cannot pass up Iconoclasts.

139151185.review: While I really, REALLY wish I could recommend this game to other players, there is one boss fight near the end of the game that's just an exercise in tedium and really drags down the game. You walk slowly to the right and hit the boss, who then knocks you back and you repeat the process. Over. And. Over. Again. All the while, the boss is slowly tossing out weak attacks that knock you back a good distance, and the windup on your attack in the fight is slow enough that you can be hit if the boss started their attack at the same time. I died the first time I fought them, and if I lost a second time, I probably would have just uninstalled the game rather than try again because the fight was that tedious. I cannot recommend this game just because of that one moment.

138323949.review:
Iconoclasts is a bit of an odd game. Graphically, it is very obvious that much love and care was put into this game. But everything else about it just... clashed.

Gameplay wise, it is very simple. But I do not say this as if it were a con. If anything, it is commendable how straightforward it is. It's impossible to deny how intuitive it is to just simply hop in and begin exploration immediately or engage in field combat with random critters. However, there were still a number of choices made that ranged from being 'mildly annoying' to 'aggravating', with my biggest complaint being directed towards boss battles. They're not hard at all once you understand that outside the first mini-boss battle at the beginning of the game, they're all QTE fights. But the amount of visual and audio clutter caused by these bosses makes it unclear what you're initially supposed to do. I ended up dying an embarrassing amount of times to the desert boss because i just couldn't tell how Royal was helping me. The dozens of games that I've played before that utilize AI controlled cross hairs on a platform game, this is the first one that I've seen that uses them to HELP ME instead of KILLING ME.

Personally, music is a very important factor when it comes to deciding whether or not I keep playing the game. In the first 30 seconds after leaving Robin's house for the first time, I came very close to stopping my play through because of how bland and generic the music sounded. Moving onto different areas to listen to a few more tracks did not change my opinion.

Story-wise, its a bit of a mess. The game does not ease you into the lore of its world, and instead starts moving the story forward assuming that you already know what's going on. With what little I experienced in the 2 hours that I played, I feel that there's an intriguing story unfolding in the background, but I just couldn't feel bothered to see the game thru because of how the story was being delivered. It does not help at all that the character you control, Robin, was made a silent protagonist for no discernible reason, so  instead of being able to piece together on your own a view of the world by talking to NPCs and engaging in two-sided dialogue, you have to wait until the next story event's cut scene plays for the game to do that for you.  

Despite my initial compliments for the art direction, I do not feel that a brightly colored world helps set the tone for a story involving an oppressive theocracy, especially when most of the characters engage you in a serious tone while their bubbly sprites bounce around.

I feel that, fundamentally, there's a good game buried underneath all these complaints somewhere. But I'm personally not gonna bother unearthing it myself. This is just not a game that clicks with me.

137038614.review:
[i]Iconoclasts[/i] is probably konjak's magnum opus. It has all the things his games are known for (tight gameplay, great pixel art, a killer soundtrack, elaborate boss fights) but refined and turned up to 11.

There seems to be a lot of divisiveness in regards to its narrative aspects for some reason, but personally I loved the story, characters, and world this game had to offer. If it all clicks with you then you'll probably feel compelled to continue partly out of a strong desire to see what happens next. I 100% completed this game a long time ago but I still think about it from time to time just because it left such a strong impression on me. I'd love to see its universe expanded upon more; Everything is wrapped up pretty nicely by the time the credits roll, but it leaves just enough questions open to make you wonder about its larger mysteries.

My only complaint regarding its narrative is that sometimes it moves along at a lightning pace with major events often happening quickly one after another (especially in the game's latter half). Some more gameplay segments inserted between those big events would have been very welcome. Not only because of how good the core gameplay is, but also for helping pad out the game's runtime more.

On the topic of gameplay: It's a puzzle-Metroidvania with a heavy narrative focus. The protagonist is equipped with an oversized wrench that she can use to interact with enemies and the environment in various ways, and progression is usually tied to using it to solve puzzles that impede your progress. Boss fights typically follow a similar style of feeling like dangerous puzzles that you have to solve before you can actually inflict damage. There isn't a single boss in this game that isn't ludicrously over-the-top in some way, which is always a big plus in my book.

Overall, the excessive cutscenes and dialogue might be a big turnoff for some, but I honestly think this is one of the best and most memorable action-puzzle-narrative-platformers available. Here's hoping we'll get to return to its universe in the future.

136019204.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
An extraordinarily polished and beautiful game effectively ruined by its story, Iconoclasts presents a top-tier Metroidvania that tries to thwart your every effort to enjoy it with a deeply pessimistic story and a cavalcade of depressing and infuriating characters. If you aren’t in the mood to be bummed out today, skip the cutscenes or skip the game.

I have to be [i]very[/i] brief with gameplay, visuals, and audio, because I need a [i]lot[/i] of words for the story, which sucks because everything besides the story is phenomenal.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As Metroidvanias go, Iconoclasts is near-perfect: a large world with many different environments to explore and secrets to uncover as you unlock new abilities, puzzles to solve, combat that is interesting and varied, and controls that feel tight, responsive, and peppy. The wrench weapon/tool is a fresh idea, letting you interact with mechanisms to solve puzzles and do fun acrobatic platforming. The game offers several difficulties, and most players should find one of appropriate challenge. A “relaxed” option makes you invincible, so you can play just for the puzzles/story. You probably won’t need this mode.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
This game is [i]gorgeous.[/i] Colorful and clean pixel art clearly communicates the game’s challenges, and the character art is charming and smoothly animated. The game’s environments feel varied and have a unique personality. The UI is helpful and unobtrusive.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Iconoclasts’ soundtrack is excellent, though perhaps not as iconic as classics in the genre. Its overall sound design is clear and effective.

[h1]Story[/h1]
I’ve had to be brief in the other sections to cover what I think is the most important part of this review: the story is [i]awful.[/i] Not that it’s badly written—quite the contrary, with deep characters, lots of backstory, and some surprising and clever twists and turns. The few times it [i]wants[/i] to be humorous and charming, it shows it’s able to; it just chooses to be deeply unpleasant almost all of the time.

First, the characters. Robin (the player character), through body language, actions, and a select few moments where you can choose her response, is depicted as determined, positive, and helpful. Literally all of the other significant characters in the game are petulant at best and infuriating at worst. As you explore the other characters—including your allies!—you’ll find a miserable cast of obnoxious, churlish, self-centered, pompous, self-righteous, narcissistic, fanatical, back-stabbing sons-of-somethings that aren’t even fun to hate.

The plot is equally miserable: an enormously pessimistic, passive-nihilist take on faith, belief, and tradition that lays out several groups of “believers” and then largely depicts them all as foolish and awful—including the “atheist” viewpoint, which is carried by characters who act like complete a**holes. The conflict between all of these horrible groups culminates in an ending which is pitch-perfect in its cynicism—and which I would have cheered if I hadn’t already been in a frame of mind where I’d just as soon watch the planet explode.

Minor spoiler: [spoiler]Then, right at the end, Robin—the only character who serves as a bastion of light in all of this misery—is forced to do something that tarnishes her character as well. And it’s not in a cutscene; the game puts that deed right in your hands. You [i]must[/i] sully her or the game won’t progress.[/spoiler]

The story is so deeply unpleasant that I genuinely wish that I’d skipped all of the dialogue and cutscenes, and would be concerned for anyone playing the game who struggles with depression or anxiety.

What’s most frustrating is that this plot and these characters would have been [i]delightful[/i] as a dark satire, mocking its targets rather than simply lambasting them, and the ending which so many have criticized would have been [i]hilarious[/i] at the end of a comedy. It’s a tragically missed opportunity.

135976342.review:
[u]Short version, no spoilers:[/u] absolutely beautiful art/spritework, & surprisingly charming characters & moving story, but somewhat marred by tedious puzzle rooms & clunky, finicky gimmick bosses.

[u]Long version, possible spoilers:[/u] I was so love-hate with this game before i finished it... so many needlessly inconvenient & frustrating design choices, which i can overlook when things really get going, but then just as i'm starting to enjoy myself [i]another[/i] one of these infuriatingly abstruse & finicky bossfights show up & nearly make me quit playing. But ultimately, i've landed on giving a positive review — it was a memorable experience & i'm glad i played it. I really fell inlove w/ several o/t characters [spoiler](especially Agent Black OMG💗💗💗)[/spoiler]  — they can come across as quite over-the-top at first, but they have a lot of depth & actually have agency, it's refreshing how everyone's individual motivations & personalities are woven together to move the plot along without any of them having to break character or be temporarily reduced to a mindless plot device. Everyone acts the way they would act at all times (except Robin, the protagonist, who's more-or-less a blank player-insert character). Had high points i'll never forget & climactic resolutions to character arcs where it mattered most. Good game, even if unnecessarily frustrating & clunky at times.

132783270.review:
Good metroidvania, more linear than the average one and with a bit less secrets scattered around the map, but the gameplay is fun and the artstyle and music are great. The bosses are all extremely cool too.

What really sets it apart is its story and worldbuilding, I usually do not care much about these things and focus mainly on gameplay but the themes this game covers and the events that occur and the way they are told got me hooked from start to finish, I did not expect the storytelling to be so crude and direct but I was ultimately pleased with it. I've seen a bunch of people being dissatisfied with the finale but I personally think it wraps up the story well enough. 

Also easy enough to get all Achievements, most are simply obtained by progressing through the story, a couple for finding secrets, another pair for getting 100% and the last one for beating No-Hit Mode, which isn't as difficult as it sounds.

EDIT after beating Challenge mode: the last couple bosses feel a bit ridicolous and not properly playtested, they are way harder than the rest of the game, especially the second to last boss, and the fights often feel like complete RNG, a minor inconsistency that overall doesn't impact the quality of the game

132200531.review:
The pixel art and punchy sound effects make this seem like the most gamey video game ever and that's not at all a bad thing, in fact its incredibly charming, but it masks that this game has a story to tell.

The game structure consists of a series of metroidvania-esque levels filled with puzzles and combat and upgrades and secrets that you can explore to find. There's a lot of mechanics and not all of them are perfectly executed like the passive buff system, but the combat is fun and the puzzles make you think. The moment-to-moment gameplay and story beats are really well paced with each level having small story moments as you progress through them and then get out of your way so you can play the game. Neither part overstays its welcome and the game doesn't have moments that are bogged down with one or the other. As much as the gameplay is fun, the story and the writing and the characters are where the game really shines. You really get a sense of who everyone is with their competing worldviews and what brought them to those beliefs. Everyone is governed by their ideology except for the protagonist, Robin who has the sole goal of helping people. She's mute and unlike most silent protagonists, her lack of speech furthers the narrative by contrasting her with those around her. Others bicker and grandstand but she just buckles down and gets things done. Her lack of speech doesn't limit her as a character though, she's incredibly expressive through animations and action and like the rest of the characters in the game, leaves a lasting impression.

I played about half of this game, had some fun, and could tell it was going somewhere, but I moved on to play other things. That's not to say the beginning wasn't good, it was but I habitually try and move on. Recently I've been trying to make an effort to finish more games and this was on the list and I'm glad I decided to come back to it. This game really is something special. Its got the kind of story and message and theming that punches way above its weight. Its the kind of story you'd expect to see in some bigger budget game that cares more about the cinematography than actually being a fun game. But Iconoclasts never forgets its a video game. Even the emotional last few bosses go down with that classic, satisfying chain explosion you expect from a retro run and gun game. That's what makes this game so special and I think it expands the scope of what games can do as a medium.

130787449.review:
Iconoclasts is a story driven metroidvania with good bosses and good characters.  The base gameplay of exploring the world and fighting overworld enemies is mediocre at best, but the story, worldbuilding, and bosses make playing through it worth it.

So the base gameplay is exploring mostly linear areas as the main character Robin.  You attack with a wrench and a stungun and as the game goes on you will obtain a few additional wrench abilities and gun types that open up additional areas, as is typical with metroidvanias.  The problem arises in that your moveset isn't very varied, and the tools you're given are very frontloaded so you reach your final form so to speak relatively quickly.  Its not bad, but your toolset (ironically despite being a mechanic) is just not as deep as you'll find in other metroidvanias so it just isn't exciting.  This stops mattering however, once you get into a boss fight. The bosses in the game are the best parts of the gameplay.  There are a lot of them in the game and each one feels unique with its own distinct moveset and strategies to fight them.  Finding a new one is definitely the highlight of exploration.

Lets get into the story then.

Lets get the downsides out of the way first.  There are times in the dialogue where the delivery falls flat.  It isn't often enough to ruin it as a whole, but there's a decent amount of cringe.  The most prime example is that there's a pretty important character who travels with you throughout the game, and pretty much every other character in the game who meets her makes the same lame cringe joke about her being smelly.  Another bad aspect of the game is the sheer amount of jargon that it throws at you, especially early on in the game.  The game will highlight important phrases and concepts to try to make it easier to understand, but there are a lot of times that you will open a lorebook and get assaulted by a wall of text full of words you have no idea what they're referring to.  By the end of the game you will come to understand it all naturally as these concepts are introduced in more detail to you one at a time, but in the beginning these lorebooks are very overwheliming and I recommend not trying too hard to understand them at first.

If you can get past the cringe and jargon, the story and world thats there is immensely interesting.  The worldbuilding is very deep and unique and the story has many unexpected twists and turns.  The characters that you meet along the way are also generally pretty interesting (again if you can ignore the occasional bit of cringe).  There is a wide array of them and I always found myself wanting to see what would happen to them next, especially the villains.  I don't want to get into any more details because it's worth it to experience all of it blind so I can't say any more than this, but these aspects are probably the strongest the game has to offer.

In summary, the metroidvania gameplay is okay and is saved by its bosses.  If your biggest want from the game is fun exploration and finding powerups then this game might be a miss for you.  However if you're looking for a strong narrative experience with some engaging bosses littered all along the way then you should pick this one up.

130153619.review: It looks really good and controls are very tight. It's not really a metroid game but more like a puzzle platformer with regular boss fights. The puzzles are entertaining enough, though suffer from the Portal 2 single player problem where they focus too much on introducing new things rather than combining concepts together or building in complexity, it feels like the training wheels never really come off. The bosses are a joy (save one or two duds) and have a wide variety from regular shoot n dodge bosses to tag team puzzle fights. The story is a hodgepodge of strange ideas and attempted pathos powered by selfish pricks who constantly refuse to address their problems until they end up being destroyed by them and I love it. Some may reasonably find the plot suffocating or even incomprehensible but hey, it and the game itself have kept me entertained the several times I've gone through it.

129954053.review:
There are only two reasons why I'm recommending this game.
First off, it looks too good not to. It might sound shallow, but this is what I dream the standard for pixel graphics was. The GBA aesthetic, the quality of the animations and the amount of effort put into every detail is just too amazing to go unrewarded.
Secondly, the game is just really solid mechanically. The puzzles are good, the boss battles are varied and well designed.

However, I'd be lying if I didn't say that I forced myself to finish this game, for two really big reasons.
The writing just sucks, and it's way, way, way too intrusive. It doesn't do a good job to introduce you to the admitedly interesting setting and it doesn't do a good job trying to keep you there. Dialogues with unlikeable "quirky" characters are around every corner, keeping you stuck for minutes. As absurd and ill-fitting as the ending was, it being (mostly) wordless was a pleasant if jarring surprise.
The game also poorly rewards exploration in two ways. Most of what you can find are materials to build upgrades, of which you can equip three. After crafting a couple I couldn't find a single new one I wanted, so I soon stopped caring about opening chests. On top of that the game makes backtracking through certain environment a really annoying affair, meaning that if it's not disinterest that will kill your treasure hunting it will probably be frustration.

In the end it's the nature of this game that emotionally affected me the most rather than the story. I honestly hope it was economically successful and that the developer keeps making games, as long as there's somebody else there to take care of the writing.

129904783.review:
Overall the gameplay is very smooth, colorful and engaging and it is the best showcase that this game was clearly a labor of love. The diverse cast draws you in and you really get attached the the main character. 

I had such high hopes for the narrative, but it falls flat by the end. Creative and crafty storytelling becomes predictable and, in some cases, insensitive. Characters who show promising growth in the beginning fail to change or learn from their mistakes at EVERY, single opportunity given to them. But one of the most grating aspects of the narrative is how often other characters insistently bully the games second main character, Mina, for her rank odor. 

This detail is established at the start of the game and is treated like a running joke that fails to be funny. This game pits white westerners versus brown easterners and thought it was appropriate to label the brown easterner as smelly and never fix the issue of her smell. At one point, a mock enemy will claim to be able to smell her which will get you caught during the stealth mission. Since "brown easterners are smelly" is a real stereotype, it just seemed weird to make it the only one in this game and apply it to a young woman. As the game goes on, it becomes irritating to hear especially when the character's disposition could have easily been fixed and used as a growth opportunity. 

Poor character development (Elro and Royal), unbeatable and annoying enemies, and a less than stellar climax has me walking away from Iconoclasts really disappointed after seeing what it could have been. 

3/5 stars

The music does a great job of communicating individual scene emotions and the went through the daunting task of creating and composing over 50 tracks for this game. 
Story (4)
The story’s first half and second half feel like they were written by two different people with different visions of the game and feature some really weird plot holes/narrative issues.
--- Spoiler cut---
[spoiler]
So the first half of the game is a (semi) light hearted romp that features heavy emphasis on comedy and quick jokes. They introduce several concepts and organizations at the beginning that ultimately all end up being basically the same organization. While it is a comedy the weird silliness of the one concern is very forgivable because they are COMICALLY inept. Regardless if it is blowing up their own people, accidently hiring known criminals or any dialogue featuring Chrome or White.
The second half of the game is just them throwing a bunch of vague nonsense at you trying desperately to get you to take the game seriously. They basically reinvent part of the start of the game to have the brother be a highly wanted and dangerous criminal for no real reason since at the time they were getting him on a different criminal charge. This brother then goes on to make literally every wrong decision for the rest of the game. At the end they just start having bosses appear for no reason to act as speedbumps without any actual foreshadowing or reason. Lastly they took all the opportunity for character development for Royal just killed him in a weird moment towards the end for no reason. Honestly between the story taking a sharp nose dive and the gameplay ramping up insanely in difficulty at the end  I was just begging for this game to end.   
[/spoiler]
Gameplay  (6)
Same as the story it feels like they had very good understanding of teaching the player mechanics and ensuring ever challenge felt fun and let the player try and figure out solutions. The bosses all feel like skill challenges with fun gimmicks.
The second half of the gameplay just consisted of dozens of enemies that are either completely unkillable or only take damage under an extremely specific set of circumstances. The bosses feel like the developer didn’t beta test them the [spoiler] Mother and Worm [/spoiler] bosses featuring mechanics that I honestly could not figure out as they had not been taught or featured anywhere else in the game resulting in over 30 frustrating deaths each before I finally just gave in and turned on invincibility mode. It is frankly insane to me that of the 7 hours of slogging through suffering the second half was they didn’t have the time to including a signboard to teach the [spoiler]  gear or swing unscrewing [/spoiler] mechanics.

129440970.review: Iconoclasts is a quality Metroidvana that feels like Megaman mixed with DuckTails from the NES.  The pixle graphics are wonderful and vibrant, the steam punk setting and characters are all great, and the music is just right for the game.  I'm a life long Metroidvaia fan and have many fond memories of the games Iconoclasts references, and as such this game fully delivered on what I expected it too, nostalgia wrapped up in a slick modern game.  It instantly feels familiar, but delivers just a bit more than a remake.   That said it didnt hold my attention.  I cant point to any real faults in my experience with this game.  I tried it, played an hour or so on a few separate days and then never hand any desire to come back to it.  I'm not recommending this game not because it's bad, but because I feel like there are other similar games that are just a bit more engaging.

129327629.review: This is a really good game, but I recommend adjusting your expectations away from this being a metroidvania and more towards it being an extremely linear puzzle-platformer (that uses some metroidvania ability progression). with a strong narrative. There is backtracking if you want, but you shouldn't do it, because all you get is upgrade resources for tweaks (basically charms) which are really good, they are sort of weak, but also they disable as you take damage and you have to do various to re-enable them, meaning skilled people get a helping hand they don't need and unskilled people don't get to make use of the system much. I played this expecting a metroidvania the first time and I didn't have a very good experience and quit shortly before the ending (didn't know I was that close) because it's very frustrating playing it. Playing it for what it is however, I enjoyed it a lot this time, both the stories and the actual gameplay. The only major criticism I have against the game except for the largely pointless tweaks system is at times poor communication on how to beat/damage certain enemies. Not just bosses (which is fine to some extent, though some are obtuse), but regular enemies too. I'll take an example (but there are more). There is one tell (a green circle around an enemy when doing a move that through the entire game mean one thing - swing your wrench to counter the attack. But toward the very end and only one specific enemy it means "use the switch gun" this is not communicated in any way, I had to look up a guide to figure it out. There are more examples of this. Other than that it's a very enjoyable game. I also like you're playing a mechanic not some warrior. The story is great. I recommend it.

[b]Iconoclasts is an incredible side-scrolling metroidvania-esque game.[/b]
The game has incredibly witty and good dialogue, with a simple yet very well written plot and story, with memorable characters, although some of the characters introduced near the end of the story (not spoiling what or who,) do feel very rushed and underdeveloped.

The gameplay is extremely solid, working like a puzzle solver and metroidvania in one, although some puzzles may overstay their welcome if you end up having to redo them more than twice.

In this game, almost every bossfight and generally just exploring the levels and finding secrets or in NG+ finding new ways to get them is a very fun experience! And this game has alot of secrets and in terms of the aspects of general gameplay, it performs very well.

Overall, after my first run and being a quarter way into my NG+ run (having not tried challenge mode yet,) I would say this game is incredible and a lovely experience, and I highly advise giving it a try if you love side scrollers, shoot'em'ups, metroidvanias, or platformer-puzzle solvers.

All in all, Iconoclasts is very phenomenal and gets a [b]19.4/20.0[/b] rating from me.  There are a handful of minor things in the game that were somewhat underwhelming the characters aforementioned at the end of the game who got unfortunately low story telling, and somewhat frustrating puzzles that are easy to mess up, or always reset on room re-entry that aren't very fun / timeconsuming to repeat.  These are not major detractors because of how few and far they are, and how the rest of the game is great.

127605442.review:
I found this game to be very enjoyable, but it almost certainly is not a universal experience.
Compared to other metroidvanias, Iconoclasts is much more story focused. Rather than a cutscene at the beginning, end, and maybe a few in the middle, expect a cutscene or dialogue every 20mins to an hour. I liked the story and most of the characters, but keep in mind they may not engage you.
The world/level design was for the most part great, excluding 1 area, which was just ok. 100%ing is a bit tedious, as a lot of the secrets are behind fake walls.
I liked how most of the abilities unlocked both progression in the world and more combat options, allowing for enemies to not get stale as the game progressed.
It's decently long, so that it feels worth the price, but not long enough to feel like a slog.
The difficulty was pretty fair, there weren't unfair platforming sections or many hard puzzles.
I felt it to be a great game, well above average, and am excited to know what the Dev's next project is.
