125485543.review:
I love metroidvania games, so when I saw Iconoclasts on the S-Tier of Metroidvania Review's youtube Tier List series I popped right over to the Steam Store and picked it up. It was even on sale. Nice!
I normally like to 100% games of the genre, so I was ready for a grand old double-digit hour long playthrough of exploration and ability unlocks. But well before the half-way point I was watching the progress percentage in the save menu like a hawk, hoping it would go up faster because I was ready to be done with this game.
To give credit where due, the art in this game is excellent. Very nice 16-bit pixel animation, with vibrant stages and enemies. But everything other than that suffers from too much ambition and a lack of focus on getting the basic mechanics of the game right.
The story/writing, of which there is A LOT of for a game of this length, tries to punch far above its actual competence level; the philosophies and "inner conflicts" of all main cast are far from subtle, and interrupt the actual gameplay with frequency. Which would be less of an issue if more of the characters were likable. Mina, Royal, Elro, Chrome, and most of the supporting cast are not. 
But that could be well overlooked if the actual gameplay was on point. But it just isn't. Hit boxes and interaction points are fuzzy, making puzzles more frustrating than difficult because the mechanics are holding you back. Also, many of the environmental puzzles only help to draw attention to the awkward limitations on how your character can attack/aim/interact with the world compared to most other games in the genre. Combat encounters can be frustrating because, while the game is MOSTLY good at communicating what the trick is for any given enemy, the slop in how your attacks might register can make it seems like you need to try a different tactic, and this can be true after repeated attempts.
The character improvement is very thin. With tweaks rarely feeling of much consequence or importance. Some of the weapons/items are very nifty, but that shine inevitably gets sullied by some puzzle made unreasonably fiddly by the loose gameplay.
Also, as a final bad taste, [spoiler]the game checkpoints you as you walk into the final boss room, despite there being a save point a few rooms over and no combat between. This prevents you from changing tweaks with a reset(?) if you wanted to... [/spoiler]
I was unhappy with the experience, but relieved it was over when the credits rolled. No interest in going back and completing the remaining percent completion.

125329286.review:
I really wanted to love this game. I was initially drawn to it because of the art style, and the beautiful main character, however after beating it after 11 hours, I'm so glad I'm finally done with it. It's held me hostage for so long. Though my review says I don't recommend it, I merely am not recommending it to people in general. I'm sure that this game will appeal to a minority, and I address this in my review

I've just beaten the game after slogging through the last 3 hours of it, and I cannot say I feel accomplished in doing so, nor will I ever pick it up and play it again.

The game cannot justify its length with its lackluster gameplay, and the story of the game (while interesting) Isn't enough substance to make the player want to continue. I don't believe I would ever subject myself to playing it ever again.

So where do I even begin?


                                                                                   ===
                                                                                   ART
                                                                                   ===
The art style of the game is beautiful and charming. Character sprites have fluid movements, and the environments are all interesting from a visual standpoint. Our main protagonist is a silent buxom blonde, with a heart of gold, supported by a cast of other interesting and quirky characters. The game is far from political, besides its theme of hurrr religion bad, and isn't afraid to craft characters with beautiful physical features, which is a breathe of fresh air in todays world of dumbing down, or making characters outright ugly.

                                                                                 =====
                                                                                 STORY
                                                                                ======
While others may dislike the story, It was literally the only thing that kept me playing. I was interested in the mystery behind Ivory, why the planet kept shaking every 5 minutes during gameplay, and history and technology within the world. I do think there are many dialogue heavy moments that interrupt the flow of the game, but after realizing the gameplay wasn't going to change at all for the next 6 hours, I didn't mind the various interactions between the characters. 

What I hate about the story is how the ending isn't explained at all.. The game spends all this time building up to what is essentially a confrontation with god, only to subvert your expectations with a completely different final boss. Then once you off that final boss, It isn't explained who he was, or where he came from, thus leaving you to pick up the pieces on your own. I extremely hate when stories do this, and if you're going to force me to slog through 11 hours of your repetitive gameplay and dialogue, you could at least explain what the fuck is going on in the ending.



                                                                                 =====
                                                                                 MUSIC
                                                                                ======
A lot of the music is forgettable. This isn't exactly to say the music is bad, it just has many generic scores that don't try to stand out. They serve their purpose, and I suppose that's good enough. There were some tracks that I bumped to for a bit, but most of the music is pretty bare bones.


                                                                             =====================
                                                                             GAMEPLAY (hardest mode)
                                                                             =====================

Oh boy, where do I even start. Mechanically, the game is interesting for the first 2 hours. You're given your tools you'll be using for pretty much the entire game within these two hours, hoping for the gameplay to change or shift besides a one off puzzle or mechanic, but it never does. Any new item or ability your character gains only serves to progress them through the specific environmental puzzle they find themselves tackling. The combat never changes, and the weapons you're given don't feel like weapons, but rather tools used to solve puzzles. This may be okay for some who are merely stimulated through overcoming a puzzle, but for those looking for interesting and engaging combat, you will be left disappointed.

The bosses were the most fun part about the combat (except for the infamous ASH fight, seriously, fuck this boss) and each boss I faced was a breathe of fresh air after the slog it took to get there. I believe that the creator wanted to put various mechanics in the game (as is evident by the plethora of stealth sections) but never committed to one exact style of gameplay. This means you get a variety of different types of gameplay, at the cost of the game being a jack of all trades and master of absolutely none of them.

The level design is by far the weakest of all aspects of the gameplay. I'm not only talking about the infamous tower level, which literally took me a good hour of riding elevators and navigating hallways that look the exact same, only to find one specific key to progress. I'm more so talking about how off the levels feel as you traverse them. They feel like rat mazes with puzzles littered throughout them, and aren't really fun to traverse. 

One of the most dreadful parts of the game is getting stuck in an area trying to figure out what convoluted solution to a puzzle or hidden area you missed, which has you back tracking and exploring the entire length of the level for minutes, only to realize you missed one switch, key, or hidden door.



                                                                                ===============
                                                                                 FINAL THOUGHTS
                                                                                ===============

I started off hopeful when I first began playing this game. While It didn't have the strongest introduction sequence, I was hoping the game would get better as I continued. I feel as if this is the main theme of this game. The player is left hoping that things will get better, somewhere, somehow, but is left utterly disappointed with each section they find themselves in.

If you're a person who loves solving puzzles, traversing mazes, and reading through text boxes of dialogue heavy interactions between characters, then this game is most definitely for you. However, If you were hoping for a game with interesting combat, levels, strong mechanics, and a fluid story, you will be sadly disappointed, and probably find yourself where I was, too far in to stop, and forcing yourself to push through, hoping it gets better, and wishing it would just end already. 

Strong concept, promising story, nothing changes, nothing gets better, nothing is improved throughout. 

That is the theme of this game

There's a whiplash to switching back and forth between the fun vibrant puzzle platforming and the bleak uprising against the theocracy storyline.

One moment you're bopping bad guys with a cartoon wrench and the next your new friend is confronting their disabled and abusive mother about how hard it is to take care of her. Don't see myself finishing this one sadly, but what's here might be to someone else's taste. YMMV.

124861409.review:
Someday I want to play an indie metroidvania that plays like Metroid Prime instead of Metroid Dread. Iconoclasts is not that game. It's not a bad one, but I was not in its target audience.

I passed up on Iconoclasts initially because of its association with the notably scummy publisher Dangen Entertainment and would not have purchased it directly through Steam either way. On top of that, I gave it a try through alternative means and left off of it, something about its gameplay rubbing me the wrong way. This is definitely a title I would give a "thumbs sideways" if Steam allowed for such. 

After receiving a key for it from a friend, I resolved to give it a more serious attempt. What I got was a game with quality art, dialogue and storytelling whose mechanics constantly get in the way of the former, at least for me. It's rare for a game to make me feel as many different things as Iconoclasts did, and not just because of the harsh juxtaposition of its cute sprite art with a dark and at times bleak narrative.

Iconoclasts deliberately cloaks much of its backstory for plot reasons, so I suppose I will as well. I will say that you are Robin, a plucky blonde mechanic with a stun gun and a very large wrench, in a society that relies on mysterious "Ivory" fuel as the basis of its civilization, where performing a job that you were not assigned to do by the all-seeing "One Concern" electric company, thus defying the will of "He" and his representative  "Mother", is considered an outright sin and grounds for having you and your entire house flattened from orbit as "Penance." Robin, of course, is not an assigned mechanic. Whoops. What ensues is a surprisingly emotional tale of grief, recovery, wanting to do the best by people, overcoming the expectations of others and, of course, the dangers of theocratic rule- a lesson that I suspect we will need to take to heart in the coming years.

Gameplay wise, you can call Iconoclasts a Metroidvania, through it is much more linear then then most of those for much of its runtime, and it's really more of a puzzle platformer then a Metroidvania, lacking not only the power fantasy found in Metroid and the RPG mechanics of the Symphony of the Night-style Castlevanias but much of the quality of life found in most similar indie titles. Robin can use her Wrench and various ammo types for her stun gun to manipulate physics objects in the environment, and you typically cannot proceed from one room to the next on your first trip through a region without solving a number of puzzles. Some bombshell line of dialogue or plot element is dropped in nearly every cutscene after the first quarter-to-third of the game, and each time I was eager to see what happened next before nearly groaning audibly when I was faced with yet another puzzle room. 

Further complicating matters is the game's relative lack of equipment progression- you receive a small handful of wrench and gun upgrades over the course of the game, with all other improvements relegated to its fairly asinine "wrench tweak" system. Scattered throughout the game and sometimes in hidden areas are chests containing crafting materials used to make said tweaks, which can be equipped up to three at a time and grant bonuses of varying usefulness, such as the ability to ignore one hit's damage, run faster, hold your breath for longer, etc. Any damage you take, any at ALL, breaks one of your tweaks- three hits and they're all broken, and have to be repaired by gathering "Ivory squares" from defeated enemies, parrying enemy attacks, and completing puzzles. Oh, I didn't mention the parry mechanic before? Well, I was about as good at using that as I was in Dark Souls. Which is to say, effectively not. In addition, there are no maximum health upgrades whatsoever. At the very least, there is no ammo mechanic- some of the stun gun's attacks overheat though. On top of that, interacting with save statues does not repair your tweaks, though it at least restores your health.

The feel of Iconoclasts' combat seems specifically designed to punish players like me in particular, someone who not only prefers the controls of a First-Person Shooter, driving game, strategy game, shoot-em-up and just about anything else except maybe fighting games to platformers, but someone who grew up playing DOS and Windows games instead of a console and has never been as comfortable with a controller as with a mouse and keyboard- a setup that platform game designers seem to have it out for- those of Hollow Knight in particular.  I got hit again and again, managing to struggle my way through Iconoclasts' combat encounters largely due to the fact that it frequently grants you mercy-health items, especially when defeating the flunky add enemies in boss fights. Add to this some irritating bonus bosses that I simply decided to skip after a few attempts given my general dissatisfaction with the combat, and you have one of my least favorite games I've ever finished. And quite frankly, were it not for the story I've given up on the game and maybe even downvoted it.

Also, the soundtrack is surprisingly mid for what is otherwise an aesthetically high-level indie platformer.

Iconoclasts is, in summary, a mixed bag. I can't rightly call it a bad game, but it wasn't the right game for me and I would say it might be worth looking at for more serious platforming fans, leastways ones that can handle a large amount of puzzles and a disappointing upgrade system. I recommend picking it up from a key reseller if you are interested in not giving Dangen money.

122994050.review:
Interesting narrative metroidvania-esque game, with a decent amount of (occasionally confusing) substance. Jokes were hit and miss for me, but I really liked how the silent protagonist was done here, especially the intro sequence and endgame [spoiler] yeah let's just punch the final boss to get its attention lol [/spoiler]. Soundtrack is typically good and catchy, though they occasionally feel randomly reinserted or out of place (maybe just me). While metroidvania games definitely inspired the work to an extent [spoiler] (let's face it, the eyes are basically X parasites [/spoiler], I see weirdly see similarities between this game and Metroid Dread (2021) [spoiler] Iconoclasts has the Ivory beast, Dread has the X abomination [/spoiler], though Samus Returns (2017) came out beforehand, so I wonder if there was any two way inspiration) between these games, as they play quite similarly. You have these semi-linear metroidvania games with similar types of combat, and it was refreshing to see a similar but diverting approach out there. I saw a review of Inmost that basically said to play Iconoclasts instead for multiple playable character action, so I decided to try it. This is definitely better. Others might compare it to Owl Boy, and I think Iconoclasts and Owl Boy rank comparatively well against one another as platformers with multiple playable protagonists. 

I compared this to Metroid games already, but I think I should use one more to describe Iconoclasts: Fusion. It's metroidvania gameplay that forces the player to complete certain tasks at certain times, much like Metroid Fusion. Although many despised how much Fusion differed from Super Metroid, there seems to be more opportunities for interesting planned segments in the linear metroidvania gameplay of Fusion and Iconoclasts. Every once and a while, it will feel like you are playing the stage of an arcade platformer, which is kind of neat. Combat is interesting, but not quite as tight as in Metroid Dread. Bosses are generally fun, but a few are especially annoying or silly [spoiler] Blocker is annoying fast paced repetitive button sequences, while the boss you fight as injured Elro is kind of boring and seems highly unrealistic lol [/spoiler]. I think the game does a good job of telling the story it intends to tell, though sometimes it gets very lore heavy (which I find way too easy to tune out), and other times they say nothing or leave it entirely to lore notes (which is not unusual in these types of games, but also can be confusing in this case). The game is quite interpersonal relation focused, and you do get a sense of the thought process of different characters, as silly as it may sound in the context of a sci-fi game. In both obvious and obscured ways, it shares the importance of understanding others [spoiler] The obscure way being answering questions posed throughout the game a certain way to appease shadows that attack you in the dream sequence before the final boss [spoiler]. I did not find the tweak system too interesting, I just used it for three damage-free hits and didn't buy any other ones. I am sure there is some strategy for optimal tweak setups for speedruns or something. Swapping between different characters throughout this game was pretty fun, though some segments were confusing at first glance [spoiler] particularly the Ash fight, which was preceded with too much vague text explanations of what you were expected to do; not to mention, "stealth" had no role later in the game.. kind of glad about that, but why say it in the first place? [/spoiler]. [spoiler][/spoiler] 

Besides some of these hiccups, the game also has bugs/weird issues:
1) in windowed mode, if you are in full resolution, every player death/gameover screen transition will resize the window to a certain smaller size every time.
2) in the tower, I found that it was possible to hold onto the ladder while riding an elevator up past the auditorium. This was under the circumstance of doing what is required for a cut scene to activate in the auditorium, so I was essentially stuck in a room transition next to it with the lights dimmed. Upon resetting the game, I made sure not to press up on the elevator ride, and proceeded to see the cut scene normally once I got to the correct spot for it. 

Overall, it feels like a neat passion project that people should experience. It has its highs and lows, but it was pretty epic and enjoyable for the most part.

122902992.review:
A tyrannical religion? Superhuman people? Then stop screwing around and go pick up your combat wrench!

Well. Honestly, this is another title where I'd prefer a "meh" review category.
I really liked the game's story, once the plot threads became unraveled passing the mid-section of the game, and most of the riddles were fun to solve as well. Personally, I was fine with the differences in pace between puzzle and action segments (though, looking at other reviews, this also seems to throw quite a few people off).
Buuut... at its heart Iconoclasts is still a Metroidvania - and the combat system is way too non-fluent for that. Several of the battles were very fast-paced at least conceptually with quick-witted enemies, but the unresponsive controls and movement-blocking attack animations made them a drag to sit through.

So, do I recommend the game or no? As my rating says, I do - but only if you're mostly here for the story and/or ready to occasionally bite down in frustration due to unnecessarily lengthy boss battles (focusing on evasion rather than risking standing still a bit to attack), or another foreseeable death due to movement constrictions. At least most pre-battle cutscenes are skippable.

121696204.review:
[b]Score: 6/10[/b]
Has some ups, has some downs. First off - weird. Iconoclasts is weird and a little jarring, and it swings both ways in whether it fits or it doesn't. The nature of the story is significantly more sinister and serious than the art and music, and this isn't really ever addressed, so you have a strange sense of not-belonging that makes earlier sections of the storyline seem just... bizarre. However. As the game progresses into the second half, and the hidden secrets start to spill, the scope widens and there's a very pleasant mysteriousness about where everything's heading that really sucks the player in when it counts. IF the player ever gets there - the primary side character Mina is so infuriatingly antagonistic and douchey that the early-middle portions of the game are a complete drag and I cried tears of joy at her becoming much more secondary as things moved on. The developer hits you with a message, and then hits you with another message, and then some others, and somewhere in the mix is what the game wants you to take away as the point, but contradictions in who the good guys are and what the bad things are presented as (which you won't fully realize until the ending sections, hence why this game has a "political" reputation) make what seems to start out as something more concise fumble around and ramble. Thankfully, you don't have to care much about that in the face of some excellent boss fights and decent, if occasionally unfair puzzling. The game has metroidvania elements, but I'd shy away from referring to it as such - the upgrades and progression are relatively useless, considering every boss can be soundly defeated with what you're given by default. On a final note, there's a character loss near to the end that's pretty unsatisfying, but honestly, I respect the developer for taking a memorable route, even if it's not executed super well. Overall, Iconoclasts is a little rough on the dialogue,  but once the conversation gets going, you'll have plenty to talk about. 

Note: if you care about achievements don't skip the credits, I beat the damn game I swear :(

120570624.review:
I didn't expect much from this game, having temporarily deposited it into the back archives of my steam library while other, newer games took precedent. I almost ended up trashing it due to a steam launch error, but I'm glad I took the initiative to play it as I did not regret it. 

The game features a unique, albeit 'classic' aesthetic reminiscent of old school platformer games of decades past. It seems to be arranged in a light metroidvania fashion, with minimal backtracking. Puzzle elements are engaging, though not overtly difficult and do not hold you hostage, interrupting your progress. Boss fights are much the same; mechanics may seem complicated at first, but are very forgiving once solved. Having a selectable difficulty at the start of every load is a nice modern touch and allows for more emphasis on progression and story if desired. The standard mode is well balanced in my experience and allows for a challenge without bogging down the plot progression.

What surprised me most about this game was the depth of the story. While this isn't the first time I've been surprised by an outwardly simplistic appearing game, it's always refreshing to be surprised yet again. In a world of cheap and hollow grind fests with bare bones scripts, having a well written and executed story is a nice reprieve. I was reminded of classics such as Chrono Trigger several times throughout the dialogue sequences; just spot on writing. The characters are quite memorable and charming. I found myself cheering for some and feeling sorry for others. The conclusion of the game seems to be intentionally polarizing as well. I appreciated the twist at the end that makes you think, which is a nice cherry on top.

I would recommend this one to anyone that enjoys a well thought out story with some classic platforming/puzzle solving action for variety.

Treat yourself.

I'll start by saying that the art and animations are absolutely gorgeous, and the boss fights were very interesting. Music was serviceable, performance was smooth and I encountered only a couple of minor glitches. That being said, the writing is just confusing and obnoxious as hell. Way, way too many words of dialogue are presented with little to no context and cohesion, sounding like nonsensical ramblings. I tried hard to pay attention to the dialogue, get to grips with the story and relate to the characters - but it simply didn't happen. The characters are almost all whiny and self-loathing, with poorly explained motivations. I hated pretty much all of them.

Gameplay started off ok and I enjoyed it to a point. But after a while the exploration and back-tracking felt extremely tedious due to lack of any traversal upgrades (the double jump doesn't count - I didn't even encounter its schematic during my playthrough, let alone the materials needed for it). The boss fights can also be egregious with how poorly telegraphed the mechanics are. You are supposed to simply die and retry until you figure out just how a boss works, in many cases. I made the mistake of playing on the harder difficulty, which exacerbated this problem.

The lacking exploration, poor upgrade system and confusing story made me fed-up enough to switch to the easiest difficulty for the sake of completing the game. I felt zero motivation towards the end and final act far overstayed its welcome.

118308078.review:
[h1]This game is incredible. To think that one man made this is astonishing.[/h1]

The biggest selling point for this game would be its narrative. Iconoclasts is not the game you would think it is at first glance (which unfortunately works against this game). Both Steam and the game's introduction give you the feeling that it's a colourful, happy-go-lucky platformer that almost seems generic, but in fact this game is very rich in its story and eventually becomes brutal in its violence. 

Religion and faith is the central focus of the plot as characters conflict on the notion of God and how society revolves around worship. So many characters suffer and experience some form of tragedy in their life as the game progresses and at one moment near the end of the game one character's despair moved me to tears. There are a lot of little details in the story that you can piece together as not everything is told outright to you through the narrative and its very clever in how its shown to you but not outright told directly. Doing a second playthrough of the game after knowing the entire picture will change your understanding of the game's events, revealing new light on the narrative through your newfound context. Simply put, it's all so very beautiful.

While the upgrade system is somewhat questionable with most perks being afterthought upgrades, the core gameplay is simple, fun and tightly-knit. I never found myself feeling bored as there was always something to do or interact with. The puzzles aren't too hard and the boss fights are on the easier side with only some standouts giving me particular trouble like the optional ones.

The music is phenomenal, the pixel artstyle is wonderful to look at, and everything, and I mean [i]everything[/i] is incredibly animated. The game oozes with gorgeous sprite animation that shines its brightest during boss fights and cutscenes.

I loved every second of this game as its themes and characters continously caught me off guard. I wanted more, I needed to see where it would all lead and I was [i]not[/i] disappointed.

Bravo Joakim Sandberg, you created a work of art.

I found the gameplay to be mostly a fight against the clunky controls. I consulted a guide twice in half an hour to find out where to go (because I simply wasn't having enough fun to keep going backwards and forwards trying to figure it out) and on both occasions was just irritated by how unintuitive the answer was. I then encountered a bugged key that dropped itself and couldn't be picked up again and gave up.

Your double jump relies on holding down a button to charge a weapon, then jumping, aiming down and firing. Some sections require this awkward motion, followed by using your 'wrench' to grab in mid-air, and then jump again, and then catch a platform edge.

This sounds like it could be interesting, but none of these action reliably work. I don't know if this game has an issue with my controller (no other games do) but if so, that's an issue too. I enjoy difficult platformers but this felt like easy platforming where the challenge was to overcome poor controls instead of the game.

The combat is a bizarre mixture of too easy (you just rapid fire and it auto targets enemies) and frustrating (you expected it to auto target and it just didn't).

TL;DR Frustrating, inconsistent, and buggy.

Iconoclasts es una maravilla MEGA INFRAVALORADA.

- A nivel gameplay Iconoclasts es un metroidvania completamente original. Se nota que esta obra toma inspiración de varios juegos no solo a nv gameplay, sino también en como está estructurada su historia la cual recuerda a jrpgs como Mother o Final Fantasy, pero Iconoclasts las hace suyas y concibe una experiencia totalmente original como nada que hayas jugado antes al igual que los mejores metroidvanias que tiene para ofrecer la industria indie, tales como Hollow Knight o Guacamelee.
Y si lo que dije no fuera poco, Iconoclasts cuenta con uno de los rosters de jefes mas ENORMES Y ORIGINALES que haya visto, contando con 25 de ellos los cuales tienen patrones aleatorios y una dificultad elevada pero justa.

-  Ahora, la historia, LA HISTORIA, si que es otro nivel. No bromeo al decir que la historia de Iconoclasts es una de las mas subversivas, impredecibles e impactantes que haya visto.
Fácilmente la pongo a nv de grandes historias como Metal Gear o Final Fantasy 6, 7, 9 o 10, una gran critica a la religión en general, pero como nunca antes había visto que se hiciera y con un cast de personajes bien desarrollado que actúan como personas únicas acorde a su situación.
Verdaderamente Iconoclasts es una obra que después de haberla terminado, te deja pensando y es fácil cocinarte la cabeza pensando en el significado de algunos de los temas que toca, un sentimiento que hace rato no sentía con un videojuego, es en verdad un trabajo digno de los 10 años que pasó haciendo su único creador.

Puntuación: 9/10

The strengths of this game is definitely the design. There are many unique looking characters and enemies you will encounter, especially the bosses. 116942340.review:
Iconoclasts puede ser considerado como un metroidvania impuro, más que nada porque conforme se avanza va perdiendo o diluyendo los componentes que dan forma a dicho género.

Iconoclasts es un juego que empieza muy bien y hasta resulta sorprendente. A mí lo que impactó fue su sistema de control, que prácticamente vuelve prescindible el uso de los gatillos. Sí, con la botonera de A-B X-Y, la cruceta y el botón Start tienes suficiente para jugar a este título, cosa que da la impresión de que su creador lo ha estado probando durante mucho tiempo sobre un teclado. Esto en un principio potencia el aspecto retro, pero más adelante diré algo que no me ha gustado.

Estamos ante un título que aparentemente bebe de los juegos de los años 80 del Siglo XX, aunque su acabado estético es más propio de la Super Nintendo. Siendo más concretos y desde mi punto de vista, parece inspirarse principalmente en los dos primeros Metroid: el juego original de NES y el Return of Samus publicado para Game Boy. Por otro lado, parece nutrirse también de lo que conocemos en occidente como Super Mario Bros 2, que fue el patito feo de la saga de plataformas Super Mario Bros lanzada para NES. Super Mario Bros 2 no era un mal juego en realidad, pero quedó totalmente ensombrecido por el 1 y 3, considerados por algunos como los mejores juegos de plataformas de todos los tiempos.

Hay que reconocer que Iconoclasts entra muy bien al principio. Su acabado artístico es de diez, los diseños y las animaciones son también de diez, la música es fantástica y su planteamiento es bueno, aunque en comparación con otros metroidvania prima más las plataformas y los puzzles que la exploración. La ambientación y la historia son realmente muy buenos, y aquí es donde llegamos a dos puntos a tener en consideración.

Pese a tener un aspecto infantil, la verdad es que la historia es bastante oscura y adulta. En ella se toca de manera muy superficial la sexualidad y el jugador verá algunos momentos duros que quedan suavizados por las limitaciones técnicas y el acabado artístico. Vamos, que la historia no va orientada, ni mucho menos, a los más peques de la casa, así que no la subestiméis por el aspecto estético del juego.

Pero como amante de los metroidvania tengo que decir que Iconoclasts va de más a menos, y la razón está, precisamente, en su historia. A nivel de desarrollo sí está inspirado en juegos más modernos, y aquí me ha recordado al Metroid Fusion de Game Boy Advance. Lo malo de Metroid Fusion es que intentaron contar demasiada historia y aquello perjudicó al [i]backtracking[/i]. Pues bien, aquí nos encontramos ese defecto multiplicado por decenas de veces, por lo que, con tanta historia (en esta faceta parece un JRPG de la vieja escuela tipo Final Fantasy), al final el juego apenas invita a explorar como lo hace Super Metroid o Hollow Knight y terminas realizando un trazado muy lineal. El [i]backtracking[/i] tampoco es que esté muy bien implementado, así que al final dejas atrás zonas que posiblemente te convendría volver a visitar.

Otro detalle que no me ha gustado ha sido el sistema de control. Al principio mola tener unos controles tan simples, pero la incapacidad de disparar en diagonal ha sido sustituida con un auto objetivo que resta desafío a los combates e incluso puede terminar liándola en situaciones en las que hay varios enemigos cerca pero repartidos en distintas ubicaciones. Me hubiera gustado que los gatillos superiores hubiesen sido utilizados para apuntar en diagonal y así dar más control al usuario, tal y como lo hacen los Metroid en 2D a partir de Super Nintendo.

Que no se entienda mal, Iconocast es un juego de notable, pero su exceso de historia termina diluyendo su forma de metroidvania para pasar a ser más bien un juego de plataformas y puzzles. No tengo nada en contra de que un metroidvania prime los puzzles y las plataformas si lo hace bien, pero sí hay un problema cuando lo hace a costa de la exploración y el [i]backtracking[/i].

116669487.review:
Allow me to preface that while I don't think Iconoclasts is one of the best games of all time or anything, this game has a lot of love and charm put into it that allows me to enjoy it in spite of its shortcomings.

Alright, so, Iconoclasts is a rather odd game. Its gameplay is as simple as it comes. You can shoot, jump, and after very early in the game, swing a wrench that can be used as a melee attack, a parry, and a tool to activate specific bolts that work like buttons. As the game progresses you unlock a few extra moves like a grenade launcher or the ability to charge yourself electrically. This is used to solve the game's MANY puzzles, and to fight the game's plentiful bosses, a decent chunk of which are glorified puzzles with a little more tension. I hope you like that, because that's essentially the gameplay loop. Mechanically speaking this game isn't very difficult and one can beat a casual playthrough rather easily even in the highest default difficulty, even if you end up getting stuck in a boss or two.

However, while the gameplay is not going to win any awards, the rest of the game is fantastic. The setting is outstanding, particularly in the way it slowly and subtly unfolds itself to the player. The spritework and animation is exquisite, and gives so much characterization to especially the protagonist, Robin. The writing is genuinely pretty solid as well. It's nothing special, but it's well delivered and there's plenty of enjoyment to be had from characters like Mina or Agent Black, and notably, from Robin herself, being probably the first mute protagonist I've actually liked in a videogame. The music also sets the tone of the game pretty well and is generally just great. There's also a large amount of side content that you can find by returning to different places and exploring, however...

I will come out and say it: the metroidvania parts of the game (returning to previous levels with new upgrades) don't feel fun. There's very little incentive to return to previous areas due to how slow it is to do so, and the fast travel somewhat helps, but you will typically still have to do plenty of walking anyway. It wastes a lot of time when you consider that you're revisiting rooms that you have already figured out, yet in some cases you still have to redo the puzzles again. Also, the second half of the game is completely linear: you go in a straight line with no way at any point to leave and return to the rest of the game. You do get a moment before tackling the final boss where you can do all you have to do, so fortunately, there is no "Point of No Return", thank fuck. Even then, after that, you'll probably want to just fight the final boss anyway, so it feels like there's no point at all to "go back and do what you couldn't before", at least in a casual or first playthrough. 

These were all minor criticisms, but what I actually want to adress is the tweak system. It blows. The reason for that is simply how unbalanced it is: Tweaks are temporary upgrades that are lost on hit. Typically, they're misc stuff, like being electrically charged for longer or being able to swim for longer, which saves up time in some puzzles but doesn't really give you too much of a bonus. The problem is that these tiny QoL buffs are heavily outclassed by the tweak Iron Heart, which just allows you to take a free hit. Since tweaks break when you take damage and slowly get repaired by doing damage or destroying certain background elements, there is no point in running something that'll give you a small boost and get lost whenever you make any mistake over just not taking a single instance of damage. There's also plenty of optional tweaks that could easily have been small permanent upgrades over how tweaks actually work, since character progression is fairly limited, as it is just "you get new tool for puzzles" instead of more tangible growths. If the system used to replace these wasn't so poorly balanced, I would have no complaints, but, alas, it's how it is.

tl;dr: this game is worth playing alone for its artistic value (read: writing, aesthetic, worldbuilding, and all that) but expect gameplay to be underwhelming, at least outside of boss fights

Ahora bien, como punto negativo tenemos la historia, que ni fú ni fá, si te gusta bien y si no, como ha sido mi caso, la verás muy floja, principalmente porque los personajes no terminan de transmitir... nada, son raros, en su mayoría insulsos, y ciertas cosas que ocurren en la historia... no sé yo, pero mucho sentido no tienen. Y que quieres que te diga, no he terminado de pillarle el rollo al tono de la narrativa, no tiene una forma clara de contarte las cosas, sino que a veces tiende a ser muy serio y otras a intentar suavizar la situación con un toque de humor que no termina de llegar al sitio que pretende, dejando al jugador un poco desubicado y dando una sensación de estar tratando con trastornados en algunas situaciones.

Por tanto, si te gusta lo que ves en las imágenes y te apetece un metroidvania algo más lineal de lo normal partes de una buena base que solo caerá según te interese la historia que te cuentan, y vuelvo a repetir, en mi caso se queda como recomendado porque estás mas cerca de estar bien que de estar mal.

Highly recommend this if you like story-based exploratory sidescrollers (Metroidvanias?). Colourful visuals, chunky story, and excellent music and boss design. Definitely hits some hard topics and yet still manages to appropriately intersperse humour to get a well-paced game. I really enjoyed my time with this.

Collectibles come in the form of crafting materials, but you by no means need to find them all to finish the game.
Additional content is available in the form of a couple of secret bosses and a 1-HP mode.

Una historia con una distopía como punto central que destaca precisamente por no quedarse en la superficie. Tanto los aliados como los adversarios tienen diferentes puntos de vista y objetivos que en ocasiones entran en conflicto entre ellos mismos dando lugar a choques inesperados. Libertad, abnegación, fanatismo religioso, obsesión por tener un propósito, diferencias sociales, venganza ciega… se tratan muchos temas con la suficiente seriedad pero sabiendo cuando aligerar con algo de humor.

Aunque sólo hay un par de armas y herramientas, el juego se esfuerza en sacarles el máximo partido a todo el repertorio de habilidades ya sea en los puzles, la exploración del entorno, los combates o los jefes finales. Siempre hay un giro extra con todo muy bien pensado y muy bien montado.

Los gráficos pixelados están llenos de detalles y animaciones, la banda sonora es magnífica y hay un gran trabajo de traducción y localización al español.

114030845.review:
Honestly, there is not one thing about Iconoclasts that I could say is objectively bad. The art and level of polish is astonishing, the combat is enjoyable at its worst and thrilling at its best (seriously, the boss battles are so good), and the story and characters are complex enough to have genuine depth while also being easy to follow and understand. 
There are three things you should know before you get this game, though:
One, it definitely feels a lot more like a linear puzzle platformer than it does a metroidvania - and while this alone isn't a bad thing, it can be disappointing to those that expected a different kind of game. 
Two, if you're not a fan of religious themes or you find social and political narratives preachy and annoying, you probably won't like the story and overall tone of this game. (I'd say that this game handles that subject matter pretty well, but even so.) 
And finally, it's not a very long game. At the time of writing this, Steam says I've spent 18 hours playing, but about eight of those were just leaving the game open on accident while I went to go do something else, so it took me around ten hours total to do and find everything Iconoclasts had to offer.
If you're still interested in the game after reading all of that, get it! I definitely don't regret it, and I'm sure you won't either.

113930524.review:
Has an incredible story that is worth the price of admission alone. Finds the perfect balance of hard hitting mandatory story beats and optional written worldbuilding that you can piece together yourself.

The games puzzles are difficult enough to engage some problem solving but not so difficult you will bang your head against them for minutes. 

While the mandatory story upgrades are all great, the optional upgrades are usually disappointing (slightly more health, slightly more movement speed, ect.) This leaves a lot of the hardest puzzles/secrets without any sort of extrinsic reward.

Its a good game.

113918296.review:
It's games like this that make me wish Steam had the option of giving a mixed review, as I can't really say I can recommend one way or the other.

Pros: solid gameplay, good sprite work, excellent boss battles
Cons: overt socio-political messaging, schizophrenic writing quality

I initially bought Iconoclasts because I saw some boss fight footage. And true to what I'd seen, [b]this game delivered.[/b] The storyline, however, leaves a lot to be desired. 
*It keeps falling back on tiresome "girl power" tropes and implies misogyny repeatedly when it isn't warranted. More on that below.
*The amount of LGBTWHATEVER "representation" is downright gratuitous. [spoiler]One of the player characters is a lesbian in a relationship with a woman who I initially thought was her sister.[/spoiler] A little surprising, but no big deal; such things are generally beneath my notice, and I could care even less. [spoiler]But then a flashback reveals that one of the recurring villains [i]maybe[/i] had a crush on/relationship with [b]a person of unidentifiable gender,[/b] complete with half their head shaved and hair dyed purple.[/spoiler] [i]That[/i] made me sit up and take notice that something was off here. Two LGBT couples in one game? Given the setting of the story, the odds of such people finding compatible partners seems statistically improbable at the very least. It doesn't feel [i]organic,[/i] which begs the question of what message the writers are trying to convey. This detail was also what made me really start to notice the other political messaging in this game.
*True to the title, this game takes a very strong stance against religion, with the main villains of the game being leaders of a cult (with obvious Christian influence) ruling over a dystopian society with an iron fist. Obnoxiously, one of the recurring villains will periodically stop what he's doing to read scripture from their cult's holy book. And one of the so-called protagonists is a high-ranking, superpowered member of the cult who was so sheltered by said cult that everything he does makes the situation worse for everyone. The main group of dissidents are scientist hippies who worship the earth/trees. And, predictably, the foundations this religion are built on ultimately prove to be false (though, credit where it's due, the reveal and design of the final boss are actually kinda clever). As someone who has studied world religions, the false dichotomies of science vs religion/Christianity vs every other religion got tiresome a long time ago, and it annoys me that this studio decided to fall back on such a tired strawman.
*This game seems to take a very, [i]VERY[/i] dim view of men. The only three male characters to receive significant screentime are all presented in a negative light. The first of them is the scripture-quoting villain. The second is the aforementioned sheltered cult member who fucks everything up. [spoiler]In retrospect, the fact you have to abandon him to a fate worse than death to reach the end of the game takes on a more sinister tone.[/spoiler] The third is the main protagonist's older brother, who is picked out as the unwitting instigator of all the bad things that happen in this story. Ordinarily, this would not be an issue. But the writers for this game seem to go out of their way to paint him as painfully stupid [spoiler](assassinating a major character in a fit of rage in a flashback, then ironically escaping without actually going into hiding)[/spoiler], imply he's misogynistic (painting concern for his sister's well-being/safety as him being a paternalistic control freak), and heap all the responsibility for what happens on him. What's more, they run him through the meat grinder: [spoiler]by the end of the game, he's lost an arm, an eye, his house has been demolished, and his wife and daughter are dead.[/spoiler] This brother doesn't feel like a real character, he feels like a political strawman who exists specifically to be punished by the universe itself. Even if I didn't disagree with the inherent politics of this story, [b]that's bad writing.[/b]

Suffice to say, the omnipresent socio-political messaging left a sour taste in my mouth. There were parts of the story I liked (especially their use of one villain's headaches), and my aforementioned criticisms wouldn't be nearly as pronounced if the writing team were able to integrate them into the story with a modicum of subtlety. As it stands, though, these issues stand out like a sore thumb and indicate that this game is trying to push some sort of social agenda. Even if I agreed with said agenda, that kind of politicization in media makes me extremely uncomfortable. Consequently, I only played through Iconoclasts once.

Basically, the game is fun if you can manage to ignore most of the storyline (or, I assume, if you agree with the devs' politics). I, sadly, cannot manage this.

113442351.review:
Ignore the tags - this is more a narrative focused action puzzle than an MV or action game.  Yes, it takes place in an interconnected map, yes, you occasionally get upgrades as you advance the story that grant you access to more areas, but it never really feels like a metroidvania because you never really have the freedom to explore until you're literally to the final boss.  It's as dialog heavy as a JRPG, but fortunately the story is a well-written one, despite going with the common silent-protagonist trope.  The story really fits the title, in that it revolves around characters breaking tradition, religious and familial, and dealing with the repercussions of that.  All in all, the story is the biggest strength of the game, by far.

As for the gameplay, well the areas themselves you take them in the order the story presents them to you, and explore through said areas in a more or less linear fashion.  As you explore the open world, combat very much takes a back seat to the puzzles  - using your wrench, electricity, and blocks to work your way to the next room.  The enemies are just there as little breaks between puzzles - they don't come in many varieties, each has it's own weakness that you need only figure out once, and you can straight up ignore them half the time - heck, sometimes you *need* to just avoid them.

The boss fights are the only time you're going to really be challenged from a combat perspective.  Expect to die a couple times as you figure out what the fight's mechanics are - they're like puzzles too - just particularly painful ones when you mess up.  But there's always a checkpoint right before a boss, so restarting isn't much of a hassle.

All in all, worth playing if you want to experience a casualish 2D indie game with a nice story about the hardships of breaking traditions in order to help people, despite all those people telling you to give up, that it's not your responsibility, that family and/or faith come first.  But if you're specifically jonesing for an metroidvania style experience, maybe play something else and come back once you need a palette cleanser.

110649057.review:
Iconoclasts won me over with its humour and charm. You play as a voiceless but expressive mechanic named Robin, exploring a colourful and pixelated world that is rich with visual detail and memorable music. The game is a blend of platforming, puzzles, action, metroidvania and story. This was all made by a single developer, which really makes me appreciate the effort that went into this game that much more. 

The characters of Iconoclasts are likeable and serve the story satisfactorily. The lore got me engaged but it also left me with several questions and wishing that it went a bit deeper with its explanations. 

I wouldn't say it's a flawless game though. It is arguably dragged down by its exploration which I would describe as rigid. Navigating the game's levels for backtracking can become somewhat tedious with how slow it is, although effort was clearly put in to alleviate this. The tools and weapons you obtain throughout play are interesting in concept but are a tad finicky when put in practice, specifically in combat with how charged abilities always felt a bit underpowered in fast pace scenarios. 

I enjoyed my time with this game and would recommend it, even if there's some vaguely questionable aspects to the experience, it's still a game that left a good impression on me.

109953521.review:
Iconoclasts is good. It is without question a very well made Metroidvania title that has a increasingly dark story that has some really fantastic elements like its bosses and platform puzzles, albeit with flimsy combat and short length. In this it is a good game. Essential? No, but if there was a clear 7 out of 10 old Metroidvania title, Iconoclasts is it. Part of me wants to rave more about Iconoclasts. As a game that took best part of a decade to make by a single person where its quality and attention to detail is top notch, I really want to hold it in higher regard. Alas its shortcomings are just far too glaring to say it ranks up there as an excellent title.

Despite my negative tone, I’m going to repeat myself: Iconoclasts is a good game. It will no doubt be one of those titles that someone out there sees as the best title of all time, if not the kind of title where the story has made someone rethink their life and how they live it. While this may sound hyperbolic you have to consider how well thought out the story and world to Iconoclasts is. Like Owlboy released in the same timeframe it has that kind of whimsical initial feeling slowly give way to a rather complex world littered with misery and chaos. If anything the conflicting attitudes and ideals of each of the (rather extensive) cast makes for a very memorable tale of religious zealotry, authoritarian social orders and cultural clashes all set in a sci-fi world that fleshes itself out nicely over the course of its 15 (or so) hour slow burn. Granted it gets a little convoluted in places as some rather important seeming characters appear and then are swept away before you have the faintest idea who they are, but the core cast of Robin, Mina, Royal and Elro are all delt with rather well. I don’t want to go into too much detail due to spoilers, but if I were to advise getting Iconoclasts for one thing, it’s the expansive story. Considering I normally am so mechanics focused, that I guess says a lot about its story line.

Outside of the yarn it spins, there is not too bad a game underneath. What you get is a puzzle focused Metroidvania. Most of the progression is based on figuring out what happens in the numerous puzzle rooms in the game, running back and forth trying to work out what you are missing and, on occasion, working out if you have the right tools for the job. Almost all of the game is based on what weapon you are using and how your mighty melee wrench can be utilised, turning gears, spinning up cogs or charging things with electricity. A lot of the puzzles are well designed and clearly had a lot of thought put into them, and they needed to be good as, bar the puzzling, there is not much to the game.

Combat is where the game is let down really. Most enemy encounters are just distractions that, due to the auto aim on the stun gun, are more distractions than real progress impeding threats. There are some combat sequences that are a challenge, but they are few and tend to come in far too bunched up moments, making them frustrating. That said the bosses are all rather fantastic and, like the platforming, are mostly puzzles that need solving rather than being stand-up fights.

Aside from the weak combat there is the issue of playtime and replay value. While the game can easily last over 10 hours, the world itself feels rather small all things considered, and the cutscenes take up a great dollop of that time. Exploration is there, but the progression made is mostly linier, giving way to moments where backtracking seems less interesting and more a chore. Combine that with what seems to be little in terms of replay value and Iconoclasts may seem like a hard sell in a genre that is known for its vast exploration and searching in the tiny nooks and crannies.

All negativity aside I know someone out there will love Iconoclasts to bits. Its story is phenomenal and has been one of the nicest surprises I’ve had from this genre along with Cave Story. Is it as good as Super Metroid or Hollow Knight? No, but it does not need to be. A great way to kill a weekend or two with.

108727083.review:
One of my favorite Metroidvanias. I've played it three times now: Once on PS Vita, once on PS4 (where I have all the trophies except the one for beating Challenge Mode), and now once on PC. It's bright and colorful, but this belies a surprisingly dark story of murder, revolution and a potential apocalypse. The combat and puzzles are tough without being unfair (for the most part), the boss fights are challenging, and there's a good bit of side content in the form of collectibles and bonus bosses. 

I do have a few niggling complaints. There are things about the controls I don't care for; for instance, you can't really aim outside the four cardinal directions - you [i]technically[/i] can aim in the ordinal directions, but since there's no way to lock yourself in place, you can only do that while in motion. Instead, Robin will auto-aim to a degree. While the checkpointing is mostly fine, there are a few areas where there will be very long periods between them. Also, I personally am not fond of the silent protagonist trope; other than a handful of instances where you choose a response for her, Robin never speaks.

Still, these are relatively minor points marring what is otherwise an extremely good game.

108711012.review: I have been trying to play through this game for nearly four years, and per each attempt I give up after a few hours of frustration and confusion. This game truly seems like something I SHOULD adore. But... Iconoclasts is needlessly complicated whenever and wherever it strives to be unique. I'll give it credit for its pixel art and character design, but everything else (gameplay, story, music, the awkward controls) falls flat. I hope I don't forget how infuriated I was on this latest save file, and redownload this in another year. Again.

108424832.review: This is a fantastic metroidvania game with some fun visuals and unique character designs. 2D gamers should love this game.

108424320.review:
[h1]Icon in the Making[/h1]
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41820896/]Check out my Curator Page for more hidden gems: [b]REVIEWS[/b][/url][/quote]
[quote]TLDR: Amazing hidden-gem of a Metroidvania with awesome visuals, an engaging story, and great combat gameplay, all set in a colorful world that is interesting to explore.[/quote]

Iconoclasts is one of those games where, after you playing, you immediately think: “How come I haven’t heard more about this title?” In this colorful and relaxing 2D Metroidvania, you play as a bubbly mechanic named Robin who sets out to help others during a period of turmoil caused by magic-wielding baddies. 

This is one of those Metroidvanias where the game does a good job of guiding you in the right direction and ushering you onto the next area to explore, such that you don’t have to spend too much time/effort backtracking across huge, confusing maps like you have to in more hardcore Metroidvanias. This is a huge positive in terms of the game design and makes for an enjoyable, non-frustrating experience traversing the large, varied biomes present in this game.

In regards to the gameplay, it’s a lot of fun, and both combat as well as platforming mechanics (like spinning Robin’s wrench to stun enemies or using it to grapple across the map) are super satisfying. It’s not really a difficult game, but it strikes enough of a balance in terms of difficulty such that it offers a relaxing but engaging playthrough for most gamers.

The story is interesting and involves Robin working with an eclectic cast to try and stop a bunch of corrupt mages who terrorize villagers and are unwittingly about to destroy the planet. The game’s many characters are varied and for the most part each have unique personalities, and Robin serves as the cheerfully optimistic anchor at the center of it all. The narrative balances its more dramatic segments with humor and overall doesn’t take itself too seriously, making for a fun and engaging story overall.

Additionally, the pixel visuals are awesome, and really fit in well with the overall tone of the game. Animations are very smooth and so well-polished that it’s easy to forget that this was largely made by a one-man developer team. Furthermore, it has an epic soundtrack that pairs really well with the energetic vibes of the game.

All in all, Iconoclasts is a really enjoyable and refined Metroidvania that doesn’t really have any flaws going for it. Exploring its vibrant and memorable world is a ton of fun for casual gamers and its 10-hour runtime is one that you’ll definitely have a good time with if you’re at all into Metroidvanias or action platformers.

107950970.review:
The crisp pixel art visuals are very well made, but everything else it hit or miss.
The music only has a few tracks that stand out in a positive way, while most others are either just okay or not my thing at all.
Gameplay is pretty decent but some areas like the Tower are very tedious. This game really shouldn't have a "Metroidvania" tag, as there are barely any elements of a (good) one. Action-Puzzle-Platformer is more apt.

The story is this game's most ambitious aspect, and also the one that falls flat the most. Most characters you are supposed to side with are unlikable and irritating. The villains do include the most compelling character in the game, Agent Black, but most of them suffer from strange design decisions and weird dialogue that often sounds pretentious and fake-deep (imagine Alex from YIIK.) The poorly thought out story is what brings the game down the most for me, and I honestly wish most of it was just cut out.

The overall setting and worldbuilding was strange and didn't feel believable to me. The game's "finale" is probably the worst offender, as it goes on for way too long and feels like a joke that wants to be taken seriously. By the end, you're left with a bad taste in your mouth.

While it's impressive that one person developed and spent nearly a decade of his life on making this game, it sadly didn't pay off in my eyes. One thing the dev definitely needed was someone else to edit the dialogue, and generally more advice on the story from other people.

This game remains rather obscure and "underrated" for good reasons. Please spend your money on something else.

107699841.review:
Iconoclasts is one of those games that I had my eyes on for a long while, and after playing it I can't recommend it enough.

The presentation alone is beautiful, with smoothly animated pixel-art and great music all around. From distinct areas to satsifying sound effects with every action you do. Amazing setpieces that stand out even with how basic it might be (like grass or desert biomes).

Gameplay is surprisingly simple, giving you only a few real abilities to traverse the areas with like your wrench and guns. What it excels at is using all these tools in different ways, both in combat and for exploration. Tweaks themselves are a nice extra for passive benefits like longer breath or damage immunity, but I never felt forced to use any of them. And sometimes the game switches it up with changing the playable character for a few sections.

The story itself isn't too complex to follow but the execution of it is great. Lots of memorable characters you will love or hate with a great silent protagonist. The way it also goes between humour and serious moments is also great, making it both compelling for the tragedy and likeable for the comedy. It also helps the lore is rich and the world feels alive.

The greatest strength I find is the boss fights, with each one standing out on their own. Whether you get to play around with the gimmicks of a new weapon, have to puzzle solve to deal damage or even ignore the boss to do something else. They each feel unique and are the main selling point of this game.

In conclusion, go play this game. It is an almost flawless masterpiece of a metroidvania that has a great story and fun gameplay combined with great visuals and lovely music.

107584665.review:
Solid little Metroidvania game, with lovely art and music: sort of a Cave Story vibe, complete with some disconnection between the lighthearted visuals and the fairly heavy story beats.

The gameplay has more of a puzzle bent than a combat bent: most of the combat is itself more about puzzle-solving than twitch reflexes (figuring out which tool to apply to the problem in which order). It's a bit railroaded for awhile until the endgame lets you go pick up the rest of the collectibles; as other reviews mention, compare Metroid Fusion. The puzzles are generally well-designed: there are a couple weird ones (and a couple moments where the game kinda lies to you about where to go next). There's one sort of odd reason for the lack of combat focus, though: you gain basically no raw stats over the course of the game (just a couple of the tweaks). The difficulty curve is fairly shallow, and the exploration rewards are just materials for tweaks with minor effect so there's not much upside aside from personal satisfaction.

The story is sincere but lacks focus: there are a dozen significant secondary characters each with their own storyline, and most of them don't really get the time needed to resolve. Sometimes these sorts of loose ends just serve to make the world feel bigger; here, it just makes it unclear what problem your actions are actually solving.

107257694.review:
I really enjoyed my playthrough of this game. I have a particular fondness for platformers, so if that's all you're interested in, Iconoclasts does a serviceable enough job to scratch that itch.

I'll start with the negatives so that I can end with the positives.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
1. [b]Conveyance[/b] is a particularly large issue in this game. While the game does give you a great amount of freedom to explore things and figure them out, as you wish and at your own pace, it doesn't do a particularly good job of showing you things at times. Sometimes, it's bang on the money, and you can get it right off, but there were bosses or sequences where I sat there with my thumb up my hind parts, trying to figure out what I was supposed to do before I died enough times to be willing to try anything. The underground tunneller boss comes to mind in particular for me. His second phase was a big "uh, what?" for me. There just wasn't the feedback from the game there, and because I streamed my whole playthrough, it devolved into me just asking the chat what I was missing or complaining that "that idea was poorly conveyed." It's my biggest complaint about the game.
2. The [b]Politics[/b] of the producer are plainly obvious to anyone who is actively paying attention. It was kinda cringe, but didn't actively or permanently damage my impression of the game. It was just a quick eye roller here or there, though the more politically inclined might make or break based on this.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
1. [b]Controls[/b] are tight and responsive. There will be a few misses where you'll feel like you probably should have hit, or that the game should have been more forgiving, in regards to some jumps and sequences, there are equally just as many hits that feel out of place. Both are few and far between, and largely can be placed squarely on my own shortcomings. Overall, I'd say the controls are tight enough to make you feel like you have recourse, and that if you're quick, you will be able to respond to every challenge placed in front of you. This is the most important part of any platformer, and I'd call this section a success.
2. The [b]Art Direction and Design[/b] are magnificent. The sprites are lively and full of emotion, and are well designed. The actual art of the characters ranges from cute to beautiful. Even the use of pixel art as the medium was a good one, because it added another layer of storytelling that otherwise wouldn't be available.
3. Speaking of [b]Storytelling[/b], this is where this game shines. I won't go into spoilers, but I can say that this game does a very good job of staying above board with it's storytelling, and it remains internally consistent, even as it gets wild. If I had any complaints, it's that the game leans into the characters faults to attempt to portray growth, and at times it can get a little heavy handed. That said, the supporting cast in the One Concern grunts had great humour beats, the antagonists felt believable and unique for motivations, the designs of each new character was engaging, and I wanted to see where it went if nothing else. The world feels silly and cartoony, but overall was engaging, and it didn't take itself too seriously, which was a boon.

Overall, I'd say that this game was a 3.5/5 to a 4/5 for me. A very enjoyable experience, with a lovable and expressive protagonist--even though she's mute--and a cast who at times can rub the wrong way, are still grounded enough to remain believable and engaging. Personal growth is a consistent theme in this game, and I'd say that any sins on the side of any of the characters is easily grounded in this growth.

This game was worth the money, but I don't know if it's worth a replay. A one-of, fun-of.

106119939.review:
So I went into the game expecting a run-of-the-mill Metroidvania but got something truly unique.

The entirety of the world map is much smaller than a typical Metroidvania and there's not nearly as much backtracking, which is fine. But what really makes this game shine are the puzzles and, more than ANYTHING, the boss fights.

Each boss is wholly unique. The game doesn't hold your hand with how to beat them, either. I don't think there was a single boss that I didn't die to the first time. Thankfully the game is generous enough to start you at the beginning of the fight. Figuring out how to beat each boss is soooo much fun! I cannot stress how great each boss encounter is.

Surprisingly, there is also a rather rich story with lore. At first glance, I rolled my eyes at the heavy-handed, done to death "RELIGIONS ARE EVIL!!!! CORPORATIONS ARE DESTROYING THE ENVIRONMENT!!!" plot, but there are some really nice plot twists and character moments. Now, as someone who teaches English, maybe I'm a bit more sensitive to this, but it was clear that someone who doesn't speak English natively wrote this. It's fine for what it is, but the script could've used a once over to cut-down on long-winded dialog and awkward, unclear phrasing. But again, I don't think most people will notice that. I went in thinking I would hate the story, but I ended up really liking the world it created and wanting more answers.

So yeah, HIGHLY recommend this game. It was a joy to play. The late game was pretty tough and a slog because it was truly difficulty; you couldn't just smash your way through things. But stick with this game till the end.

The full game exceeded all of my expectations.

Most of Iconoclasts achieves a 'flow' state with the puzzles, enemies, and platforming.
Puzzles are perfectly balanced and are respectful towards the player: not at all tedious, hard enough to keep things interesting, easy enough to never need to be looked up.

That being said, there are minor and sporadic incidences where a poor design choice or oversight appears.

102407004.review:
This game has a few very good things about it. For starters, it's pretty. The best part is the occasionally brilliant puzzles. Sometimes you get stuck for a minute or two, then have an "a-ha!" moment, and suddenly it all becomes clear. It's a pity that this isn't a more puzzle-focused game.

The pinnacle of this is a certain boss fight that's actually not much of a fight, because it involes sneaking around in tall grass and puddles of water. You might think a stealth boss fight that's also a wildly atypical sequence is a recipe for disaster, but it does work very well here. The non-combat mechanics are flexible enough to hold it together. Again, it's a pity that this is an exception, and not how you deal with enemies on a regular basis.

Most regular boss fights are puzzles, too, in that you don't just memorize patterns, but also discover the principle of a given fight. It's much more rewarding than traditional boss fights and gives you at least some reward for having to repeat the same fight over and over (actually, I beat most of them on my second or third attempt). Once you discover the principle, the fight becomes easy anyway, and I like it that way, because it makes me feel that the game rewards thinking.

The main problem with "Iconoclasts"  is that it tends to make things more and more complicated. It doesn't show restraint. The puzzles are exempt from this, because they hit a natural limit once they become about two screens large. They can't get any bigger because then they would become impossible to track. This keeps them at an enjoable level. The same does not apply to combat. In the first half of the game it feels clunky and a bit frustrating, especially once the soldier type enemies begin to show up. Then at some point the challenges begin to stack in ways that break the already strained mechanics, and suddenly you hit a brick wall. Same thing occurs with boss fights. At some point it's just no longer fun: yeah, I get what this fight is about, but now I also have to keep practicing until I do memorize the patterns. I know some people enjoy this kind of gameplay, but to me it feels like work. It just stands in the way of the fun parts.

A similar problem plagues the narrative. The story itself is simple, but the game obsfuscates it with so many, many, many words. The characters talk too much. They use complicated phrases to convey simple thoughts. They hold meaningless arguments. Their emotions are cartoonish. They are also entirely one-dimensional. At first I thought the verbose dialogue was meant as a parody, but no, it's not a joke: the game turns out to take itself super seriously. It's a pity, because the central conflict actually has an interesting "it's not what you think" vibe to it, and definitely deserves a narrative with shorter conversations covering a larger number of story beats.

I don't usually skip dialogue in games, yet here I did it all the time, because I just couldn't bear it.

All in all, this game is not so much "bad" (quite the contrary, I've enjoyed large parts of it), as it is inconsistent. It just begins to try too hard at some point, and that's why I've ended up disappointed.

102389085.review:
[h1] Interesting labour of love, weighed down by bad writing. Deserves to find its audience [/h1]

This game was made by one, clearly very talented (or just very hard-working), dude who clearly put his heart and soul into it. As such, it's a valuable, interesting and worthwhile game that deserves to find an audience that vibes with it. To find out if you are one of those lucky people, watch the trailers and imagine that game, except with four times the dialogue, one-tenth of the exploration (don't be fooled, this is NOT a metroidvania) and with a clammy wet blanket of depressing, pessimistic angst thrown over the cheery, bouncy pixel art visuals. 

The biggest problem with the game is the story and writing, which is bad because there is so much of it. It feels like the game is trying to cram an entire JRPGs worth of story, lore and characterization into a ~12 hour action game.
Moreover, much of the writing is just...bad. You can tell that English is not the writer's first language. There's a certain stiltedness to the dialogue that makes many of the jokes fall flat and much of the more florid writing feel overwrought and just subtly wrong. The tone veers between despair and vulnerability and MCU-style "great, just what I needed...more robots for me to shoot with my cool gun!" self-aware snark from moment to moment in a way that is awkward and baffling. The pinballing between dystopian horror and cartoon comedy just felt uncomfortable, like watching a friend of a friend have an emotional breakdown at their own birthday party.

Many aspects of the world that do turn out to be legitimately cool and unique are rushed and poorly explained, not helped by the fact that the pixel artstyle just does not do enough to communicate the nuance this original setting and these complex emotional beats would require. 
When the story does come together, it's not at all bad. Across 30 or so hours, with expressive character portraits, more detailed backgrounds and maybe voice acting, it could've been a great, emotionally resonant RPG, but here it just saps the joy out of what would otherwise be a fun, bouncy platformer. I felt BAD after every session. Not moved, not motivated, not touched, just BAD.

All of this is a huge pity, because everything else about Iconoclasts is really good. The game especially does a great job creating cool, memorable set pieces and unique bosses. It's well animated, colourful and visually charming, plus it handles well. Without all the writing, this would've been an easy recommendation. Gameplay has its nitpicks, but overall is very good, at times even great.

The game just shows that just because you can and want to do it all yourself, doesn't mean you'll do a good job. The developer is clearly very good at a number of things, and pretty good at a bunch more. He's just not good at everything, and that weighs this game down to beyond what I'd call enjoyable. I would have quit midway through, but the game's story, bad though it was, was interesting and irritating enough that I powered through to the end, using one of the Shantae games to clean my palette after every session.

If an unnecessarily downbeat, overly-written, mostly-linear 2D platformer with minimal optional exploration sounds like your jam, then ignore my rating and go buy it. I can't recommend this at all, but that's not because there's nothing good here, but because there was a lot of things I didn't like. You might like it and if so, the dev certainly deserves your support.
