Picked it up on sale earlier this week, and just finished my first play-through. It was very good! The game mechanics are really well done and feel good to play. I enjoyed most of the bosses; often you'll be introduced to some new game mechanic, and shortly after face a boss that requires you to use that mechanics, which I thought was pretty cool. The puzzles were also really good, and made fantastic use of your toolset & abilities. There were several headscratchers that felt really good to figure out (but... if you are less into puzzle platforming, many of the most difficult are optional). I also found the plot pretty engrossing. I really liked the characters.

I think my only complaint might be that the game is pretty linear; there's not really the same sort of deeply interconnected map that you see in some other games in the genre. Not a huge deal though; there were opportunities to revisit earlier areas, just maybe not as many as you might expect. But also, considering the whole game was pretty much done by one guy, I can't really hold this against it; the game is awesome and I had a huge amount of fun with it.

tl;dr it's good, and you should definitely play it!! I got it on sale, but honestly, I think it's well worth it at full-price as well if you like puzzle platforming and the idea of hitting foes with a giant wrench.

100982106.review:
While I did have fun majority of the time (enough to recommend it to anyone curious about picking it up), I can definitely understand all the criticism it gets. It's not the easiest thing to get into and even I had a hard time really getting invested until a few hours in. 

And I think in the end it sits in the category of being "okay". Amazing sprite and pixel art, but okay. On the gameplay side of things there's a lack of visual clarity and way too many occasions of enemies having only one weakness, that weakness is the only thing that hurts them, but not going to tell you what that is. Nor do the enemies give you that much in visual hints. Something that looks armored can't be damaged by the stun gun, but you can take it out with a bomb. Makes sense. Until you find more armored enemies that can't be damaged by bombs either. Or machinery that looks roughly the same as other machinery that could be damaged by the stun gun, except these ones do need bombs and rockets. Or more armored guys with shields that resist everything, but you can take them out just by ground pounding on their heads. 

Most of the bosses at least follow the "use the new technique you just learned" somewhere which can help narrow things down. But not always (Awkwardly spent way too much time trying to break glass/ice with every explosive I had, till slowly realizing I was supposed to use the wrench...)

I am also torn on Relaxed and Standard Mode too. There is a steep difficulty spike right near the end, one that seems doable but absurd, and then there's Relaxed Mode where you just cheat through everything. I wish there was something else in between.

Story wise, it's interesting, not at all what I thought it was going to be though. I won't say it's bad but I could see why some people wouldn't like it, as I think it runs close between being too miserable, or sounding too pretentious a bit too often. I'm not so sure it even accomplished what it set out to do [spoiler]Most if not every character seems about the same or worse off than at the start, tbh. Besides Robin I guess?[/spoiler], and I think I had more questions than answers by the end of it at any rate.



TL;DR, Iconoclasts is something of an experience and still worth checking out if you have the slightest interest in it. Especially if you love retro 2D games of that style. It's another one of those games I could totally see fitting in with the rest of the "weird, niche titles that somehow got a cult following" gems (Mischief Makers, Terranigma, etc) solely on the vibe it's got going on. I always suggest waiting for sales though.

Another indie it reminded me a lot of is Owlboy. As it's got a lot of things really similar (the plot, pixel animation, both are metriodvania-esque), but darker.

100663675.review:
[h2]Introduction[/h2]
[i]Iconoclasts[/i] is a Metroidvania Platformer title that has little in the way of character upgrades and instead has players go about some segments in different ways, such as stealth and "hide and seek". While [i]Iconoclasts[/i] itself plays just as one would expect from a traditional Metroidvania, there are instances of minor stealth and character switching that mix up the formula the game uses.

[h2]Iconoclasts Indeed[/h2]
Imagine a world in which the majority of the populous believes a divine power outside of their comprehension oversees the world and its inhabitants. Now, imagine said world with many punishments and hardships for those that defy the teachings or fight against this entity’s will. Imagine if there is some truth to this divinity, but you’re unsure as to what exactly this god-like entity is. With that, you are presented with the general idea of what [i]Iconoclasts[/i] is at its core.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zt0c5tE5Gno&ab_channel=Plebles%27ReviewClips

As the name suggests, [b]Robin[/b], the protagonist of our story, accomplishes many different feats, including helping people and meeting new friends, sometimes making dents in the [b]One Concern[/b]'s plans along the way. She is an engineer, and initially gets in trouble when caught fixing something in a relative's house, which is a felony in this world. [b]Robin[/b] encounters people that are devout followers and members of the [b]One Concern[/b], who worship a god-like power known simply as [b]Him/He/His[/b]. She also meets people that believe it’s all nothing more than a means to control and interfere with their way of life, while more still slowly change their views as the story unfolds.

The story as a whole had me guessing at every turn. What really stuck with me after completing the story most, was how people lived: aside from the constant fear of assault from a benevolent force, most of these well meaning people are effectively brainwashed, whether it be through just sheer fear or unconditional love. I experienced the world through the eyes of [b]Robin[/b] and to a lesser extent, her friends, but I couldn't help but wonder all the while about the innocent people. Every decision has a ripple effect, and thinking how every single human has to cope with all of this really makes me wish there was a little more focus on the common man/woman's life, just to see what day to day challenges they'd face.

[h2]Weapons, Mechanics, and Combat[/h2]
[b]Robin[/b] starts out with a stun gun and wrench, which the game refers to as “tools”. It’s amazing and outlandish to think she can effectively fight the many threats and enemies that get in her way. It works well enough though, and other more powerful tools are obtained later on that would definitely do some serious damage, such as the roller bomb shot. There are instances where the game requires the use of specific weapons and tools, usually for puzzles and bosses, and the standard simple puzzle to get you acquainted with said weapons.

Weapons can be charged, serving both as a solution to puzzles and combating enemies. The wrench is the ultimate tool: any nuts found scattered about can either be used as a means of swinging from place to place, slide on airborne rails, fight bosses, or even open doors and manipulate the environment itself to continue onward. Projectiles can even be knocked back towards enemies, in some cases being a very effective means of counter combat. The last mechanic I’d like to cover is the implementation of small bonuses that help out with general gameplay known as tweaks. Throughout the game, schematics can be acquired that grant [b]Robin[/b] the ability to use these bonuses once the necessary resources are found. I didn’t use a large majority of them because I didn’t feel they were necessary, but I found "breathless" and "fleet foot" useful. Having more time underwater before oxygen deprivation became an issue and moving faster were very helpful and made all backtracking more bearable. Up to three tweaks can be used at a time, and duplicates can be made for use, so long as the material is available. Taking damage “breaks” them, however, and defeating enemies or destroying certain objects replenishes the tweak’s health. I don’t like how this was implemented, as one hit essentially removes 1/3 of your bonuses, but serves as motivation to get good at least.

Combat is handled the way one would expect in a Platformer: you jump and climb, take cover, and attack enemies with your weapons. There are a few cases where direct combat isn’t the answer, however, such as certain stealth sections. The stun gun is the fastest-firing weapon available, though the shots are rather weak. I feel it's not a great weapon, as once I got used to enemy patterns, it was just a matter of me using another weapon for more damage while dodging. It’s useful for dispatching weaker enemies and small crowds, especially since it has a form of aim assist, which makes aerial threats easier to deal with. The roller bomb shot is a rolling ball bomb, like one would imagine. Shots roll a set distance and explode after a short time, which can be useful in some combat situations. When charged, a missile is fired that won’t arm until it moves a certain distance. This means that if you’re too close to an enemy or object that obstructs the shot, it’ll just bounce off and land harmlessly. While competent, the combat isn't very interesting but works well enough.

[h2]Audiovisual Direction[/h2]
Graphically, [i]Iconoclasts[/i] ticks every box on my “great visuals” checklist: vibrant colors, pretty pixel art, and various locations with their own flavor. Enemy and boss designs are sometimes wacky, sometimes tacky, but always unique.


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2613485380

The character designs are neat, but I personally feel more love and care could have been applied to certain characters, with the most prominent character design that I find kind of odd being [b]Robin’s[/b]. It’s more than likely her weird looking chicken legs were intentional, but they throw everything else about the character’s look and feel off.

The soundtrack is phenomenal overall, with some tracks, of course, being hits and others being misses. The true beauty here is the variation in the genre and tone of the soundtrack as a whole: the game throws some chiptune style at you one moment, then later you may find yourself listening to some ragtime, and even songs that sound like a mishmash of many different genres serving as background ambiance. I love music, and I was quite pleased with the variation most of the time.

[h2]💻Performance💻[/h2]

My Specs:
CPU – Ryzen 9 3900X
GPU – AMD Radeon RX 5700 XT
RAM – 16 GB
Storage - HDD

[td]Visual & Resolution[/td]
[td]2560x1440, max settings.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Controller Support?[/td]
[td]Yes. I recommend controller.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h3]Bugs[/h3]
I experienced no bugs during my time playing.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
I’d recommend giving [i]Iconoclasts[/i] a try, as the story is pretty neat and the variation in combat and locales is fantastic. There are cases in which just shooting at your problem or working out puzzles won’t work well, as scripted events call for different ways of playing. This is not very common, but it happens enough that it grants a refreshing shake up to the experience. For its price point, the gameplay to price ratio is fair.

This is a great game. Great action, great platforming, and it has metroidvania elements to it and that's my second favorite genre (outside of RPG). The story is also fantastic, as well as the music.

100414970.review:
Iconoclasts is all around super pretty. You can tell that much from the trailer and I can assure you it looks that good from start to finish. I'll even say it's pretty creative with how you use new abilities to solve puzzles and find new areas, which is a hallmark of a good metroidvania. However, past this point I have nothing good to say about this game.

Iconoclasts' game play never stopped annoying me. One of the best parts of any metroidvania is travelling all around the map and going back to old areas with new abilities that totally change what its like to move through them. In Iconoclasts, going back to a previous area to complete a quest or pick up one or two chests that you needed a specific ability for feels like a chore even after you unlock fast travel.

Starting-area enemies can still be annoying at the end of the game because plenty of them have quirks that make them immune to all but one specific attack in your arsenal, which is doubly frustrating when the attack you were preparing misses because your attacks are so clunky to use. Of course this gets 10x worse with bosses where you have to decipher their quirks in the heat of the moment, flipping through your weapons while trying not to die before you can sleuth your way into figuring out you've gotta swing off their hand [i]just so[/i] in order to make them vulnerable. Except that's not true. As long as you equip Iron Heart on all your tweaks you don't have to worry about dying. The boss just becomes a game of how long are you willing to sit down and practice lining up your shots.
(To be fair not all the boss fight are this complicated. Sometimes all they have you do is hold right and press a button when you reach the boss.)

The story doesn't save this game either. All the characters are so insufferable and self-centered all the time. Especially Elro, who practically spends the entire game throwing a tantrum because he can't make everyone do what he wants. The only character who gets any development is Royal, but before he can complete a character arc, [spoiler]he gets left to die on the moon[/spoiler]. I get the sense that I was supposed to be invested in these characters before I bought the game. Like the creators released biographies on all the characters leading up to release. But I'm just sitting confused as everyone in the game keeps telling Robin how heroic and helpful and good she is when all I've been doing is letting the world take me where I need to go to progress.

The game calls itself "a beautiful platform adventure that tells a personal story about faith, purpose and the challenge of helping people." To which all I can say is... eh? If you insist? I don't know if I helped that many people when it seems like most of them ended up either miserable or dead.

EDIT:
I spent a bit more time hunting down all the achievements. Not much more to add except the Usurper is uniquely frustrating to use. Also nothing wears you down quite like fighting Agent Black and Star Worm/Bird in challenge mode. The former would be easy if not for the lack of save points between the phases, and the latter overcompensates for how easy it is with a health bar that feels bottomless.

It just hit me [spoiler]that the final boss of the game is this alien bird mechanic.[/spoiler] Just out of nowhere. Never gets resolved. It sorta adds to the feeling that the people making this game just got tired with it toward the end. The pretty bits looked pretty and the boss fights worked, and everyone wanted to bring it to market.

I guess I had more to add than I thought.

NATIVE LINUX SUPPORT HELL YEAH!

Iconoclasts is a colorful Metroidvania that is super fun to play. The pixel art is gorgeous, the story is interesting (albeit a bit abstract), the gameplay is fun, but with some quirks. I beat it in 8 hours in standard mode, an additional hour was needed to 100% it with the secret boss. Still, I had fun playing this game, a clear recommendation. 7/10. Also DON'T PLAY THIS IN EASY MODE, THIS GAME IS ALREADY FAIRLY EASY IN STANDARD MODE!

99814848.review:
I tend to not write reviews but I'll make an exception for this game. Iconoclasts caught me by complete surprise. I've been trying to get more and more into Indie Games myself. While I mostly keep an eye on new Indies coming around the corner, occasionally I go back and pick up old goodies that I missed. Iconoclasts is more than a goodie. This game, albeit it paling in comparison to a ton of other games I've played in Playtime, is easily in my top 5 games of all time. The gameplay itself is solid. Combat is simple yet fun to play. Melee, Range, Parry, the usual hijinks. Bossfights is where it shines though. All of them have a unique gimmick to them that's fun, surprising and never overstays it's welcome. Even in the odd instance that I wasn't an enormous fan of how a certain enemy would have to be handled, they never drown you in doing the same mechanic. 

Where the game shines most for me is it story however. I finished this game months ago and occasionally still recollect on moments that took place in it. The dialogue, the characters, the music that backs them up, it's all just fantastic. I couldn't recommend this game more. I'm no critic nor do I claim to be but if you are even the SLIGHTEST bit curious about this game, do it. Bite in. It won't disappoint.

99766993.review:
A few things. 

The art in this game is phenomenal. Almost every part of it looks visually excellent, and there was NEVER any detail that took me out of things - it was consistent all the way through. Absolutely great art quality, direction, animations, everything. I only have one gripe with any part of the art.

I don't like Robin's design. It's the leg and arm designs - big sleeves with tiny chicken legs doesn't mesh with me. I preferred more or less every single other character design in the game to hers. Her hair is great, I don't mind her actual shapes, and her animations are great - it's the choice of attire that bothers me. 

There are a few segments of this game that are not fun. They're difficult, finicky in the mechanics in use, and don't really feel that satisfying to complete. There are quite few of them, but there ARE a few. I can understand why only about a third of players have actually beaten the game.

The core cast generally aren't that likable. Robin herself is fine; mostly silent, but she still comes off as quite strong and upbeat, which is good. Mina...eh. She's a VERY mixed bag, moreso than even actual people tend to be. Elro was irritating every time he was on screen, without exception. Royal...I'll be honest, Royal was the only standout character for me. He showed actual growth over the story, and seemed to have been developing towards a positive outcome. The only character to actually try to understand others, even if he was bad at it.

This is not a great example of a metroidvania. There is basically no motivation to backtrack at any point, and no need to actually go any direction except in the linear, straight forward one. I actually stopped bothering to check rooms about three hours in, because I knew the game would force me there eventually. And it did. It's still fun, most all of the mechanics are good, but it's not quite what I was expecting.

There is one mechanic that bothered me immensely: quirks. Quirks seem...mostly worthless. I think I crafted 3-4 in the entire game, because none of them really seemed worth anything except for the ones that made charging up quicker. There was no difficulty curve that required them, so they felt redundant. Upgrades should be something you really feel you're benefiting from; not just a thing you can say 'oh, I guess that's nice' to, whenever they happen to be there.

In conclusion: Good game, okay story, fantastic art.




Now, some quick theory stuff. DO NOT read this if you haven't played the game.

This 'planet' is entirely artificial, and is not meant to have humans on it. It's a giant machine, designed to carry out a specific set of operations. Humanity accidentally arrived on it, propagated, and put the whole thing in jeopardy with seeds from earth which could rapidly consume the fuel source for this machine. This is probably when first contact with the alien ship occurred; early human settlements were probably wiped out, and all of Earth's nature was suppressed to keep damage to the machine to a minimum. A deal was struck with the stranded humans who remained: use as little ivory as possible so the planet doesn't run out, and you can stay. Unfortunately, like most things, time passed and people distorted events into a religion worshiping the aliens instead of actually upholding the agreed upon deal. This is why the birdman at the end was so angry about the fuel being used up - it was causing the machine's ACTUAL purpose to run out of fuel and break down.

Incidentally, this is also why the 'Eyes' cannot connect to normal humans. Humans aren't part of the machine the eyes are designed to integrate with; all other 'life' on the planet IS. Those with ivory in their bodies were also susceptible to these Eyes as a result of the ivory itself - the foreign element in their physiology. 

I'd wager a guess that the alien had NO intention of humans ever getting injected with ivory, as this would be a waste, and as shown, gave humans the power to actually break the shell on the alien's ship. Imagine if that ship confronted Mother, at the peak of her power? She could have ripped the bird man out of it. There's no way he would have been okay with humans getting that kind of power.

Last thing - the bird man himself had no special powers, just technology. It's possible humans developing power over ivory via injection was something his species had no idea was possible - and might even be something only humans were capable of, due to their radically different physiology. That might even be something latent in humans that the ivory was stirring up.

Oh, and - no reason Royal should be dead. Considering his relative invulnerability, if the part of the moon he's stuck to ever fell to to the surface, he'd regenerate. So it's not as if that character has been written into the 'absolutely dead' corner. I'm not saying he SHOULD be alive, but it wouldn't be hard to explain it if he was.

99272203.review:
Good game.

I think the best quality of the game is probably the story. There's a lot of nice environmental storytelling, and characters don't exposit more than they need to. I felt like they had realistic motivations and character arcs. Though I feel like Robin could have used a little more characterization, I got the gist of her, and that was more-or-less enough. Some of the dialogue is written kind of awkwardly, but overall it seemed like a lot of care was put into the story.

The pixel art and character designs are very good. The cast is very distinguishable and there are rarely any moments where you get confused about what's going on visually. I felt like the characters' emotions came across very well through the animations, and all of the zones of the game were distinct. 

The music is also very good and I find myself listening to tracks from the OST sometimes. I really liked Ferrier Shockwoods and The Tower. There are a lot of good, emotional character themes as well.

As far as gameplay goes, it has a good feel for a platformer, and fighting feels fun. I've read other reviewers say that the save/continue system was frustrating, and that sometimes you restart too far back, but I didn't really fail enough at the gameplay to notice anything like that. I've seen other reviewers express frustration about being lost or not knowing what to do during boss battles, but that didn't really bother me.

Now, I played it on Hard Mode, which I felt was a decent challenge, but I have some criticisms:

- The tweak "dodge" feels like it'd be more fun if it were its own thing. It takes up a Tweak slot, and Tweaks break when you take damage, so it feels kind of lame when you lose it. I always made it my first Tweak so it'd be behind two other Tweaks. Maybe it'd be better if you got a tweak to extend the invincibility frames of dodge instead.

- I didn't really find myself using the energize ability during combat much. It didn't really feel like it added a significant amount of damage sometimes. The Tweaks that improve it felt outclassed by other Tweaks so I never used them. A lot of enemies felt too dangerous to approach with melee attacks so it didn't really feel worth investing in melee, especially since you can lose dodge.

- The Tweak system itself I feel kind of breaks down in Hard Mode. It's so difficult to obtain energy to repair your Tweaks and so easy to lose them that I tended to stick with dodge and two shields. It'd be nice if there were tricky things you could do during boss battles that like, instantly reward you with enough to repair one Tweak or something. Maybe there could be a short window where if you spin your wrench to deflect a shot just before it hits it could repair a Tweak. Honestly I feel like the Tweak system is sometimes just sort of a gimmick that makes you not want to play around with it.

- It would be nice, for convenience sake, if you could instantly switch to and fire any of your gun modes with one button press, instead of cycling through them. However, not every system has enough buttons for that, so I suppose I can understand that.

- Firing direction lock, so you can keep firing in one direction while jumping. But that would also take up another button, so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯.

Overall, it felt like a 4.5/5 experience. There was enough to overcome the flaws in the gameplay mechanics that I enjoyed it, and for most people it'll be fine. It's a lovely game that deserves a playthrough, though it might be a little frustrating sometimes.

98850697.review:
Iconoclasts is tagged as a metroidvania, and while that's true, it's mostly a story-driven, action, puzzle-platformer.

I originally started the game back in 2018, but got stuck on a boss and put it down for A Hat in Time (also very good). I decided to finish it this summer and despite not remembering any of the story from the first three areas of the game, was sucked back in quickly. I slowly filled in what I had forgotten as I played, while pushing forward with more and more curiosity. The story is fantastic, and every character fits the title of Iconoclast in their own way.

Most of Iconoclasts' gameplay is running around 2D areas, each built like a metroidvania map, finding secrets, solving puzzles, and fighting enemies. There's a few mini-bosses per area, and an end boss before you can move on, all of which were clever fights where the issue isn't how not to die, but how to damage the boss. They serve as mini-puzzles of their own, and were a highlight of the game, especially the big story related ones.

For a game made by one guy over 7 years, Iconoclasts is very impressive. The graphics are beautiful, the music is full of high-energy jams and more emotional pieces, and everything weaves together to form a finished product that I can't help but recommend. 
Please, give it a try, there's so much more to discover than the opening will suggest.

98743420.review:
Iconoclasts is one of those games where it's difficult to find something to nitpick about it because every one of its pieces are masterfully done.  The story builds its world and characters excellently and has consistent themes throughout alongside some brilliant twists and turns that never once pads itself out through the roughly 10 hour experience.  The controls and level design follow suit by being smooth to control and get around, on the level of the Castlevania DS games and Super Metroid, with combat crossed between Cave Story and Metal Slug, all accentuated by a unique cast of bosses that all require a different skill set and strategy.  To make things even better for the story, the bosses and enemies alongside the residents of the game's world tie into that world's building, even when they come and go in the plot.

The graphics pop with color, details are abound in the environments and even in scenes of dialogue, the music is diverse and perfectly accompanies every set piece and with its strong story, level design and combat it all comes together to make one of the best action platformers I've ever played.  Play this game.

97673828.review:
Steam needs to give us a side thumb option because this is one of those games with tonnes of shades of grey.  First off, this is one of those games where I can give you an 80% synopsis of the story with a 30% explanation of why.  For example, the main character is a heathen is a simple enough trope.  Why?  Because she's an unlicensed mechanic.  The whole thrust of the story is that you, your brother and his family, all get persecuted by religious zealots because she's caught adjusting water pressure without a license.  Why doesn't she just apply for her license?  That's just one of many instances of plot happening but I'm left with more questions than answers.

The Metroidvania aspects are quite linear, which I'm okay with because there's really no incentive to go back and get crafting materials for a Tweak system that's pretty useless.  There are exactly two sidequests: Delivering Love/Breakup letters and trying to give a girl in a bed a twinkie.  Those quests really did not expand the world, feel meaningful in the moment, or offer meaningful rewards.  

The gameplay is fun.  Wrenching and shooting.  Puzzles.  Ziplines.  There wasn't a single aspect of the actual gameplay that frustrated me.  The bosses were pretty easy on normal, so I'd just start on hard.  

The story elements are bizarre but ultimately stick with you.  I woke up today trying to figure out the story and in a 10 hour metroidvania game with a silent protagonist, I would call that an accomplishment.  I finished Iconoclasts when I could not finish similar games like Owlboy.  Theres enough there that the $6 I spent on it off HumbleBundle is not a regret.

97401649.review:
So. Iconoclasts is a really good game, with a really good and engaging story and some really fun characters.

It has fantastic gameplay, and all that... and I really can't recommend it. Not because the gameplay falters, or the characters get uninteresting, or the story falls flat on its face. No, I can't recommend this game because it [i]betrays you, the player[/i], your trust in the game-as-story, and your belief in the main character's in-story abilities at a [b][i]very[/i][/b] late moment, almost directly before the final boss.

You are forced to [spoiler]abandon a character you have likely come to enjoy to die, due to a mechanical problem that is entirety within the main character's ability to fix, or, at this point in the game, [i]bypass entirely[/i] with a position-swapping gun.[/spoiler]

This is not unintentional, but the way in which it is done is extremely mean-spirited with how it betrays your trust - you are not allowed the main character's own skills, which are at this point [i]extremely[/i] well-established, the equipment you've gathered, which should be a solution, or even an in-story justification for why neither of the previous aren't viable options.

Oh, and it gives you an exceptionally long timer during this sequence, so you can try everything you can think of and, as designed, not succeed.

It sucks. It shouldn't suck, and though I even get why [spoiler]the character involved should die narratively[/spoiler] it's done in a way that nothing else in the game handles with anywhere near this level of disregard for the player.

So, yeah. It was a good game. And then I put it down before finishing it.

97265223.review:
This is a very good game.  While the dev explains Metroid Fusion is the main inspiration, graphics looks like 32-64 bit era sprites, with a lot of assets and effects inspired on Neo Geo / Sega Saturn / N64 / Treasure games.  Art is nostalgic, unique, and very distinctive. Music is good enough.  Characters are mostly interesting, lore is expansive, and gameplay is really, really good.  The tweaks system is a good compromise of getting slightly better, but not stronger to the point you're playing a different game/character at the end like most games with an upgrade / leveling up system.

Hopefully there's a more refined sequel/prequel with returning characters as I think it would elevate this game further.  Someone else mentioned the devs should look for an editor.  I agree.    Some of the story/character development could be told without mountains of texts, especially at the begging, where the game has yet to earn the player's full commitment.  But overall, I highly recommend this game.

96900457.review:
First off: As other people pointed out, this is not a metroidvania, it's a very linear puzzle platformer with little meaningful combat except for boss fights. You can just run past most enemies, since defeating them gets you nothing but health points. The upgrade system is not fleshed out at all, but there's some cool, gameplay-changing core abilities to pick up.

______

I don't know with this one. I finished it, but I was pretty done with it by the end. The game's high points, for me, were the beautiful and super cute animations, the puzzles and the clever and demanding boss fights.

But atmosphere and story of this game are all over the place. There's a weird disconnect between the cutesy-tootsy graphics, the light-hearted quips (some of them are pretty funny!) and the very, very brutal plot. The lore and dialog don't make all that much sense to me, mostly because quite a few characters speak in riddles. You're constantly thinking "all right, I'll understand what this character meant to express later on"... but it never becomes any clearer. I guess I sort of understand the gist of it, now that I'm through? But.. really, there's no shame in having a straight-forward story for most of your game. At least introduce your world a bit more first. By characters not literally quoting in-world scripture on a cliff.

I wish I could give a more nuanced score on Steam, but this is a 6/10 for me. It was obviously put together by people with exceptional skills in level design, animation and art. But beyond finding the main character adorable, I never got to care about any of the cast. If there wasn't so much dialog, then that wouldn't be such a big deal, but I sort of wish I had skipped the story. The concept for this world is certainly interesting, but it's all potential and very little pay-off, in my eyes.

Still giving it a thumbs up because of the wonderful production value. If you don't care about story, or don't mind sitting through super cryptic dialog, then you may want to give this one a spin.

96504063.review:
[h1] Another Wrench Thrown into the Metroidvania Stew [/h1]

[b] Iconoclasts, [/b]  
My feelings towards this game are pretty mixed.
You know when a game is pretty good but it's not particularly impressive? Yeah, this is one of that.
The game is not bad, it's efficient at being a game and all, but I just don't care about this one.
(Yeah I've read about the development process of this game and how it affected Joakim Sandberg, but the game tho...)

Alrite, let's go through the good stuff first:
 
- The visual design is pretty darn good, the pixel art quality reminded me of great GBA games like the Megaman Zero series, Final Fantasy Tactics Advance, and the Metroid games. Even the UI designs made it feels like it belongs on the GBA, that's how slick it is. Nothing looks lazy here, that's for sure.

- The combat mechanics and the boss fights are generally fun. Set pieces with boss encounters are genuinely unique, at least for this type of game. Many of the bosses required more from the players, wanting the players to use most of the main tools given, instead of just mindlessly damaging them with your weapon. Good job, Joakim! Oh yeah, the final boss's great! 

- Ah shit, I've run out of great things to say about this game

Now, the middling stuff:

- The gameplay's fine, mechanically the entire game feels like it works well enough for it not to fall apart. You can tell that certain details in the game are there to accommodate gameplay mechanics that aren't very flexible with its utility outside of combat. Certain blocks and switches just had to be there so gameplay can happen. I'm not gonna fault the game for being a video game, I just thought that thematically and visually these things are not very cohesive with the world its trying to build.

- The story we got here is an amalgamation of Dune, dystopian fiction tropes, and Final Fantasy 13? No, wait think about it! A female protagonist (Robin) goes on an adventure to save her sibling (Elro) from a theocratic authoritarian force, accompanied by someone outside of the main community who coincidentally has the ability to save the world (Mina) featuring a white haired boy (Royal) with a mommy issue! Oh my god, what other game rips off FF13, my dude?! Alrite. Kidding aside, the story's just okay. The worldbuilding didn't excite my curiosity and my imagination. I don't care about Ivory nor the world. Replace it with Mako energy and nothing will change. The story and lore might be thematically deeper than what we got in the game, but I don't care anymore. The humor's nice at times, some of the more serious dramatic parts overstayed their welcome. There's like one backstory exposition dump right before a boss fight that's as memorable as how many times I save a game before I close it. Eh.  

Conclusion:

Want a great story? Go play something else.
Want a fun 2D side scrolling game? Go for it!
Want to fight a collection of unique bosses? This game got some. 
Want an excellent Metroidvania game? This one's alrite.

96373908.review:
Like many games in my library, [i]Iconoclasts[/i] has been gathering dust in my backlog for a long time. And, like many games in my library, I should have played this one much, much sooner. 

As my 40ish shared screenshots of this game suggest, the pixel art in this one is fantastic. Each area, set piece, character, or enemy the player comes across was painstakingly crafted to be as visually striking as possible. I don’t normally gush about graphics in games, but some of the scenes in this one will stick with me for a long time. Of course, screenshots don’t do the game justice; one has to see it in motion to really appreciate it.

But I don’t personally believe that a metroidvania can be carried by its graphical style alone. Luckily, this game was fun as all hell to play! But, while there are a lot of standard metroidvania traits here (exploring, upgrading, backtracking, etc.), I can see how it might not be someone’s cup of tea… This one is extremely puzzle-heavy and story-driven.

It might be saying a lot about me, but some of the puzzles really twisted my brain into knots. I found them to be very clever, even when finding the solution had me slamming my head against the wall. The few puzzles I felt I needed to google never left me crying “bullshit” – the answer was in front of me all along and I was either too dense or too many beers deep to see it. But the puzzles aren’t just limited to static environmental stuff: every boss is treated like a puzzle, too, making each one unique and memorable. I really loved the way they made me recall and use all the tools at my disposal in order to defeat them.

Then, there’s the story. I was absolutely a fan of the narrative: it was kind of nice to see a game in this genre really dive in and explore the themes it presents instead of delivering them in abstract ways and letting the player piece everything together themselves. In other words, it’s lousy with longwinded characters. On top of that, it has some strong opinions about religion and government. It’s literally the name of the game, after all. So, you know, if a story that critiques theocratic authoritarianism that threatens planetary devastation would get you hot under the collar, you should probably steer clear. 

Anyway, as always, if those things didn’t turn you away, this one is absolutely worth your time. I think I’ll end up throwing on my growing list of favorites when I’m done typing this up.

95654513.review:
My review is basically this by RockPaperShotgun:
https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/iconoclasts-second-opinion

I like metroidvania games. I loved both Ori games, I loved "Dust - An Elysian Tail" and finishes all games at least twice. I also finished Hollow Knight so I know my way around hard metroidvania / platforming.

Iconoclasts is frustrating. The controls aren't as precise as the game needs them to be, the hidden treasures are boring and useless and often in dead ends so you don't even progress with the story line while solving a rather annoying puzzle.

And the puzzles are annoying. Many of the puzzles are trial and error, often you have to do the puzzles not once but twice because the first time you activate something that you need on your second run which actually lets u pass the puzzle. If you die after that puzzle progress is not saved and you have to start from the last manual save point.

The story is uninteresting, hard to read and extremely long. Sometimes it feels like I'm reading a comic, not playing a game. I'm also not a fan of the art style but you see that before you play it so that's on me.

And often you simply don't know what to do. At one point you switch from Robin, the main character, to Mina, the side character. She has a gun and for the longest time I didn't know how to use it. Every other weapon was "press x (on controller) to fire", hers wasn't. The first time you press x, there is an aim line that you move up and down with the controller stick. Only the second press of the button makes it shoot. But beware, if you turn the stick ever so slightly to the left or to the right you will point your gun horizontally in the direction you accidentally moved the stick to and that happens immediately. You also can't walk while aiming so trying to do that will result in you completely losing your aim, giving the enemy time to hit you.

I'm not patient enough for this game so I'll leave it be.

95011835.review:
I really wanted to like this game. I played it all the way through only because I play these kinds of games to complete them, but it was painful. Although I respect that one person made the game basically himself, he could have really used an editor. The story was all over the place, making all kinds of political commentary about religion, communism, fascism, economic and environmental issues and yet never really making a point. Rather, it just seemed to go out of its way to make almost every character unlikable because they were all some kind of nut job for one faction or the other and none of their plot lines really resolve. They don't seem to learn anything from their experiences, just kind of die or go home at the end. The main protagonist was the fine, I guess, but other than a few dialogue sequences, had nothing to say. The story was a convoluted mess and none of it really made sense and the end felt dragged out, with too many plot twists that didn't seem to really twist much. 

The vast majority of the upgrades were optional, so it didn't feel like there was much real progression other than the few weapon and wrench upgrades, which were probably the highlight. There were very few of those though.

The controls felt sloppy and could have been a lot tighter, but precision was required where it seemed unnecessary and was not really possible when it would have seemed useful.

Many of the enemies had certain tricks or weak spots, but the game doesn't really provide for any way to figure out what they are other than to die, repeat, and just experiment over and over.

Overall, this game has many neat elements, I think if the designer had brought in a few people to help cull the story to make it more intelligible, fine tune the controls, and add some better communication of some of the key elements of the puzzles, enemies, and boss fights, it could have been really great. As it is, I won't go back to it again.

94306477.review:
I played this game a year ago, and writing this review, my feelings are the same as after I finished it: it's one of my favorite games of all time. As is widely noted, the art is spectacular, the animation is wonderful, and the music is great. The platforming is extremely tight with great controls, and the boss fights - Joakim's hallmark - are fun as hell. 

It's the story that sets it apart, though - underneath its retro-fun and often colorful exterior, it has one of the most mature stories I've ever seen in a video game. It is a story about characters that do NOT grow and change - as in the real world, it is filled with people whose lived experience has calcified their beliefs and prejudices. And yet, these characters are written so well, that despite the limitations of 16-bit-style text boxes, their motivations, personalities and general being is so believable that you are constantly surprised by the empathy you feel towards them. 

The world of Iconoclasts is intriguing and mysterious from the beginning, and the game explores and explains this world, bit by bit, while beautifully avoiding the sort of out-of-character exposition that is so common. Like any great story, it shows, rather than tells. Iconoclasts explores weighty themes that are rarely touched on in such a well-architected manner. Think of the kind of stuff that's often present in modern, epic JRPGs, but without being hit on the head by it. The world opens itself up to you to reveal these themes, rather than having them endlessly explained to you, as if you were a child. I suppose that's what I mean when I say how mature the story is; it doesn't require tremendous amounts of silly lore to flesh out a realized world. For me, Pathologic - an absurdly text-heavy game - is the high point of gaming in terms of writing and dialog, and I think Iconoclasts, a game with a story told in small text boxes and environmental clues, is right up there with it.

There's much I'd like to write, but won't to avoid spoilers - I'll just say that I found myself constantly awed by moments in the game. The ending may be my favorite ending in any game - it ties up all of these themes and ideas in a shocking, and incredibly satisfying way. (As an aside, the concept of "Ivory" and its uses is masterfully creepy while being understated.)

I know this was a fawning review, so, is there anything I DIDN'T like? I can only think of one, and it's incredibly minor - the "power-ups" in the game felt like a bit of an afterthought while playing, and lo-and-behold, when I read an interview with Mr. Sandberg, it turned that it indeed was - at some point later during development he felt it was a necessary component in a metroidvania, and added it in. And who knows, maybe it is? I'm not sure if I would have missed them if the game didn't have them, and regardless, they certainly don't detract from the game or story in any way.

I adore this game.

93821250.review:
The most important feature of videogames is the gameplay: the way the player interacts with it is what defines the media and a game can be called successful only when it is fun to play. Because of this, everything else, like the visuals, is less important and not as necessary to make a good game; this also means that a story in a videogame is superfluous and can be very simple or even absent.
Despite this, videogames can be an interesting base for a story, either by finding interesting ways to tell it or by making it feel more personal thanks to the connection it creates with the player, who is functionally acting the story by playing.

While playing Iconoclasts, I was enjoying the gameplay: it's the result of many years spent perfecting it by the developer, who single handedly created also everything else, so the game is solid throughout its entirety, with very few issues. As a videogame, it does its job perfectly.
However, it didn't fully convince me: the base movement and combat is fine, but the later upgrades don't add a lot to the game and between the 'modifiers', only a handful of them are interesting. The game does fully deliver with the best it has to offer, the boss battles, which are all great and many of them even excellent, so, even if I didn't fully enjoy some of the gameplay, the game was still very fun.

The game is worth playing already by only considering the gameplay, but it also has nice visuals and a competent soundtrack, so that's enough for a successful videogame; it didn't need anything else, so a simple story would have been enough to tie it all together. But that didn't happen...
The title is maybe the most interesting thing of this game: it is never referred in the game and it's also an uncommon word, but it perfectly describes the story and its characters, which are truly the best thing of the entire game. It has been a while since I played Iconoclasts, but I needed some time to completely assimilate it, because it makes you reflect: the story poses interesting questions, the characters have deep motivations that are not clearly stated and, if that wasn't enough, the lore hidden in the game is plentiful and difficult to comprehend. You might stop playing the game after completing it, but you won't stop thinking about it for a while...

Iconoclasts is a masterpiece. A single person managed to create one of the best examples of what videogames can offer as an art form. If it connects with you, you won't easily forget it.

93693215.review: Easily one of the best Metroidvanias I've ever played. With fantastic pixel art, top-notch music, tight controls, unique mechanics/combat, rewarding puzzles, and a superb story and world, I have almost nothing but good things to say about Iconoclasts. Even with the backtracking involved that is somewhat typical for the genre, this game just makes the overall movement and control enjoyable enough to keep it interesting. One of the best things about this game for me was definitely the boss fights. Each one is unique, complex, and cinematic. It's clear a lot of passion went into making this game a reality, so if you have even a slight interest in the Metroidvania genre, do yourself a favor and check this one out!

Gripes: Yes, indeed, the action isn't as fluid as Hollow Knight. I'd liken it to the controls of SOTN. There's also a fair bit of dialogue which I've seen complaints about. There's visual and textual storytelling here, so player beware I guess.

I went back for an "insane difficulty" run, and then a third time to try and piece together all of my remaining questions off story clues which are never totally explained to the player. I buy copies of this game for my friends. I joined the fan discord. I light candles in a little, creepy shrine in my linen closet to Agent Black.

If you like The Talos Principle, Neir: Automata, or Binding of Isaac's story and themes this is a hidden gem you will never forget.

92510537.review:
[Potential spoilers ahead.]

Generally, I take games as a combination of three aspects: aesthetics (look/feel), mechanics, and narrative.

This game's aesthetics are sharp: beautiful pixel art, slick animations, evocative music, good sound effects, and generally good controller handling. So all positives, here.

The mechanics are a mixed bag. I thought the environmental puzzles were fine, and while some were, to use a word seen in other reviews, "fiddly," many multi-screen puzzles seemed pretty polished. Boss fights were interesting, as it generally took me about 2-3 attempts to figure out what the game wanted me to do. There are telegraphs for actions throughout, but the player's hand isn't "held" with most of them, which increased satisfaction in "solving" boss fights. That being said, both boss fights and the game in general, as many have pointed out, are extremely linear. Like other negative reviews, I too take issue with labeling this game as a "Metroidvania" due to that linearity as well as the sparse amount of power-ups. The tweak system had potential, but the truly interesting tweaks are hidden away within the game's small handful of sidequests. Plus, since you can lose the use of the tweaks when getting hit, it doesn't affect player choices enough to really play much of a role in the game-playing.

FInally, the narrative: this is unfortunately what killed the game for me. My short version of summarizing the tone of the cast of characters, aside from the silent protagonist Robin, is that "the women are angry and the men are deluded." Most characters spend their time 1.) yelling at each other, 2.) obtusely philosophizing with ambiguous antecedents, or 3.) making strange and often plot-dictated decisions as they act more like caricatures than characters. There are a sparse handful of emotional character notes that shine, but these were quickly lost by such notes being repeated over and over. A theme of self-loathing also echoes across many characters (again, aside from Robin)--which never seems to reach any sort of resolution, and in fact for a few, seems to only loom as an inevitable prophecy of destruction. It is unfortunately advised not to form an attachment to characters either; not many survive the story. Those that do (or do not, for that matter) grow/change as characters either not at all or very little. I acknowledge that this story seems to operate under the nihilist ideology of a capricious universe that giveth and taketh away without rhyme or reason, which is certainly a viable narrative choice. Simultaneously, I as a player putting work and effort into the unfolding of the story felt especially pained at the empty-reasoned losses suffered throughout. I stopped playing right as the rocket sequence started; at this point I did not feel like the story was rewarding me for sticking with it, but rather punishing me. I ended up watching a playthrough of the remaining game, and it was still quite painful to observe at several points.

I think part of what is difficult to hold about this story is that feels like it has the capacity to be something more than it is. There are a lot of interesting  opportunities, especially with the world-building. But it seemed to never reach beyond a veiled and vaguely derisive socio-environmental commentary, and even this is defeated by a bit of a deus ex machina ending (which, perhaps, was the ironic point of the final boss and aftermath).

And perhaps I am expecting too much realism from this world, but I still can't figure out how Robin's ponytail up in the wrench-u-shape could logistically work. Bothered me the whole game. I think part of why it did was because none of the other characters had any similarly inexplicable visual traits.

Really mixed on this one.

Sprite work, the amount of creativity in boss fights, music and sheer scope of plot really lends itself to making the game really great. 

But.

For every fun boss battle, the clunky controls holds it back. For every clever puzzle, there's moments of frustration as the game forces you to repeat over and over for the most obtuse sequences. For every touching cut scene, there's reams of dialogue that's worded odd and drag on too long.

If the game just took a moment to step back and not be afraid to have empty maps where you didn't always have to fight an mob or solve a puzzle, that'd have lent itself to allowing the game to be a more smoother experience || Looking at you City One sequence ||

Another review mentioned it beforehand which i think is the best way to view the game. Do you like puzzles? then you'll find lots here. Just don't expect it to be a metroidvania because that is not what it is. The upgrades are okay at best and work best when they're solving puzzles rather than best fights which more often than not, are marred with frustration. 

Ultimately, for every pro, there's a con attached, preventing the game from being brilliant and falling to just pretty good.

Would i recommend the game? Yes. But only if its on sale or you'll willing to forgive the game for its short comings.

91898814.review:
I ultimately recommend this game, even though there are aspects of it that could decidedly be better.

So the good stuff first:
The graphics are really good with fluid animation.
The boss battles are creative and varied and the highlight of the game.
The level design between the boss battles offers plenty of puzzles that challenges you to explore your acquired toolset to their full extent. Though for a metroidvania it is quite linear.
The story... and here is where the weak part was, at least for me. The thing though is: it is well considered story with realized characters. The bad part was that the game started out with a ton of jargon that left me feeling at arms' length from the story. And several plot points that I think could benefit from being explicitly spelled out was left implied. As it was I was never quite sure what to feel about the various going on's since I didn't feel like I had a solid grasp on the interpersonal relationships and the political and theological make-up of the settings. Once I read up online what was going on I thought the story was quite strong, but the fact that I had to read online to understand it kind of illustrates why I found it lacking. In addition: the ending really drags on, so once you feel like you've reached the climax, bear in mind that there is a lot left to do, so if you're forcing yourself to just finish the very end you might like me stay up way past bedtime and have a sleep-deprived brain like the game less. I should also mention that it was only at the climax that I had a solid enough grasp on the plot to get the emotional impact of the going ons, and at that point it worked, though I was really tired.

So in summary: A great game whose story means I probably will have forgotten all about it in 6 months.

91469628.review:
Story and puzzle-focused Metroidvania with fairly limited/optional backtracking. Upgrades and tools/weapons are nowhere near as plentiful as what you'd see in a game like Super Metroid, making for a more focused and linear experience.

Follows the outlaw mechanic Robin as she escapes corporate-religious-fascist authorities and eventually gets involved in a threat to her world's very existence. Many details of the story are implied rather than explicitly spelled out, so there's some room for interpretation outside of what literally happens during gameplay and cutscenes, of course.

The game is extremely cute, especially character animations, but does at times dip into some rather grotesque (albeit cartoony) body horror stuff.

Mina (companion character) and Samba (tertiary character) are gal pals who are in cousins with each other. Meaning they're a very gay couple. Also, I'm headcanoning Robin as gay and you can't stop me.

I just finished this game last night, and I immediately wanted to start over and play it again. I'm not sure if I have the time, though. Maybe I should get a second copy for my Switch to play on the bus?

...

One potential downside is that the game doesn't always teach you all the options for Robin's tools/weapons, but rather expects you to experiment with them and figure out stuff like how far the gun's rockets need to travel before they become armed. This obviously hearkens back to games like Super Metroid, which did things similarly, but players who are used to modern tool-tips and tutorials might have issues?

91398248.review:
Everything about the game feels off, as if the developers stopped at the stage just before having a finished game. 

There are multiple elements that make the platforming more difficult or tedious than it needs to be, such as having to constantly charge your wrench when you want to slide along powered lines, or the pixel perfect accuracy the game asks you to have when attempting to interface with said power lines. 

At one point in the game I got stuck on a puzzle, not because I didn't know what to do, but because the missile you launch from your gun to solve some puzzles has an "activation range" and won't do what it is supposed to if you're too close. This never came up anywhere else in the game, and I don't recall a single place that mentions it. In the end all I had to do was take a few more steps back and it worked fine. The missile doesn't cause damage to the player, so the activation range just serves to make using the weapon annoying. Along those same lines you need to charge up your weapon to fire the missile and after you do there is a cool down. While it make sense to do this so players don't spam a powerful attack in combat, it makes puzzles tedious because a small mistake means having to wait for the cool down to try again. On the combat side of things the extra damage/ larger size of the charge attacks were never worth the cost to use them. Not only do you need to wait for a cool down, you can't even fire your regular weapon while you wait. Using the charge attack in combat was never worth it as firing your regular gun a few extra times dealt with most enemies just fine, I only ever used them for puzzle solving which just made the cool down pointless and annoying.

One of the core mechanics of the game is you can get upgrades to make yourself strong or better at doing things. Standard affair, but it was coupled with the confusing choice to make it so those upgrades turn off when you take too much damage. The only way to get them back on is to kill enemies or break statues. So on top of having low health you now have none of the upgrades you worked hard to get that might have actually made having low health less of a problem. The right most upgrade is always the first to go because 1 hit makes it unusable, so I usually just stuck something there I didn't care about and focused more on the other two slots. I have no idea why they did this, it made the upgrades almost pointless because as you traverse through an area, or fight a boss fight, you eventually lose all your upgrades before you reach the end. On top of that the upgrades themselves are very minimal, so the whole thing just makes one wonder why the developers included the system at all.

The story starts out simple, perhaps a bit cliche, but it pulls you in and makes you route for Robin the main character. But as it went on they just start throwing more and more at you, new characters, new concepts; and all of it is presented as either everyone knows about it so explains nothing properly, or no one knows anything so nothing is explained. It quickly became a mess and I lost all investment to keep playing as I no longer understood what the stakes were or why I should care. 

I don't wish to drone on much longer, but I wanted to quickly mention the boss fights. They are hit or miss, with the hits making it to the bare minimum of a good boss fight, and the misses being boring or frustrating fights. They tried to incorporate puzzle elements to the fights, with you having to use your weapons and abilities to make an opening to deal damage. But none of it works well together, and for several boss fights part of the process is getting far enough to see what knew thing the boss does, die, then start over with your knew knowledge. 

All the work for this game when into the visuals, but I wouldn't call the game visually stunning. Everything looks nice, the animation is crisp and expressive, but there is almost nothing interesting to look at, and you constantly run back and forth through the same areas with the same nothing to look at. In comparison to something like Hollow Knight, another Metroidvania, even when you had to go back and forth through the same area you at least had interesting things to look at. In Iconoclasts the level design feels like a school project, functionally acceptable but visually uninteresting. If they put as much work into the world as they did the cute animation of Robin shaking her head or nodding her head in place of a simple yes or no text option, Im sure there would have been something of more substance.

As it stands, I can't say the game is worth buying at any price. There is a lot in it but it feels unfinished, and like the developers didn't care to hone their game play. The animations are nice, and the sprites cute, but thats not even close to enough to carry the game. I am 6 hours into a 20 hour long game and the thought of spending another 20 hours playing this game makes me feel dreadful.

91362408.review:
It's a beautiful looking game - however the characters are generally unlikeable. It is like spending an entire adventure with angry teenagers. The dialogue is occasionally hard to parse and that's not helped by the odd bit of cod philosophising  that goes on.

The boss fights are generally excellent and imaginative, although be prepared to take one or two attempts to get the strategy required. 

Checkpointing and difficulty is generally pretty well balanced, but there are some notable spikes in the last stages of the game when the number of enemies seems to increase. Dropping the difficulty down from standard seems to remove all damage, which goes a bit too far. 

Properly spectacular, love the world and the effort that's gone into the graphics. Doesn't quite nail those satisfying loops of other Metroidvanias though. 

Controls are occasionally a bit fiddly - although those only really got on my nerves during set pieces or in the early game. 

The tweak system, which is the only reward for exploration seems dead on the vine to me: the effects seem to be negligible and you lose them as soon as you take damage.

91294125.review: Great action puzzler with a good story!

91262325.review:
Iconoclasts is a fascinating and divisive game. TL;DR 8/10 overall, an incredibly well-made puzzle platformer with a compelling story marred by a weird ending and tacked-on crafting.

The visuals are gorgeous, and the music is fantastic. The gameplay feels really fucking smooth and polished. When you press the jump button, you immediately feel "oh, that's a good jump". The different weapons are pretty classic, but there are only a handful of them. The game has boss fights at a regular pace, and they range in quality from "fine" to "the best fucking bossfight in a 2D game I've ever played".

It's got the trappings of a metroidvania with gaining new abilities to solve puzzles in areas you've already gone through, but the rewards are paltry. I didn't care, though, because I found all the puzzles to be genuinely fun and engaging by themselves. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this game as a metroidvania, but fans of metroid will find themselves at home with the basic gameplay.

I should note that I ran into multiple bugs while playing that other people don't seem to have run into. During cutscenes, the audio would constantly peak and then rewind a second, which was frustrating to say the least. I also ran into several moments during boss fights where the scripting would break, leading to my character being elevated off-screen as the second phase of a fight just fails to load. I also had multiple crashes, mostly happening when the game went to autosave before a cutscene and boss fight. I'm playing on a 6 year old laptop, so I don't expect these to be common issues for others, but they *can* happen. Outside of cutscenes, framerate and performance were solid.

The real strength of Iconoclasts is in the narrative and characters. If there was ever a game that's a poster child for Cerebus Syndrome, this is it. The first hours are deceptive, and by the end I was deeply invested in the fates of these characters. Elro and Black in particular are incredible. The unfortunate part is that in the very final minutes, the narrative takes a barely-foreshadowed left turn that shatters the mood that had been building up to that moment. I can understand why Konjak made the decisions he did with it, and it's not total nonsense as some might believe, but I personally think it's a step down from the powerful narrative leading up to it.

Iconoclasts is flawed. Fans of metroidvanias may find themselves disappointed with the lack of upgrades, and fans of puzzle games may find themselves disappointed with the amount of combat, and fans of the story may find themselves bored by getting dragged back to gameplay just as the story is getting somewhere. But if you drop any sort of expectations as to what you think this game *should* be, you'll find a unique and engaging experience that's well worth your time.

91028063.review:
Me propuse a jugar este juego sin saber lo que realmente me iba a encontrar y me sorprendió gratamente. 

Iconoclasts comienza de inmediato, no nos dan textos introductorios ni grandes tutoriales, nos dejan que exploremos y nos adecuemos con las mecánicas casi desde el minuto 1. Me pareció curioso el cómo se me permitió tener una boss fight en menos de 10 minutos de juego y, de hecho, gracias a este tipo de planteamiento no tan común me atrapó de inmediato.  

Un muy interesante juego de plataformas (porque de “metroidvania” tiene poco y nada, la verdad) en donde es muy divertido, gracias a las mecánicas, ir de un lado a otro. Éstas mismas son bastante sólidas en su ejecución, tal vez pecan de ser poco explotables ya que no hay modo de diversificarlas, pero funcionales y divertidas, en definitiva.  
Realmente, nunca sentirás que te sobran las mejoras que consigues, el juego sabe aprovechar los recursos que tiene para que todo te sea útil a lo largo del mismo... bueno, esto no es del todo cierto, hay una gran excepción y son las “mejoras crafteables” que el juego provee.  
Esto es lo único que pienso que debió pensarse desde cero en temas de jugabilidad, porque no sirven de mucho. Me pasé el juego en Normal, craftee las 3 primeras mejoras que encontré y no las volví a cambiar en toda la partida, y todo esto sin ver afectado mi progreso en prácticamente nada.  

Las peleas con los jefes (que créeme, van a ser muchas) a lo largo del juego están para mi sorpresa muy bien pensadas. Y es que a esto me refiero con que no sentirás que te sobra casi nada, no hay jefe que se parezca al anterior en mecánicas ni ejecución. La progresión de los mismos es muy orgánica de cara a derrotarlos, te puedes llegar a atascar en ciertos momentos (como me pasó a mi) pero no creo que te cueste nada deducir el patrón o modo de vencerlos. 

Los personajes que este mundo presenta están bastante bien, algunos no cambian en absoluto a lo largo de la historia, otros son bastante memorables por el desarrollo (simple, pero muy efectivo) que poseen. Como también el propio mundo, el cual es bastante interesante, teniendo sus propias culturas y/o religiones (todo esto siendo importante para el propio desarrollo de la historia) sus reglas y sus formas de vida... digo, no es impresionante, pero todo fue ideado por una sola persona y el resultado es bastante gratificante.  
 
... 
 
Pero, creo que mi problema más grande con este juego es con su narrativa... no exactamente en lo que cuentan si no en cómo nos lo cuentan, me explico: 
Gran parte de la historia de nuestros personajes la podemos saber gracias a las cinemáticas, gracias a estas sabemos qué piensan, qué quieren o cómo interactúan entre sí... pero todo esto, sacrificando tiempo.  
Las cinemáticas (aparte de seccionar la experiencia al crear una línea muy visible entre JUGABILIDAD/HISTORIA) son muy sobre explicativas, y no lo entiendo, el juego se esfuerza en repetir ciertos pensamientos, ideas, justificaciones, etc. a lo largo de la historia para que el jugador entienda de qué va todo, pero generando conflicto con el conocimiento que ya hemos adquirido anteriormente porque todo al final se vuelve reiterativo. 
También, la manera que tiene el juego de hacernos saber estas cosas es solo a modo textual, casi no hay interacciones entre personajes más allá de hablar por largos minutos, y no me agrada mucho en un juego que tiene muy notorias intenciones de ir un poco más allá del estándar. 

Pero, para ser sincero conmigo mismo, la historia (aún con los defectos que comenté) merece ser experimentada, hay un intento por contar algo nuevo y al menos a mí, la experiencia en general no me decepcionó. 

En conclusión, Iconoclasts me parece un juego que, aunque tiene defectos muy notorios, merece más atención de la que tiene. 
Recomendado.

En un género en el que ya se ha hecho tanto como es el de las plataformas en 2D, encontrar algo que sorprenda de una forma u otra es algo francamente difícil, y aún así Joakim Sandberg ha sido capaz de crear una obra a la que vale la pena darle una oportunidad. En términos generales nos encontramos ante un metroidvania de libro, sí, pero uno tremendamente sólido, con una jugabilidad excelente, una dificultad bien ajustada, y sobre todo muy entretenido. Durante todo el juego, se nos ofrecen gran variedad de situaciones que ayudan a que el juego no se haga tedioso, a lo largo de zonas muy bien diseñadas en las que se intercalan de manera bien calculada zonas de plataformeo con puzles y zonas de más acción. Mención especial merecen los jefes, todos ellos están muy bien planteados, haciendo que cada una de las batallas sea tremendamente divertida.
El apartado artístico es precioso, destacando el diseño de los personajes, cada uno de los cuales brilla con luz propia.
En cuanto a la historia...bueno, no quiero entrar en muchos detalles, dado que ha sido una gran sorpresa, puesto que me esperaba algo muy simple, y en su lugar me he encontrado con una trama que empieza como algo sencillo, y va complicándose poco a poco, haciendo que en más de un momento te pares a pensar en las ideas que se plantean tras una fachada que a priori no es tan compleja.
La única pega que le pongo es la música, que se hace tremendamente tediosa, salvo en algunas batallas contra jefes, pero son excepciones.
Imprescindible 9.5/10

I happened across this game while it was on sale, having never heard about it and not knowing of the [i]seven year[/i] development time. I can understand why it took so long, since it's quite a good game.

The tags call this a metroidvania, but the parkour is a little too easy for that title. (take this with a grain of salt, the only other metroidvanias I've played recently are Celeste and Hollow Knight). Not to say the parkour is bad, it's just easy. Remember that. Easy parkour is not bad parkour.

I think this game is better suited being called a puzzle platformer, since the puzzle aspect of the game is what makes it more challenging. Admittedly, some of the puzzles are stupid, but all of them are doable without googling. Given enough patience.

The combat in this game is fun, though. There are, as advertised, over 20 boss fights. Which, sneakily enough, are also puzzles. With health bars. Sometimes multiple. And you will likely die to them. But don't be ashamed of that, this game doesn't have a death counter as far as I know. (I haven't looked)

The tweaks system, which is the closest thing to an upgrade system, is in need of a buff. Or at least remove the limitation of "Only changeable at save points". The only one you need really is the one that makes you not take a hit.

And the story? It's, well, twisty. Like, "Is this the twist ending that reveals the final boss?!?" levels of twisty. Multiple times. And considering how bright and colorful the game is, the story get's [i]dark.[/i]


Also, one of the enemies has a cat that does not die after the boss fight. So that's a big plus.

Overall, 8 twisted hex bolts outta ten, very fun if you're not a pedantic fool who obsesses over the definition of video game genre and hates this because it claims to be a metroidvania.

---

It’s not a name that has a huge fanbase or widely known popularity, but after reading this review, perhaps you can stick this game on your wishlist. Iconoclasts is a metroidvania. I’m fully aware a lot of reviews I’ve posted over the last months have all been metroidvanias – it’s a genre I enjoy playing and as a result will have some reviews about them 😉

Iconoclasts surprised me. Going through my steam queue I noted a pixel graphics style metroidvania, so obviously that went onto the wishlist. It stayed there forgotten for the better part of a year, until it showed up in a bundle on Fanatical. I got the game because I had it wishlisted, and I have to say – zero regrets.

The theme
Charming, proper retro feel and a lot of attention to detail. The main heroine of the game is a mechanic in a far and distant future where a white liquid called “ivory” is used to power biomechanics and electricity. World changing in a way you could not imagine until you reach that point in the game where things are explained without spoilers.

The game gives a feeling of various super nintendo-era games and does this very well. Right down to the not-so-smart sidekicks, over protective siblings and evil characters turned good. For the art and movement style I would say it reminds me of Starbound, crosscode, chrono trigger and stardew valley. Somehow all those styles were turned into a single metroidvania, and it was done well. The graphical style is very colorful, and the characters both good and evil have a way of showing quirks that really bring them to life. This game is not for the faint of heart. People will be kicked off hills, arms will be torn off and characters may or may not be vaporized by a giant beam of death from the sky. You have been warned. The comedy especially really just “works”, and it works very well.

Any other SNES era style RPG where your character nearly drowns and gets fished up – would be the start of the story. In Iconoclasts – you are thrown back overboard! (Sorry, small spoiler, very early in the game and that bit had me laugh out loud)


Full review at: https://ggplayers.com/iconoclasts/
