89151214.review:
It’s hard to describe this game exactly; it feels like it doesn’t know what it wants to be.  After seven years in development, that doesn’t really surprise me, but it made playing the game rather unenjoyable.  I never would have expected it to have turned out like this; this is not what I thought the game would when I first saw its store page, but here we are.  It is average at best, and to some it’s even worse than that.  It is clearly enjoyed by some, but I could never recommend this.

Many of the reviews describe the game in a way that I feel gives it too much credit.  I would describe it as average overall.  Although there are points where it stands out, it doesn’t make up for what it lacks.  

I would not consider it to be a metroidvania, as the game is very linear and the upgrades it provides has very little, if any, impact on gameplay.  With that in mind, the exploration becomes unrewarding and unfulfilling, as they only offer these upgrades and the materials to craft them.  This is closer to an action/puzzle platformer if anything.

I would also not consider it well written, its jarring tonal shifts clash with the rest of its presentation.  In a game that first presents itself as bright and fun through its great artstyle and soundtrack, it gets shockingly dark and gruesome as the game progresses.  It feels hamfistedly placed into the game, and I am not certain how Konjak thought it juxtaposed well with the game as a whole.  Not only did it feel joyless to play through, the story failed to garner any of my investment.

The gameplay is your average action/puzzle platformer.  You’ll get some tools to kill enemies, solve platforming puzzles, and explore the world as you try to reach the end of the game.  Some of the puzzles are clever, the combat and movement as a whole are serviceable, but there is nothing in particular that I would say makes it stand out.  Even if you cared about gameplay above all else, the game would still only be average.

It’s clear that Konjak has put a lot of time and effort into Iconoclasts.  This isn’t some asset flip worthy of the truly bad title, I just did not enjoy it as much as I would have liked.   I commend him for his effort; game development is not easy, especially solo.  I do not write this review because I hate him, nor do I wish for games to be bad solely so I can point out the obvious.  I only wish that this turned out to be something I enjoyed, but it sadly did not.  I wish him luck on his future endeavors, he has proven that he has the ability to do great things, and I will be watching intently, even if I may feel otherwise about this game in particular.

88612054.review:
It's okay, but nothing in particular stands out enough to lift it above average. 

[h1]Combat(6/10)[/h1]
Generic platformer stuff with one twist: about half of all enemies have invulnerability that can only be bypassed with specific tools. Fun at first, but did nothing but slow me down and annoy me later on.

Bosses are fun. Each one is like a mini-puzzle that you have to figure out.

[h1]Upgrades/tweaks(2/10)[/h1]
This is outright awful, because this one feature ruins the entire game. For now, all you need to know is:
[list]
[*]They are craftable. You get blueprints and you know exactly what you're getting immediately after getting a blueprint.
[*]You can only use 3 at a time.
[*]They break. When durability drops to 0 they get disabled until they are fixed.
[*]Most of them are useless outside of platforming puzzles. I used movement speed for gameplay and the rest was for metroidvania obstacle reasons.
[/list]

[h1] Exploration(4/10) [/h1]
The base for exploration in this game is great. Tools you use in exploration are fun and synergies between them later on also seem nice. Mechanically the game is sophisticated enough to be amazing. 
 
So why 4/10?
[list]
[*]Rewards are materials for crafting previously mentioned upgrades. Upgrades are useless so crafting materials are also useless by extension.
[*]A lot of puzzles are too easy, which makes it feel like the game is just wasting my time. Like imagine a room with 3 consecutive jump (with ledge grab/climb) sections. Does that sound fun? Why is that even in game? It's not challenging nor fun! it's just pointless.
[*]Metroidvania style backtracking.... a lot of it. This one is only a problem because rewards are useless. When rewards are not meaningful enough and puzzles are dull, backtracking across entire game to do 1 more puzzle for a useless reward feels like a chore.
[/list]

I think 2 biggest mistakes are related to exploration being unrewarding:
[list]
[*]Giving blueprints, lets me know ahead of time, that those items are useless. That means I am not incentivized to look for materials for those blueprints. If chests gave those upgrades directly instead, I would still be inclined to explore, because I wouldn't know what I would get.
[*]3 upgrade slots means crafting 4th item is pointless. I think getting upgrades to improve instead of getting duplicates would greatly help with that. It would raise the power cap, but it would give 9 items value, instead of just 3. 
[/list]

87924528.review:
Iconoclasts: 2018 Metroidvania (kind of) 
Gameplay: Iconoclasts is a solid gem in this regard. A smooth experience all around with unique mechanics that build on themselves although not to a very complex degree, and sometimes there will be times where you'll forget something you haven't done for a bit if you don't keep playing the game a lot. The combat uses all of the mechanics from platforming, but in different ways to bring pain to your enemies although there will be times where doing the one thing will trump doing anything else which is often unfortunate in games. One last thing to say is that it indeed fills out most criteria to be a "Metroidvania" (2-d exploration platforming puzzler with bosses centered on movement) it is a rather linear game. There's often little to no reason to go back to 
Art\Animation: I'm not very good at recognizing what is and is not good visual art at times, but I do know what monkey brain likes and monkey brain likes this a lot. Things are almost always cute in the 2-d pixel style that encompasses the entire game. It's got a lot of heart here and when things move it is absolutely buttery-smooth. I love just watching anything move in this game as everything is crafted with such detail that momentum and weight can almost be felt. There are times near the end that seem a little lazy, but I didn't mind all that much it was really only to slap one more mechanic at you.
Music: Not particularly impressive in any one regard honestly, but it's always very fitting. I enjoyed most tracks, and there are a few that really stand out and are just fun to listen to. 
Story: Absolutely knock-out of a story. There's lots of really great humor and cute little scenes and it just keeps coming which is good because it really needs as much of that as it can get because this is a tragically dark tale. Deep morals about philosophy and environmentalism, what your role in society is, and how much it can hurt just to help someone else. With the cute music, and art the writing makes the game almost seem almost bi-polar, but not in a bad way.

87854106.review:
Wow, that was a ride.

The dialog felt a bit strange at times, but the world and story are fascinating. Things get [i]weird[/i]. It's also surprisingly brutal and dark.
I'm not entirely sure I understood everything, the game certainly juggles a lot of elements and is quite happy to not spell everything out. Still, really interesting stuff.

If you're looking to play a good Metroidvania though, stop. It's not a good Metroidvania, I'd argue it shouldn't even have that tag. There's not much to explore and the "upgrade" system in the game might as well not exist, it barely changes anything.

It is however a very nice story-driven, linear action/puzzle platformer with a heavy focus on boss fights. Sometimes I found these to communicate what you're expected to do badly, but everall they're all very good and certainly the highlight alongside the story.

87826570.review:
The aesthetic was really the selling point for me. Everything has a unique, geometric style that sets it apart and the sprite-work and fluid animation were really top-notch. Iconoclasts also boasts a unique theocratic world and lore that make you WANT to learn more even after the credits roll. Beyond the colorful aesthetic, there is a very grim underbelly to the world that was a joy to uncover.

One criticism is the upgrade system leaves a lot to be desired. From beginning to end, you only ever have 3 slots for abilities to equip, and these are very generic. One blocks damage for a hit, another increases damage for your wrench or length of its spin attack, one increases the amount of time you can hold breath underwater, and mau. You never have the ability to upgrade health, weapon range, cooldown times for firing, radius for bombs, etc. Simply not enough variety, and in a game that provides plenty of challenging puzzles that reward you with upgrade materials, there wasn't enough incentive for me to keep doing them after the first couple levels. I had the abilities I wanted, and never swapped for the entire game. That's a long time for a 15 hour game... More variety of abilities would've gone a long way and really would have been pretty simple to integrate in terms of coding. Especially when considering the amount of work went into the pixel-perfect art assets, this would be nothing by comparison.

That however, is a small critique in an otherwise very worthwhile game that impressed the hell out of me in terms of artwork and its intriguing theocratic world and lore. I would recommend with a solid 8/10.

87692179.review:
Good game with a nice set of lore and really expressive art. Lots of "show, don't tell" in the design. I could easily have seen this cast and plot in a JRPG. I loved the "twists" and surprises near the end, bulge and all.

Some weird inconveniences that I don't fully understand. Your abilities, called "Tweaks," break when you get hit. They refill mostly by successfully killing. So in practice, these Tweaks, which should make your fighting and exploration easier, are exclusively for people who are already good enough to not need them. Taking damage already feels like failure when you just lose HP, but nullifying an ability really rubs salt in the wound. Imagine if you were playing Mario and every time you failed a jump your jump height got reduced a little: that's how this feels.

Except not really... because Tweaks are all mostly inconsequential save for maybe a few key moments that call for them to be stacked. You can craft and stack 3 Underwater Breathing Tweaks, for example, and yet you never *need* them for any area or puzzle except an optional secret (and even that area only needs 2).

This creates a weirdness where you feel bad because you lost a Tweak but also you don't really care because that Tweak wasn't helping you much to begin with.

Also, I'm certain that the only reason it takes two button pushes to charge your wrench is to justify equipping the Spindle Tweak. 

But enough about Tweaks! By the Tri!

The game is smooth and plays well and feels good when you do it. I'm not a huge platformer or Metroidvania player, so what some people see as shortcomings I see as complete blessings. 

At some points I can see where this game originally wanted to be more than it is and at other points I feel like it was already being pulled too tightly on all corners. The end result is a little lumpy. Lumpy isn't bad. Iconoclasts is kind of its own thing and kind of a mixed bag of other things, and I like that about it. Thumbs up!

87511301.review:
Iconoclasts is a game that surprised me in a lot of ways. Going in, I didn't expect the story to be so engaging; I really got hooked by the premise and it kept me interested throughout the game, pushing from objective to objective. The gameplay itself is solid, allowing for very fun puzzle-solving and exploration using Robin's tools, while also constantly switching things up to make sure you're never repeating things for too long. The art and music are a treat and complement the gameplay well.

The game does have some faults in it's combat; while the controls are responsive and smooth, there are a lot of enemies that require specific actions or positioning that is difficult to intuit; this tends to make most boss fights more of a puzzle than an actual test of skill, which is sometimes rewarding and sometimes...annoying. It can be especially frustrating if said boss can only be hit from a very precise angle (Looking at you, [spoiler]Ivory Beast[/spoiler]). Also, one very specific area in the midgame is a complete nightmare to navigate, mostly due to annoying elevator mechanics.

Overall though, a game very much worth playing. 8/10 would recommend.

86867783.review:
A flawed game, but one that i look back on fondly.

I'm going to focus on the bad in this review, since the good is either spoiler territory, or you already know it. Here's a skim of it

The game looks absolutely stunning, It's without a doubt one of the best looking games i played, and it runs smoothely even on my potato
The characters, story, and lore are the main selling point. If you love getting lost in a world's history and setting, this is the game for you
The music is bretty good
The boss fights are universally loved, and you unlock a (in my opinion too difficult) Boss rush at the end

And now for that bad.
The gameplay leaves a lot to be desired. Enemies are more like annoyances than threats. Along with that, the game isn't really about combat at all. This is by all intents and purposes a puzzle game. Unless you're in a cutscene or a boss fight, You're completing a puzzle or moving from A to B.
Some of said puzzles are unfair. Not in the sense that it is too hard, but in the sense the the solution is dumb. Once a game also makes the way you have to go a hidden path, another time the instruction are just unclear. Don't be ashamed for looking up playthroughs, Everyone has.
This game is NOT a metroidvania. and there is no reason to go back to an area even if you didn't get any chests in it, Since tweaks are almost useless. There is also no feeling of getting stronger or getting new abilities, since the abilities and guns you do get are almost exclusively for solving puzzles
The ending is...very divisive. I hated it, But some people like it. I can't really say anything more on it. The story up to it is still really good though


It's also worth noting that this game FAR darker than the artstyle implies. Like, Your entire family dies in the first 20 minutes level dark. Don't buy this for your kid.

A good game, but a linear one. Decent number of bits to hunt down and find for completionists, but too much 'scrape map for hidden passage' type of secrets for me to hold my patience. Good puzzles, good platforming, boss battles range from average to excellent, though you'll need to retry a few to figure out their mechanics.

85167811.review:
It's a good game, but I was expecting something different. There's not much in the way of Metroidvania gameplay. There are some chests you need to come back for later, but they only give crafting materials for tweaks I wasn't really interested in. Overall, the game is almost completely linear.

The focus of the game is boss fights, with a heavy dose of puzzles. The dialogue is very JRPG-ey, which I didn't care for but I'm sure a lot of people will like. The story did start to draw me in toward the latter parts of the game.

Pros:
-Nostalgic graphics and sfx reminiscent off the SNES and NeoGeo era, with some NES sfx in the mix too.
-Varied world with some interesting platforming.
-Some of the boss fights are really good once you get the hang of them.

Cons:
-Mina's clunky aim mechanic for her shotgun. Why not just aim with the right stick which isn't used for anything else.
-Most tweaks never need to be used for anything. There is one for a double jump, but you don't get it till the very end of the game, when you might be working on 100%.
-Moves the game never tells you about, e.g. you can charge your gun and shoot down mid-jump for some extra height, taking the place of a double jump. You can also hold the Wrench button to fast-climb ladders.

85046296.review:
Certainly a game that warrants a greater audience than the current one it has now. This little gem was sadly overshadowed by Celeste that came only 2 days after the release of this title, so it's understandable how it went a bit under the radar. Aside from this, let me list what I enjoyed about this game.

The visual art style was very enjoyable for me, sure there is a case to be made about the oversaturation of pixel art style games in the indie market, but each title never ceases to amaze me how they can all look so beautiful and can be so different. Games such as this one, hyper light drifter, celeste, and shovel knight are all fantastic examples of the diversity of the pixel style and the jaw dropping visuals they may have despite their simplicity.

The music is top notch, there was not one track I did not enjoy in my entire playthrough, they all had their place and fulfilled their purpose, a few of which amped up the thrill of a scene, generated great suspense, or just really tug at my heart strings. 

The story was quite enjoyable for me, may have been weak at some parts but the other aspects of the game really come into full force to compensate for it. after finishing the game 100%, I just craved for some more about this world the developer created, it has a genuinely interesting premise that I hope is explored more in the future... hopefully not another 8-10 years this time.

Now for the fundamental aspect, the GAMEPLAY. The gameplay reminds me alot more of megaman then it does of a metroid or castlevania game. Sure there may be SOME backtracking, but 90% of it is for collectibles and not for actual progression, still fun to backtrack and find new secret paths with your acquired goodies though. Puzzle solving is very enjoyable, nothing too stellar but it was def a highlight of the game for a few portions. Now for the action and platforming, both of them are top tier for me, the speed, the little mechanics here and there and some of the tweaks you earn really make maneuvering and combat a blast, especially for the boss fights where each and every one is memorable and thrilling! I just crave MORE and a sequel just can't come soon enough, I'd certainly get some DLC if the option was ever given to me.

Do yourself a favor and get this game, you won't regret it!

84213418.review:
I thought it would be good... But I didn't think it would be that good.

Iconoclasts is... Probably more Mega Man and Castlevania than Metroid, and the sooner you think that way the better. Almost every time I fought a boss I was miffed by the drastic changes and the almost frantic shift in how to approach them that I swore against the game in terms of gameplay almost every single time, questioning how you were expected to know how to respond to a move change or attack that either disorients the player or makes you offensively bankrupt by playing too offensive.
--But when you take out the idea that it is remotely related to Metroid, the bosses make more sense, and the game just feels better to appreciate. 

The thing that kept pushing me from buying the game was the idea that I kept hearing that males were just making all the bad decisions and females were mainly the ones who thought rationally and made an actual difference in power and intellect.
--While those people aren't entirely wrong, I feel like it is more of a representation of the types of characters that ended up gravitating towards the MC (Main Character) more than anything... Just thought I'd say that before I went on if there was anyone else kind of annoyed by that in media...

Since I already started on that note, Let's talk about the characters as a whole.
ALL OF THEM... are GREAT!
--Do I like all of them? NO... But if you've ever met someone so consistently continuitous to their character or motive that you really want to know why they are the way they are, then I implore you to play this game. There are kindhearted characters, selfish cowards, stoic, blasphemers, self righteous, narcissists, ignorant, naive, silent, brash, egotistical, arrogant characters in here. To the point where they are crafted in a way where it is surely believable that these characters have in fact been living for a very long time, because they behave in such a personified, dictionary sort of way that you cannot help but want to know more about them for your own sake, so when you deal with those emotions or feelings you do not hold the mindset that possessed these people to be so cliche in the way they present themselves. 

The story... Well when you're playing, if you're like me, you wonder why in heck the game is called Iconoclasts, but when you play it and realize so many characters are pushing the bubble in a race to see who pops it first, it makes perfect sense. I'm not sure if I've done nearly enough to speak on the story even though I beat it, but it is quite simply... A world set in an environment where certain people have been given an amplifier of sorts, that amplifier is something I will tease you by comparing it to Mako energy in Final Fantasy VII... So the people who have this power are individuals who think and act differently because of the people they are, and since they were all human, their experiences and hardships have molded and perhaps broken their mental state over time, and because there is almost always a larger force at work, it's like watching a bunch of people with authority at each other's throats for inconsequential slivers of power.
-On the other side of that fence is regular people, Skilled people who shape the world with knowledge and not power. You wonder sometimes how they even got involved, but at the end of the day... The tease I made at Mako energy will probably spell out why things are the way they are.

Gameplay is next...
-Gosh... I played it on the harder difficulty and I will say that the game is a very smooth experience when you get familiar with what you are doing. THANK THE GODS that the game will save checkpoints before boss battles and after important events. Because most if not all of the difficulty comes from being overwhelmed by mechanics and patterns you either are not familiar with, or didn't really have enough time to figure out. 
-That being said, there are a few times near the end where mechanics that are required have tight hit zones, and because charge attacks overheat your gun, things that you rely on working can leave you in a state of helplessness. Granted, for a short time.  Other mechanics like swimming and jumping can really make you scratch your head because there are at least 5 instances where you really feel like you should be able to get to some chests and areas, but cannot because of a lack in ability that seasoned gamers will not suspect is halting them from getting where they need to... very small quip. 

I would say Graphics... but no.
The art style is deceptively adorable, but aggressively so. The only character that has any business looking that cute is the MC. Every other character has some sort of personality that warrants them to have a more seasoned, deliberate type of style that exposes them for being who they are. But the sad part is, it accomplishes what I just said, but the way the characters are almost purely cliche in terms of their behavior and ambitions, I can't help but feel like there could be more done to give more life to some of the harsh, vivid and somewhat playful text bubble content that some characters speak towards one another. I highly approve of it, which is why I am giving it a hard time. I want to make that clear. It is very very good.

All in all. I'm happy I gave the game a chance. There is also New game plus, so after I write this I'm either going to try to see whats underwater in this one area, or play new game plus on easy or normal mode to see what I was supposed to experience while getting my cheeks spread coast to coast by some of these enemies. I definitely think it's worth a purchase if you like Castlevania, Metroid, Mega Man, Final Fantasy VII, High Bit art styles, 2D Platformers, etc. 

I'll give it a "Don't point your butt at me!" Out of 10.

I have to emphasize how rarely I write reviews...and even more, how rarely I actually binge a game from start to finish. This game is a remarkable accomplishment for one person, regardless of how long it took him (and seeing the sheer number of custom sprites, I'm not at all surprised it took that long!), and it absolutely needs to be played by anyone who claims to support the indie scene. 82554404.review:
So I just finished this game and I WAS enjoying it up to a point.

The game has snappy controls that are easy to get used to and the sound and music is a complete joy. 

The crafting system, however, is mostly just a minor distraction. It's upgrades are mostly useless and the whole system is just an afterthought the developer didn't want to include to begin with. Just stick all the damage blocking upgrades in the slots and ignore it.

The game feels a little linear for a metroidvania title and there isn't much need to go back to an area you've been to unless the game specifically tells you to do so. Even then it's pretty rare. I'd consider this more of a puzzle platformer than anything.

Now the characters and story are what really make me not recommend this game. The main character, Robin, is adorable and runs around wanting to help everyone she meets and her reactions to events in the game are fun to watch. The supporting cast hurts me though. 

Spoiler warning for characters beyond here just in case.
------------------------------------------------------------

Firstly the main character's brother is whiny and selfish, complaining through pretty much every moment he reunites with Robin. This goes to the point where he'd rather watch the world die with them on it than allow Robin to continue forward.

Mina is a little better but is untrusting of even the person she's following around until near the very end when she goes all in.

Royal is one of the better characters but everything falls apart at the end of the game and he just gives up.

Honestly I liked the enemy characters more than I liked your allies for the most part. Find out more about them makes you really start to care for them. Oh, but don't bother trying to save like anyone you might like in the game. Dev pretty much spite kills them all.
------------------------------------------------------------

As a summery, the game is enjoyable for it's cute sounds and tight controls but don't expect much when it comes to much else.

81732120.review:
Normally I don't write negative reviews, but this game deserves it.

Initially I decided to force myself to finish the game, until I encountered an invisible boss and realized that my time is better spent elsewhere. I managed to get to 60% in 10 hours.

The short version is: the game is a mess of everything.

I utterly love metroidvanias (I grew up playing Metroid a lot, so yes I'm old), but this game just poorly executed everything. The biggest offense is that somehow it's a very linear metroidvania. You go from area to area, usually pick up 1 new upgrade/trick, which you then use to move to the next area (after the mandatory boss fight). Once further into the game, the world slightly opens up more, and you can go back to previous areas to pick up missed items/secrets. However, the world is still very small and closed/linear. There is a very clear step-by-step area-by-area design in place, which does not fit the spirit of a metroidvania. A metroidvania should have a very big and open world, where you run into obstacles that you know you will later get back to once you have the right upgrades.

The story in it's idea and concept are kinda interesting, however, execution is poor. Too much poorly written text. So much unnecessary drama, just to try to make it not bland. But it just ends up with annoying and either simplistic or unrealistic characters, dialog is abysmal. Sometimes there are quests which just means talking to 2 people back and forth 4 times, and then you get some item. In other words: Boring.

There is a party system, where the main character has friends with her as you play. However, it's completely and utterly ignored/useless. You cannot switch between characters, so this just means that in the top-right corner there are a few faces of your group which you just ignore. So far (60% complete) you needed to use 2 characters while playing and switching between them. Twice in 10 hours... just leave it out then.

As you explore the world, you find materials which you need to craft simple upgrades for yourself. Besides 1 or 2 key upgrades, they are overall quite weak. On top of these weak improvements, you can only equip 3 at the same time and if you get hit by an enemy 1 breaks. So now health went down, as well as getting weaker due to 1 less working upgrade. This is completely an unnecessary mechanic, neither fun or sensible.

Overall, everything just feels like a mix of ideas that aren't executed well nor do they blend nicely together. Don't bother with this game, not even on sale.

77891069.review:
Iconoclasts is a game I always saw floating around on youtube when watching other metroidvania games but never really thought of trying out. Then I saw gameplay of it and was instantly interested, and eventually here we are, game was bought Ive played it fully and my thoughts were very positive. It certainly doesn't feel like most other games of the same genre with more of an emphasis on puzzle solving and boss fights than exploration and upgrades. 

The game also does more with the story than ive seen most metroidvanias do, having a constant narrative reason for doing the things you do, and the story and characters are definitely one of this game's strongest aspects in my opinion, giving you a world that gives you enough lore to have you understanding it but leaves you asking questions. The cast itself is certainly something that comes to my mind with the silent but eager hero Robin, to the mysterious yet dweeby Royal. I legit was on the edge of my seat for a lot of the story wondering where it was going to go next. 

The gameplay itself is also quite solid, with a lot of puzzle solving mixed in requiring you to think of how you can use your arsenal to progress while also sometimes require you to think quick as well. Combat isn't normally what keeps you going in this game as you don't get too many weapons throughout the course of the game and charge shots require a rather hefty recharge time. However boss fights are where the game really kicks up in terms of gameplay whether they require you to figure out how to expose their weak spot with puzzle solving or are just 1 v 1 reaction tests where you need to dodge using what the game gives you, or use one of your many tweaks that act as pseudo character upgrades to give you an edge in combat and movement. Either way, the boss fights and story was what kept me going in this game as I was constantly wondering what was coming next... not to downplay the stuff in between because every area is interesting to explore (minus one area that I wont spoil here). The bosses and story is the driving force that will keep you going most likely. 

Presentation is very solid too, Iconoclasts is a game that takes cues from 16 bit games with vivid colors and crunchy sound design that was popular... though it feels less Super Nintendo and Genesis and more Game Boy Advance if that's wierd to say... tho maybe not since the game had heavy inspirations from Metroid Fusion, either way the game's looks and sounds were amazing and catchy. Characters moved really fluently and despite not being the most detailed sprites in the world I could typically tell exactly how a character was feeling during cutscenes, with music that fits each area very well and makes every boss encounter feel really invigorating. 

Overall Iconoclasts is a great game that I'd highly reccomend to anyone who enjoys metroidvanias. The game really has a great feel to it that makes it overall just fun experience. For $20 its more than worth the price in my opinion.

[b]☑ Gameplay [9/10][/b] - I never felt bored while playing, each area presents a new mechanic and puzzles, and they're all great, although some puzzles can get a little confusing.

The interesting and diverse characters really drive the whole game, hitting every tense "Oh shit!" moment (and there were a lot of those) or funny situation or one-liner. The dialogue is sometimes clunky, but I was glued to the screen by the fantastic plot and universe, and I would seriously recommend this purely from the story. Seriously, there's hella drama and very mature themes. Seriously, right before the final boss I just sat in shock from how many emotional punches had been thrown at me.

Like some others have said, it's more of a puzzle platformer with some metroidvania elements, so just be aware of that going in. I think the puzzles were majority well executed and the gameplay is *mostly* smooth, though there were light moments of clunkiness. The variety of creative bosses means you never get bored, and finding secrets was rewarding.

The music is above average and the spritework is amazing - everything is so colorful! I highly, highly recommend this game if you love a good story-driven platformer.

The game's visual design reminds me of the Castlevania games on the DS. The music is very catchy and the general sound design of the game is excellent, with sound effects such as bomb explosions and the sound of Robin's wrench hitting an enemy all have an incredibly satisfying 'crunch' to them. I purchased this while it was on sale due to a glowing review from a well trusted YouTube source. However, I'm not really happy with this game, for quite a few reasons:

- You cannot go back and 100% the game after you finished the main story.
- Combat is tedious, borderline boring.
- Most boss fights are incredibly easy. Those that aren't are just frustrating.
- You play as the main character throughout 95% of the game. The other 5% when you do play as other characters, you have to familiarize yourself with their style. You play them so infrequently and for such little time, it's kind of pointless.
- Puzzles, for the most part, are easy and intuitive. Except when they aren't, they're downright frustrating. I can't remember a time throughout the game I was satisfied with any of the puzzles.
- Dialogue was absolutely horrendous. 
- There was little to no character development for any of the characters. Eventual deaths left me not caring at all.
- The story was a mess. Hard to follow at times, and when it wasn't, it was very bland.

There were a few moments I was impressed with, but overall, just not happy with this one. If you're well seasoned in the Metroidvania category, maybe give this one a go if it's on sale. Otherwise, I can't recommend it.

75337121.review:
TLDR: Wasn't that big of a fan of the combat or the puzzling, but the story was pretty good.
For the combat:
Sort of metroid-style, with different guns you switch between. Most enemies aren't very interactive, and it feels like a waste of time to fight them when you can just jump over them. The ones you cannot usually have some form of a gimmick where, for example, you cannot hit them unless they are attacking you. I believe this was supposed to make them feel like more of a challenge to defeat, but in my opinion, it made them moreso annoying than anything else. Other enemies are literally unkillable unless you make them walk on spikes, which are a whole different story.
The boss-fights feel more like puzzles than actual enemies you had to defeat, where once you knew what you were actually supposed to do they became very straightforward. Sometimes you had to figure out you had to use a specific gun, or use a specific move (like a wrench swing or a ground pound) on a certain hitbox.
Next, the puzzles:
Some were pretty good, but they all rotated around a few mechanics that (in my opinion) got old pretty quickly. Not only that, but it got pretty repetitive to always have to solve a puzzle to get a key to unlock the next area.
If it wasn't to unlock an area, the rewards for the puzzles were usually just an extra "quirk" material, which are this game's collectibles. They're not the most creative upgrades, where most are just, for example, making you capable of swinging your wrench for an extra fraction of a second. And so, it felt pretty bad to solve a puzzle, only to find out all I got was another piece of "improvium" I was never going to use.
The story:
The story was definitely this game's main focus. It was fairly good, with a cast of characters that get developed and influence different events around the game's world.
Conclusion:
If you are looking for a very story-focused game with relatively-fun gameplay on the side, look no further. On the other hand, if you're in it for fun and engaging gameplay, you may be disappointed.
Overall: 6/10

75278341.review:
I played this game for a bit on PC, refunded it because I wasn't really feeling it, but recently bought and played it in full on Switch, so keep that in mind.

Iconoclasts was a very interesting game. Made by one person over the span of several years, it sports gorgeous pixel art, great music, unique puzzles, and a surprisingly dark and existential story. It follows the story of a young adult named Robin, who ekes out a life as a mechanic for her small settlement - illegally, as much of the world is dominated by a theocratic empire called the One Concern, which forbids unauthorized civilians from tampering with Ivory, essentially a magical superfuel that the One Concern have integrated into just about every part of construction possible. Robin's life is thrown into turmoil after the One Concern find her in the middle of repairing her brother's home, and she has to go on the run to escape them, with the assistance of Mina, a "pirate" whose society is hunted by the One Concern for offering a different religion than theirs; Royal, the pompous if disillusioned heir to the One Concern's pope analogue; and occasionally Elro, Robin's traumatized older brother. Through her journey, Robin learns more about One Concern as a society, Ivory's true nature, and the lengths people will go to to fulfill their ideals.
 
As a metroidvania and a game, I can't recommend Iconoclasts. Movement and action is generally smooth, but never changes enough for me to really enjoy it - there's only a handful of upgrades through the game, which generally just let you solve more puzzles instead of offering new and interesting ways to move around the world. You also obtain upgrades in weird ways, they're usually just handed to you with little fanfare instead of getting them for completing a boss or challenge like you'd expect. Combat isn't super interesting, and I found myself actively avoiding it by the end of the game since often it can just be waiting for the opportunity to reflect any enemy's shot or spamming gunfire until they die. If there's a part of the gameplay I can compliment, it's that the puzzles are overall very unique and often are really good! What's more, bosses are plentiful throughout the game and each one is really interesting and usually fun to fight. Some can be pretty tedious or annoying, but overall each boss is very unique and there's a ton of passion behind their design.
 
Despite the problems I have with the gameplay, I'd still recommend Iconoclasts as a must-play, because its story is excellent. Characters are interesting, have depth, changing motivations, and quiet moments that make you feel for them even if they're unlikeable as people. Decisions made by characters impact the story greatly and it's amazing to see a lot of the themes they address. Like I said earlier, the game is surprisingly dark in the latter half, in an existential sense that makes you imagine what choices you would make if you were in their situation. It's emotional to play through at many points. The only downside I can claim about the story and characters is that the English translation can often be confusing or poor, which makes some parts of the story harder to grasp until further in the game. 

Overall, please play Iconoclasts. Support this labor of love by an indie developer, it was a really good and unique experience.

74681371.review:
Hands down one of my favorite games I've played in 2020

Iconoclasts is a Metroidvania-styled puzzle platformer with fantastic gameplay, music, and story. It follows the story of Robin, a mechanic, as she travels across the world as chaos ensues and she has to bolt it back together (being vague since this is seriously a game that the story is that important) I got Iconoclasts from Chrono.gg as the last game I got before their Chrono Coin Shop closed and being the most expensive new game they were selling I got it quickly with no clue with what I was getting.

Gameplay of Iconoclasts features the usual platformer getup with a standard jump, solid movement, and a stun gun to shoot things with. Robin has a few more inclusions in her moves like having a ground slam move, or being able grab up ledges. But one of Robin's most versatile moves she has is her trusty wrench. As a mechanic Robin can screw bolts in the world to activate various machinery or use to them to swing across to higher platforms, as the game progresses you get more abilities to use with your wrench and stun gun with that introducing more ways to solve the game's many puzzles, platforming challenges and amazing variety of bosses. Also included is the tweak system where you can choose up to 3 buffs to Robin that can help you out but the catch is that if you get hit you lose a slot and you'll have to fill it up again by defeating enemies. (You can also play as other characters briefly during the story mode which was a nice touch)

Iconoclasts has a pixel artstyle for practically everything in the game and it's some of the smoothest and most beautiful pixel art I've seen in a while. All the sections of the game feel distinct from each other thanks to sheer amount of effort in the environment, visual and enemy designs and animations. Robin and many of the other characters have a cutesy art style which is fairly different from their portrait art but is still animated so well. Like Robin's crawling animation has little tip taps and it was just so adorable, while characters like the Agents have more gritty animations in the same style. Major props for some of the bosses having so much dang movement and speed that it was just amazing is see and fight.

Now I don't really want to spoil the story of Iconoclasts that much since it's definitely one of the best things about that game and something that kept me hooked and invested for the entire journey. LIke during my second session of the game I played it for 12 hours from the 3rd area straight to completion and I was invested in both gameplay and the story. The music here also is pretty awesome and fits the mood perfectly for whatever's going on and you can purchase the soundtrack separately if that interests you.

There were a few criticisms I had with the game, like with bosses' having so crazy moves that it's hard to understand what exactly you need to do to deal damage, while it didn't prevent me from completing the game it did take a few tries and attempts to learn almost everything about the boss' moves. Also a very tiny nitpick is that the health pickups aren't affected by gravity which was annoying when I needed health but the pickup was just a tad bit out of my reach. (Obviously this was me playing without the double jump tweak)

Overall, Iconoclasts is just a fantastic game, with solid mechanics, great music, and an amazing story that left an impact on me. In fact I enjoyed my time with Iconoclasts so much that I even made [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2204555723] Fanart [/url] of one of the Agents. As the last game I'll ever get from Chrono.gg's Coin Store it was certainly the best game I've gotten from that service and I honestly hope more people will try this game out.

This game is more on the line of a deep story with a game wrapped around it, rather than a game with a deep story. Not to say that this makes it bad on its own, but it wasn't the experience that I enjoy.

The gameplay itself feels great. Very smooth and interesting, not overly complicated. The problem is that it doesn't much evolve. Throughout the entire game, you essentially unlock a few new guns with interesting mechanics, but that's about it. No health upgrades. There are also small "upgrades" you can craft called tweaks, but they are hard to rely on since they break after you get hit, you can only equip 3 at a time, and there is no way to unlock more slots.

As for the story, it's very deep and quite interesting. My personal problem is that it took over the gameplay. There is a LOT of dialog, and thus a lot of reading. I got tired of some of the back-and-forth between some characters, and at times would wonder "when can I get back to actually playing?". The story itself also was disappointing. It gives the impression that choices matter, but it is very much a linear narrative. Also, (Sort-of spoiler) [spoiler]the end seemed to come too quickly, left a lot of unanswered questions and was in some ways confusing.[/spoiler]

I played through the whole game, and got all the achievements (except for the challenge mode) to feel I got my money's worth. Unless you are a player that cares more about the story than the game, I cannot recommend this.

May be one of the best Metroidvanias I have played.
It takes ten years for the developer to single-handed produce this game, and you can feel the time the developer has devoted to it. You can find many lores in the game, including texts on notification boards, dialog and ancient glyph in the world, which reveals the world of Iconoclasts bit by bit. The game has a surprising ending, though not surprising at all if you think afterwards.
The graphic of the game is colorful and decent, though the story and spirit are deep. 
The control feels excellent. Not many Indie games have such good controls. Boss fights are interesting. You can parry a Ninja's attack with your wrench! Hollow Knight may have many boss fights, but they mainly focus on dodging, but this game's boss fights are more mechanic-driven, yeah, "mechanic"-driven, you get me here. BGM is good, though not impressive, sill decent.
The only thing that needs improvement is boss-rush. Hollow Knight has a room full of status so you can practice each boss, but in this game you have to go through 10-minute-long boss fights to challenge the boss you're not familiar with, which is somewhat frustrating.

73638327.review:
[h1]Fun action platformer[/h1]

[b][i]Iconoclasts[/i][/b] is an action platformer or light metroidvania with Run & Gun elements, depending on your perspective. It follows a young mechanic whose abilities are tightly controlled by The Establishment, in her path towards...

(Some spoilers ahead)

Look, I'll be honest. I didn't follow the story that well. It wasn't gripping for me. [spoiler]There's a techno-magical element tightly controlled by the Church/Government used to enhance soldiers and some chosen superhero-like types? The ragtag bunch of misfits led by the mechanic go and try to topple the Magical Government that's keeping people down and killing the Earth with their greed. Any coincidences with FF VII are a coincidence, yes sir.[/spoiler]

But past these, there's a fun game in here. The controls are tight, the weapon/abilities are varied and fun and the story is just short enough to enjoy them all without dragging on too much compared to your regular JRPGs. While the main campaign can feel a bit short, there's some collectables and extra bosses for the completionist that so desires them. 

All in all, you're getting a dozen or so hours of fun. I highly value shorter experiences if they are fun and this is one of those, but if you're looking for something meatier to sink a long time into, I'd look somewhere else.

73631927.review:
TLDR: This is a 3-4/10 game with a 7-8/10 presentation. The visuals are really great, but don't bother with this game if you place more importance in gameplay.

The only thing this game has going for it is the sprite work. Visuals a truly great for a pixel art game. You might also enjoy the soundtrack if you're into 8-bit music but, since I'm not, it's hard for me to tell how good it is.

What's not hard for me to say is how extremely far all the other aspects of the game are lagging behind its presentation.

First, this game can barely be qualified as a metroidvania. The feeling of non-linearity comes more from how contrived the level design is rather than how open it is. I was following a very linear path, I just didn't realize it because that path required me to do so much back and forth that it gave me the feeling of being lost. The fact that level traversal is so unremarkable didn't help keep my attention, which might be tied to the fact that upgrades are few and far between, and don't really open up the gameplay as much as they let me finally progress. 

Combat is extremely basic but functional, and the Tweak system that lets you pick minor buffs has so little impact that I forgot about it until the game reminded me it existed. The bosses are a highlight and they're definitely visually fun, but they didn't present much of a challenge as soon as I found their gimmick. Until that moment, they could be frustrating as their moves were sometimes chaining too fast for me to figure out what I needed to do. In short, die a couple times while you figure out what you need to do, then kill the boss on the next try because execution isn't a challenge.

That also applies to most puzzles in the game, if you can even call them that. They're mostly a 2-3 steps puzzles that take about a minute to figure out since they aren't many possibilities and your move set is so limited. When the solution wasn't immediately obvious, I just tried everything I could do and the solution was clear within 30 seconds. Again, this didn't help with how boring the exploration was for me. My thoughts kept going back to CrossCode while doing these puzzles, and I find CrossCode to present much more interesting puzzles than Iconoclasts, both in terms of complexity and execution.

Story-wise, I can't really say much since I couldn't bring myself to finish the game. After looking it up, I made it a bit beyond the halfway point, and none of the characters particularly grabbed my attention. I found the setting and the bits of world-building to be pretty interesting, but they are too spread out and center too closely around the religion and limited natural resource of Iconoclasts' world to leave me satisfied. I would also have appreciated the ability to always skip to the next bit of dialog as the game can sometime be slow to move through dialog phases, but that's a relatively minor nitpick.

All in all, I find this game to be very amateurish. The only aspects Iconoclasts shines for me was its art direction, while the rest felt like an unfocused and underdeveloped pile of ideas borrowed from games whichexecuted on these ideas much better.

Fantastic 2D metroidvania/puzzle game that feels genuinely original within the genre.  While the game is generally pretty easy, it still remains enjoyable throughout it's playtime as it continues to throw new ideas into the mix. The gameplay itself is crisp and constantly evolving.

73446337.review:
Iconoclasts is one of the most charming, beautiful, cute pixel-art game in here. It has one of the best animations too, with every move being incredible fluid and well made. Differently than the majority of metroidvanias, this one is heavy on the story side, with tons of cutscenes and plenty of characters to relate, feel for and to see grow, or change while the story progresses, but the story itself is a confusing religion+doom cliché with characters making some nonsensical choices, so it is not an amazing story. The controls in Iconoclast are great, being very responsive, excellent air-control and plenty of jump, climb, or reflexes stages to put them in use, a very important factor for a metroidvania/plataformer. The sound is also top tier with  plenty of adorable and very good music. 
The game does not shine in the combat, being more a bothersome than anything rewarding, after some time you will just skip enemies since there is no xp mechanic and the game is focused chiefly on story and puzzles. And that has its own problems, I found some puzzles, despite easy-ish, to be infuriating, some timed mechanics are not fun to play, and the rewards are always boring materials to craft stuff that you don't really need or even can use since you are limited to three Tweaks active. Also, for every metroidvania there is a crucial factor, the map and how well can you navigate on it. Despite a very good map and some, not great, fast travel mechanics, I felt that mostly of the areas to be incredible annoying to traverse. That ivory tower made me grind my teeth with the elevators. The game also has places that are scene dependant, meaning, you will reach a place, find nothing and move on, but after a scene that place is now important, something the game does not make it clear, and because of that you will wander the map for much longer than you should, a big flaw for a metroidvania game.
It is a good game, not a great one unfortunately. After weighting the positive and the negative I would recommend mostly because you can see the effort and time it was put to make it, the developer really loved his project. But I would wait for a sale, if buying it at all.

73197532.review:
I'm legitimately shocked at this game and I'm sure that I wont forget about this game anytime soon, but for the completelly wrong reasons.

Iconoclasts has to be the #1 game in the history of gaming that suffers the most from the problem of "over-design". Seriously, this game needs to be studied for years to come as a prime example of something that ends up being LESS than the sum of its parts, defying all logic and reason. The developers clearly tried too hard and wen't WAY overboard with the overall design. For an analogy: despite having used top quality ingridients to make a cake, they let the cake bake too long so while the cake is still edible due to the good ingrdients, its too overcooked.

It's mind-bogling really when you look at the individual parts: the game has excellent pixel art, nice gameplay, decent music, interesting characters and intriguing story. But when those elements are glued togheter here in Iconoclasts, the final form is... a very weird kind of bloat.

But once you start digging at each piece of the project, the problem of "trying too hard" and over-design starts to become clear:

ART: Excellent craftsmanship of pixel art... but its actually too noisy. The ground and tiles are too exagerated and over detailed. The effects for projectiles are overdone too and it's very common in boss fights to lose track of projectiles and boss attacks because everything from the explosion effects to trailing projectiles blend togheter and you can't see shit.

GAMEPLAY: Nice gimmick with the wrench and Robin controls really nice for the platforming... but the gimmick ends up being just that and the platforming feels unrewarding. Compared to other platformers, there much less action in this game since there's a lot of puzzles to solve, but they very quickly become more of a chore than anything which in turn means that there isn't a good feedback loop to it all: you're just moving from screen to screen, you know, just going trough the motions, because there's no real challenge to platforming, the puzzles are at best a chore and unrewarding, and as for the combat outside of bosses, you can just pretty much run past anything as it's a better use of your time than have to deal with each individual enemy gimmicky-way to kill them.

MUSIC: Decent enough... but sometmes it just doesn't fit: eletric guitars playing when where they don't fit the scene theme, etc.

STORY: I could write a whole thesis about it, so I'll try to keep it short: There are some very interesting topics, themes and messages underlying the whole plot... but it's delivery is completelly and utterly tone-deaf given the surprisingly dark themes that it tries to tackle, and it is also way unecessarily verbose in its dialogue delivery, and the overall plot is too overbearing and long-winded to it's own detriment, with the cherry on top of being kind of obtuse just for the hell of it.

Also interesting to note that this came in the same period as the game Celeste... you know, a properlly refined game that while it is also ambitious with its goals, managed to cut down on unecessary bloat in all its elements to keep the overall experience feeling tight and rewarding, eding up being MORE than the sum of its parts.

You know what, despite my negative review I'm actually going to recommend that you play it till the end, if only to see for yourself the very rare and unique case of a game that embodies that old saying: "too much of a good thing, ends up being a bad thing".

100% at Harder Difficulty and I can't recommend this game.
While the game's presentation is nice, most of the gameplay aspects are not.
The main flaw of the game is that exploration isn't rewarding at all. All exploration does for you is gathering materials for "tweaks" that aren't a core mechanic of the game, so they are useless for the most part.
Map design isn't great either, there are some places where you can't go back once you enter without having to go all the way around (and I'm not talking about important areas or boss fights, just regular places where you enter crawling and can't crawl back, for example).
I found the story uninteresting, which was pretty bad because the game has many dialog scenes.
Aside from 2 sidequests that led to optional boss fights, the rest are just going from point A to B and back... and then back to B and back, I can't even...
Boss Fights are okay, but most of them have few patterns and become pretty easy after a moment of watching them.

Iconoclasts brings nothing new to the table and it's impossible for me to recommend it seeing that games like Hollow Knight offer 5 times the duration with better entertainment at a lower cost.

73082311.review:
I should disclaim that my recommendation is tepid - I think there's a lot of good here and the potential for a better game inside this one, but I think most people will only get enjoyment out of it if they are really looking for this kind of game. In general, however, this is a pretty game with some interesting ideas, but it is sometimes a chore to play.

To start, what I liked:

1) Gorgeous graphics and nice music. You can tell the dev is an artist.

2) Interesting mechanical idea. I like the idea of a mechanic hero who wins encounters by ingenuity rather than brute force.

3) Interesting world concept.

For the bad, I think a good example is this series of thoughts I had in rapid succession toward the end of my playthrough:

"Why is there a bullet-sponge boss hidden under an underwater maze? Why didn't it tell me that swimming faster is less oxygen efficient? Why is this the only boss I've died to that doesn't autosave to the beginning of the boss fight? Why is the first stage of this boss only vulnerable to a particular weapon?"

Most of these are things that I could've discovered with some experimentation, but because of the save mechanic, it was a 10-minute boring slog between attempts and this really characterizes much of how this game felt. So much backtracking, so much downtime between clunky combat encounters. Occasionally, there would be a somewhat clever puzzle, but that was itself a rarity. Occasionally, I'd solve that puzzle, not want to backtrack to a distant save point then get stun-locked on the next screen and die, forcing me to redo a puzzle I had already solved. No matter what choice I made, I'd be traipsing through screens I had already played, wasting time on play that just isn't engaging.

Some things that I think would greatly improve the game (and would be valuable to a follow-up game):

1) Remove the save points. Just auto-save by screen. They don't really add anything but wasted time. Having a much quicker reload pace on whatever challenge I'm currently working on means it's less frustrating to figure out certain rooms by experimentation.

2) More traversal upgrades that feel good to use. The zip-line is nice, but very situational. End-game getting around the map is the same as the beginning of the game, except now I've seen everything a dozen times, and getting to the teleporter can itself be time-consuming.

3) Better collectible/sidequest tracking. It took me an embarrassingly long time to realize that small gold dots on the map were already-collected pickups. I assumed they were bigger pickups like quest items and blueprints. It's also difficult to tell where are in a side-quest when you've done some bits while on your way to something else.

The wrench mechanics are a neat idea, but usually they just mean the melee attack is a context-sensitive use button. There are a few bosses that make good use of it (especially the final boss), but they're often so hectic and fill the screen so much it's difficult to concentrate.

The writing leaves me wanting a bit more. A lot of the characters (as well as the cultures here) feel more like archetypes than fully-realized. There are some individual stand-out moments that I really like, so the potential is definitely there.

First, a piece of advise if you decide to play the game: Don't backtrack until you are very late in the game. You won't be able to complete those areas anyway and it's pointless to get those materials. You'll be able to get back later. I'll get to the review now.

So, I must admit my first impressions were bad. While having cool graphics, the gameplay was really simple, and the dialogues were PAINFULLY SLOW, and also having too much of them in a short ammount of time. At some points I read so much faster than the speed at which the new sentences appeared, I decided to skip them. And honestly the story wasn't that interesting yet. Overall it felt almost like a game for little kids (and it isn't the case).

But everything got better as I kept going. A big part of the game are the small puzzles you have to solve along the way, which get more interesting after the first areas. The boss battles were mostly interesting and fun, being themselves in a lot of cases little puzzles to solve, discovering how you can beat them. 

The story ended up being a major part of why I enjoyed the game so much, with great themes and characters ( and also with a darker tone than I expected), and some good plot twists. By the end I cared a lot about some of these characters, and I'm really happy I kept playing.

Having seen Joakim Sandberg's artwork even before Iconoclasts was even in the works, I still find it very beautiful and this game does not lack in that department. It does however lack in some other aspects, namely overall game and level design. Some puzzles felt very obtuse, areas annoying to navigate, enemies placed in a way that it would be easier to just rush through with i-frames. A lot of bosses made me confused, even though most of them didn't take more than 3 tries, often time a boss fight would just boil down to mashing the attack button instead of trying to figure out a challenging pattern. Some of the confusion can also be attributed to visual clutter, it's a pretty game but sometimes it would be hard to tell what exactly is going on with all the vibrant colors. The tweak system feels very underpowered, as most of them only give small bonuses that are easily lost if you take any damage. Which also ties into the exploration being rather unrewarding as all you can find is resources to craft the tweaks.
Narattively the game fell flat for me. Throughout the whole game you're being told about [spoiler]how religion is bad, and so is inequality and consumerism[/spoiler] it's just a mess of ideas that reads like someone ranted it out in a blogpost. 
All that said, Iconoclasts is still an enjoyable game, that while lacking in substance does deliver with visuals, music and some interesing gameplay ideas.

72496485.review:
Iconoclasts is a game that clearly has a lot of effort put into it. There's a lot of different characters in the world and everything is well drawn and animated. The music is usually nice too. Game length and number of boss fights is surprisingly high for an indie title.

But the gameplay itself is drab and often annoying to me. What mechanics the game has are explained poorly. Upgrades don't provide much improvement to your abilities and thus make the effort of gathering materials lose its appeal. The further you progress the more irritating boss fights become. Often where the action happens things get too busy visually, effects cover what is actually happening and you end up taking hits because you're blinded. Collision checks also sometimes fail to match what you see on the screen.

Frustration. That's pretty much what I was ultimately left with from the game especially after the ending that left a lot of questions unanswered.

72457122.review:
Fantastic game, gorgeous art, great music, and puzzles that are actually challenging and feel rewarding to figure out.
It was genuinely a joy to play this game, but if you're buying it on PC, change the control keys. My first few hours playing was a mess of frustration and keymashing confusion. I thought I would've gotten used to the controls after playing it for awhile but I really didn't, and the game demands a lot of quick and precise movements from you on some puzzles. 
The default setting puts the jump button right between the attack button and second attack/main action button, so it's a bit awkward to get used to. 

The bosses are all very diverse and most of them are very fun to fight. On some occasions, I found myself mildly disappointed to defeat a boss when I had been enjoying the battle so much. Similarly, the puzzles are very satisfying to get through, but because many of them can get kinda difficult, it can end up being a bit frustrating when something just doesn't click. 

The game is also very dark, which is not something you'd expect from the cute pixel art and music. The story is interesting, though the lore can get kinda hard to understand. The game is not afraid to kill its characters, or put them though torture, death, suicide, grief, etc., and force you to do things you might not want to. The fact that everything looks and feels so cute makes the darker parts of the game even more jarring, but I think that adds to the game's charm.
If you're looking for a lighthearted game though, this one isn't for you. But it's still a genuinely fantastic experience.

72454209.review: Although the game can be a bit of a slog at times, the great character and level design, along with the story make it a solid game and an easy recommendation for me.

72439019.review:
Iconoclasts, o mejor traducido como "destruye ídolos", tiene buen nombre este juego. Es un juego con una historia sencilla, pero que me encanta, esta basado en un mundo donde el marfil es un liquido que se usa como fuente de energía, pero es limitado y la gente es obligada a vivir sus vidas conforme la "Sociedad Unica" dicte. Una religión (o secta) que funciona a la vez como govierno, que usa la ciencia como si fuera magia, si sucumbes al pecado, la "penitencia" va literalmente a por ti. La ciencia es limitada y solo la Sociedad Única decide lo que es bendito y lo que no. Aquí es donde entra nuestra mecanica, Alondra, que con ayuda de su llave inglesa, ayudara a su familia y nuevos amigos, afrontando varios puzles y jefes en este metroidvania.

Es un gran juego, el cual te pasas en... 12 horas... Bueno, yo me lo e pasado en 12, pero yo ya tenia este juego... Aunque no en steam... no se si me explico jejeje. Pero me gusto tanto que lo compre para apoyar a este gran creador. Busque en el pasado y el desarrollador tiene otro juego parecido, no lo recuerdo bien, pero creo que se le parece.

Tengo que decir algo que no me a gustado de este juego y es... El "bossrush", que se trata de luchar contra los jefes sin parar. La cosa que mas deseaba que estuviera en este juego, resulta que combates a los jefes con una sola vida, y los "AJUSTES" (luego digo que es), son los de resistencia y no puedes cambiarlos. Soy bastante bueno con este juego y me lo voy a volver a pasar por 5 vez. Pero me fastidia una barbaridad que empieces cada jefe, del bossrush con la vida con la que te dejo el anterior, y con los ajustes igual que antes...

En este juego existe una cosa llamada "ajustes" que son como "habilidades", se obtienen de "diagramas" que te encuentras, y de cofres, los cuales suelen estar MUY ocultos, que tienen un objeto, estos objetos los combinas en una mesa de creacion y obtienes el "ajuste" el cual equipas en el mismo sitio donde guardas la partida. Pero tiene una pega MUY GRANDE, resulta que cuando recibes un solo golpe, el ajuste de la derecha del todo se "rompe", tienes un total de 3 ranuras de ajuste, y se van rompiendo conforme te golpean. Se pueden reparar al resolver puzzles, destruir objetos del entorno y enemigos, pero NO al guardar la partida... El "doble salto" es uno de estos ajustes... a y por cierto, es opcional (ademas de que creo que se hace con un jefe secreto).

Un consejo MUY IMPORTANTE, el arma inicial, la "aturdidora" (lo que parece una pistola), tiene un ataque que es mantener pulsado para un ataque fuerte, para "simular" un doble salto puedes beneficiarte de esto, pega un salto y apuntando hacia abajo usa el ataque fuerte de la aturdidora, llegaras mas alto y te ayudara a encontrar mas cofres al inicio de la partida, yo lo uso mucho, no solo para los cofres. Parece que los desarrolladores no se dieron cuenta de esto, lo digo por como están puesto los cofres y los puzles, ninguno requiere doblesalto, para avanzar, lo mismo con todas las partes del mapa obligatorias, ninguna requiere doblesalto.

Hay una habilidad en el juego que esta "abandonada", es decir, no sirve para hacer NADA en el juego; si tu pegas un salto para caer en picado (pulsado el boton de salto + abajo estando en el aire) y lo haces en una rampa, derraparas mientras caes por la rampa, es una tonteria y no sirve para nada... Pero ¡EH! hay esta... A por cierto, esta habilidad ya la tienes desde el principio, la de caer en picado tambien.

Espero que os guste el juego tanto como a mi, creo que tengo que añadir mas cosas, ya editare el comentario si me acuerdo.

72248458.review:
This is an amazing game! Honestly, I didn't think I would like it as much as I did for a few reasons...

First off, I heard the puzzles didn't make any sense and that they were hard to figure out towards the second half of the game. Nope, or at least I found them pretty straight forward and they made sense to me. I guess I'm just naturally mechanically minded ;)

Secondly, someone said that the wrench has to by very precise to hit the bolts you swing off of and that if it's ever so slightly off it would make you completely miss the bolt. Again, nope. I actually found it pretty forgiving most of the time, unless I'm just naturally super accurate :>

And last but not least, I've heard people say that some of the bosses make no sense, and that you have to learn how the boss works, usually by figuring out it's patterns and dying in the process. Excuse me but isn't that how bosses usually work? Like name one main boss in any video game where you instantly knew how it worked and didn't have to learn it's patterns.

Personally, I've died less to these bosses than in most other games. Usually it took only one or two tries to figure out. The most it ever took was three and that was near the end of the game.

My point is that this is an AWESOME game and that you shouldn't always trust other people's reviews. I almost didn't get this game because of those reviews until I saw Snowman gaming's video about why you have to play this game. Thank you Snowman gaming and thanks even more to Joakim Sandberg for this awesome game!

72242962.review:
I'll get my complaints out of the way first.
The game doesn't teach all the button combinations, like the ones that let you climb ladders faster, jump higher, or skip cutscenes.
The Tweak system is mostly useless and kind of stupid. Konjak himself [url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2019-02-08-tearing-down-the-lone-developer-myth]said he didn't really like it either[/url].
There's a lot of irrelevant details before a certain boat docks at Settlement 17, and the story is confusing if you don't pay attention to the stuff inside and after the boat.
Elro is a poorly written character.
Robin never wears eye protection when doing mechanic work.
 
Other than that, I enjoyed the game, but I don't think it's must-play. Different people hate different parts of it. Play it only if you're curious about what it has to offer. I liked illegally opening doors, exploring the world, collecting items that I know I'll never use, and reading optional conversations, such as the one with Petra and Mina. The puzzles rearrange familiar mechanics more than they add new ones, although the ones outside the Tower were a bit easy. The music is good. I spent a lot of my hours pausing the game, leaving the sound on, and doing something else. The story and non-Elro character development get deep and sometimes uncomfortably honest. It's definitely not a "they all lived happily ever after". The conflicts seemed to be based on what a real person would worry about if he spent 8 years developing one game.
 
My favorite mechanic (yes pun intended) is how Robin carries her wrench and all 3 guns at the same time, and how the Tweaks and other items are mostly useless. You can never equip a weapon and then, a few minutes later, suddenly realize your weapon is bad and you should have used a different one.
