72122296.review:
TL;DR: IN MY OPINION, it's a very good platformer/metroidvania/puzzle game with some very serious flaws that could ruin the experience, but also epic moments and points that can improve the experience. If you disagree with me, please, talk to me, i would like to hear more opinions (as long as you're respectful with me).
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whole Review:
Ok, this will be a pretty difficult one to review, since it has some stuff that, IMHO, it's worth mentioning. You're very welcome to disagree with me. Talk to me, guys. Maybe i didn't see some stuff you did. I would like to hear (well, read) your opinions about it.

1) Pros:
- Graphics: I don't really care about graphics, but, omg, this game has an astonishingly beautiful pixel art. I mean, The whole game is visually very detailed. The characters, the landscape, everything, so, the graphics are 10/10.
- OST: The same as the graphics. Each piece of music fits the environment and the moment perfectly. Every single music is most certainly worth having on your phone/PC. I would like to highlight the music of Blrockrock at the morning, Darland Ascent, Boss battles and Isilugar, since they fit their respective places . So, it's 50/10.

- Villains: I have a reason for not putting characters, but anyways... Most of the villains are very memorable with interesting backgrounds, looks and stuff. Black, Chrome, Sna... i mean... Lawrence, the Samurai dude on the tower are all memorable.

- Gameplay: The gameplay is very fluid and responsive, so it fits well to a platformer and/or metroidvania. The only issue i had is with the stairs, since, if i hold the up button while i'm walking and get to a stair, Robin climbs up ok. However, the same won't happen with the down button. Somehow, if i walk to a stair while pressing down, Robin won't get to the stairs. It won't ruin the experience, but it's a little annoying, specially if you've played Megaman. I'm not sure if this is something with my keyboard or a bug, but i thought it was worth mentioning.

- Weapons: They're awesome, nuff said! You have a stun gun that, once charged, becomes a nuclear blaster. You got a bomb that becomes atomic when charged. You got something i can't even describe that, once charged, you can switch places with stuff (you thought i was going to say atomic related stuff again, huh... think again!), which is VERY useful.

- Bosses: They are awesome. No more comments needed... <3

2) Cons: 

- Tweaks: Well, since Robin is a mechanic, she can hunt for materials and build those tweaks for making things easier. Unfortunately, those guys are minor improvements such as breath a little longer in water, spin your wrench for more time and stuff. They're pretty useless if you ask me, since you don't need them to proceed. I guess that's ok, but you get discouraged really quickly on hunting for materials, since it's not worth the effort. If you have the breath, spin and shock tweaks, you're definetely good to go (like you weren't without them) and can maximize your performance really quickly!!

- Plot: Since it's a subject i value most, i must say that i didn't like the plot that much. It's pretty confusing and doesn't explain stuff very well. It's like you need to play another game before this one. It also seems that stuff are just thrown in your face with little development. So, when the story starts to make a little more sense, you're not that appealed to pay much attention to it. One of the exceptions is Black's story, since she starts as an villain with a big grudge (for, at starters, no discernible reason) against the main character and ends as a tragic anti-hero. It's a shame we can't play as her (as far as i know!)! Chrome, with his messiah wannabe attitude is really appealing as well. Aside from that, i'm afraid that the plot isn't that interesting. HOWEVER, i liked the idea of the "Iconoclast" part, since they're going against an oppressive sect that, despite having its reasons, lost its objective as time passes. If the plot was a little more developed, it would be a great story.

- Main characters: They fall in the same issue as the plot, they're not well developed and, as a result, you don't seem to connect very well to them. The villains are more interesting than the characters. The fact that Robin is silent is a little proof of that. Even though you play with her, it doesn't feel that way.

- Party System: Well, i liked the idea of a party system in a metroidvania. Castlevania III did something like it and it was awesome. However, you can't switch characters (again, as far as i know) at anytime you want, only at specific (and very few) moments. What's the point of having a party system if you barely can use them (i would be ok if you had, at least, 5 times more chances or using them, even if they were to be used in scripted chances). That also affect that bond with the main characters i mentioned above. Man, what a waste of having a "stealthy" thief with a darn shotgun and barely use it (and believe me, using Mina is great!).

- Gimmicks and Puzzles: Don't get me wrong. I love gimmicky and puzzling games, with different stuff to do and different way of solving stuff. However, there's a problem: They are too many! In fact, there are so many gimmicky puzzles that breaks the pace of the game, which, imho, doesn't fit metroidvanias and platformers very well. Ok, i know metroidvanias such as SotN had some puzzles, but they didn't break the pace as much as this game. I took 10 hours to finish the game, and i'd say 6-8 hours was with those pacebreakers. I know that's the core mechanic, but, i think they were just too much. Not to mention some puzzles are not as easy to figure, which also breaks the pace the game (or, since i'm not the sharpest knife in the drawer, maybe it's my fault). So, in short, this game takes a pretty long time to finish, but not for the right reasons. Speaking of which...

- Gamedesign: That was a tough one to choose, but, due to the previous item, i find it as a con, due to the pacebreaking gimmicks, which, for me, ruined the experience. Since it is a metroidvania, it has its backtracking moments, but, with the pacebreaking, it becomes pretty annoying. Also, the game is pretty confusing, since it starts as a platformer with metroidvania and ends as a puzzle game with little to none battles. It seems that the game is inconsistent on what it wanna be.

I guess that's about it.
Well, it seems like i hated the game (no, i liked it!), so why i'd recommended? Because, despite its flaws, it serves is purpose very well, it is fun, with silly yet funny jokes, with interesting villains, touching moments, great OST. So it's definetely worth a shot, but it might get tiresome due to these flaws and becomes less appealing as time passes, but it IS a fun game and worth some hours of your time.

However, i must praise Joakim Sandberg for such a great work, since it was developed by him alone. You have great talent and i expect more games from you, man. Also i felt he did this game with tender and care. Some stuff wasn't very well executed, but it was a game made with love nonetheless.
So, if i were to rate the game, i'd say something between 6/10 to 7/10 (i'm conditioned to rate as 7/10).

71334665.review:
[b]Iconoclasts[/b] is a very solid game, I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I would initially, wish I bought it sooner to support the developer.

[h1]General Info[/h1]
First things first, it's not really a metroidvania. Iconoclasts is a rather linear puzzle platformer with a heavy focus on story with a large amount of dialog and cutscenes. Progression is usually gated by story triggers instead of abilities, however you can backtrack to previous areas for some collectibles. It's quite similar to [url=store.steampowered.com/app/115800]Owlboy[/url] in this regard. You play as Robin, a girl mechanic with a wrench (used for melee attacks, parrying, grappling, as a makeshift lever etc) and a few weapons (blaster, bombs, and a third weapon acquired late in the game). Puzzles involve moving blocks around with bombs, electricity charge (from your wrench) and of course turning nuts and bolts in the correct order. The puzzles are generally on the clever side and it's an enjoyable gameplay loop, if a bit repetitive at times. Most enemies and bosses are again puzzle like in their nature and must be either hit with specific attacks or have their weak point exposed first. It's not uncommon to get obliterated by a boss because you've no idea what you're supposed to be doing, and then effortlessly beat it once you finally realize the correct strategy. There are 20+ completely unique bosses, each featuring gorgeous sprite work, and they're definitely one of the highlights.

[h1]Collectibles and Power Ups[/h1]
The only collectibles in this game are schematics and crafting materials stashed in chests in each level. They're used to create "tweaks" which are equippable perks and act similar to the charms in [url=store.steampowered.com/app/367520]Hollow Knight[/url], you can equip up to three and they have effects like: +movement speed, +wrench attack, +air when diving, tank one hit etc. The only real game changer is the dodge roll (don't spend any ivory oil until you find the schematic for it). Now, this "tweak" system is a bit controversial, as it acts like the weapon levels in [url=store.steampowered.com/app/200900]Cave Story[/url], you lose a tweak slot (starting with the right most one) when you get hit and you need to kill a few enemies to restore it. Tanked multiple hits? Whoops, all your special abilities are locked. Thankfully you can usually regenerate tweaks by hitting a boss so the system is not too punishing in the boss fights.

[h1]Graphics and Music[/h1]
The graphics and music/sound are very, very impressive for a [b]single man project[/b]. And even if it were a group effort I'd still rate the pixel art as some of the best in the industry. Excellent choice of colors, many frames of animations for every silly little action (including cutscenes), true uncapped framerate (yes, this is one of the few 2D games you can play at 144Hz). Sure, Cave Story (another 2D side-scroller made by just one person) was impressive back in the day, but this is on the whole other level. Joakim Sandberg (Konjak) sure knows his craft. The music ranges from catchy chiptunes to sorrowful piano pieces and it's almost always a good fit. Overall, production values wise Iconoclasts reminds me of the [url=store.steampowered.com/app/999020]Mega Man Zero and Mega Man ZX[/url] games a lot, but more technically sound and modern.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
Now the story is where the things get a bit more murky. Konjak sat on the game for way too long and managed to cram in way too many themes and tropes into his story and worldbuilding. You have government conspiracies, religion, environmentalism, rebels, pirates, literally agents from [b]The Matrix[/b], superhumans, aliens, brainwashing and many other things that I don't want to spoil. It's a mess, and the general writing is bloated as well with characters often going off on random tangents or having mental breakdowns every other scene. And despite the fact that the story is so verbose the protagonist is (mostly) silent. There's a backhanded explanation for this but it feels bizarre that Robin just blindly follows whoever happens to yell at her. Still, the twists aren't too bad if a bit convoluted at times. I just wish the script was trimmed down a bit and proofread by a native English speaker.

[h1]Bottom Line[/h1]
As far as 2D side-scrollers go, Iconoclasts is a meaty game with a lot of content and will take you about 10-15 hours to beat, depending on how thorough you are with collectibles. As a story heavy puzzle game you will probably not want to play it again, but I still very much recommend experiencing it if you're a fan of the genre.

70982818.review:
I wish I had listened to my gut and refunded this. The longer I played, the more frustrated I got with everything, and the more I didn't want to play anymore. It's less about the game as a whole and more about how each minor annoyance adds up and overshadows the rest. Throughout the entire game, things just felt... off. Not a lot, but enough to be noticeable.

This is not a metroidvania game. Exploring is absolutely unrewarding. All you'll find is blueprints and materials to craft Tweaks, a system similar to Hollow Knight's charms, but utterly underwhelming and cease to function if you take a hit. If you're hoping for some nifty new abilities or power-ups, prepare to be disappointed. There are lots of hidden places, but none of them are worth exploring.

Movement is fluid and responsive but platforming is just serviceable. There are no issues with ledge grab detection but the precision required to lock onto some track bolts becomes really, really irritating when it throws off a timed puzzle several times in a row or forces you to recharge the energy lost flailing futilely in mid-air. Oh, and an entire boss fight is built around this mechanic, too.

Speaking of, the bosses are all visually and mechanically distinct, often with multiple phases and changing attack patterns. Some are pretty neat, and others are just awful. The one that stands out the most involves stealth, does not explain what it expects mechanically, and what I thought should work, didn't. Ultimately, there's only one solution for each and once you get the pattern down, it's a cakewalk. They don't all play great, but at least they look great.

I do like the art and animation. The level art style is also good, but I didn't care for the level design at all. Progress is constantly impeded by environmental puzzles and one-way shortcuts that force you to retread the same paths over and over again. I will say they are clever and creative, but more often than not I found them tedious to complete, especially when combat is mixed in, and combat quickly grows as boring and tedious as the rest of the game.

I almost made it to the end, but I just couldn't stand it any longer. The story is bad, there wasn't a single character that I liked, dialogue is cringe-worthy, the varying mechanics feel bolted on for the sake of being unique instead of interesting and engaging, and the game either over-explains or doesn't explain at all what it expects from you. The "hours of nut-twisting platform action-adventure" description is spot on, because playing this for an extended period of time makes getting your nuts twisted with a wrench seem appealing in comparison.

70313570.review:
Great puzzle/adventure game! The story and characters are the main reason to play, in my opinion, as you will get a lot of interesting people with complicated motives inhabiting a richly built world. The story takes a little while to get started, but when it did I was hooked. This is one of those stories where nothing is handed to you, in fact the central plot isn't even known to any of the main characters, you just have to piece it together on your own.

Puzzles are mostly good. Lot of obvious puzzles, but enough good ones and nothing I would consider hard or too obtuse. I will say that near the end there is a certain puzzle room that is really annoying, as it requires you to blindly rush to your death and memorize the enemy patterns, but dying requires you to restart a few rooms back. This was a very annoying experience.

Regular combat is OK, you have a few attacks and most enemies are weak to something, you just have to figure out which attacks to use on which foes. There are a few rooms though that are infuriating, say an enemy that has two attacks, you have to duck one and parry the other to damage them, but there are two of them and they alternate different attacks. It's impossible to beat them, you either have to reset the room or just run past them. In fact, most combat in the game you are better off just bypassing.

Boss fights are a mixed bag. You just have to learn their patterns and the only way to do that is to die to them over and over again. Once you do figure out their patterns most are pretty easy. Most of the bosses are at least interesting, if not good. A few too many are of the "you can only stand in a little space in the far end of the room" variety. Overall I liked more than not, and only hated a few.

A big warning, the game suffers from Meat Circus Syndrome; the final act of the game is way, way harder than the earlier sections. Expect to breeze through most of the game and then spend the last act dying a lot. Another warning, people are calling this a metroidvania but it is not. You will need to check your map and navigate with new weapons, but the game is almost purely linear, you will rarely need to explore, and rarely more than just a few rooms.

Overall, it's a neat little adventure game with a complicated, rich story. Highly recommended!

70026519.review:
The game is beyond conflicted with itself, it's so hard to try and describe what it's like. The first half of the game, very light-hearted, Shantae-esque/Cave Story mechanics, humor, artstyle etc. The second half of the game then suddenly nose-dives into lore, mature themes and characters forcing themselves into 'plot elements', and starts to try to mold itself into a Devolver Digital game like Katana Zero instead. 

The first half of the game feels like a breeze, the second half feels like the game's suddenly a rush. Major characters have really interesting tidbits about themselves, but are never fully explored in detail, and are even sometimes conflicting and incompetent. The only exception to this is the character "Mina", who is the only really compelling character in the game. But otherwise, when I finished the game, I just had more questions than answers for what was going on, and yet I still felt like I could predict what was going to happen, and I actually ended up not really caring for most characters in the game, regardless of their importance towards the plot/the main character, Robin.

The first half of the game has a nice pace with a rising difficulty spike, the second half of the game throws a complete screw into the formula and has very anomalously hard bosses with somewhat cryptic patterns with no room for error. With other bosses allowing for "haha gun go brr brr" levels of brain-dead. The game has a mechanic similar to Cave-Story in which the character is somewhat upgraded based on not getting hit and for killing enemies, but this ends up being very high risk-low reward and I start to avoid late-game enemies (which tended to be the same three reused over and over due to the plot). 

All of these nitpicks are further accentuated by the very contradictory art style. I was very surprised to see such a bold, gritty and realistic title-screen, only to be greeted with very soft, cartoony, Shantae-esque sprites in game (which is personally the style I preferred).

I liked this game overall and I could see the work put into it, but these poorly executed concepts and ideas may throw some people off. Even though I feel like I'm thorough in terms of Metroidvanias, I only ended the game with 49% completion. Most "items", or should I say "components", don't feel too significantly major to collect. 

If you want to play the game, I'd recommend it, but in my opinion, this is not a Metroidvania which I'll revisit after my first playthrough.

Thumb-neutral-positive game.

69763064.review:
Overall a great experience. I was expecting a fun Metroidvania to fill in the space in between games, and I got that with actual story and good characters. Not too long either (the playtime was 100% the game with a map for the secret items). 

Pros
-Thought provoking story with very little confusing elements
-Gorgeous graphics with expressive animations
-Great characters with depth and personality
-Fluid gameplay with only a few minor hiccups
-Great puzzle and platforming, the difficult challenges are hard without being frustrating
-Fun and action-packed bosses, with one exception
-Perfect game length, and well paced

Cons
-I probably missed the sign, but there is a double jump you can perform with a charged shot. Really useful and required for some collectibles, but never utilized beyond that. It would have been great with some of the platforming.
-Two bosses were a little annoying. One had a gameplay shift that I needed to learn on the spot, and the other was just annoying to backtrack to. Luckily, the latter is optional and not that hard of a fight.
-Some collectibles are hidden behind invisible sections of wall, and most of them are really easy to miss.

Overall, I highly recommend the game. Most of the cons are either short portions of the game or are ignorable if you don't want to 100%, and none of them offset the pros.

69723396.review:
Iconoclasts is a fun game with alot of unique and interesting ideas for a platformer, mixing, combat, puzzles and platforming together in unexpected ways. While the game doesn't do everything perfectly, it more than makes up for it with a high level of polish, and an abundance of charm. Sprites are well animated and have a ton of personality and detail. Each locale is vibrant and unique, dripping with color and providing unique challenges and puzzles. Music and sound are a great fit for the game, with music conveying the right ambiance for each scene, ranging from upbeat and chipper, to eerie and depressing.

Combat is fairly simple, albeit a bit clunky.. Mechanics like melee and parry are introduced early but seem underutilized in many circumstances. Enemies in the latter half of the game can be tedious and annoying as you need to switch weapons and avoid obstacles to fight them. Tweak system, (which gives you various bonuses) is also underutilized as many of the more useful tweaks are only unlocked after you've beaten most of the game. Majority of tweaks don't feel game changing or all that helpful, especially since you lose your tweaks if you get hit. Aiming can also be a bit frustrating in more demanding fights but, this usually isn't an issue. Combat is satisfying with just enough depth to keep you invested. Most enemies have unique mechanics which require you to approach tackling them differently and create unique situations. Bosses are all also very unique and introduce their own new mechanics into the fight,

The story is great and probably the best part of the game, covering alot of different and mature themes by the end. Despite being a platformer the game does a great job of conveying the weight of your actions and helping you to empathize with both heros and villains of the game. The story takes a bit of time to get going, as the mystery of what exactly ivory is takes time to unfold but by the end, it would be hard to not be invested in the cast.

It's not hard to recommend this game but if you're looking for a challenge then this game might not be for you. The game isn't overly easy but, provides moderate difficulty throughout with a few sections peppered in that are a bit challenging. Certain areas are a bit esoteric and the game doesn't always do a good job of letting you know where to go next, but the world is manageable enough. If you're interested in a great story, solid mechanics and luscious pixel art, and some unique takes on combat and platform puzzling, then definetly check the game out.

69511442.review:
All in all a very solid Metroidvania.  I enjoyed it from start to finish.  That said, the game is a little on the shorter side.

Now, I will admit I used a guide here and there.  I do that for games like these because I have to play them to 100% and usually some things can end up missable, but I was happy to find out some of the things I discovered in said guide would have made me frustrated if I didn't read it.

Ignoring those things entirely to avoid spoilers still makes it a very enjoyable game.  I spent about 11 hours on my fully completed save.  I also bought it on sale for about half off or so.  So, I'd say it was money well spent on it.  Is it worth the full $20, though?

Here are my thoughts on the rest of the game:

The gameplay is very reminiscent of the genre it comes from.  There's no real RPG elements like level gaining or stat-boosting, but you do gain powerups that open new locations for you.  There are extra items you can "craft" that can enhance certain things about you, but can be optional for the most part.  In fact, except for optional stuff, I probably could've gone through the entire game without them, but they were pretty handy.

Graphically it looked like 2D 16- and 32-bit era.  Very colorful and every area has it's own vibrant palette that makes it stand out.  Growing up in even the 8-bit era, I know what games could do to look detailed with what we had, and this definitely shows the detail.

The story was quite good as well since it really shaped the characters, both the good and the bad.  There were even some bad guys I felt sorry for.  I won't say much else on it though.

All in all I do recommend people play this game.

69208041.review:
This game relies overly on the nostalgia of old metroid games and goes as far as to rip off the mapping grid system of metroid. One of the biggest pet peeves I have with this game is the extreme rigidity in aim directions. The story is passable but only just. The storyline feels as if the characters should get some form of development during the middle of the arcs but (spoilers alert,) they remain one dimensional at best. Iconoclast has a plot but it feels cheap to involve so many "deaths" and injuries in an otherwise upbeat game. Other parts of the story feels as if there are different paths to take, but when replayed it reveals that there are actually no real choices that matter. 

Another major issue that pissed me the hell off was that there is a complete lack of potential sequence breaking so prevalent in metroidvania games. Within the first 2 minutes of gameplay there's a "secret" entrance that is completely inaccessible until the boss is fought no matter what. After defeating the area boss, the location allows you to simply walk across the secret threshold, but till then its completely solid.

As far as I have explored, there are only three guns. Crafting items are utterly useless unless you happen to find the Ivory Oil and even then the tweak crafting recipes suggest that you should be finding an abundance of it. I found the boss fights to be infuriating in the way that you might have to struggle to find the sequence of guns/moves to begin damaging it. It could be that i took the time to figure each boss out on its own, but aside from pixel perfecting every boss move, some of the boss fights on higher difficulty settings would basically force you to play as robotically as possible (aha.)

I like the artwork. It feels like a lot of interest and effort was made into animating the enemies and characters but I feel that the artwork does not fit the overall doom and gloom of the plot. But the hell do I know about storywriting and art design. The music is good, but severely lacks of variety and begins to grind at my nerves when I have to backtrack a lot. This effectively forced me to play without music for a good portion of the game. Upgrades are more of a "dammit finally...." feeling rather than a "holy shit yes". 

Overall: 6/10. Buy this game if you absolutely love the art and love the more puzzle aspects of metroidvania, otherwise I strongly suggest another game.

69174381.review:
Iconoclasts is a platforming shooter in the same vein as Cave Story, with a bit of metroidvania thrown into the mix. Iconoclasts' gameplay doesn't feel quite as smooth as Cave Story's, but where the game really shines is in its mature story and compelling cast—one character in particular has made it into my favorite video game villains.

Like Cave Story, Iconoclasts is on the shorter side; at the time of writing this review, I've just finished getting 100% on my first playthrough. I expect that I could complete a second playthrough in an afternoon. One thing that streamlines this is the inclusion of New Game+, which allows you to retain your upgrades and frees you from the need to tediously hunt down every little secret all over again.

Overall, Iconoclasts is a superb game, with a story that I won't soon forget. It has something to say about religion, revenge, leadership, and family. It's no slouch in the gameplay department either, and I highly recommend it to fans of Cave Story and anyone who wants to play more games that tackle heavy themes.

69129902.review: I was actually yawning while playing this. There is nothing special here. The bosses are so boring and uninspired and the exploration was such a slog. I respect that it was made by one person. That was the only reason I tried to play it to the end but I kept asking myself "why am i playing this"? So I stopped.

69001521.review:
If there's one thing i regret about this purchase, it's that i didn't make it sooner. 

SHORT REVIEW:

Beautiful, beautiful graphics and animations. Super cute player character. Catchy music that doesn't get old, reminiscent of Towerfall Ascension's soundtrack. Straightforward gameplay, easy to learn but hard to master, satisfying and responsive. Lots of unique enemies. 

The story is both well-written, detailed, deep and quite dark. Reminiscient of Final Fantasy 7 (The original - i haven't played the remake)

I can't get over all the little details in the animations - these pixels are more expressive than most people! Absolutely gorgeous visuals that always surprise with their incredible amount of detail.

DETAILED REVIEW:


Where do i even start? The art is FANTASTIC. Despite being pixel art, it's so detailed (and so extremely well and fluidly animated) that you can make out anything from how your character (which is absolutely adorable, by the way!) jumps in different manners based on how fast you are moving, to how her cheeks puff out when you're holding your breath! Adorable, adorable pixels... And sometimes oddly sexy, which is confused me at first due to the overall look of the world. It seemed out of place, but only at first glance, before i learnt more of the story.

Don't let the appearances decieve you. There is a LOT more depth to this than i thought at first glance - i'd never imagine the story, and it's characters, would be so interesting. There is a lot of depth to all of the main characters that appear. I am barely four hours in (without a break, unusual but this game just keeps me going) and there has already been several twists and turns i'd never imagine. 

There is a lot of originality here. It's very refreshing.

Besides the breathtaking graphics, the music is also outstanding. You never really get tired of the ambience or the atmospheric music constantly playing in the background - all the sounds work extremely well to draw you into the experience. Also, did i mention your adorable player character also has adorable music notes for footsteps? And Kirby-esque sound effects for jumps!

If you like true metroidvanias, you are going to LOVE this. Unlike others of its kind, there is hardly any backtracking - you'll only ever really have to backtrack if you get lost, and there's always a map available for you to use should you need it.

Character interactions play out really well, with great writing (and translation) as well as extremely lifelike expressions and gestures. I've never experienced anything like it before from pixel art.

68995470.review: I have to say that Iconoclasts is an excellent game. If I had to classify this game, it would be a Metroidvania. Iconoclasts would be a boon to any category that you wanted to add it to. Simply put the mechanics, level design, music and even the story are well crafted here. The controls feel excellent. The action is varied. The mini game sections of each level feel fully integrated to the level and not out of place or irritating. There is plenty of back tracking that you will do after you receive a powerup opening more of the level but the levels and the art look so good, you do not mind seeing it again. The puzzles are varied and not repetitive. I highly recommend this game if you are looking for a good platforming puzzler with some pretty cool mechanics (specifically the wrench).

68263059.review:
Calling Iconoclasts a metroidvania is selling the game short on so many levels. There's nothing wrong with explaining to someone what Iconoclasts is in one word but I feel there's more to be said there. While Iconoclasts does have some metroidvania elements inside its brightly colored environments and peppy soundtrack, its heart and soul lies within its characters. Iconoclasts characters are well-developed and like-able. They trigger a sense of emotion within you as you progress throughout the story. I know that it's hard to sell Iconoclasts based on the characters themselves when the content of the game goes for ten to twenty hours. Besides the characters, Iconoclasts does shine in the gameplay department. Its over twenty bosses is its main selling point and it's saying something. Nearly every boss is fun to defeat, once you figure out its weakness. You can receive upgrades throughout the game to your trusty stun-gun and to your staple weapon, the wrench. Speaking of wrenches, being a mechanic is not just some job placed on the character you play as, Robin, but the story and gameplay explain why mechanics exist and certain puzzles make you feel you are mechanic. May I point out that this game was developed by only one person? Joakim Sandberg developed the art, the music, the story, the characters in the game, which I'll say is not a small endeavor. I would question the price tag on the game, however. $20 seems a little steep, but that could be the cheapskate in me talking. I would wait until the game goes on sale to purchase. Although, I am not disappointed by the $20 I spent. 

TL;DR
Iconoclasts is more than just a metroidvania. Great game with excellent characters, stunning gameplay, bright visuals, and a fun soundtrack.

9/10

67899541.review:
I waited quite a long time to jump into this game.  Way back when I played the demo in 2012, I saw potential in a beautifully pixelated metroidvania style platformer with a cool wrench mechanic.  It was bright, colorful, and rich with character design and story.  I badly want to recommend titles like these.  I can't.  

Make no mistake, this is still is drenched in quality.  The time time and dedication shows with each world.  Boss fights are incredibly inventive and Robin, the mute protagonist, is as endearing as they get.  I DO recommend most folks give this a go, as it might engross them long enough to reach the end.  I was not one of those individuals.  

With a rather convoluted plot, an uninspired crafting system that leads to mundane powerups, and some of the worst backtracking I've had to deal with since Axiom Verge, my interest dwindled towards the back half.  There's a chance I might pick this up in the future, but I had to cut my adventure short on this one.  I know there will be a lot that will still enjoy the adventurous side of roaming the game's world.  I just don't have that kind of time anymore.  

With some the best pixel animation you'll see in games of this genre, and some incredibly designed boss fights, this is still worth anyone's time.  If you can accept the game's shortcomings in plot progression and a sub-par crafting element, Iconoclasts may well be worth your time.

6/10

67819061.review: A game with a great story, great gameplay. You gonna like it if you enjoy to make puzzles and dealing with challenging bosses

67807712.review:
Iconoclasts is a 2D Metroidvania platformer about Robin, an outcast mechanic who, by choosing her own job rather than doing what the church assigns her to do, has become a wanted outlaw. But greater things are afoot, and the world itself seems to be shaking beneath your feet…

This game’s story is odd. The premise of the story seems strange, but the game quickly pulls you into the strange world. The One Concern is a military-religious-scientific organization that basically serves as the world government. Led by Mother and her agents, people with seemingly magical powers and supernatural resilience, these people praise Him. This seems like a fairly standard “evil church organization” plot, but in truth, it’s anything but; the One Concern is much more than some sort of bizarre cult, and many of its most important members clearly don’t believe in the benevolence of their god, and have other tasks on their mind.

The characters are armed with guns and explosives of various sorts, and there’s a great deal of advanced technology all over the place. And yet, simultaneously, many of the people seem to live very simple lives. This dichotomy becomes increasingly apparent the further you get into the game, and it becomes increasingly clear that things are complicated. While at first it seems like a fairly simple “One Concern bad, hippy commune folk good” sort of plot, the further you get into the game, the more you come to understand what drives the One Concern, and also how much further they see than their sort of happyish opposition.

The game has a certain sense of humor to it that reminds me of the sillier bits of Final Fantasy 6, and yet it also has a lot of very serious bits to it. This creates quite the dichotomy; the game early on seems fairly lighthearted, but it starts getting darker and darker, and many, many people start dying or being very gruesomely injured. The further you get, the bleaker the story becomes, as everything goes wrong, more and more people start dying, the hope for humanity seems to become increasingly distant, and the end of the world seems nigh.

And then, after all that buildup, the game’s final area is fairly anticlimactic, and the final boss appears with a visual gag introducing them. What exactly was going on is not explained, and the player is left wondering what the point of it all was, as a major subversion of the player’s expectations is thrown out at the last minute, raising even more questions about why the One Concern was worshipping Him in the first place, at which point the game ends.

Thus, it’s hard to say whether or not the story actually delivered; it definitely has some high moments, and I felt bad for several characters, including a few of the villains. Ironically, two of the least sympathetic characters you end up seeing are two of your teammates, who treat other people like garbage and aren’t a lot of fun to be around. All of this is good, and I wanted to see the characters succeed.

But at the end, it feels like the story deflates, and ends rather abruptly and unceremoniously after some quite solid buildup.

Gameplay wise, the game is fine. The overall motion of Robin is quite fluid, and she’s fun to control on the whole. You run, you jump, you swing around on your wrench, you have three different guns (each with their own charge shot), and you can “tweak” yourself to get different bonuses. The game has over two dozen bosses, and they’re quite varied overall – there are a lot of different types of boss fights, from the straightforward to the puzzle boss to the sort of boss where your goal is to survive while doing some other task, and the variety in terms of bosses is very good.

Unfortunately, while the bosses were pretty good, the levels were more of a mixed bag. There were definitely some good areas in the game, but other areas felt kind of tedious to go through; they weren’t difficult, they just required you to go back and forth a bunch of times, and that wasn’t particularly fun to do. The tower sequence in the middle of the game is particularly egregious in this regard. The biggest problem, however, was simply the fact that the enemies didn’t really feel all that interesting to fight most of the time; they were interesting at first, and figuring out some of them was fun, but in the middle part of the game, it felt like the game stopped really introducing interesting new enemies for a while, only to start doing so again at the end.

Overall, Iconoclasts is a decent game. There were a few bits that were quite good, but there were other bits that were disappointing – including the very end of the 14 hour long game, which left a bit of a sour taste in my mouth.

If you like Metroidvania games, this is a fine game, but there are better ones, like Hollow Knight, and more visually striking ones, like the Ori games. I don’t regret playing this game, but there are other games in the same genre that are of higher quality that are worth playing over this one. Still, you could do worse than Iconoclasts.

Simply beautiful. Not only is it amazingly well crafted and gorgeous to look at, it is beautifully done in terms of storytelling. The whole story is not told only through dialogue, but most importantly, through gameplay.

I was shook by this game and it took me time to process everything that happened in the story.

there are nods to great metroidvania games (I wouldn't call this a metroidvania) and the mecanics are solid and fun to play with, Bosses are fresh and each and everyone of them needs to be dealt with differently. 67598689.review:
I have a mixed opinion about this game.
On one hand, it looks nice. The sprite art is gorgeous, as are the animations. Colors are bright and vibrant.
On the other, it feels and plays like a standard metroidvania game.

As far as character design, there's room to improve. I didn't have any sort of investment in Robin, since its hard to parse a personality out of a mute protag. Other characters fare little better, with their experiences acting more as punctuation to a level more than being integrated within it. The vast majority of my gametime was spent solving puzzles and navigating levels, not getting to understand these characters and what their struggle is about.

As far as themes go, this game plays with the idea of faith and faith within society. Which is... neat? But it doesn't marry with any other parts of the game outside of dialogue and imagery. Is there a message I'm missing? Because, all of the characters within the game treat theocracy and planned society like it's second nature. The main exception being Robin, because we're left to fill in the blanks for her.

I think this game is good, but I don't know if I'm going to be able to muster enough nerve to make it through the tower area; which is so annoyingly designed that I more or less succumbed to tedium of trying to actually navigate it. Doesn't help that by that point in the game I was beginning to grate on Robin's limited moveset and obstacles placed specifically to exploit that limited moveset.

It's interesting if nothing else, but is it a game I'd recommend? AAaaaah, nah. Not really. If the theme and visuals excite you, then it might be a good fit. It's a perfectly functional experience, but not one that I find thrilling.

67533140.review: I got this game as a gift from a friend for my birthday and let me put it this way: this is one of those games that's so good that a part of me wishes that I had paid for it. If you like metroidvanias and puzzle platformers, this is the game for you. Trust me on that.

67498416.review:
*перенёс игру в коллекцию "осталась одна ачивка"

Начну с сюжета, потому что это самое вкусное. Сюжет здесь воспринимается схоже с Cave Story; несмотря на внешнюю милоту, сам сюжет здесь довольно жёсткий в эмоциональном плане, и довольно кровавые (хотя у злодеев течёт костяное масло в жилах, так что не "кровавые" технически) сцены смерти персонажей только усиливают мрачность происходящего. Воспринимается как Cave Story, если бы в ней дали больше упора на сюжет (все мы помним геноцид зайчаток в Cave Story, да?) Или на эти ваши японские мультики. После пиковой точки (захвата Сити Один) сюжет идёт на спад вместе со сложностью игры, но до этого он очень даже. Персонажи душевные, аутист альбинос как всегда присутствует.

Геймплей: Головоломки топ, боёвка очень неровно - есть замечательные боссы, есть ужасные. В общем и целом, геймплей здесь идёт за сюжетом - то есть,в некоторых местах (и боссах) справедливый челлендж был потерян, чтобы наверстать эпичностью картинки. И это - как правило - хорошо. По этой же причине сюжет сильно, СИЛЬНО более линеен, чем в большинстве метроидваний. И это тоже хорошо. Просто не покупайте, ожидая Дандару, Hollow Knight или там даже Cave Story. Ещё чуть линейнее.

Собирательство - сундуки раскиданные по карте - радует; хотя, конечно, твики не так разнообразны и нужны как в Hollow Knight, например. (Но адекватнее чем в Blasphemous).

В общем и целом: да, классно, местами странные геймплейные решения, но сюжет их оправдывает.

67489543.review:
Este juego merece mucha más atención de la que recibe. "Iconoclasts" es una obra muy personal hecha con el mayor mimo y cuidado. Se trata de una suerte de "Metroidvania" que no se limita a reinventar o alterar la fórmula que ya sentaron Super Metroid y Symphony of the Night, en su lugar, sorprende con una jugabilidad nueva y única. Y sobre todo, fresca.

La exploración y las interacciones con el entorno son mucho más importantes que el combate, y los jefes parecen más bien enormes puzzles que superar. Todo ello se acompaña de un apartado artístico y gráfico precioso. 

Pero lo que de verdad importa de este juego es su historia. Porque el juego está enteramente diseñado para contar una historia, con unos personajes interesantes y carismáticos, con los que empatizamos rápidamente y que vemos como progresan a lo largo de una trama de ciencia ficción y existencialismo profunda e intrincada.

Hay que tener en cuenta con "Iconoclasts" que el aparentemente infantil y desenfadado apartado visual esconde una argumento complicado, violento y triste, con momentos muy perturbadores. Aunque no le faltan momentos cómicos o desenfadados

La trama es oscura, esotérica y por momentos difícil de entender, aquí la pretensión narrativa juega en contra de la comprensión de la historia, y no obstante, pese a ello, vale la pena experimentarla.

8/10

67401584.review: Oozing with character, Iconoclasts is one of those games I can't stop thinking about weeks after finishing it.  It's intelligent, beautiful, endearing, and a shining example of good game design.

67327521.review:
Absolutely wonderful 2D action platformer with a heavy emphasis on puzzles. Even the combat is very puzzle-like, because you often have to use a combination of weapons and and the environment in order to defeat the many bosses and enemies.

Iconoclasts looks like the prettiest SNES game that never got made and its story is surprisingly dark and violent despite the cheery colorful look. Not unlike many of the RPGs and action adventure titles of the 16-bit era, its themes and characters are deeper than what they initially appear to be. I was constantly surprised by the story.

Give this one a go if you're a fan of Metroidvania style games, though this one isn't nearly as heavy on exploration as it is on puzzle-solving and boss fights (so many boss fights). This is a very clever, charming, and challenging game.

67169672.review: To be honest, kind of generic (despite not looking like it) and boring.

66978525.review:
Basically: starts really interesting, but as the game goes on you can really feel how this was too much for a single developer.
Pros:
-INCREDIBLE PIXEL ART AND OVERALL DESIGN, seriously, despite all the negatives, visual polish alone makes this game worth at least a spot in my heart forever.
-THE MUSIC: great work, I loved all of the songs. This along with the visuals make the game seem a lot more finished than i really is.
-THE VILLAINS: the agents were really cool, they have some decent deph and are really entartaining. 
-The worldbuilding: Its a pretty interesting world, and i like the contrast of the happy visuals with the downright disturbing things taking place.
-The boss fights(half of them): This is an example of the limitations of this being developed by one person. This game has some really fun boss fights, but those are really in the first half of the story. Later boss fight get really clunky an boring design wise. And there are some that are just bad... like a stealth boss fight for some reason.
Cons:
-The heroes: I hated every single character that wasn't a villain. Everybody acts like an teenage girl in a 80s movie: dumb, anoying and overly emotional. And most of these character dont feel like they belong in this epic tale about the future of the planet and the religion implications of it. Its as if the cast from Glee were dropped in the middle of mass effect 3.
-The Story: the world may be cool, but the storytelling is a bit on the boring side. The story keeps taking this weird turns that feel really out of place. And right at the end when you feel like things might add up to something cohesive, it takes another even weirder turn, AND THEN ANOTHER, and then it ends... Its just a mess.
-The combat- its pretty whatever for most of it, but there are some weird design decisions that make it a bit annoying, like the gun cooldown times that i dont know why were included at all. And the equipable upgrades that break when you take damage, making them completely useless.
-The puzzles- most of them are just not that fun, the tower level for example, was one of the most confusing levels I have ever played. And it doesn't help that the bomb bounces all over the place when fired, making things quite clunky.
-The secrets and backtracking: since all you get are materiels for the upgrades(witch are useless), there is no reason to explore.

66963792.review:
REVIEW IN PROGRESS:

Konjak has made his name well known among the Multimedia Fusion indie game developer crowd for some time -- particularly for his Metroidvania-style games (look at Noitu Love) and his frankly gorgeous pixel artwork.  

I remember when he first released the Iconoclast demo years ago and had released a statement following its warm reception that the project had been cancelled.  I was pleasantly surprised when the game did eventually release - and not only on PC/Steam, but on consoles! 

ICONOCLASTS follows a similar gameplay style as his other games: in a Metroidvania-vein style presentation, you play as ROBIN, a young mechanic who finds herself in a world where operating machines is illegal without sanction from the holy Mother.  On the run after she is caught servicing her brother's broken-down home, you end up on a globe-trotting adventurer with several other party members - often on opposing ideologies and sides - as you unearth the mysteries of the mysterious One Concern organisation.    

Gameplay is tight and features Robin's signature wrench and her stun gun, both of which get upgrades throughout the game in the form of new features that unlock traversal options.  You also pick up materials as you go along that go into various equippable power-ups that allow Robin to have more health, swing her wrench harder, or dive roll - but taking hits from enemies temporarily disables them, slot by slot, until you regain them through exploring the world or defeating foes.  It's a neat little system of offering you a small way to customize how Robin plays without drastically becoming reliant on them.  

One critique that I have seen on the discussion boards which I agree with is the fact that the game offers quite a few different combat options, but often makes enemies frustratingly weak against just one.   Having to figure out which specific attack is useful against the enemy that you're fighting can feel like grunt work and removes the flow of adventure that the game does have and which halts the exhiliration you get from running into room after room. 

Similarly, the pacing of the game can sometimes feel [i]too[/i] breakneck.  You often end up feeling like there isn't a pause in the game; while there are some towns and villages that you get to spend some time in, other than speaking with the locals, there often isn't much to do and the game is content throwing you into the next dungeon as it is.  

The writing also suffers a little - the dialogue is a bit stilted and sometimes reads a bit awkward.  The plot is engaging but the use of various terms, with the inconsistent highlighting, also hampers some of its coherency.  Overall, however, Konjak tackles some challenging and relevant themes that are handled quite well.  The party that you travel with unfortunately isn't the most engaging crew -- some of them are quite unlikeable, to be honest -- but I do feel that most people who pick this up are in it for the gameplay, not the story. 

Heartily recommend.  I will update this review once I complete the game, but for fans of the Metroidvania genre, it's a fantastic game with good length and chock full of meaningful and fun content.

Every character is insufferable and unlikable.  They all behave like emotionally insecure teenagers, melodramatic and randomly yelling for no reason. 66478467.review:
Iconoclasts, on the surface, seems like it would be a great game. It's got a great presentation, a lot of the character designs are really good, especially the Isi designs, and the soundtrack can be really good. However, it has way too much bogging it down

-The story is a bloated mess. At one point I assumed it would be a western religion vs. other religions plot and thought that would be neat, but no. It just goes places.

-The gameplay feels unpolished. The Tweak system especially annoyed me. You have all available Tweak slots from the beginning, which is cool, until you realize that you needed them all from the beginning for the system to actually be worth anything since you lose a tweak in one hit and then have to grind way too much for it to come back, and the movement in the game doesn't aid this at all since you only get a dodge roll from a Tweak. Which you can lose

-Exploration feels tacked on. You only ever get Tweak materials from exploring, no optional weapons or anything. It becomes a "why bother" situation. I started running past chests near the end cause I didn't care anymore.

-Elro's entire character. I'm not going to spoil anything, but he can be the most insufferable character at times. He's incredibly nihilistic throughout the second half of the game and you just want him to go away.

To sum it all up, the game had some really good potential, but it just becomes a bloated mess when you look at it deeper. Get something like Celeste or either of the Bloodstained games if you have the Metroidvania itch.

65645429.review:
No debería autodenominarse [i]metroidvania[/i] un juego cuya única característica en común con dicho género es el estilo del mapa, porque lo demás es un quiero y no puedo. 

El [i]backtracking[/i], que es lo que hace que te lo pases bien en un juego de este tipo, está fatalmente implementado: no sólo es anecdótico sino que además es innecesario. Cuando quieres volver a recoger los objetos que has ido dejando atrás ya estás en una parte del mapa sin comunicación ni transporte con las zonas en las que dejaste cosas por recoger, lo cual te obliga a pegarte un buen paseo hasta la primera zona que tiene comunicación con el resto.

Por si fuera poco, el paseo apetece aún menos si cabe cuando te das cuenta de que los objetos que recoges son completamente innecesarios para completar el juego. Consisten en una serie de materiales para construir mejoras, que se pueden cambiar en los puntos de guardado. Pues bien, prácticamente todas las mejoras que puedes construir tienen una utilidad nula o limitada. Después de probar varias y de no saber si la que has elegido funciona o no, acabas tomando la decisión de que lo mejor es equipar tres veces la mejora que limita el daño que recibes. Estoy convencido de que podría haber terminado el juego sin recoger nada y sin tener equipada ninguna de las mejoras.

Para mejorar esto, el número de armas es de sólo 4 (3 armas de fuego y la llave inglesa), y no hay habilidades que desbloquear (olvídate de doble salto, [i]dash[/i] y similares). Mención especial al control del personaje Mina. Su movimiento está restringido con respecto al personaje principal y el apuntado con su arma es un absoluto despropósito. Por suerte controlas a este personaje pocas veces y poco tiempo a lo largo del juego.

El argumento no es malo y podría ser perfectamente el de cualquier Final Fantasy (es más, creo que Iconoclasts sería mejor juego si hubiese sido un J-RPG de corte clásico con combate por turnos), como juego de plataforma funciona bien (digo más, creo que Iconoclasts hubiese sido mejor juego de haber sido exclusivamente un plataformas de acción en 2D centrado en la historia), los puzzles están bien planteados y el plano artístico es bueno.

Soy un gran amante del género [i]metroidvania[/i], tanto que se ha convertido en mi género preferido con el paso de los años, y tenía muchas ganas de jugar a Iconoclasts. Ya puedo decir que es una de las mayores decepciones que me he llevado en los últimos años como jugador, y puedo afirmar sin dudarlo que es uno de los peores [i]metroidvanias[/i] que jugaré jamás. Si lo tienes en tu lista de deseados y buscas un [i]metroidvania[/i], compra otro que esté en tu lista. Por suerte hay propuestas diversas donde elegir.

65434463.review:
This was a great game, I think my main gripe with it was I felt the story was hard to follow. After watching some videos afterwards, some of the things that confused me make more sense.

The story follows the main character, Robin, who is a mechanic. In a world governed over religion, each person in the world is supposed to follow the job that they are "bestowed". Failure to do so gets your house and/or family destroyed through a "ritual" called Penance. Robin doesn't follow this religion and wants to go her own path. What follows is a tale about going against said religion, and the crazy evil truth behind it all.

NOW, the only reason I can tell you all this is because the videos I watched helped clear up my confusion. Throughout the game I felt I could understand the story somewhat, but a lot of it was a lil difficult to follow. This may not be the case for everyone, but it was for me.

The gameplay is super solid, it's a 2D action platformer that's almost like a Metroidvania. You'll unlock new guns and upgrades to your wrench to traverse the world. You can also find hidden materials to equip tweaks like being able to run faster, or increased melee damage.

My personal favorite thing about the gameplay is the party system. You'll occasionally find other playable party members who have their own different playstyles, and it's especially fun when they help you in boss battles.

The boss battles, OMG! I believe the boss battles were my favorite thing about this game. Each one was memorable and had the perfect amount of challenge. This also goes to the art style of the game which reminded me of the animations in Metal Slug, cept now I get to play with taller models and in an RPG-like setting.

The music was very good, I hummed along to some of the tunes while going through dungeons. I believe this game's strongest suit is definitely the characters. Both the good guys and bad guys were very well written and I found myself eager to learn more about them and their motivations.

I have a few gripes however. The story, though really good, was also really confusing on my first go round. I eventually was able to understand after I did some research after the game, but part of me wished I could understand it better while playing. The two times I got stuck in the game were kinda meh as well, Once I got stuck because I didn't hit a box with a certain weapon in the right square so I ended up thinking that I was doing the puzzle wrong, but I was actually doing it right. And then there was a boss battle where it wasn't clear at first what I was supposed to do so I had to research it and figure it out. Basically what I'm saying is, sometimes the game was quite unclear on how to do things, but it did not stop my overall enjoyment of the game.

Final thoughts? I liked it it. The boss battles were my absolute favorite parts of the game. It reminded me of how good the boss battles in Crosscode was. I can honestly recommend this game if you want a good 2D Action Platformer. Took me close to 10 hours to beat so it's a good moderate length. Thanks for reading!

TL:DR: A good and colorful 2D action platformer. Story was a lil hard to understand, but the gameplay was solid. Boss battles was AMAZINGLY fun. I recommend it!

65034684.review:
Iconoclasts is a game I found myself very disappointed in.

As usual, I'll start with the positives. The pixel art looks phenomenal, easily one of the best I've seen yet. The amount of detail on characters and environments is astonishing. For a tile based pixel art game, I think this might be as good as it gets.
The music is pretty good and well composed, with a few memorable tracks.
Controls are very fluid and the game is overall really stable.
Characters have great, recognizable design.

Unfortunately, that's about it, and I wish I had more to praise here.

Gameplay-wise, it's a "metroidvania" but with the inclusion of puzzle rooms. However, in terms of mechanics and content, I've found it to be an exceptionally weak metroidvania and not very entertaining to play.

Combat is par for the course but your character sort of auto aims her basic gun which takes away some of the challenge (despite being able to shoot up and down, already a big boon in this kind of game). You can charge your guns for a more powerful shot, but this causes an overly long cooldown before being able to start charging again or even shoot uncharged shots, a baffling design decision after decades of Mega Man and Metroid being out.
Bosses are often cool looking but they tend to rely on trial and error with simple patterns that, once memorized, provide little challenge. I'd certainly consider them a highlight of the game nonetheless, and I enjoyed fighting against a few of them.

The puzzle rooms wore out their welcome really early on for me. While maybe novel at first, it didn't take long for them to become showstoppers, breaking the flow of the game and, consequently, my engagement. They are numerous and in basically all of them you're required to do tasks such as using your bomb weapon to time an explosion or move a crate onto a button in order to open doors and activate platforms.
None of the puzzles felt particularly clever enough to warrant their inclusion; I found myself figuring out solutions quickly simply because there aren't many options to begin with, and after seeing a few puzzles, you've seen them all. Even worse, some puzzles, due to their navigational nature, need to be done again if you revisit certain rooms. It felt like busy-work. Overall, I found the puzzles repetitive and intrusive to what would be otherwise a much more free-flowing action oriented game.

The mandatory upgrades felt very lackluster and didn't enhance overall gameplay, their acquisition serving only as step-stones in order to progress. This could have been salvaged by the Tweak system, if only it had any semblance of good design behind it.
Tweaks are upgrades you can apply to your character at any save point, and you have three slots in which to equip these Tweaks. Tweaks need to be built on workbenches you find around the game world, and for that you'll need to first collect a one-time-use blueprint of the particular Tweak, and resources, one of which, Ivory Oil, is quite rare. Some Tweaks don't require Ivory Oil, but the more useful ones do.
The problem: Tweaks are overall not worth the effort of making them, providing negligible bonuses such as a slightly faster running speed or a few seconds of additional underwater breathing. Some can be built more than once allowing for effect stacking, but the three slots limitation forces you to choose between distinct weak effects or a twice/thrice stacked effect that will still not change much at the end.
To make matters worse, upon taking a hit, your rightmost working Tweak slot "breaks", nullifying the effect of that Tweak until the slot is repaired by collecting shards that enemies and environment statues drop, and quite a few are required to repair a single slot. If you fail to repair a slot before taking another hit, the slot to the left of the broken one is now broken as well. In three consecutive hits, you'll have no working Tweaks.
What this means is that three Tweaks fail to improve your character in any meaningful way and even if they did, taking a hit and losing at least one Tweak for some time is an always looming possibility, especially during boss encounters. 
Because of this, pursuing materials for Tweaks felt like a complete waste of time. Unfortunately, materials and Tweak blueprints are all you're going to find in secret areas, so the exploration aspect of this particular metroidvania is rendered moot.

I understand perfectly well the desire to have an original system in a game, but this just doesn't work. Optional, even limited upgrades are not a new concept and they've been implemented perfectly well in past games, so what happened here?

Not to mention the many nonsensical design tidbits, such as: too many platforms requiring you to grab onto their ledge to pull yourself up instead of being able to clear them normally, taking longer to navigate them than necessary; including a basic move, dodging, as a Tweak, which will be lost if you take three hits at most; a very specific and costly Tweak being required to access a secret area, which will only net you a material to make more Tweaks anyway; one of your abilities taking two hammer swings to fully charge - the first swing stopping just short of being enough - but there being a Tweak that will allow you to fully charge with a single swing. Why?

Now, regarding the story, I'll tackle both plot and writing together in this case, for convenience.

I personally didn't like it. It's such a heavy-handed, bleak, drama-filled story that is a stark contrast to the gameplay. Pretty much every significant character, aside from the silent protagonist, is a broken mess of an individual with deep personal issues who flies off the handle, punches walls and shouts to high heavens about ideology or their suffering at the slightest provocation. Even non consequential NPCs treat the main character with an unjustified disdain I don't often see in games.
This kind of melodramatic writing would be grating enough anywhere for me, but here, in a colorful metroidvania where I'm supposed to be happily running around finding secrets and shooting enemies, of all places?
The in-game world itself is an absolute hellhole to live in, with a pervasive, on-the-nose evil religion that deprives a family of their livelihood, or even kills them, for so much as interacting with a "sinner", and it doesn't take much to be a sinner in this world. 
The game is also surprisingly violent, with many characters dying or getting injured, sometimes in gruesome ways.

I found no aspect of the worldbuilding in this game to be anything but joyless. The constant bickering and moaning from the characters made me not care about any of them. There was no cool place, information or goal to look forward to, nothing for me to think "well, this makes it all worth it" or "this is really interesting, I want to know more".

All in all, my time with Iconoclasts was not enjoyable. It's a real shame, one of the biggest ones since I've made a Steam account almost 8 years ago. But it is what it is.

Now, I am aware that Iconoclasts was, according to the store page, made by a single developer over seven years. As harsh and unfeeling sounding as this review is (an unfortunate byproduct of the text medium), I have no intention of, nor the presumption of being able to, taking this achievement away from him. The fact he managed to make everything in this game by himself is nothing short of praise. Anyone who has worked on a software, game or any similarly big project knows how monumental of a task it is and I feel secure saying most people are not equipped to deal with it alone, but this man did it and that's really inspiring to me.

Congratulations, Joakim Sandberg, for pursuing your dream and seeing it through to the end. More important than anything I've said here, I believe you have incredible tenacity and talent and I hope you'll continue gracing the industry with these strengths in some form or another. I look forward to seeing your next effort!

64871816.review:
Iconoclasts is somewhat of a mixed bag. Going with the negatives first, there are some objectively badly designed elements like the game often not communicating enemy weaknesses and immunities clearly enough, sporadically poorly placed checkpoints, not being able to see the map of an area you're not in so you can check if you want to backtrack, and an upgrading equipping system that frankly is utter shit.

>BUT< , this game just has so much damn character. The art and animations are fantastic. The body language and facial animations absolutely sell every character  and the enemies in both combat and in cutscenes. The characters in story are actually well written and have a surprising amount of character, despite (intentionally) seeming bog-standard when introduced. The setting is very unique and the world building has a great mix of slowly revealing things while keeping some history somewhat mysterious (while still hinting at possibilities). The more I played, the more I loved all of it, despite the parts of the design I didn't like. 

As for the other parts, the combat is fine, and decent difficulty puzzles are a large part of the gameplay.  The bosses are mostly cool, well designed and animated, but can suffer from the same lack of weakness-communicating that regular enemies suffer. Overall, yeah, this is definitely worth a buy.

64751493.review:
Iconoclasts is a gorgeous action platformer with minor Metroidvania exploration. The vast majority of the game is played in linear fashion following a story that starts a bit weak but really grew on me and by the half way point I was fully invested in the characters though the overall lore/story was dodgy at times. But the moment to moment happenings really shine; largely thanks to stuff actually happening. This game is very good at keeping the plot moving and I'm adding a spoiler section to the end of this review to rave about one portion of it.

Now past that Iconoclasts has vibrant, engaging audiovisuals that start off a bit generic but get to an unique point. All the characters have ton of variety in animations and really bring the world alive.

The gameplay starts equally basic but as you gather a few more weapons and abilities(there aren't that many; it's a tight package) you really get in the groove. Especially during a variety of bosses you are really allowed to get in a flow state that just works and normal difficulty is tuned just right where you have enough time to learn the mechanics on one life but if you are a bit slow on the uptake the game will kill you. I only ever needed 3 lives to beat a boss but still felt like I was being challenged to an good degree. The puzzles are lplentyful and relatively light, no complaints there.

So yeah all told I can really recommend Iconoclasts as a light metroidvania with highly engaging characters and fantastic pacing throughout.


[spoiler]Now a big thing that kinda surprised me was that people die in this. To me this looked like your normal PG cutesy indie game where maybe bosses kinda disappear off screen and so forth. But no, both bad and the good guys properly kill named; major characters off. Limbs get torn off, bad guys shoot characters in the face and good guys make dudes burst in very explicitly painful ways. Now to be clear all of this is rather free of blood.

And even the main character gets in on that action. Late in the game(after you have fought her a couple of times) you come across your nemesis again and one of your friends basically says "hey I know you've had a chance or two before and haven't taken them; but right now you really gotta kill this bitch" and then you actually do it. Not in your normal bossfighty style where at the end they fall off the building through their own volition or something. You knock them down over and over and inject a thing into them that slows them down and in the end bursts them open. It is more serious(though again free of blood) than what I at least have come to expect from these sorts of games and really worked well.[/spoiler]

63997605.review:
In Iconoclasts you'll spend a lot of time running around doing platforming challenges, some light puzzle solving, fighting enemies, and experiencing the rather rich plot the game has to offer.

The game seems to fancy itself somewhat of a Metroidvania, with nonlinear levels (but very linear progression) and paths gated behind certain abilities, but it's not really a Metroidvania. Every so often the game will expect you to backtrack through a level or, on one occasion, comb through a level you just went through to find a plot trigger to move the game on, which made me resort to just using a guide. Aside from that, there's not really much of a reason to explore because the rewards you get for exploring (tweaks) are generally unessential and not very useful. I used the same set of tweaks for almost the entire game.

The bosses are where the gameplay really shines in my opinion, and there are quite a lot of bosses. Each boss feels unique and requires a different approach in order to be defeated. I found myself having to tank quite a bit of damage in most boss fights before I could figure out their pattern, but the fights rarely felt unfair. 

There is a lot of emphasis on the game's plot and worldbuilding, and I think it pulled it off quite well. The story seems to meander from one thread to the next at first, but it builds up to a tense and dramatic climax that really made the whole thing click for me. There are some weird and slightly questionable writing decisions, like the amount of focus on a particular character's family melodrama and an endgame reveal that left me disappointed, but none of that ruined the plot for me. The writing toes the line between humourous and serious very well, in a way that actually kind of reminds me of Metal Gear Rising. Not what I expected going in, but there you go. 

Oh yeah, and one guy made like the whole thing. Pretty impressive.

63849531.review:
Iconoclasts has gorgeous spritework and sound, as well as an intriguing setting that is presented so poorly it hampers the entire experience.  Exposition and explanation is deliberately withheld in favor of a more "natural" sounding dialogue for characters that don't accommodate clueless players.  This can be fun for puzzling things out on your own, but the sheer quantity and frequency of cutscenes feels less like learning an intriguing mystery and more like reading a book where you skip chapters at random.

Worse, the abundance of story constantly clashes with the game's aspirations of being a metroidvania.  Areas can be revisited with new powerups to unlock alternate routes, but instead of using level design to guide the player, the cutscenes constantly roadblock, teleport, and redirect the player character.  Once, I defeated a boss and got sent to a part of the level I hadn't seen before.  I worked my way back to the center, assuming a landslide I saw earlier would be clear and I could progress.  It was still there.  Instead, I had to go back to where I was teleported, go in the opposite direction a bit to trigger a cutscene, and THEN go to the cleared landslide.  Even when not being shuttled around by story, backtracking is constantly required to advance the plot.  There are very, very few interesting power ups or alternate routes when revisiting old areas.

On the plus side, the bosses in the game are great, both in visuals and in moveset.  I wonder if the developers would have been better off making a linear game instead.

The story is taking a long time before it starts to become engaging, the first couple of hours you are often forced to listen to long dialogues that sometimes don’t even make much sense. But about halfway through the game the story started to finally make more sense to me and in the final part of the game I really liked the story. I know he's supposed to be controlling all of it with the mind control ray thingy but it is all left in a big question mark. Theres also no epilogue[/spoiler]

The game is not very difficult, unless you've played through the game once and unlocked challenge mode (wish you could've picked it from the start!) I played through the game on the hardest difficulty and without doing any ability upgrades in game to try to make it a little bit more challenging, got through it just fine.

The reason that I am writing this review however is one thing: the bosses. These are the most fun boss battles I have EVER played in any game, each and every one of them brings something different to the table. They felt like rewards after going through the puzzles, and their themes are mostly hyping up the battle.
They're seriously what made the game for me, they never felt repetitive or unfair. 

Overall I like this game. The art is amazing, music too, it had a couple of very memorable pieces like Psychopomp and Preacher, and it has controls that are fluid, but the amount of backtracking that you have to do currently prevents me from wanting to play through the game again in challenge mode but I might do it sometime.
7/10

A must-play for anyone who likes Cave Story or similar games.

A rare gem of a story that lets you discover its bone-chilling depths through the imagery and environments rather than just reading walls of text to have something explained to you. Don't let its bright and colorful artwork fool you, it may have some comic relief and genre-awareness, but it's very dark and serious most of the time.

The highlights of the games are the bosses and the story. Collectibles are very unrewarding to find, so not much purpose in going for those unless you're an obsessive 100%'er. Boss rushes are fun though! 

For those saying that the story isn't great, it's complicated. It's not spelled out for you, much is implied and many discoveries are made out of chronological order. It can make it hard to understand the whole thing the first time through, but it's truly captivating once you start putting the pieces together! You'll get your replay value out of the story. You'll get more of it the second time you play through it, just like a good book.

As I'm writing this, I'm halfway through New Game + and I'm enjoying it even more than the first time!
