Is Iconoclasts beautiful? Absolutely. Does it play well? Sure. Does it tell a good story? No, I personally don't think it does.

Maybe I missed something major throughout the course of the game, but I was constantly left feeling like I had more questions than answers. The character designs were incredibly interesting, but it always felt like nobody had a good motive to do anything. The dialogue was plagued with references to things the player has no context for, that only get explained in the most hand-wavy kind of way later on. Stuff just kind of... happens, and you just happen to be there when they do.

The level design is alright, but there ends up being a lot of backtracking. There're a few levels that are effectively closed, by which I mean they are self-contained and feel claustrophobic without intending to. There's one area that is meant to feel that way and it does a great job of it, but I'm wondering if it wasn't by accident, given that much of the game ends up feeling that way.

I think, overall, the game is worth playing through once. If you really like it, and think you might be able to pick up on more story points and just can't get enough of the gameplay, maybe a second time. But I don't think I'll be revisiting it.

If you are the kind of person looking for a 10 hour long metroidvania experience filled with a compelling story, pretty pixel graphics, a memorable world to explore and simple gameplay then this might interest you.

On the one hand there are puzzles of varying difficulty, some of which have made me sat down and ponder for a while but in a positive manner (in very few instances I felt frustrated though it may have been due to my own lack of attention). On the other, it has a cheeky sense of humor that can be quite subtle at times but it's noticeable irregardless. Partly, it shows a distinct care for the way the dialogue was written and how the characters were portrayed in different scenarios.

There's also the fact that I believe this game was developed by one guy for over 7 years-ish, which makes it a lot more special to me in terms how it turned out. Might I add that the soundtrack usually fits with atmosphere of the level? Just in case you were wondering about the dlc.

All in all, I'd say grab it on a sale even if it's not too expensive and try it out. It's worth a shot at least.

60960598.review:
Hello, I want to make one thing clear. I recommend Iconoclasts. However, if you pick this up, this is what you will get:

A varying difficulty puzzle platforming metroidvania style game. The story apparently divides people, I thought it was good - be prepared to read a bit, and it should be easy enough to follow. The gameplay is decently tight - I wasn't sure that I was playing the same game that many of the negative reviewers did - this may have been due to some updates, I can't say for sure, however, all in all it's a fun play. 

The bosses are either great, or frustrating beyond belief (the hide and seek one gave me a lot of stress). This game is either great at communicating to the player what it needs, or really, really bad at it. Some of the controls are a little wonky, but the wonky controls are never the base controls for the main character (looking at you, Mina's shotgun). 

The puzzles are frustrating not because they're overly difficult, but because you simply forget what all you can do at points. 

As for story, I did like it. The world is decently built, and leaves a lot of questions, though you may not exactly like how it's built. For example, what the hell is the finale? What is the blue infection, and why does it look like it doesn't belong, and yet seem like it does? (You'll understand by the final boss what I mean here. I get most of the concepts and lore of the game but this blue infection in particular is quite trifling, I just don't see why it's there if it's totally acceptable in the game world. Can you sense my confusion about it yet?) Additionally, and this may just be me, a certain character was LGBT, and it wasn't clear until the end - my problem is not with the LGBT part, simply the fact that she fearlessly defends her culture, which is one centered around male and female reproduction. This made the inclusion of the LGBT here seem heavy handed, whereas if it had been Elro, it honestly would've fit much better. 


Ending (spoiler thoughts)
The ending is confusing and potentially bad, depending on your point of view, but my biggest thing with it is that
[spoiler] it seems to almost make the game a sort of joke? As in, the whole planet is actually some weird alien's personal ivory gas station for their star worm space ship. Seriously though, why does the blue infection affect the bird as well? I really don't understand it - everything else within the narrative and lore has a place, except for this strange blue infection. [/spoiler]

60773757.review:
Overall: 7.5/10

Game type: 2D Metroidvania-lite platformer

tl;dr: If you like solid platforming/puzzling, good music and a great artstyle, and can put up with a overly ambitious story that the game can't quite tell effectively and some annoying technical quirks, I'd say this is a good buy.

Pros
- wonderful art style
- amazing animations for all characters
- great platforming feel, and the combat is just complicated enough to be satisfying
- puzzles are at the right difficulty, and use interesting mechanics with your weapons
- good music
- nice length
- really creative boss fights

Cons
- The story isn't bad, but it doesn't fit the aesthetic at all, and it feels like a lot of information is missing, leaving the player with many questions.
- Most of the characters are fairly unlikable; I would say that their likability is inversely proportional to how much dialogue they have (which means the main character is fortunately the most likable of the bunch)
- A few of the boss fights are frustrating due to a lack of context on what to do (You'll see what I mean if you fight a boss named Ash)
- Some of the text and dialogue feels like it needed a once-over from an editor for vocabulary usage
- upgrade system isn't really super important, and chests only serve it. Doesn't feel super motivating to get chests, even though they have some fun puzzles.
- Lacking technical polish

Overall I really like this game. When you are doing the platforming and running through and shooting, it feels really tight, and the animations and controls are top notch. It tends to get less fun when you have to deal with a boss without being given a clear method to do damage, and the story is pretty darn dark and serious for the cutesy art style and music. The further into the game you get, the darker it gets. I also feel like more time could have been spent providing more information about the world of the story; I've picked up a fair amount of what the state of the world is, but not how it got that way, or how the antagonistic force in the game came to power, or anything.

Speaking of story, the writing here is hit-or-miss; the developer wanted to go into some deep philosophy about religion, freedom, morality, duty, etc. , but I'm not sure if English is their first language, and it's led to some awkward sentences and conversations in the game that could have been smoothed over. Not a big deal, but it keeps me from giving it a higher score.

I call this a 'Metroidvania-lite' because there aren't that many upgrades, and you don't unlock that many new things in previous locations with them. Revisiting old locations is mostly to get materials to get some small perks (more damage, bigger explosion, free damage hit, etc.). Because these perks (called 'tweaks' in-game) don't significantly change the game, getting materials from the aforementioned chests doesn't feel super rewarding; for the most part you're going to select a set of tweaks that works and rarely change them or build more, so the materials are just a badge of achievement than something you will actively feel the need to look for. That said, the puzzles around the chests can be fun.

Finally a few technical issues that deserve mentioning:
* I've been playing on a computer monitor. When I try fullscreen, there is a ton of screen tearing, and there are no video options in the game to fix this. I do not have this problem when playing windowed, but there is no borderless windowed option, so you'll end up seeing your icons and the title bar doing this. Not the biggest issue, but it is annoying.
* Whenever I die in-game, the window shrinks to a smaller size, and I have to re-expand it. I guess this acts as a deterrent to death, but the issue below explains why I end up having to deal with it more than I like.
* This is the most egregious: a good portion of the time, taking damage gives you iframes that also make your character invisible onscreen while they are active. This means when you take a hit, you have about 2 seconds where you don't necessarily know where you are due to knockback, and if you are surrounded by a lot of things that can do damage, you get stuck in a loop where you continually take damage, become invisible, and try to figure out where you are and if its safe or not. During normal platforming this isn't a big deal, but it's very frustrating in boss fights or when there are many hazards/enemies present. I'm not sure what causes this, but if it would be the number one thing to fix if this game ever gets bug fixes.

The word I can use to describe this game is inconsistent. My own feelings with the game were inconsistent; I wanted to like this game, I really did; but in the end, it felt jarring and rough around the edges.

The graphics are cool and the controls are tight and responsive. The music is GREAT, some of the characters have such great stories (Mina and Black are my personal favorite stories), but that just might be about it for my positives here.

Again, inconsistency. The puzzles are fine, but sometimes rather than being satisfying they end up being frustrating and not worth the effort. At times the ways to get around the map feel clever and unique, other times it feels monotonous, uninspired, and vague. The dialogue is a lot to chew through, and while the plot itself is interesting, it has a lot of ways to lose you in its intricacies. I don't feel like that's a bad thing, but it is something that I can see bothering people.

I wanted to like Iconoclasts a bit more, and yeah, sometimes the puzzles were awesome and gratifying, sometimes the characters really popped out and made the game, some bosses were hype and engaging. But that's just some of the time. I think there's a value to behold for people who like metroidvanias and brainteasing puzzles with a subversive plot, but it just didn't quite hit the right spots with me. 4/10

59486971.review:
Art is wonderful, story works, game length is just right, and characters are really well written.
But core gameplay is аss. It starts nice, lets you master basic mechanics, then doesn't give a shit about what you've just mastered, throwing at you bosses with unique mechanics (which is good!) that are utilized in these only bossfights.
Hitboxes are big, readability is poor, MC is very often lost in visual effects, wrench swings are inconsistent and useless due to the lack of stuns, weapons cooldown feels like eternity and the warmup animations on some attacks just don't exist.
In a correctly designed game you learn how to do basic movement and fighting, apply this experience on bosses that you don't know shit about, learn what works and what's not, master it so it can help in later bosses, and on later bosses you apply everything you know to beat them.
This game: learn basics, fight a new boss, then throw out basics and just learn timings in a few attempts, then beat the boss with little to no health lost.
Tweaks system is a fresh idea, but becomes just dumb later on. You've got youself a nice kit with a roll, cooldown reducer and armor, and guess what, you can't roll in a long bossfight *when it's needed* because it's just broken. Your hp is almost full though.
Cave Story used weapon levels to encourage players to dodge, though you can still fight with lvl1. This game discourages you to use tweaks, because your tweaks become unreliable. Just fill it up with speed boosters and forget that this system exists. Either dodge everything perfectly (hello hitboxes), or just don't bother.
This game wants to be Cave Story, but it can't deliver what it's promised. Dev doesn't seem to play hardcore platformers like the Cave Story much.
I love this game and would probably recommend it, but gameplay-wise it isn't challenging, not even frustrating it's just disappointing. Would recommend playing it on easy modo just to enjoy the art and the story.

59080663.review:
Iconoclasts is a fantastic game, held down by a series of problems. And a note, I had this game gifted to me by a friend.
First and foremost, is inconsistent information. At the start of the game, and enemy jumps at you with a green flash, signalling that you need to hit it with a wrench to make it vulnerable. Then a couple of minutes later, a enemy flashes green and it fires a projectile that you need to deflect. Seems alright? Right? Then much later in the game certain bosses will expect you to just know when to deflect projectiles/stun them with your wrench.
There's a lot of things you can only learn by tanking damage, and would have no way of knowing with what the game has taught you. Certain power ups have applications that you have to learn through trial and error, and certain items seem just barely reachable, before you realise after an hour of trying to jump perfectly that there is in fact a power up to make it work.
Then in another area there is a puzzle, in which I shit you not, you have to first roll a bomb up a slope at a 45 degree angle in the ceiling after jumping in order to get it to push a piston. Seems alright? Well, you also then have to get the exact positioning to get your bomb to roll on the very top of the hill before the slope. It seems like the sort of thing you'd get a power up later to solve, but is in fact just a skill shot. It's never clear whether you should keep grinding on figuring out how to solve a puzzle or if you need a powerup to get further.

However, if you can look past these frustrations and inconsistencies, you'll find a fun metroidvania game with some of the most realistic characters I've ever seen, put in a shitty situation that there isn't a clear solution to, all with different goals, aspirations, beliefs and culture put behind their every action. I was seriously impressed with the writing.
The art could carry the game by itself, and there is a lot of variation in character design. It never once felt like they were trying to cut corners by giving certain characters limited animation. I was especially impressed by the character's animations and art in cut scenes, all of them felt like their own unique character brimming with personality in their every gesture.
There are a multitude of incredibly interesting boss designs, and there are a LOT of bosses. It felt like I was approaching the end of the game around halfway through because of the sheer number of bosses I had fought, with all their own unique mechanics.
Sadly, the bosses also suffer from unique gimmicks you have no way of knowing without taking damage or dying to figure out, because none of it is explained beforehand. But there's a lot of interesting bosses each with their own mechanics. i never once thought that a boss was too similar to one I had fought before.
There a lot of unique and interesting puzzles, that also suffer from the poor explanations of what your kit can actually do, and signs telling you what powerups you need for a certain puzzle. If you want to 100% this game on your first run, you'll need a guide or to comb over the entire game again once you know you have every power up, because doing it after getting a new one in each area is quite frankly painful.

This is a fantastic game that is well worth your time, but will frustrate you with small problems throughout the otherwise great experience. It's worth your money.

A final complaint, with major spoilers ahead, is for the ending.







There's a massive build up, to an anti-climatic ending where the character punches the god of the world, makes a speech bubble about a tree, and then the worlds problems are literally all solved at once for no reason. Could have done with some more explanation, or even better just showing the dead god and fading to black. You might disagree with me, but I didn't like this ending much. Especially after putting all the effort into making realistic characters, only for the main character to fix everything by killing a god. At most it should have stopped the apocalypse, not fixed the world.

58722050.review:
This is a difficult review to make. On one side it's gorgeous art, brilliant story, mostly tight controls and likeable music set this game up for success. Sadly the overall result is a frustrating slog. Like a long walk where mid way through water makes it way in your shoes. After a very charming introduction, your will to play will be slowly sapped. All caused by it's continuous clumsy execution. Thankfully it's quite short.

The tweaks are god awful. A useless and poorly thought out system. I bought a ton and stuck with the first three I ever made except for the swimming point where I had the breathing tweaks. The breaking / repairing system picked up from Cave Story is exactly the opposite of fun. In Cave Story, the gameplay is based on upgrading to more powerful attacks and empowering the player when they do well. This game would have been better without it. 

The enemies are mostly bad and boring. Unless you're locked in a room with them, simply skip them. That could be said for all Metroid like games because it's a feature from design unlike Castlevania like games. However what Metroid likes usually do well is to have inspired enemies that are original and fit in their environment / story. The other thing they do is usually serve to introduce mechanics and give other helpful hints for the story, potential secrets and bosses. Not here.

The bosses all feels like chores except one. The boss battle that satisfied me the most was Chrome. Well executed, entertaining and tight. Very well done. Now obviously that is the result of the great story and could not have been done for all bosses. The main issue with the bad bosses is the gimmicks... that are supported with partial invulnerability. Always. Prepare yourself to see that icon that means your attacks are ineffective because it's going to come up a lot.

Finally the things that is not straight up bad but just clumsy. The dialogue during battle, they're not voiced and will not stop the gameplay. No health upgrades or tweak slot upgrades. The many beautifully drawn NPCs are usually seen once with a single dialogue and they're done. Why such waste?

At least the save system is solid. Five slots! With autosave! NICE.

Thanks.

58644810.review:
[h1] TLDR: Mediocre.. (65 out of 100) [/h1]
[b]Get 'Shantae and the Pirate's Curse' instead.[/b]


Game had potential to be awesome, yet some parts fell flat undermining the whole experience.

[i] Things that went right:[/i]
- presentation: the pixel art is great and remains this way throughout all zones
- bosses: big and well animated, offer multiple attack patterns without the feel of being spammy or stunlocky
- controls: had no issues with those - snappy and responsive (keyboard)

[i] Things that were ok:[/i] 
- genre?: platformer? - sure, but not metroidvania
- music: hit-and-miss; it's fine, but features no catchy melodies or memorable tracks
- puzzles: some rely too much on your key-pressing rather than solving skills
- gore: it feels right in Metal Slug, but in Iconoclasts most of time gore appears to be added for shock values only

[i] Things that went wrong:[/i] 
- story: focus-less, convoluted and overcomplicated mess. The game's world is poorly thought out with player getting showered with heaps of bland exposition monologues. There is also a number of 'controversial' themes, but game never fully commits to a single one. oh and does this game even contain a single joke?
- characters: 90% of the cast is uninteresting, underdeveloped and lacking significant character arc. So many stubborn and selfish chars, yet barely any kind or friendly ones. Not sure how player should relate to any of them (except maybe for the protagonist, though I suspect it's because she gets no lines at all)
- pacing: gets really bad towards the end, with corridors replacing puzzles\challenges. And don't get me started on the final boss?.. it made zero sense.. Did the developer run out of patience\motivation?
- tweaks\crafting: useless mechanic, completed the whole thing with a single 'swing time' upgrade


In summary, a pretty platformer with staggered pacing and incoherent writing.

57254195.review:
Great little metroidvania title with amazing writing. On the basis of its puzzles, combat, platforming, boss fights, and other enemies, I'd probably rate the title about an 8.5 out of 10. These aspects are all very good.

However, the writing is absolutely fantastic. It was substantially above my expectations, and I have very high expectations. The way the plot weaves tragedy with small shreds of hope and mixes occasionally fulfilling those hopes or setting up another tragedy is pretty masterful. Your journey through the world is a very tiny part of something much larger, which you have very little awareness of. This is my favorite type of telling a story, as I love to try to piece things together while I play a game. There are a few 'explanation dumps', but there's still a substantial amount of information that is only explained once or twice. I never felt like the game was hammering home plot points into my brain because the authors felt I would be too dumb to understand, which is something I typically feel in games. Without engaging in spoilers, I'll also say that I particularly enjoyed the ending because it subverted many of my expectations for what would happen.

This isn't even getting started on the characters, who are also very well written. They all have their own current concerns, backstories, and personalities. While your closest companions are the ones who get the most direct characterization, the (mostly silent) protagonist, Robin, also gets characterized, if mostly through actions. She's consistently kind (sometimes to the point of naivete) but also very driven. This makes her kind of a pushover in many regards (in that she can be swayed by smooth-talking), but she's unwilling to budge on her ultimate goals of helping people who matter to her. The rest of the cast is equally well-rounded for the most part, with the only exceptions being minor characters who only make a couple of appearances. Honestly, even that is a strength. A few of the characters who rarely appear are some of the important ones within the enemy organization. Just by chance, Robin's path takes her through some of these figures but not all of them. This is more realistic than fighting an enemy force in an endless series of 1v1s (though there's certainly no shortage of that).

Honestly, in retrospect, I would have bought this game if it was just a video of watching somebody else play it. That's not to say the gameplay is bad, but everything else is just so great.

57155618.review:
This game is bad. 

The dialogue is witty for about 3 hrs in, then it gets tedious af as if somebody else was charged with it. 

The "secrets" are so bad. Either they're blatantly obvious or they are "exactly at this spot you have to jump into the wall" while the "spot" doesn't look any different at all from any other wall. Half the secrets don't show on the map, so essentially finding them is either getting lucky af or hugging every wall on the map. Very innovative. The poorest secrets I have seen in a metroidvanian in ages.

The puzzles are often a chore, because they will refresh. So half the time, once you solve a puzzle, you can go through the room without problems, because they save, the other half they don't, so you spend time doing the same mediocre puzzles again and again if you want to find secrets. 

Half the time the game betrays its own mechanics as in "oh, you can't grab THIS ledge, silly, just because we say so. It looks like a perfectly fine ledge. But you can't, otherwise there would be more than one solution to our garbage puzzles." Again, very poor for metroidvanian standards. Have you played ANY Metroid or castlevania game where you have to do half the puzzles again, because, why the F not? Yeah, I doubt it, too. 

Some enemies have shots you need to parry so you can defeat them, but guess what? There are enemies that tell you, that you have to parry their shots, but still are invulnerable to them. Again, the game betrays its own mechanics. Also, there are literally invulnerable enemies. Fun, right?

The bosses, oh boy. Gimmicky to the max. Started out interesting, then it's just "figure out what the F the game wants you to do, break weakpoint, deal dmg, do it over until next phase, learn pattern", and once you do, there is literally ZERO challenge. Some bosses have super flashy effects, so often it's hard to see what actually hurts your character and what is just a flashy effect. Some bosses literally have a very clear giant attack, and a flash around them, but guess what? All of a sudden, literally everything hurts you. Why go through the effort to make a sprite for an attack, when the blue circle around the boss is the damn hurtbox? WHY!? This game is inconsistent with EVERYTHING.

Also, there are puzzles in the second area that require a weapon you find only five hours later. Altogether the game is ABYSMAL in terms of the tools you get and that you can use. It's a joke, really. This game is a mediocre action platformer, not a real metroidvania after all. 

EVERY character in this game is a complete and utter idiot. Every. Last. One. Artificial drama that even preschoolers would find tedious and it gets worse in every instance, the further you go. 

I mean, the game literally cracks a joke about the unnecessary overusing of "do it all again, go there, fetch three Xs then, go back and do it all again" kind of quest loops, just to literally send you the F around in a loop! Beat area 5? Good, now go to area 2. Not there? Go to area 4. Not there? Try area 3. HAHAHAHA, it was in area 5 all along. Seriously? Fking seriously? AFTER you made the joke about bad quest loops in area 3? Wow. The game literally feels like two different teams worked on the game, the first one was fired after ~3 hours of content. From area 3 on it feels like a bloody chore. No new tools, no nothing. 

Half the time the puzzles and secrets are so abysmal, the game tells you how to use each tool, only to expect you to use them completely differently or just laugh in your face like "lol, I know what I said, it just doesn't do anything!".

I mean, there is literally a note next to 3 boxes saying "do not expose to open electricity or X[redacted for spoiler]".  But if you use your skill that allows you to literally create ball lightning that floats in the air, guess what happens? Yeah, nothing. 

Often, the game will send you from the right end of the area to the middle of the already explored area to continue, because you have to go to the extreme right, trigger a sh*tty cutscene, and all of a sudden, the way is open. That's poor design. Artificially inflating playtime by literally wasting yours. Great job.

Fast travel exists, but as soon as you unlock the machine to do so, you gotta visit every damn area by using it, otherwise you have no chance of knowing (in all but one case) where the access to the fast travel network is. How can you f*ck that up? Metroid didn't even have a fast travel system and still did OK, because it wasn't designed like sh*t! One, singular long map from left to right. Wow, what a good idea. Splendid. And THEN you F up the fast travel system. Good job. 

Controls are OK-ish. Your character has some kind of auto-aim for ranged attacks, problem is only, for some reason, half the time it just doesn't work. And if it does you have to be about 30-50% of the max range of even your already short-ranged basic attacks. Wtf is the deal with that?

Literally EVERYTHING in this game is half-baked and feels like they went with the first idea they came up with, no testing, no revision, no polish, no comments, nothing. From story, to controls, to the way literally everything else works, every aspect of the game seems like 50% effort. 

The pacing is horrible after the first 3 hours. In these the game really feels excellent, is fun and you have the feeling that there is actually some challenge, secrets and you make good progress toolwise, etc. After that, it breaks off, you gain no new abilities and no tools, everything feels like you are running around in circles. Even IF you get something it feels absolutely not impactful or interesting.

You have three "tweak" slots, which get broken one by one every time you take dmg. Some of these actually grant weak and rather uninteresting abilities, some just allow you to deal more melee dmg, negate a single hit or make you hold your breath for longer. Not a fan of that system, for many, many reasons, number 1 being that your hitbox is garbage. Sometimes you get hit in the legs while being well away from the attack, but mind you, if you wanna collect powerups (health you have to collect, everything else flies into, why the hell is it so INCONSISTENT, AGAIN?!), you better catch them with your legs, because the upper half of your character has super-sharp borders and you better be dead center. Arms sometimes don't count, whysoever. How about one or two tweak slots that are "safe"? Oh, and that's it, btw. You start with 3, you finish with 3. The end. Great progression system.

Everything, literally everything is inconsistent as F*CK! Why does your character lose more oxygen per second in smoke than while full breast-stroking through water. ARE YOU AN AMPHIBIAN!? What is it with that? Why can't the game behave the same way it introduced you to it under the same or similar premise?! 

Saving grace: Sound is OK, Soundtrack is fine, graphics are pretty good, the world is interesting enough. But nothing is phenomenal and they made far less out of their world than they could.

The game is a dumpster full of good ideas that were exploited for 50% of their value and then tossed into the garbage. Shame, I hope they get it right the next time, because it could have been a lot better if they stayed consistent with their writing and pacing from the first few hours. 

______________
TL;DR: Game feels like they half-*ssed 50% of literally everything that's in the game, and the unsettling degree of inconsistency is the only consistent variable I found. Also, this game doesn't stick to anything that can be considered a standard for a metroidvanian game for good reasons, making it more of a very weak action platformer than an metroidvanian. Got this for 8 bucks, still feels like too much, since they half-*ssed everything they should get 50% of whatever they are asking for already.

57139428.review: When I first started [b]Iconoclasts[/b], judging by the [b]cutesy, stylized [i]pixel-art[/i] style[/b] and [b]joyful music accompaniment[/b], I expected a [b]heartfelt, quirky storyline[/b] throughout, presented in a [b][i]RPG-y[/i] fashion[/b] - and do not misinterpret my words: [b][i]it is[/i][/b]. However, said [b]imaginative story[/b] is also brimming with [b][i]extremely[/i] gut-wrenching scenes[/b] and [b]deeply political[/b] and [b]religious nuances[/b], even if the [b]main focus[/b] is on our [b]heroine's journey[/b]. If you add the [b]outstanding, [i]puzzle-sque[/i] level design[/b] and [b]heavily technical boss fights[/b] to the lot, you end up with a [b]top-notch [i]metroidvania[/i][/b]. Evidently, that is not to say it is not a [b]flawed creation[/b]: [b]major fights[/b] sometimes have [b]a lot going on [i]visually[/i][/b]; finding the [b]right combos[/b] for each enemy requires a [b]certain amount of trial-and-error[/b]; and [b]certain characters[/b] and [b]plots[/b] - main [i]and[/i] secondary - are [b]presented [i]yet[/i] barely fleshed out[/b]. That said, the aforementioned inconveniences are but a tiny smudge, as [b]Iconoclasts[/b] performs [b]beyond expectations[/b] in every other aspect, and in my book, it has [i]undoubtedly[/i] become a [b]must-play [i]platformer[/i][/b].

Lovely pixel art, interesting worldbuilding. Terrible gameplay, clumsy storytelling.

[i]Iconoclasts[/i] is a game that's bursting with great ideas, but fails to execute them well.
[list]
[*] Each boss battle has unique mechanics, but they're poorly explained and there's no time to practice them. The game dropped me, unprepared, into frantic melees and expected me to figure out new movesets [i]and[/i] boss attack patterns all at once.
[*] There are plenty of interesting puzzles, but the platforming is far too floaty and imprecise. Ironically, here the game runs into the opposite problem: I knew [i]what[/i] I had to do, but struggled to maneuver my character in order to [i]get it done[/i].
[*] A lot of thought went into the world and the characters. Unfortunately, very little of it comes through while playing the game. I could only make sense of the narrative [i]afterwards[/i], by reading other people's summaries and re-watching cutscenes on YouTube.
[/list]

It's really a pity, but I did not enjoy my time with the game and cannot recommend it.

56394607.review:
So I'll get this out of the way: I haven't beaten the game yet (I'm at [spoiler]The Tower and just freed Elro and Mina[/spoiler], but I love it so much I wanted to right a review. 

I got Iconoclasts through a giveaway and knew nothing about it aside from what the main character looked like, not even who developed the game or what the age rating was. Due to her oversized wrench and funky hairdo I thought this was going to be a cute, silly game. Then [spoiler]she got called a harlot within the first fifteen minutes of the game[/spoiler] I'm not sensitive to that sort of stuff, but wasn't expecting that. It just got darker as time went one, but I won't go into that for fear of spoilers.

Gameplay is pretty fun, you have two weapons, a wrench and a gun that can use different ammo as time goes on. I have gotten stuck a few times due to the fact that I forget that when there is a small gap your character needs to be able to hang off it to crawl through it OR be on the same level as it. There's a few parts where you are slightly lower than the gap, not lower enough to use it as a handhold, and can't do anything with it. 

The art is also super fun, despite being pretty pixelated it's very detailed, especially for bosses. My computer sucks (sometimes even Minecraft is too much for it) and this game runs beautifully which was a nice surprise.

The music is weird, but in a good way. That's the only way I can describe it, I'm going to try to get the OST some time.

This next part is going to be mostly spoiler tagged, just in case, it details the mechanics of a certain boss battle. 
My biggest complain would be how the game does throw you into situations head first sometimes [spoiler]During the boss battle where Robin and Mina tag team to beat the guardian robot you need to switch between the two while fire, bombs, and smaller enemies are being rained upon you. This is the first time you can play as Mina and her play style is way different than Robin's involving having to stand still to aim her weapon among other things. I died several times to that boss just trying to figure out how to play Mina well.I would have appreciated a chance to be able to use her in a less stressful situation, maybe the wall comes up before the battle starts and you need to play as her to trigger the fight so you can get a feel for her controls?[/spoiler]

Overall, if you're willing to get frustrated sometimes I'd totally recommend this game! Also there are difficulty settings that you can change every time you get on so you can tailor your experience every time.

This is a thoroughly 7/10 metroidvania. I think $20 is too much for it compared to what you could get elsewhere, but on sale it's not a bad pick up for fans of the genre. It's worth noting that it's almost more of a puzzle platformer than metroidvania, but it's a blurry line. 

The art is pretty great, and the stand out part of it. Movement is pretty good. Combat is a low point outside of boss battles, but it's also not as prolific as many other games. Most of the bosses are fairly original and creative, however almost every one of them has at least one or two moves that are completely impossible to understand what to do without trial and error, which is bad. Iconoclasts is agame with an amazing story and extremely well written characters. 

I did not know what to expect when I first played the game, I had seen the game before and was out of metroidvanias to play so this was my next target. 

While not a true metroidvania, the dev called it more of a puzzle platformer which fits a lot better. 
This does not mean there is not any exploration as there is plenty of exploring to do, not only gameplay wise but also the amazing amount of details in the background which gives more hints as to what is going on in the world as well as backstory. 
I have played through the game numerous times at this point and I still find myself playing it again to spot some detail in the background or to find some more hidden dialogues, as there are a few of those.

The story and characters as mentioned earlier are excellent and I got really attached to them, especially Royal and Elro.
I don't really want to go into too much details as the story is something special and should be enjoyed without knowing too much as the surprises will be a lot heavier then.  But what little I will say is that it gets pretty heavy and very emotional.

The spritework is amazing and there are so many small details even with them and they are very energetic and full of life. 

Last and not least the music. The music fits very well and Konjak sure does have some musical talent. A few of my own favourite tracks would be "Mother", "Indoctrination", "Moonlight", "Castle Doctrine" and my absolute favorite "Descent".

I cannot recommend this game more than enough and I am sure that this game will remain with me for a long time as one of my favorite games of all time. 
What are you waiting for, go and play it!

55432172.review:
The game looks incredible - and that's what really sold me on it, few pixelated games look anywhere near this good - , but I really wish I had read other reviews of this game before I bought it. The plot - whilst occasionally humorous - is both overly ambitious and underwritten. It's at times almost incomprehensible, with this melodramatic Metropolis-esque dystopian theocratic story that often doesn't reflect the tone of of the game, the visuals, nor what you're actually doing outside of boss fights, which is laboriously backtracking through labyrinthian maps fighting monsters that are - so far at least - totally unconnected to the main plot. It's actually a real turn-off - it's impossible to care about this story. 

That's not what matters though. It's a passion project of one person, so in the face of the gorgeous visuals, a lackluster plot is totally acceptable - not every first major release by a solo developer can be Cave Story. However, the problem here is the gameplay, which is occasionally fun but gets more and more tedious as it goes on. A lot of the time the game doesn't even hint at what it actually wants you to do, which was acceptable in the early 90s to an extent, but not today. I'm only on Isilugar, the third level of the game, and already I'm ready to put this game down for good. The puzzles just get increasingly tedious, the fights moreso - I'm fighting this group of robots at the minute, 2 at a time, that almost act like minibosses considering the ludicrous amount of health that they have, and it's just totally joyless. There's no tension, no feeling of reward when I eventually win after dodge + jump + shoot shoot shoot for 8 minutes or so, it's just a total chore. The game might pick up later, but unless someone else recommends I keep going with it - and it seems no-one else who has pointed out the same flaws that I've noticed so far would do so, since even a few genuine fans of this game still seem disappointed with the ending - I'm out. 

It's a shame, because with some assistance with the actual gameplay element of the game and perhaps a ghostwriter to help sort out the plot a bit, this chore of a game could easily have been a minor masterpiece. It's not that the developer doesn't know how to program a game - this isn't a game that suffers from glitches, in fact a lot of the time the programming is too precise - it's that he doesn't seem to understand - or care - what fans of this genre want. Look again at Cave Story - a metroidvania which is visually far more simplistic but still very evocative, with a wonderfully written story and gameplay which is frequently challenging - especially if you go to hell - but is never not fun. If this game had even been like 50% tedious 50% fun I would have stuck it out for longer, but the more I play it, the higher the tedious ratio gets.

55226205.review:
Excellent game! Easily the best $20 I have spent on a video game in a long while. Iconoclasts is a fun game that has a limited number of mechanics, but a surprising amount of ways to implement them. The puzzles are appropriately difficult, there were a couple of head-scratchers but nothing that couldn't be solved with some out of the box thinking. Where the game truly shines are the boss battles, which are fun and engaging, and pleasantly varied. One boss requires multiple phases where you switch between two characters. Another simply relies on learning the patterns and knowing when to dodge. One is a slightly annoying "stealth" fight. Every one however, is enjoyable and requires you to adapt to the bosses' gameplay style, which goes beyond using whatever mechanic the game just introduced.

In terms of story, it's pretty good, probably a 4/5. The game does its best to tackle big issues, and does give you a good amount to think about. There are cutscenes that feed well into boss fights, and the carnage that you wreak in the name of your quest will give you second thoughts about if you're doing the right thing. Pacing is good as well as dramatic elements, though some may seem cheesy at first. The characters are endearing and while the story has a rough start and leaves some plot threads unresolved, I enjoyed it. How it affects other players may vary, and is ultimately up to personal preference. Story is definitely more JRPG than traditional platformer.

If I have any criticisms with the game, it is that occasionally there is too much happening on screen, during both gameplay and cutscenes. In one instance, a boss fight in an elevator takes place during a plot critical conversation in the next room, requiring me to dodge the enemy's blows while trying to keep up with the plot. The music is well done, though it lacks a staying power (don't buy the soundtrack, is all I'm saying). There are a few stages where I wondered a stage aimlessly trying to find the way to the objective, though that may just be my own insufficiency in playing Metroidvania games. There are also sidequests that have minimal impact on the story, but you'd be forgiven for forgetting them.

Despite my criticisms, I had a thoroughly enjoyable time, clocking my first run at 11 hours. The game does a lot well, and I would encourage everyone who likes action-adventure platformers to try it. There are also aftergame features, such as a boss rush and new game +. I won't retry immediately, but I'm sure I'll return soon to give it another go. 4/5

55185782.review:
I'm going to leave my original negative review in place below, but I've since come back and finished the game, so I think it's worth revising my opinion.

My first game file was the one that prompted the review below. But I have a hard time leaving a game unfinished, especially right at the very end. So I reinstalled and started a fresh game file. I got bored really quickly, as everything was still a little too fresh. I moved on to other games and gave Iconoclasts a long rest. For close to a year.

Given plenty of time away from the game, I came back and started it up fresh with a third game file. Here are my thoughts, this time after actually finishing the game with 98% completion:

- Story: For the most part, I haven't changed my opinion here, except to soften it regarding the dialogue. It's still obtuse and preachy, but you can just skip it if you don't care. With the ending under my belt, I can say the story between the lines is much more interesting than what happens in the game. It has a few potent emotional beats and a decent plot structure, but it's probably not going to wow you unless you get something profound out of the dialogue. The lore and worldbuilding are where it's at with this game.

- Mechanics: Thoughts here are pretty much the same as below. I don't know that I'd call it a metroidvania, but that's fine. Fast travel (which I didn't mention before) is a little clunky, but makes it easier to go back and collect items you missed, once you find all the travel points.

- Combat: It's still probably the least impressive gameplay element, but it's not as bad as I made out originally. Some of the tweaks that require Ivory Oil can modify it in useful ways, like adding a dodge roll or making the Usurper Gun go through walls. Also, said Usurper Gun will often, but not always, trivialize puzzle based enemies. The frustrating combat challenge was not so bad this time around. Maybe I'm just better at games now or maybe I was looking for an excuse to quit. It still killed me once, but that's not terrible at all.

- Bosses: I still think the best bosses are the puzzle bosses. They make more use of the unique skillset Robin brings to the show. I even cleared an optional pure combat boss fight this time and hoo boy was that rough.

- Player Characters: Yeah, don't make me play Elro or Mina ever again. Especially for their respective boss fights.

I came away this time with a more positive view of the game, but Iconoclasts is still not for everyone. It's probably not even for me, to be honest, but it's a decent effort all around. Give it a try if it looks interesting to you, but keep your finger near that start button and don't be afraid to press it if the dialogue isn't your cup of tea.

-------

Very early on, there was something about the game that made me question whether I wanted to finish it or not. Aabout halfway through, I was absolutely certain I wouldn't be getting 100% item collection and still couldn't decide if I wanted to actually finish the story. In basically the eleventh hour, something happened that frustrated me so much I decided to quit playing and uninstall the game. Here's what I think about the experience in more detail:

- Story: It's serviceable whenever the characters aren't talking. There's a decent flow from location to location with nice little lore bits scattered throughout the world. However, the dialogue basically ruins any enjoyment. It's obtusely written with long winded monologues and preachy philosophical ramblings toward the player poorly hidden behind the religious conflict in the game.

- Mechanics: As a metroidvania style platformer with an engineer as the main character, Iconoclasts does well to focus much of its moment to moment gameplay around puzzle solving. In general, those puzzles are fairly well designed with solutions that make sense once you figure them out. However, a few of them can be almost as obtuse as the dialogue. Like a metroidvania, upgrades to your equipment will open up new solutions to (often) old puzzles/locked doors you had to pass by the first go round. However, those upgrades seem to come at fairly random intervals without any real fanfare and the split up world structure means you typically have to go out of your way to go back to a given puzzle rather than organically circling back around to it.

- Combat: Iconoclasts falls really flat here, in my opinion. There are a lot of different types of enemies, and many of them try to be a mini puzzle to solve. That's fine the first time you see an enemy, but it can become grating the tenth or twentieth or fiftieth time. There's nothing wrong with giving you a way to dispatch old enemies more quickly after a few encounters. Hopefully without spoiling anything, the thing that made me want to finally quit playing was a really frustrating combat challenge that added more puzzle mechanics onto enemies I'd seen before.

- Bosses: There's an interesting sort of variety in the boss encounters in Iconoclasts. Some of them act more like puzzles to solve, while others focus almost entirely on combat. In general, I prefer the puzzle bosses, because they play to the strengths of the gameplay design, whereas combat focused bosses tend to just be exercises in frustration until you learn their patterns.

- Player Characters: This deserves special attention because it is a uniquely frustrating aspect of the game. Robin (the blonde with the wrench) is the player character for a vast majority of the game's playtime. While not necessarily incredible for combat, her mechanics do feel cohesive and fairly well polished. And being that you spend a lot of time with her, you at least become familiar enough with them to make things work even when they're being obtuse. However, there are a few times throughout the story where you are forced to play as a different character to advance some aspect of the plot off in a different part of the world. None of these feel particularly good to play, and I think it's because the alternate characters just don't feel as polished or put together as Robin. Two of those character cutaways are actually necessary boss fights, and they're closer to what I'd call combat bosses rather than puzzles. They are simply not fun gameplay moments. There are also a couple situations where you have to switch back and forth between characters and I don't particularly care for those either.

All in all, if you can get past its flaws, Iconoclasts might be a good game for you. I just don't think I can recommend it in the long run, particularly because it frustrated me to the point of quitting so close to the end.

54966930.review:
A misleading experience from the start that quickly spirals into a disjointed and whiplash inducing headache. It's like the game had two directors, one that really wanted a light hearted fun experience, and one that wanted a super dark existential story. The characters motivations and behaviour make no sense whatsoever. It's like they took generic Shantae-esque genre characters along with their happy go lucky dialogue and stuck them in a totally different tone and setting. 

You could say the story is at least candid when it comes to death and metaphors about religion, philosophy and good intentions, but the story pays absolutely zero respect to any of these concepts and has nothing of value to add to any of these topics. 

The gameplay is boring and straight forward. The "customization" aspect of the game as laughably terrible, with only 3 slots to use and precious little variety in the tweaks you can craft. The variety in combat and puzzle solving is abysmal, all revolving around your 2 weapon options for 75% of the game (You get a third near the end) and somehow fails to meet the bar Megaman set decades ago. 

Truly a waste of money and time. Only buy if you find the idea of playing a female Forrest Gump in a post apocalyptic world filled with horribly written jerks morbidly fascinating.

54604971.review:
A charming platformer with challenging puzzle and action sections that, despite occasionally landing me in spots of relatively high resistance that took some time and effort to overcome, easily earns my recommendation.

There's more quality to the story than a year or two of big budget triple-A shovelcrap games combined. You've got your varied, exceedingly human characters who act, react, experience different emotions and occasionally freak out. Almost as if they're people, right? It's almost a story about ourselves, as much as it's a story about them.

However deeply or shallowly you want to take it, Iconoclasts is nice to look at, fun to play, pleasant to listen to, packed with nostalgic retro style and a great deal of passion and polish. It's a varied and delightful journey with the occasional sucker punch thrown in to make sure you're engaged and paying attention.

So if you're interested, buy it. And the next time some pretentious self-proclaimed genius poses the nonsensical question, "Can video games be art?"
...Just tell 'em, "Yep. Go play Iconoclasts."

Highly recommended!

54576150.review:
A very well-rounded puzzle-platformer with some light-metroidvania elements and a strong focus of plot. 

The gameplay flow very well overall. Upon finishing the game and thinking back, there is not a single section that I dread replaying, much to the credit of the game directing. There is however a problem with the difficulty: the game is overall too easy. The puzzles, while not insulting, never require more than 20min of thought. Likewise, most encounters (minus a certain pair of hidden bosses) can be overcome within 2 or 3 attempts at the highest difficulty available during your first playthrough. That said, there are some secret scenes and dialogues that you probably won't discover on your first attempt. These aren't vital, but it gives some insight into minor background and side quest characters.

Regarding the plot, it's a comedic adventure that ends up as a tragedy as you uncover just how broken the cast is, both from their past and from the events that occur during the game, all while still keeping the comedic elements and cutesy visuals. Weather or not that's your cup of tea will affect your enjoyment of the final product. The world building is small but sufficient, and much like its themes, leaves a lot fridge horrors blank for the player to dig into. 

Overall it's neat little gem of game that is worth the price and time investment.

The most annoying thing about the game is that sometimes it's unclear wtf you need to do for some boss fights. There was one fight where involved hiding inside bushes took me a good 10 minutes to figure out what to do. Had no issues with any other fight. Part of the gameplay is to figure out what to do for the bosses since it is mostly a puzzle game.

Overall, I'd recommend, though if you're looking for a solid metroidvania, I don't think this is really one. There are better options for metroidvanias. It is an above average game for platformers in general.

54333096.review:
Iconoclasts is a solid 2D action exploration game with some issues but it doesn't break the experience. Don't be fooled by the tags of Metroidvania.  The art, action and story telling style is more comparable to Cave Story. Here are some observations I've made.

The animation of the characters remind me more of a game that would be geared toward children but man.. it's jarring to see some mature themes set played out in a Scribblenauts aesthetic.  Be aware of that if you are playing with someone that isn't "ready to handle themes of loss or brutality or censorship or misguided religion", you might want to avoid playing with them.   Maybe a different art style would help?

The protagonist is affected by "mute syndrome".  There is little known about her personality or her deposition before and after key events.  For all we know, she could be a super cheery and optimistic person then turning resolute to make it to the end but we just don't know for sure. The lack of definitive dialog takes away from this character. While on the opposite side, all the support characters flaws and quirks are exaggerated.  The protagonist doe not have anything to complement the support characters.  All of these characters were in position to play a big part of the interactions and when they join the protagonist on her adventure but nothing really significant is brought about it.  The characters and party system seems intentionally unfinished and leaves a noticeable void.

The action overall seems easy on standard mode. The platforming action and combat is akin to what Cave Story offered back in the day.  The bosses are unique to the themes that it had making it endearing but not really memorable per se.  It might get a little frustrating with some areas not completely logical but whatever. 

The equipment system is pretty basic and the "tweaks" system seems like there could have been more done with it.  Also the restriction of 3 tweaks at any time seems odd.  A lot of resources could be gained through tracking chests but it doesn't seem to amount to much other than minor advantages.  I hope the sequel "buffs" the use of the tweaks and makes it something that the protagonist can use to create a noticeable influence on their play style.

One thing that has been done well was the exploration and backtracking experience.  While some boxes are easy to find, other secrets are especially well done and are rewarding to find. 

While Iconoclasts is a solid game in its own respect, there are quite a few things here and there that are "slightly" off making the game feel weird at times.  Cave Story is a masterpiece in its time pioneering something that hasn't been seen back in its day.  However, I can't give that same pass to Iconoclasts as it should learned from some of the issues that Cave Story encountered and repeated those same issues and not followed what has worked for other games.

The story has a weird unfolding which left me with a "unfinished/inconsistent" feeling, in other words with a "iconoclasts 2 ???" feeling. Maybe it's too much of a stretch for me.
That said, the pixel gfx is _really_ amazing, the music is ok (relative to my taste), and the gameplay mechanics is sharp and good, just felt a bit messy. I do humbly think that iconoclasts would have been even greater with more polish given to a shorter experience.
The gnu/linux\steamos port is perfect.
Only insane people would not recommend this game.

54201596.review:
It's hard to find anything wrong with this game. The gameplay is fun, the level design is excellent, the graphics are great, the puzzles are simple but thought-provoking, and the music and SFX are well-done. The story is wonderful, full of rich, realistically-flawed personalities with conflicting goals. It has some great moments that really tug on the heartstrings.

The lore is trickled through to the player in a way that kept my interest up the entire game. Left me with a lot of unanswered questions but enough hints to come up with my own ideas. Personally I really like that type of thing. It leaves me with a craving after I finish the game.

My only complaint is that there isn't more of it!

54155683.review:
Very fun and interesting game from a developer that surprised with his creativity, many times before(check out Noitu Love 2 and other games on his page). This game is presented like an open-world platformer, but it's way more focused on the puzzle platformer aspect. It feels like a huge bundle of good ideas. It's as if the developer put a lot of effort to think an original way to implement every aspect of the game.
The world is pretty linear even though you can visit most of the places you've been before, at a latter stage in the game. The aesthetics are very pretty and unique, in the nice style the designer has shown before. There isn't much to say about the enemies, but the game strength are the puzzles, so it's not too bad, but the bosses are AMAZING. They are just another puzzle teasing you to find out how to damage them while sometimes, another character is helping you fight it, and you have to figure both the enemies and your companion times. There's a lot of action, even in scenes where nothing much seems to be happening, background characters may pass by interrupting conversations, it's very dynamic. The story is very wacky, but with serious conflict, and very rich.

54140169.review: I often actively search for games with great stories, and feel somewhat wronged that I never came across Iconoclasts in those searches. I went in just expecting a nice looking pixel metroidvania, but this game has a world, characters, and dramatic moments that will be with me for a long time. It deserves a place at the top of anyone's list of best game stories.

54130866.review:
Wow, what a game!
I've finally finished it. I tried it when it was released but dropped for some reason. Something bored me as far as I remember.
Sometime later during this year summer sale I purchased it on steam (sale price, yeah, nothing to be proud of, but I may buy it again later to thank the developer), decided to give it another try and this time I finished it with 100% tweaks and achievements. One-hit challenge mode I'll leave for the next playthrough somewhere in the future.

I was waiting for this game since I played alpha-version in 2012. I fell in love with those pleasant sounds (for instance, Robin jumping and running and working with wrench), music, controls and beautiful colorful pixel graphics. As it turned out it's a very serious work. The story is for elder people, I think and it so much triggered in my head because there are themes I care about and try to understand too.
Music is charming as well. It beautifully makes mood for each location. I most of all loved the piece of Blockrock before the final fight. Such a spooky, calm, soothing and nostalgic tune! Like I heard it somewhere, but I'm sure it's just a tune he created under influence from games of our common past. 
This game has so much of that retro-charm! And a true adventure too, my favorite genre! A lot of secrets to find, places to visit, people to talk to and things to find and upgrade. Just what I like.
Oh, and those bosses!!! Amazing experience. It's very interesting to fight each of them. Battle system and all damage effects are very pleasant. Colorful fickers when you hit an enemy is something I love in retro games; also there are some comic-like video effect when you hit someone. All this is a sign of a very thoroughful attention to details.
What's the most charming is characters pixel animation. Robin had it the most ) Very very cute animated poses, emotions, actions. And lots of them. Some only to be used once ) That's how creator Joakim loved his main character! I was so surprised and touched seeing Robin SPOILER, DO NOT READ WHO DIDN'T PLAY sitting in the lotos pose instead of on all fours as usual in location closer to the end :) SPOILER ENDS HERE 
That's sooo cute! )
And those beautiful text boxes in game... People, you won't see this often. It's a work of art. You are like playing a comic book. And letters express person's emotions with changing size, colors, movement and speed of being drawn. Something similar is used in recent Katana Zero.

Unfortunately, there are some cheap animations - like a water splash or trees growing and some more, it's a common practice nowadays - Rayman origins, Ori, again above mentioned Katana Zero and a lot more, they all use that. I call it plastic animation. Maybe made out of time economy. 
But hey. No grudge. Those games are fun. We are all not without a sin! ;) Especially considering a man did all by himself. It looks ok in the game, but a bit sticks out. I just always aim for perfect animation, I know that's a problem maybe. And perfect animation is hard. So I guess I'm nitpicking here. Overall the game is very very pretty!
I'm glad for you, developer of this masterpiece! It took some time off your life, but you fulfilled your dream and created a good thing! Finished sinners won't understand what it's about, but you didn't make it for them, did you? ;) You did it for yourself. And I like what you did very much. I also dreamt about making a game... Maybe there's still time. Hey, what if every gamer made own game? Own work of nostalgia... I think that would be awesome! We rely on companies too much, but look what one man can do.
All the best to everyone! If you like platform and adventure retro games, you'll most likely like this cutie.

54122573.review:
The first thing I want to say is that Iconoclasts isn't really a metroidvania. It's got some aspects of it, but it's a bit closer to an action platformer like megaman X than a metroidvania. Some backtracking, some upgrades, some exploration, but not that much.

That being said, Iconoclasts is an amazing game.

It has great music, great controls are snappy and tight, story is pretty good, the puzzles make you think, the characters are enjoyable, and the main character is cute as a button. Fairly long. I played it on the hardest difficulty with few deaths, and have nearly 100% completion. But it's just damn good.

The only cons i'd say is the story does get kinda obtuse and leaves a lot that you want to know more about or get explained, and a couple points in the game the way forward gets a little but obtuse. 

Overall this game is wonderful, and if you like action platformers, this one is an absolute gem. Some people may feel differently at some points, but you can't deny the heart and character put into this game.

54122513.review: Cute graphics, decent movement control (key mapping would be better remapped), just don't think it's going to hold my interest. Would be worth picking up on deep discount Steam sale (maybe $5)

54117099.review:
This game was a rather large disappointment, let's break it down:

Gameplay - 3.5/5 - The game's controls are adequately tight, but not much is explained and there are definitely some counter-intuitive things that will trip you up. Did you know you can basically double-jump by charging a shot and firing it downwards when you jump? I didn't until 90+% of the way through the game.

Story - 2/5 - There's an interesting world here, too bad that it's so covered in BS that you never get to experience much of it. Storylines and showpieces are introduced and hinted about and then dropped like nothing. This story is jumbled, confusing, and overly obtuse.

Characters - 1.5/5 - The cast of characters in this game give you nothing to care about. The protagonist's brother is a worthless dick who is constantly being both condescending and jerky, and he's one of the better characters.

Overall - 2/5 - Skip this one, it's a waste of time and there are far better metroidvania games out there.

54100727.review:
As much as I want to like this, I just can't. Let's go over pros and cons for me to express why, because I don't want to write paragraphs of opinions in this review.

Pros:
- Great pixel-art
- Pretty interesting and solid lore, overall good writing
- The music is pretty nice
- Some mechanics are actually enjoyable (swinging and jumping from bolt to bolt, riding powered rails (especially when charged up), power-stomping and sliding on top of curved surfaces as the result)
- A lot of jokes and overall humor are also pretty good 

And now, cons:
- Tweaks (will get more in-depth about them a bit later)
- Game fails a lot of the times at telling you what you need to do exactly (Ash's boss fight, top side of the ice block, waiting for the Silver Watchman to teleport first and much more)
- Puzzles become more and more tedious as you progress, eventually turning into a chore that you just want to get done with and never touch again
- Hitboxes. Yes. (more of a minor issue honestly, but I did struggle a lot in the Impact Zone because the charged shot didn't hit the eyes pretty much all the time)
- Smoke, gas, etc in the places where they are just overkill (again, more of a minor issue because it was not nearly as common)
- Absurdity of the final boss (of course not saying what it is, but in my opinion it honestly fucks with the lore and doesn't give any explanation whatsoever)
- Movement could be a tiny bit more fluid just to make dodging things easier (without the tweak, that is) 
- Horrendous level design and enemy placements later in the game (especially Impact Zone)

Now, about the tweaks. First of all, gathering materials for actually useful ones requires Ivory Oil, which is mostly rather hidden, and you need quite a bit to even make a couple of tweaks. Sure, you could look up a walkthrough, but it's nearly not as fun or exciting as finding them on your own. But this, again, is more of a minor issue, even though you do miss out on some cool stuff without them. 
Second, the biggest issue I have with them is the fact that they break and their durability. I understand that if they wouldn't break it would have probably been somewhat overpowered, but trying to balance very low durability by collecting bits from enemies is just dumb. It takes like 3-4 hits for all of them to break, and honestly most of the benefits (except Iron Hearts and the ones that require Ivory, of course) are not even that significant. You could at least make it so that they fully or at least partially repair at the save shrines like how it restores health, but no. 

tl;dr negatives overweigh positives from my personal experience, so I can't recommend it for the gameplay at all, but if you want some good writing and smooth pixel art and animations, then go ahead, up to you
overall, 5/10

54083205.review:
I highly recommend Iconoclasts. 

The art style and soundtrack immediately make the player feel at home in the unique world the game builds, and as the story continues the world becomes more real, fleshed out, and intriguing. Progressing through Iconoclasts' world was a unique experience from a gameplay standpoint, as well. The puzzles scattered across the world often require some thought, but aren't frustrating. I'm no puzzle game master, but there were very few instances in the game where I had to resort to a walkthrough for a solution. The new tools and ideas are introduced little by little, increasing both the number of tricks in your arsenal and the number of different puzzles the game throws at you. 

As soon as I started the game, I began to grow attached to the main character, and since then many of the more minor characters have also earned a place in my heart. The story itself is phenomenal, and it's what made me feel a connection to the characters and their journey. Every protagonist is sympathetic, whether you agree with them or even like them, giving the narrative a satisfying degree of realness. The antagonists, while not always sympathetic, have personalities that are crafted to make you love them, or, failing that, crafted to make them fun to hate. 

The fights against said antagonists are somewhat difficult but not impossible. They all leave an impact on the player, whether it comes in the form of a boss requiring twitch reflexes, or a boss requiring slow, methodical strategy. The game is very good at creating dramatic tension, and making a fight feel epic or daunting. As you progress through the game, the sense of scale of the story grows wider and wider, with more pressure mounting on your shoulders as the stakes are drastically raised.

Overall, I'd give the game a 9/10. It's definitely worth your money and deserves a place in the modern metroidvania hall of fame.It carves out its own niche to stand out against many other games trying to do the same thing it successfully accomplishes. The only con I can think of is that the tweak system is almost completely irrelevant. That didn't hurt my view of the game much, it's just a strange inclusion for a mechanic that's unnecessary and barely affects your experience for better or for worse.
