54022830.review:
An astoundingly detailed, well crafted and thorough story driven platformer which is otherwise spoiled at times by extremely frustrating moments.

The story begins almost immediately and fully establishes the narrative rapidly without ever stumbling. It goes on to construct a highly unique and complicated world filled with very real and genuine characters. The world is surprisingly deep and the story surprisingly serious despite how colourful and streamlined the game otherwise looks. The only real weakness in the story is that certain concepts towards the end are not fully explained to the player, which leaves them uninformed on the nature of why certain things are happening. The plot is executed near flawlessly otherwise and is honestly both indicative and worthy of being its own film or novel.

The gameplay itself is smooth while being decently varied and creative with the various mechanics. It certainly does feel distinguished among other platformers. However the tweak system is quite lackluster. Not only are there a limited amount to pick from but they don't even matter half the time if the player is getting damaged a lot. Virtually all of the collectibles in the game are either tweak unlocks or resources for tweaks, so in turn the collectibles in the game are quite boring. It seems like as the game progresses there ends up being less and less reasons to actually fight using melee when the gun is so blatantly easier and stronger. Then eventually only a specific mode for the gun becomes appealing as it is the most blatantly powerful mode, so the game invalidates a lot of the players combat options by the end. Aiming diagonally with the gun is barely possible or responsive at times, while aiming with the other gun you control during certain points of the game is extremely finicky.

The side quests are one of the worst parts the game. They are incredibly pointless, tedious and unfun. Basically, pick up this item and take it literally maps away to another place then come back to where you got it and quest complete. Maybe, you might have to do that multiple times, literally multiple times; to get the quest complete. The game would be better off if they did not exist as they are not fun, they seem to be designed to waste the players time and the rewards are lackluster. Yet players are tricked into indulging them for the sake of gameplay and rewards, only to simply have their time wasted for near to nothing or eventually just give up and stop doing them since they are blatantly frustrating and unenjoyable. That half hour spent grinding them before realizing this is pointless and not worth it, thus giving up and going back to playing the actual game; that half hour really is a stain on the early game.

The art is solid but it is the animations that really make it special, there are so many animations in the game for various characters and events with them all being quite fluid. The music manages to be fairly unique with a good variety to the various tracks. The character design is exceptional, lots of different cast members and they are all interesting and thoroughly scripted. Although, it would be nice if the female characters had less blatantly sexualized outfits. The intention with that wouldn't be as noticeable if so much effort hadn't been put into making the protagonist's pixelated buttocks look so tight and plump at all times. And they go out of their way to make her turn around so you can see it often.

The boss battles are utter genius, it's practically unparalleled how unique they are all while still being enjoyable and satisfying to fight. But the save system could of not existed. It really doesn't add anything onto the game besides the tedium of having to save periodically, and the wasted time of being knocked back to the last save if you lose. This is especially prominent during the three phrased boss towards the end where; the first phase is cinematically beautiful but the second phase is extremely trial and error based. So everytime you die to the second phase, you have to waste your time with the first phase again and have the entire cinematic appreciation of it ruined since you're playing through the same intense story sequence over and over. In general the end of the game starting at the bastion is the point where it begins to get unfun, the difficulty just comes from players being forced to fight groups of enemies whose attack patterns contradict each others. So you can't fight properly since you're always getting hit by something.


The early game anger of discovering, then forsaking, the side quests combined with the late game anger of that one three phase boss fight and all the obnoxious enemy spam encounters before and after; severely wounds the overall experience. While the production value of the game is monumental, and the quality of the story and bosses is marvelous; those sequences of annoying tediousness that the game goes through are incredibly unfortunate.

This was still brilliant as a whole, and the story straight up deserves to be adapted into a film or novel; but it really is still hard to look back on it without thinking of those extremely frustrating moments. But, knowing the side quests should be ignored and playing the game on normal difficulty; hopefully would make it significantly more tolerable otherwise.

54004557.review:
Iconoclasts is an amazing single player story with incredible pixel art. It is fairly short but full of puzzling action from beginning to end. It easily is among the better games on Steam.

The game is beautiful, Every single pixel in every part of this game is just placed perfectly, And by every piece i really mean every piece, The Menu, The HUD and ofcourse the game itself. It is easy to fall in love with the graphics. The soundtrack is also amazing, it enhances the game every second. It truly exceeds in every aspect.

The Story is about Robin, Her father died recently, he was a mechanic, Robin wants to be a Mechanic too. In the universe they live people get assigned jobs, Private practices are also prohibited. You meet a lot of interesting characters who all have their own personality. Robin needs to go to the moon and back in order to save the world. It truly is a great story but i won't give any spoilers. 

Robin has a wrench, Which can turn bolts, kill enemies, reflect projectiles, charge energy, Robin also has a stungun which can be shot in succession or be charged for a more powerfull attack, There are more weapons to unlock, One Allows you to fire grenades and rockets, another one allows you to shoot a powerfull attack that makes you teleport to solve puzzles.

The controls are just right, Robin always does what you tell her to do. The game is pretty easy on Hard, But Challenge mode is a real challenge, one hit and you go back to your last manual save point. Some things are near impossible to perfect, So for those insane difficulity gamers, This one might be a challenge.

There are more than 20 unique bosses with their own attacks and their own weaknesses, If you die from a boss you get to retry right away, No need to load the previous save. If you are up for the challenge there is also a boss rush mode which allows you to set a time for beating all bosses in succession.

Robin has 16 unlockable tweaks, some of which you can stack. Some give you abilities, like double jump, combat roll, meditate to fill tweak slots, others make you faster give you a extra hit without losing any life, make your wrench do more damage or make Robin hold her breath longer. You can adjust your tweaks at any time, but you can only choose 3 at a time.

There is also a new game plus mode, which lets you keep your tweaks but not your wrench and weapons. It does not make the game harder, But challenge mode is a challenge enough of itself. 

In short Iconoclasts is one for the collection. I give it a solid 10. everything about this game is awesome. It all melts together into a masterpiece that should be played by everyone.

Thanks for watching my video, If you liked it, please let me know, I am also open for suggestions on games to review and any questions are welcome.

53997085.review:
Cute Waifu with a bigass wrench fights the Catholic church. 
If you're willing to tolerate the kinda irritating movement, you'll probably like this game, cus even if the movement is a major turnoff for me, I haven't found any other major issue with the game so far.

Edit:

Damn its been a few years since I wrote that original review. Due to reasons I was never able to finish the game. I stopped around the final few chapters and if you've played this game then you KNOW that I stopped at the best part.

What stands out about this game is the amazing storytelling. Iconoclasts tells a story that attacks religion (I'm religious btw)  and the naive nature of humans. Its a grim story with intense moments and well written characters but it never takes itself too seriously. It's equal parts tragic as it is goofy and I love that. And when I say that, I don't mean the marvel kind of writing where a character breaks heavy tension by trying to be a smartass, the story knows the right moments. The story itself has a few plot holes and can be a little difficult to understand at times but the characters are so interesting that it keeps you going even when the story is a bit messy.

Nobody is a hero, everyone hates each other till the end and that makes sense. Too many stories try to make characters suck each other's dick by the end. That's not how things work in real life. You can go through something together and still not like each other and that's fine. The last interaction between Elro and Mina we see is Mina shooting Elro and it was one of the best interaction between characters, which would have been ruined had they been buddy buddy by the end. The strongest characters for me were Black (who isn't black) and Royal, but every character is well written.... except our main character.

When it comes to mute, blank-slate characters Robin has to be one of the blandest ones out there. Sure she has charm sometimes (like sommmmmmmmmmmmmmmetimes) but other than puffing her chest and having cute animations, she's so boring. Also her involvement in the story just doesn't make sense, at any point of the story she could just turn back because she's just kinda there for no reason.

Now that I've talked about the story, let me talk about the gameplay. Everything is a puzzle in this game, and I mean EVERYTHING. It's not so much this platform heavy action side scroller that you expect out of a metroidvania but more of a puzzle game with a little bit of combat. You'll be using your guns to solve puzzles more than killing enemies and I find that to be fun. It makes the game more memorable than its peers and I'd rather solves fun puzzles than kill a thousand mindless grunts who will never give me a challenge. But all that said when it comes to boss fights, this game goes harder than any indie game has ever gone. The bosses are so unique, exciting and cinematic that you'd think they belong in a God Of War game. And much like the rest of the game, even beating the bosses is a puzzle. Once you figure out the gimmick they can be pretty easy but its always fun and if you don't figure out the gimmick the bosses can be impossible. Some bosses taunt you, some bosses will make you not want to kill them and some bosses can destroy you in seconds. You'll question if you're right to kill the bosses or if you even can but coupled with the amazing soundtrack and just how fun the fights are, the game keeps telling you to push forward and WOOP SOME ASS! The Black bossfight will be on my mind forever and well unfortunately the final is the weakest of the bunch (Chrome should have been the final boss), but compared to all the boring shit we get in videogames these days, Iconoclast's worst boss is better than the best of most. 

I'm glad I came back and finished this game. It's been a while since I've played such a memorable videogame with such a "videogame" story. I don't know if you get what I mean but most videogame stories these days are very "hollywood" like. They're amazing stories but I always feel like I'd rather watch a movie about that story than play it. Often times the gameplay just gets in the way. Even indie games do that now, but this is a story that you have to play to love. 

And trust me, you will love it.

Movement is still very stiff though.

53995362.review:
Iconoclasts is a good game and you should play it.

If you like games with good stories, action platformers, puzzles, or all three you will love this game. A significant amount of my enjoyment with Iconoclasts came from its compelling narrative which surprised me. I typically find videogames to be a poor medium to tell a story but Iconoclasts just gets so much of it right. The pacing, humor mixed perfectly with dark moments and character emotions, satisfying payoffs and things you are still left wondering about after the credits roll. The lore itself is also very fascinating if you are into that kind of thing. There definitely is a lack of discussion of the lore online and I would like to see more in depth analysis of it. 

The story isn't the only selling point though, gameplay itself is fun and satisfying. Solving puzzles and fighting bosses are the highlights. You're always unlocking some new ability, fighting some kind of new enemy, or exploring some new environment. Playing the game rarely feels stale, there is always something new to mess around with. 

And the MUSIC OMG, I don't know what it is about these indie passion projects but they always have such good soundtracks! If you like chiptunish retro sounding music you will love the it. I get Stardew Valley vibes from it :p

I feel like this game kinda got overlooked and has not got the attention it deserves. The game isn't insanely long, 10 hours for the main story give or take (20-25 hours if you decide to play new game+ and boss rush modes). Iconoclasts is definitely worth your time. I hope interest in the game will grow greater as it ages. It's not my favorite game by any stretch of the imagination. But the level of polish and love put into it shines through an experience I won't forget anytime soon. 

final score/TL:DR -> 8/10 would wrench again.

53945910.review:
So, I finally got to play Iconoclasts. Bit late to the party perhaps, but its a nice game. Storywise, it takes some getting used to, the writers perhaps had their coffee made by a Mr. Saturn? I don't know. 

What I do know though is that Iconoclasts is a fun experience. It does feel akin to a puzzleplatforming game with metroidvania elements thrown in. Some sections set you on a track for a bit before you have free reign. The bosses are quite varied, with some additional optional ones thrown in. No two of them feel exactly alike and they will keep you on your toes. It is a good thing you have unlimited continues though as they (and the levels) can kick your butt six ways till sunday.

The world design is vibrant, colourful and cheery, but the story is.. well, kinda grimdark. The characters who join protag-chan Robin during the game all have... call them issues. One's suicidally depressed, another runs away from her familial problems (and b.o.), the third finds a prophetic upbringing does not mesh with reality... And then there are your antagonists, many of whom are in chronic pain quite aside from their mental issues.

I could wax poetic, but Iconoclasts is a game you're better off discovering on your own. And for what it's worth, I do recommend trying it pronto.

53803827.review:
Iconoclasts is a little gem. Don't know why I've waited over a year to finally play but don't repeat my mistake. It's well worth its full price and then some.

Set in a world on the verge of global crisis, we control Robin the mechanic, whose habit to help everyone kicks off a colossal chain of events. There are additional party members for some parts of the game that we even get to use in some unique sequences. The heart of the gameplay is exploration, puzzle solving and tons of exceptional boss fights. As a metroidvania, it's way more inspired by Metroid but is never too obscure or "trial and error-y" with its secrets. Controls are slick and responsive and the balance between action and puzzles is spot on. Boss fights are certainly the crown jewel of the game, visually stunning and mechanically satisfying, with decently high stakes on Harder mode.

Another big selling point is the story. For the genre, Iconoclasts has a particularly intriguing world building and lore and a complex and ambitious plot. Maybe it does get a bit too convoluted for its own sake in some instances, but overall it's a very emotional journey, with impactful moments. Unfortunately the same heights aren't reached for the characters, as there are some interesting ones but a couple of the "main party" members are so incredibly unlikeable. Considering the genre, it's a very minor flaw overall.

Completing the package we have awesome art direction (gorgous pixel graphics) and a superb OST that deserves a purchase on its own. As skeptic as I was with "one man, long-in-development hi-bit metroidvanias" after hating Owlboy, I am more than pleasantly surprised. Go buy the game already.

I went into Iconoclasts having heard of it, but not much else. However, it's got some buzzword tags that drew me in, and the art was extremely appealing. I was not disappointed, let me tell you straight up; if you couldn't tell by the Recommended tag, then this game definitely drew me in and kept me there.

There's something charming about this game that caught me early, and it hits you often. The style is beautiful, the characters simple and memorable. The story doesn't hold your hand and guide you through the narrative, but the path you walk to pick up all the pieces is excellent. You'll find a lot of traditional elements here from classic Metroidvanias and platformers, and if you find a little backtracking, expanded mobility, pickup based progression, and themed stages with bosses familiar and beloved, there's a lot to love here.

Along the way, the story can lose you, and not everyone will enjoy the character beats and narrative changes. The story has some surprisingly dark elements, some touching scenes, and a lot of very cool, occasionally chilling moments. Personally, I enjoyed it from start to finish. I don't know if it can rank among the masterpiece classics of yore, but for an indie game with a limited budget, schedule, and staff, I couldn't ask for better.

If you looked at this game, read that it was a Metroidvania, and looked the screenshots, chances are you'll get what you came here for and enjoy it.

51651082.review:
This is going to sound like the rambles of a huge fan, and I'll admit, it pretty much is.

First off: the game is somewhat buggy/unstable. May be my gaming laptop, but while the game normally runs smooth as butter, it has frozen once or twice at bad times. Saving often helps, but definitely check those specs.

With that out of the way: HOLY ****, what an incredible game. I fell in love with 2D platformers as a kid, and this scratches that itch perfectly. The controls are responsive, Robin is a breeze to control, the extra characters are a fun break in control (though I wish they weren't as limited as they are), and the gunplay/melee feels perfect for the setting. I loved the melee just a wee bit too much and adored switching guns on the fly. Tweaks added the incentive to explore for components and made my New Game + playthroughs way more fun as I half broke, half gamed the overworld.

Speaking of the world, thank god the designers don't think realistic/gritty = grey and brown. The areas are gorgeous and colorful, with distinct set pieces. Are enemies and ideas reused? Yes, but there's no mistaking one area for another. Going back to areas with new tools is sure to reward, and the fast travel option, though it takes awhile to get to, is sufficient (though backtracking can be a bit annoying, there are tweaks to help). I personally backtrack at every opportunity, though it gets repetitive and I'd recommend against it the first time through just for sanity.

Next, the story and characters. Sweet jesus, the story. Keeping it all spoiler free, buckle your seatbelts kiddos, this is a depressing, yet realistic and satisfying story. There will be tears. There will be loss. There will be pain and you will want to hug the characters. Robin as the protagonist was great, because even though she was technically silent, the writing makes it plausible and she does speak, though you get to choose how she acts. And those interactions, however small, WILL impact the story. Other characters are interesting looks into the normal cliches, and for all the AAA titles bragging about "diversity" and "inclusion", Iconoclasts does it without shoving it in your face. The characters are people first, not just quota fillers. And each has a reason to belong, has stake in the story. The tones and ideas aren't anything new, but they are definitely looked at uniquely.

So... you can probably guess that I really really love this game and highly recommend it for people who love platformers or good stories in games. If you're on the fence, I would say that, for the price, it's a spectacular game. If you want a solid game with a heatbreaking story, you can't go wrong here.

51393752.review:
8.5/10 - This was a very pleasant game to begin, play through and finish. Just the right balance between challenge, fun, story and ambiance. 

Unlike some other people who disliked the amount of dialogue, I found it to be well sized and well written, commenting on a lore that's meant to be explored but never fully explaining it all, leaving much of it up to you to deduce. Characters and story are unique and original, with minimal common tropes. 

It's a pretty functional platformer, and yes, a very metroidvania-esque game in the way that you unlock new abilities that allow you to backtrack and explore new places. It's more emphatic on puzzles rather than combat; however, boss fights deserve a special mention: fun and challenging, they are clearly the most thought out aspect of the game. 

Graphics and art are beautifully drawn, yet performance is sound on any machine; it's clear that this game was heavily fine tuned. Soundtrack in general is very pleasant, with catchy and coherent tunes.

Overall, it's a consistent game, showing how one-person productions can achieve high degrees of quality not seen in current triple A titles. I highly recommend this if you like a good, old school, decent platformer.

i wanna say that it's super impressive to make an entire game practically on your own and no matter how i feel about this game i still think that's an awesome thing to accomplish!! 

iconoclasts is pretty, and it does some nifty things with its core mechanic of the wrench, but it's sort of a disappointing experience overall..... i'm not really a master Videos Gamer so i don't think i'm really qualified to talk about a game's merits at length, but there's not a whole lot of incentive to really explore or collect upgrades beyond a certain point, unlike other games in the metroidvania genre. besides mandatory upgrades and a couple of annoying puzzles you'll never really need to go hunting for secrets off of the critical path.

my real point of contention, though, is that the characters and progression of the story totally infuriate me!! the creator describes the story as a "personal indulgence", which i guess means it's only for him to fully comprehend. people who love theorizing about lore could really go hogwild with iconoclasts, cause it basically leaves everything it sets up for the end of the game unanswered and underdeveloped. the game practically ends on a cliffhanger.... it totally took me by surprise cause it's a really cynical, depressing outlook compared to like the first 75% of the game up to that point. you wouldn't think such a cute and colorful game's ethos would be "everything sucks for no reason, and there's nothing you can do about it". i think by the end i was only playing out of spite just so i could say it was finished and i wouldn't ever have to come back.


i don't think i'm really the target audience for a game like this, but i couldn't tell you Who Is with how its themes clash so hard. i definitely wouldn't recommend playing iconoclasts if you're looking for something rich with innovation or upbeat and feel good. it's shallow and sometimes frustrating, without much of a silver lining to either one.

50949485.review:
I am very conflicted about what to put regarding this game. There were parts of it that I enjoyed, but other parts that I very much disliked. Perhaps the mostly annoying part was the endless dialogue. The story is very long and complex and because of that, you are constantly having your gameplay disrupted to go thru a seemingly endless stream of dialogue boxes and long/drawn out conversations between the characters. Which is surprising because the main character doesn't talk at all. But all of the other periphery characters don't know how to shut up! I realise this game was made but one person, and he obviously had a story he wanted to tell in very fine detail but it is honestly way too much with the dialogue. If I can use an analogy of an author publishing a book for comparison purposes. There is a reason why books have editors that edit an authors work before it gets published. Because the first drafts are usually very bloated with way too much content that is necessary for the novel to work as a whole. The editor trims down all the unnecessary parts and leaves the novel with a much more poignant story. The developer of this game really needed an editor to do that with the excessive dialogue in this game.

That being said, there were parts of the game (the actual gameplay parts between the dialogue) that were quite enjoyable. It is kind of a metroidvania, but more linear. The boss fights are numerous and quite enjoyable. There is some platforming elements as well as some combat elements that blend together nicely. The retro-graphics are very nicely done and the music is also well done.

Overall, I completed the game in just over 13 hours (it isn't a short one that is for sure - but that is likely because there feels like at least half of my playtime was taken up by going thru the endless boxes of dialogue). I will give this game a thumbs up because it is obvious the single developer put their heart and soul in this game and I do respect them for that. That being said, don't plan on rushing thru this one - it takes a lot of time and patience!

50636766.review:
This game is charming, and the controls feel very good. Here's why I don't recommend it:
1. Hand-holding: this game does not really let you explore -- it instead falls into the trap of Metroid: Fusion by directing you to your next goal.
2. Too Much Polish: The game looks very good, and there is a lot of nice animations that really breathe life into the characters. However, it feels to me like there's too much polish, and this becomes distracting noise to the player. For example, on certain screens, there are lots of visual animations and sounds that are too "bright", which can be distracting and off-putting. Another example: when the main character runs on screen, she has a clicking sound that matches up with her shoes touching the ground. This created too much informational noise for me.

If you're new to Metroidvania games and don't mind being told what to do, give this a try. But know what you're getting into.

50603848.review:
Many Platventures have a focus on exploring, gaining upgrades, and using those upgrades to reach new areas.  This one, however, focuses a lot more on story, as there are very few mobility upgrades.  As such, areas will be inaccessible for story reasons, rather than mechanical reasons, but it's never obnoxious about it; it's smart enough to pace the story in such a way that you never reach something inaccessible before the story concludes.  Which of the 2 styles is better is just a matter of personal preference, but I think that it works pretty well here.  Of course, the strength of something like this is carried at least partially by its story and its characters, and while the story is excellent, the characters are a few hits, a lot of misses, and a surprising number of grazes.  

The story is about an evil, oppressive religion, but this is only obvious to the player; all of the characters - save for those, who are part of a mysterious other group - aren't so much drinking the Kool-Aid as guzzling it down with a few simultaneous IVs giving an even steadier flow.  The writers paid good attention to detail with this, as people don't use religious colloquialisms from [i]our[/i] world; they use those that belong to this religion, like "By the Tri!" and "Mother be praised!"  The aforementioned other group are demonized as pirates, but you eventually meet up with them and learn of their own ways.  It goes without saying that the two clash throughout the adventure, and the conclusion of it all is very satisfying, but the neat thing is that you find that neither religion is completely blameless.  In fact, the one to fix it all was the one who didn't subscribe to either school of thought, and only cared about helping others.

The characters, as mentioned, are a mixed bag.  First and foremost is our heroine; she's quirky and adorable in a way that's not obnoxious, and I love her.  She doesn't actually speak, but she has speech balloons with little pictures in them, and they're all great.  Agent White is one of the villains, and all he ever does is shout one-word accusations, like he's Fujin from Final Fantasy 8, but isn't meant to be taken seriously.  Agent White sets the general tone for the adventure, and he's great, too.  There are a few other minor characters who are cool, but don't get enough screen time to leave much of an impression.

On the other side of the coin, we start with Robin's brother, who is a self-important jerk, who refuses to give her any credit, when even her enemies respect her.  Agent Black is just an absolutely miserable person with no redeeming qualities.  This is fine, because she's a villain, but then, the story tries to pull on your heartstrings with her backstory, but it doesn't really justify her behavior.  This is where we get to the edge of the coin: there are a lot of characters that go back and forth between being likable and being genuinely terrible people; it's like the writers didn't even know what direction to take them.  This winds up being most of the cast, both protagonists and antagonists.  One might argue that they were supposed to be real people with real flaws, but the way they were written more strongly suggests that these inconsistencies were unintentional.

Of course, no game completely lives and dies by its writing, and a lot of what makes this good is its gameplay.  You have both guns and your trusty wrench.  The guns can be charged, but will have a longer cooldown time after firing charged shots.  The wrench can be used for striking, swung at the right time to reflect projectiles, twirled for a good DPS attack, twisted to crank knobs to move pieces of puzzles the size of an entire room, and can even attach to grapple points.  To summarize, the game plays like a combination of Metroid, Bionic Commando, Castle Excellent, and Monster Party; it's quite a mash-up, and tests your brain just as much as your reflexes.  The bosses are no exception, and since there aren't many upgrades, you often have to think about [i]all[/i] of your skills before you can find a solution that works.  Many of the boss fights are quite engaging and fierce - it's rare for a game to expect you to be a good fighter [i]and[/i] a good puzzle solver - but there are a select few that are stupidly easy or just plain obnoxious.

The visuals are made entirely of pixel art, but it's not the low-detail variant that screams indie at the top of its lungs.  This is high quality, and has a very unique aesthetic.  The characters - whether I like them or not - all have excellent visual designs.  The scenery is also unique, both in its shape and its coloration; in the very first area, you have trees with little cubes on them for leaves.  The music complements all of this fairly well, and while there are only a handful of standout tracks, few of them are bad.

If you have good reflexes, can think quickly, and don't mind a reasonable challenge - you're likely going to die a few times - then I'd recommend it, because for all of its faults, it does present something unique and worthwhile overall.

50547379.review:
Iconoclasts has received a lot of praise from numerous reviewers, however, disappointingly, I did not have the same positive experience. 

The positives:

The gameplay is great - especially the wrench mechanic. Iconoclasts is primarily a puzzler, and many of the rooms are well designed and are fun to solve and get through. It’s brilliant, the weapons are not only designed to eliminate enemies, but they serve as tools to solve the game’s puzzles. 

The graphics are wonderful, bright and colorful, and the game offers a variety of environments to keep progression feeling fresh.  

The negatives:

The story would have benefited significantly with fewer threads. This would have allowed the primary story beats to have more impact and clarity. Instead, by the end of the game, there is so much going on with multiple characters and story elements that it all becomes a muddled narrative mess.

Concerning the dialogue, this is perhaps Iconoclasts’ greatest issue. Numerous scenes span excruciatingly long and are a chore to get through. Moreover, the dialogue is not well written. With revisions, I think the game’s ideas and beats could have been more effectively conveyed. 

Signposting is terrible in this game.  Multiple points throughout my playthrough, I found myself completely lost on where to go or how to achieve a goal in order to move forward.  This is perfectly captured by certain instances where you’re up against invincible enemies, but you’re not visually informed that you need to run or solve a puzzle rather than fight. 

Final thoughts

I really like the gameplay and movement, it’s well done. However, the serious narrative tone is in complete contrast and feels incongruous as a result. Dragging it down further, the story is not well written and truly struggles to juggle all its elements.

50546190.review: Some parts, mostly the art and animation, are excellent. The lore and worldbuilding is great too. But the writing, and certain core gameplay mechanics are just horrible. 50518729.review:
An overall excellent game, just terrific aesthetically, mechanics are consistent and (usually) intuitive, puzzles are challenging but not punishing, and the level design and checkpoint placement never let me down. 

I have two very minor issues however:
First, the dialogue kind of seems like a placeholder that never got revised. There's a lot of non-diegetic jokes and commentary, and a lot of the conversations just don't flow, like the characters are having separate discussions from the person their talking to. This serves to make some of the characters unlikable, like the annoying brother and the pitiful psychic guy.

Secondly, the hitboxes and (lack of) invincibility frames tend to make some segments artificially difficult. The hitbox on your character just doesn't feel tight, you constantly take hits to the bottom of your shoe when trying to jump over an enemy, whereas some enemy hitboxes will no longer set off your rolling grenades the moment they start their jump animation, even though they're still on the ground. I'll admit I ragequit several times during the Mothers Corners hidden boss for this reason. 

The game definitely has enough positives to outweigh these issues, especially if you consider the game was made by a single person. The guy can do game design, art, code, and music, I can forgive that he's not also the worlds best writer.

If steam did numerical ratings I would give it a 4/5.

Iconoclasts is a compelling game from start to finish. The game-play itself is quite enjoyable with puzzles and exploration being main tenants of the game's design. The combat takes many cues from the classic Metroids and has a great sense of its own personal style. There are also many memorable boss fights that are challenging, but never feel unfair. Iconoclasts really nails just the right amount of difficulty.

Where Iconoclasts really excels is the storyline. It is absolutely brilliant. All the characters are well-fleshed out. The main themes really hit home. It is perfectly shown. Iconoclast really ran with the metroidvania formula, tossed in more story elements, and took it home.

49905455.review:
Absolutely incredible game.
It was hard to put down. The gameplay is a joy, from the puzzles to the exploration to the moment-to-moment feel of the character(s), all combined with the drop dead gorgeous pixel art and animation. The star set pieces are the boss fights, which blend up the mechanics and locations and story in brilliantly exciting ways. (I particularly love the bosses that are small and human-sized like you, with a vicious array of powers. That first fight with Black... genuinely taught me a new meaning of non-male-gaze sexy.) As for the story, it's probably the most interesting political epic I've ever read. It feels nuanced and powerful and beautifully dark against the cutesy art style, while at the same time displaying a wonderfully silly and self-aware wit.
Overall, a supremely deftly crafted package wrapped up with the most lovable and fascinating style. I recommend it.

Some downsides:
I found non-boss combat mainly a drag, but never too laborious to plow through except for one or two awful sticking points. I never used the upgrades system, past loading my three slots with one spin-speed-up and two extra healths. Why swap in something else if I have to give up those? I still enjoyed looking for collectibles and buying up the upgrades, though.

49866647.review:
[b]writing[/b] 
[list]
[*]overall uplifting message
[*]lovable/relatable characters (including antagonists)
[*]several cutscenes with depictions of murder that may not be suitable for immature or sensitive audience
[*]in-game lore that is fleshed out just enough to enhance immersion without becoming tedious
[/list]

[b]artwork[/b]
[list]
[*]style elements with game-world significance (those hand-drawn polygons are not just a gimmick to look hip)
[*]clear indication of mechanic-significant elements (you don't have to constantly run around clicking on things to figure out what you can activate)
[*]somewhat dry soundtrack (but still worth listening to while playing the game)
[*]occasional rough edges with technicalities, but nothing that I found jarring
[*]mostly cartoony violence (not a constant stream of blood and guts)
[/list]

[b]gameplay[/b]
[list]
[*]fast-paced combat that is more about figuring out how to defeat enemies than testing your reflexes
[*]mostly easy puzzles
[*]many hidden collectibles
[*]minimal penalty for not finding collectibles (it would not make the game much more difficult if you just didn't open any chests)
[*]somewhat verbose level design (it doesn't get tedious but the play time likely could have been cut a couple hours without losing anything)
[*]simple player-character mechanics, complex environment variations
[/list]

In the time it took me to play this game (about 12 hours by the in-game timer), I could have watched a 25-episode anime series.  The time commitment is a little steep for the content, but overall I think it was still worth it.

49799016.review:
I need to make this clear, there are two separate issues I have with this game. One of these issues stems from just how bland and boring the gameplay is for the most part. The other issue stems from the awful storytelling. Some people will disagree with my opinions on the story, and argue that my politics are involved in the decision, but the problem I have is not which side it takes, but how improper it is within the narrative, and how it waters itself down by way of its shallow understanding of the moral dilemmas it talks about.

The gameplay:
This game is a platformer with some of the most boring platformer design choices I have ever seen. The wrench is involved in puzzles that are consistently worse than the top gadget from Zelda Twilight Princess, but somehow both more simple and more tedious at the same time, which is almost an accomplishment of awfulness. Every bad wrench puzzle is either a very easily understood puzzle that takes way too long to complete even though it is easy, or one that makes you think you have the answer but the answer is actually some thing you could not have known because it involves some item you do not have or some location you have not visited. So many little terrible design choices affect it in wrench puzzles in every area. I want to say so much more about the mechanics of this game, but it cannot be explained, only felt through the pain of playing it. Don't misunderstand, the game is not awful when the action gets going on many occasions, but the wrench mechanics are annoying tedium for the exploration, and the fact that those same tedious wrench mechanics are used in several boss fights makes them insufferable to someone wanting the game to be fun.

The story:
Have you ever heard someone say "the road to hell is paved with good intentions"? I have heard that countless times, I bring that up so that I can address it later.

It has mixed writing. The political and religious commentary not only is lacking in subtlety but also sounds like it was written by a person who just got out of highschool and is angry at their parents. Even so, the characterization is fantastic. Sadly, these polar opposites actually don't mix well due to one simple issue: the moral dilemmas this game explores. You see, the game, as to its title, is about the concept of "iconoclasts", which is a whole topic of thought that is a massive subject involving political theory and rectification of moral authority. While the issue is something that has been used as a catalyst in the characters of many great games, it falls short in this one game because the writers do not understand the simple fact that people can be horrible by choice unclouded, and not just by nurture or nature. 

As for the subject of the political and religious commentary in this game, I usually enjoy this topic in games, because it usually is done in an amazing way such as Tales of Symphonia, Final Fantasy X, Final Fantasy XII, and some of the Shin Megami Tensei games, which all handled religious and philosophical concepts while opposing the moral authority. However, Iconoclasts does not handle the material nearly as well because it does not actually have anything of its own to say.

If I were actually to explain just how much of the political and religious dribble is in this game, I would have to spoil the game, so I will:
[spoiler]
The government is a theocracy. The religion practices literal "whitewashing". They use a triangle symbol, which may be a bash at the Trinity. The god of their religion is a lie. Every major white male character who is a good guy is either dead or severely and permanently wounded to the point of disability by the end of this game, with the female heroes being unharmed and the story does this as a punishment for their past mistakes, despite none of the important female characters suffering such a penalty. Also, one such character is suspiciously inconsistent in his actions, and such hack writing is par for this game.[/spoiler]

Remember when I asked if you ever heard someone say "the road to hell is paved with good intentions"? The truth is that this old statement is actually a common lie. Sadly, people are awful. People claim they mean well, and when things go wrong they say "mistakes were made", but in reality people are horrible and never meant well. Perhaps you have met someone who would lie about you, then smile with glee as you got in trouble for something you did not do? Perhaps you were hurt by someone who clearly enjoyed it? The reason these people did such was not with good intentions, but with selfish intentions. Such people do not cherish others, and truly do such for petty reasons that anyone can see as absolutely evil if such actions and misdeeds were revealed, but the awful person will claim they mean well, that they have pure intentions, and that they are nice. I have dealt with this type of evil human being before multiple times over, and they have many different ways they do their evil deeds. 

The reason this makes Iconoclasts bad is that the game never has a single bad guy who is actually evil and not an ardent believer in something dumb. Every single villain is a virtuous character following some moral or virtue, and none of them are out for personal gain. The truth is if a genocidal dictatorship were to take over any nation, it would do so with overwhelming support. Some would support for their own survival, but many would support it for their own benefit. The evil of people is exactly why the Nazis happened, why slavery has existed, and why there are countless dictatorships across the globe. They chose to be evil, not because of some misunderstanding or misplaced value, but because they take solace or enjoyment in the suffering of others, and fully embrace such choices within open arms to the detriment of others. This game tries to argue that such moral decisions are complex, but the fact is that these choices are very simple, and that the evildoers argue them complex to placate us and pretend themselves clean. If people sell out their good morals for convenience and power, then they are not good people, but willingly and knowingly on the side of evil. The fact that they turn away from the suffering and feign ignorance does not make them good, but rather it makes them dishonest.

However, it gets even worse when you consider that none of the heroic iconoclasts of the namesake have any morality of their own. None of the main cast have any moral standing or belief of value other than "being bad is bad". In order for one to stand against a different ideology, one must still have ground to stand on; none of the main cast have any grounds to stand on, and none of them provide any alternative moral concept or ideological argument against the system in power. In other words, even if the bad guys are provably bad, the reasoning of the heroes is not at all any better. 

I should also warn that the soundtrack is nothing special. I would not pay for it if I were you.

49764528.review:
Don't get me wrong. This is a very well made game. But it is just not for me. What I expect from a Metroidvania is uninterrupted gameplay. But this game contains so much talking and cutscenes, it's taking me out of the flow all the time.

Apart from that, I don't like the level design too much. Too many equal looking corridors where you have to go back and forth and up and down again and again.
And the puzzles didn't give me any satisfaction solving them. They are too obvious to begin with; they keep repeating the same mechanisms over and over, just the execution is a bit complicated sometimes.

The handling of your skills is also a bit on the annoying side. One example: to stomp down you need to press down and press jump. Why not do it like Mario where pressing down while in the air is enough?

Exploration doesn't satisfy me either, because you never find cool new abilities, you just find the same 4 materials which let you craft things that are not really exciting at all. To me it's important in a Metroidvania to find cool optional stuff here and there. That's just never the case here.

The boss fights, while looking really pretty, are super messy; maybe it's just me. I couldn't stand them.

I'd give a middle thumb if I could, because it's really well crafted, just the gameplay doesn't excite me.

49698798.review:
Amazing game with likable characters. Joakim has mastered what many action games try to do with million dollar budgets, with only a few pixels and a lot of polish. The boss fights are not only cleverly intuitive in their mechanics, but are also cinematic setpieces that leave your heart pounding. The game has a bit of an identity crisis, but once you get past that its really an unforgettable experience thats worth playing through.

First off this is a narrative driven game. There is very little exploration, but to me this was a good thing. If you like the gameplay of metroidvanias but dislike backtracking then this could very well be the game for you. The story itself is dark, set in an imaginative dystopia, but filled with tender moments. Again, Joakim somehow expresses so much emotion in so few pixels. You can't help but relate and feel for the characters.

While your moveset is small, you use literally ALL of it. Rather than a Metroidvania where you tackle bosses out of order and you pick the best powers for the situation, Iconoclasts is constantly forcing you to master even your most basic of mechanics. This combines well with its unique bosses who all bring different gimmicks to the table. Ranging from switching characters mid-boss, to blocking off a rampaging superhuman. 

The game has heavy puzzle elements. Personally I found the puzzles very engaging. The mechanics are satisfying and snappy to execute. Robin's actions all have great weight and feel to them. But if puzzles aren't your thing they're 100% optional and only give minor upgrades that don't impact gameplay much.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game, but just make sure you understand what you're getting into. This is a narrative-driven, linear adventure game, with some meticulous and well-executed puzzles, and intense boss fights to reward you throughout. It feels like Robin's journey against this oppressive force is your own. Your moveset is limited to a stun gun and some weak bombs, and you're constantly crawling through dangerous and complicated areas against all odds, then you're treated to these cathartic boss fights that leave you excited to start the process all over again. If you're looking for something hyper-focused this might not be the game for you. But for me it was worth the long anticipated wait since Noitu Love 2.

49671303.review:
(Note: This game takes around 10-13 hrs to beat, but my playtime is low because I mostly played offline.)

This game really moved me. I was in it for the gorgeous artwork, snazzy soundtrack, and metroidvania gameplay, but what I got was so, so much more. I've been a fan of the developer's work for years and played some of the earlier releases of the game, and I couldn't wrap my head around how much MORE Sandberg added to an already compelling preview of a game. Anyway, focusing on the finished release of Iconoclasts, it's an incredible game that feels so deliciously well-rounded; so much time and effort was put into the narrative, music, artwork, level design, game mechanics, and boss fights (all by one person!), and the result is a game that feels very polished with surprising depth. If you like metroidvania games (and welcome a rich story-driven experience); if you like sci-fi storytelling, complete with its own mysterious world, cultures, and terminology; if you like believable, lifelike characters who don't act predictably, but realistically, who won't just drop everything and taciturnly agree to something that goes against everything they stand for because it's Time to Save the World; if you like running around, shooting things, and solving puzzles that require some thought, you should really give this game a try. Time and time again, while playing this game I felt so taken by the captivating characters, momentous story, thoughtful world-building, dynamic and varied boss fights, ingenious puzzles... everything just blew me away (and I could go on!). The writing can be pretty funny, too, and when the plot twists hit, your heart will ache (unless you're just here for the gameplay and hit skip during every cutscene. It's such a great story but, well, if you don't like reading, there's still a lot here for you, too).

If you're on the fence about this game, go to konjak's website and download one of the early demos--if it feels good to play and you like the world, you'll LOVE what the game grows into. It's such a beautiful game that really builds on itself as it progresses, and the characters will grow on you a lot, too (if you don't already love them from their goofy introductions).

To summarize, I can't recommend this game enough. My only regret is not playing it sooner. Thank-you so much for making this game, Joakim Sandberg. You've created something deeply moving and unforgettable, something truly inspirational and a testament to what depth and polish can be achieved in art, narrative, puzzles, and gameplay when a game's development cycle can take as much time and creative freedom as it needs. It makes me wonder how many more amazing, thoughtful games could be created if 1-3 year time constraints weren't the norm. (Of course, it takes WAY more than time and creativity to make a game, but I digress.) Iconoclasts has become one of my absolute favorite games of all time; I've already bought 3 copies for myself and others, and honestly, it probably won't end there. Worth every cent, but forever invaluable in my heart.

49671200.review:
I haven't finished Iconoclasts, so maybe I will come back and change this review but at this point I am probably going to stop playing because I'm tired of all the little annoying things that this game keeps throwing at me.  

There are a few things this game does very well, the world building is well done and intriguing, some spots have poor pacing but I keep wondering what is going on and why, which is great.  The graphics are very well done in their chosen style.   The sound effects are well utilized and well synched and at least one or two of the tracks are well done.  

This game is at its best when it tries to be fun and when it tries to show you it's world.  This game is at its worst when it wants to drag you through aspects of its gameplay because it feels like it has a duty to show it to you.  

Now here's all the little annoyances in case anyone wants to read through all of them.  
Iconoclasts acts like it's trying to be a metroidvania but it can't let go of the player and give them any freedom which is a core concept of the genre.
Building on that, the items you could backtrack for are near useless anyway and the crafting system is somehow underutilezed even though the only thing you collect is crafting elements.  
Those enhancements you craft are practically useless and dissapear after a few hits, when I forgot about them I suffered no ill effects.
The combat gets stale quick.  It needs probably twice as many weapons or abilities or something.
The only interesting mechanics is the electric tether ride thing and that's fun, but that's it.  
Most boss fights are puzzle fights that are terrible at telegraphing what you're supposed to do.  
The menu interface is terrible, why can't I hover over my items to see what they do, or for quest items find out where I'm supposed to go or who to talk to.
The characters are one-note, if they have a note at all... The protagonist somehow has less personality then a regular silent protagonist and I'm not sure how they did that.  The other characters are only a shade more interesting, if only smelly was a personality aspect, one character would be two-note!
If you made it this far, congratulations, your life must be as boring as mine!
Last but not least, You're an action platformer, YOU DON'T NEED A STEALTH BASED BOSS!  LEAVE STEALTH TO THE STEALTH GAMES!
I don't hate this game, but I am really annoyed by it because it could be so much better with a little better direction.

49344879.review:
I tried to love this - I like this sort of game and I'm a fan of Sandberg's previous stuff, so this should have been preaching to the choir. But...yeah. I just can't recommend this one.

The opening is actually really great, the graphics are fantastic, the music is nice, the story has potential...then it all becomes a slog. The stages are too long and just not very fun to get through. The puzzles feel more like busywork than like I need to really think them through in any meaningful way. I could often figure out what to do right away, but then the puzzle would take forever because I couldn't land the wrench precisely on the right pixel or get a bomb perfectly in position. It's frustrating, not fun. 

With the bosses, it's the opposite problem. It's often hard to figure out just what the game wants you to do to damage a boss...the mechanics are really poorly communicated. I'm not asking for "shoot the big glowing eye" levels of telegraphing how to kill off a boss (this is actually a joke that Sandberg himself made in an earlier game, so I get he wants to do something different), but I had to look at one too many YouTube videos to figure out what the game was asking for. So, again, frustrating, just in a different way.

The story is also...not very good. It's interesting at first and sets up some cool concepts, but then it becomes buried under a bunch of jargon and a whole cast of annoying characters that I just didn't want to spend much more time with. The heroes are just really unlikable and they talk so damn much. There's no joy to them and the whole thing is just way too serious. I feel like Sandberg wanted to create an epic comic book series and then decided to transplant that storyline into the platform puzzle adventure game that he had just designed. The two things just don't work very well together (I'm not saying they *can't*, it just doesn't work here).

I understand why someone would like this game, but its strengths just can't make up for its weaknesses - great art and cool music can't do enough heavy lifting to support boring puzzles, a lackluster story, and lame characters. I'll stick with Noitu Love 2, I guess.

When you play this game, this is key: Have a page of youtube loaded. A lot of the 'gimmicks' from the stages range wildly from exceedingly obvious to, guess what the developer is thinking. I will recommend this but god, if something beats you 3 times and you still haven't figured it out, go watch a solution on youtube, it's not a sign of defeat. Some parts of the game don't tell you what to do and do not make it obvious how to progress.

Oh and the warp rooms are stupid. Most warp roops use names or let you use the minimap where you are to orient yourself in the world. This one has a small png. 

Go buy it, it's fun, but man it could've been fantastic. As it stands, it's only good.

49020913.review:
Not perfect; but overall a damn good game.

Lets start with artwork. This pixel art is extremely beautiful and vibrant. Pixel art is timeless and will hold up practically forever. The characters have a nice attention to detail with the animations to their bodies. Some of the enemy designs are kind of "samey" but the game isn't long enough for the designs to ever feel repetitive. 

Soundtrack is great. All of the tracks fit the emotion in the scenes very well in my opinion. That massive blast of sound going into the title screen can scare the hell out of you though.

Story is overall good, but really hard to follow. Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm just dumb. But I had a hard time following certain parts of the story. Overall it was a good story though, which can be rare for metroidvania platformers.

Difficulty was overall pretty low. Not really a complaint since I have a bad habit of putting hard games down and forgetting about them, but being too easy can be an issue for some people. No boss took me more than 2 tries on Normal difficulty and I never died in the overworld. Believe me I'm not trying to brag, I'm honestly pretty bad at 2D platformers even though I love them so much.

Performance was perfect. There were no graphics option beyond windowed sizes and full screen. Not that it really needs any options. Framerate was locked at 60 for my entire playthrough and it never slowed down or stuttered. 

Honestly I feel like Iconoclasts is very underrated. Sure, the review aggregation on Steam is Very Positive, but honestly there's not enough people talking about this game online. I believe it went under the radar for most people. I'll certainly be doing my part to spread awareness.

48941199.review:
Of all the games I've ever played this is the only game that I loved at the beginning and absolutely hated in the end. 

It has pretty good visuals and decent sound design, but this where the good stuff ends. 

The game starts without explaining anything about its world, how it works, and who you are. And then just starts pouring story at you assuming that you know what it all means, what the hell is going on and that you care about it. Mother? Ivory? [i]Him[/i]? What's Ivory? Who's Mother? Who is [i]He[/i]? Explain, game, explain, damn it! 

There's a LOT of dialogues which is unfortunate, because writing is just obnoxious, it's pretentious and self-absorbing. And for some reason all the [i]good[/i]  characters are absolutely nuts, bonkers, insane, annoying, psychotic, and just unlikable and unrelatable, while the [i]bad[/i] guys are actually pretty okay. the problem is that you're going to observe "good" guys most of the time, and my god that time is gonna be miserable. 

Anyway, you partake on some jolly adventuring around pleasantly looking locations accompanied by cheerful music, all is fine until the game slowly but surely starts to spiral down into the vortex of despair and loathing.

You solve puzzles again and again, you engage in pretty dull combat from time to time, you walk, and you walk, and you walk, and talk, talk, talk some more, oh great, a boss battle. Boss fights are the only moments when you feel adequate in this game, except for puzzle bosses. Those just suck. Especially when you have to fight the same boss multiple times.

Closer to the end of the game, the overall mood gets more and more depressing and psychotic, the characters become just [i]mad[/i], and I really wanted to part with this carnival of psychos, but guess what, THE GAME WOULDN'T END. After what seemed to be a final boss encounter whose motivation and all-absorbing hatred was still unclear to me, the game decided that it wasn't done with me, and dragged on for, I don't know, an hour? maybe two? I mean, it took 17 painfully long hours to finish it, and it stopped being fun around 10 hours in.

And it ended with the most ridiculous and disappointing ending you could think of. I imagine Konjak thought he was being ironic and witty, or even, god forbid, DEEP but for me it devalued all of the problems and conflicts that took place, which effectively rendered the whole adventure damn pointless. What a shame.

And an icing on the cake - there's a lot of backtracking and pointless wandering through the game world, when you have absolutely no clue what you are supposed to be doing, and considering that exploration and solving puzzles reward you with resources that you can spend on upgrades that do little to nothing... whew, what a ride.
/endrant

48766131.review:
To preface I don't normally review games, I play and enjoy or hate and that's all there is. 

This game was on the whole spectacular, honestly it had to be as the last Metroidvania-type game that I played and enjoyed was "Hollow Knight" and that is a damn hard act to follow. The gameplay works, the characters are interesting and almost all of them are deeply flawed, and the world is charming and interesting and beautiful and so incredibly unique. But it pulls above the sum of its quite good parts with how you as the player can relate to the characters.

I'm not good at 2D platformers but i played this game on "Harder" mode anyway and it was a consistent reasonable challenge that utilized your upgrades as you came across them; you have a gun to shoot things or to charge-shot-jump with, a wrench to smack things or interact with the environment for puzzle solving and mobility. Later this expands to grenades to move heavy objects, Electro-magnetism to power things for puzzles or stun enemies or glide on rails, a dodge roll, Electro-magnetic grenades, a "Swap-Gun", and a double jump, and it all *WORKS* perfectly reasonably puzzles are varied and only occasionally tedious combat is interesting and tests you on certain weapon gimmicks making it largely about "Figuring things out" and it just WORKS. Things in the end-game get much harder as they want you to utilize multiple things at once and its not always clear what problem-solvers are required from your tool-box but it is incredibly satisfying to figure it out the whole way through.

And as for the Story; It's dense, it's complicated, it's confusing and it's seemingly poorly written in some places but never so much so as to draw you out of the experience. Rather the building confusing and increasing complication puts you and the player character in an incredibly similar position of being incredibly out-of-our depth but filled with incredible confidence in our ability to push forward and solve problems in the face of a world that, when you take the time to think about it, is trying its hardest to remind you that there are consequences for helping people. Even if I didn't relate so well to the main-character in an oddly-meta sort of way, the flawed-nature of the side characters is *GREAT* the heroes are idiots, narcissists, and assholes all and the villains can be well-meaning and sympathetic and endearing and the writing pulls far ahead of the standard it sets with regards to its character building. 

If I had to call anything in this a "flaw" it would come down to the exploring, I could not 100% this game's collectibles blind, I felt like an idiot doing it but i looked up a guide at 72% and found an optional boss I missed, several dozen useless upgrades/upgrade materials (as I was done with my playthrough)  and THE DODGE ROLL, and the last of those things would have been incredibly useful in a number of boss fights throughout the 15 hours of my first playthrough. I am a moron however, so it's more than likely that this wont be as large of an issue for other people who will either find these things easier or simply not care to go looking in the first place.

I recommend this game, if it's on sale you should buy it, if it's not you should consider buying it anyway.

48747335.review:
I was sorely disappointed with this game - but, ultimately if a game isn't for you, it just isn't for you.

The art in the game is top notch. The music gives me nostalgia for playing Super Nintendo in the 90s. It looked like the game had a cool over-arcing storyline. I was pumped.

However, ultimately, after 6 hours of gameplay I had pause the game and had the realization that I was not enjoying playing the game. Why was this?

1) The storyline, to me, was convoluted and confusing and just TOO DENSE. Eventually I found myself just hitting the start button in order to select "skip" because I didn't want to sit through all the text again. I also found that I had no clue what was going on. So many concepts within the story get thrown at you that I realized after a while I couldn't keep track of the story - and the bits I could I just...well...didnt' care about. 

1A) Tangentially related: there are a few instances where there's a dialogue scene right before a boss. If the boss kills you (and it probably will a few times) it doesn't restart you at the beginning of the boss fight. It restarts you at the beginning of the dialogue scene. I can't for the life of me understand why developers would make this decision. If I'm trying to progress through a frustrating boss, having to deal with that scene every time makes it just plain annoying.

2) This is the big one: I felt consistently lost. I understand that part of the appeal (for some folks) of the Metroidvania genre is backtracking and things like that - you see an area you can't approach due to some limitation, you play the game and level up, then return to that area later with the ability to advance. But this didn't feel like that. Often times I'd wonder around forever, realize I'd covered what seemed to be the entirety of the map, and see the only clue I had was a vague sentence (yes. One sentence) in the pause menu that offered me no real information. The solution? Well, often times it meant areas I had already been to now had new editions that allowed me to advance - but I was never informed of them. Or maybe it was buried deep within that dialogue I started skipping over. I'm not sure.

Ultimately, I don't feel like Iconoclasts respects the players time. I realize that for some, the stuff I mentioned above won't bother them, but for me, it's too much. There are too many dang games out there to spend hours and hours playing one that doesn't blow your hair back.

48653750.review:
Iconoclasts is a truly magnificent game, and I'd easily rank it among the top side-scroller/meteroidvania games I've ever played. The artwork is breathtaking and the soundtrack works with that to create a compelling atmosphere that almost perfectly suits every situation Robin (the main character) finds herself in. Combat is fun and puzzles are intuitive, but both are still challenging enough that I don't feel bored going through the game. The characters are fleshed out and have distinctive personalities, from the plucky protagonist Robin to the enigmatic and cruel Mother to the renegade pirate Mina. The story is distinctive and engaging, even though the plot can be notably convoluted at times, and I was invested in it to the point that I had to go and lie down for a little while after I finally finished.

I will not, however, forgive Bifrost Entertainment for what those b*stards made me do to Royal

Nine bolts out of ten. Worth every penny.

En el episodio de hoy de Manqueando... "Iconoclastststs"

Creo que hay algo de juego en mi cinemática.

Le tenia muchas ganas a este juego, y tras haberlo terminado ahora mismo, tengo una sensación agridulce. Tecnicamente, me encanta.  Jugablemente... no tanto.

Empezaré diciendo que aqui rajan más que las porteras. En ocasiones me he llegado a preguntar si era de square-enix. Hasta el punto en el que te corta el rollo cada 2 por 3 con una "cutscene". 

Y la historia no es que esté mal, el problema es que es raruna. Han creado un mundo en el que nadie te explica nada, asi que oyes hablar de penitencias, de pecadores, mecánicos y gaitas. Por otra parte, hay personajes que mueren pero no, y otros que mueren sin pena ni gloria.

Y le voy a dar un 7, por que el 8 seria solo por la parte tecnica, y por la jugabilidad y demás un 6. Asi que ni pa ti ni pa mi. Y si, lo recomendaria, aunque mejor de oferta.

48463094.review:
Iconoclasts is a beautiful 2D action-platformer with some metroidvania elements. On Steam it is tagged as a metroidvania, which I think is reasonable, however you should be aware that it is not a standard metroidvania and you only need to backtrack if you are looking for the few collectibles that initially were inaccessible. The overall game play is a pretty standard affair, with basic platforming, light puzzle solving and some combat mixed in. Although the game does not do anything particularly unique, all of the game play elements feel great so it is a joy to play. 

As you progress through the game, you will collect various resources that can be used craft and equip "tweaks". These tweaks provide small boosts to your character such as increased damage and increased movement speed. I do wish these tweaks provided more of a game play boost as I found I rarely changed the tweaks and for the most part didn't even care or notice what tweaks I had equipped. You will also obtain a few "upgrades" as you play through the story that will open up new paths to progress further. There are not many upgrades in the game and most of them do not significantly change the game play, but they do keep things interesting and provide further puzzle solving mechanics.

As deep down Iconoclasts is really a story driven game, I will say that the story is probably the weakest part. It can be hard to follow, is a bit convoluted and overall is just bizarre. I will say that when I went in I expected a family friendly game and was pleasantly surprised by some of the deeper concepts and dark moments.

Pros:
- Beautiful vibrant graphics which look amazing in motion.
- Controls and platforming are tight and feel great.
- Boss fights are varied and unique.

Cons:
- The story is bizarre and can be a bit hard to follow.
- Could use a few more abilities.

All in all, I highly recommend this game. The fact that such a deep and beautiful game was made by 1 person is truly astounding and just adds to its charm. Definitely do not sleep on this game if you are even a slight fan of platformers or metroidvanias.
