48212091.review:
With his lush, vibrant and colorful pixel art, its marvelous cast of likable characters, and its nice, weird, slightly disturbing Sci-Fi setting, Iconoclasts is easy to love. Too easy perhaps, and the gameplay might not be fully satisfying. Do not expect a cool world to explore, but a nice platformer with some great moments along the way. 

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Player-friendly in the good way.
+ With one exception, the boss fights all provide lots of fun, and never feel the same. 
+ You have a checkpoint at the beginning of each boss fight so you can really focus on learning their patterns. 
+ Overall, everything is neat and precise. Fights are very enjoyable for this reason. 
+ Very good pixel graphics, with many different areas with their own atmosphere.
+ The characters are very interesting, with their own personalities, and I really liked most of them. 
+ Just before the final boss you have a save point and a teleporter so you can freely explore the world if you still have treasures to dig out. 
+ The story is interesting and have a few very good, moving, and even epic moments. 
+ In Standard Difficulty, you can die, but when you feel that you sorely need a savepoint and fear to have to restart all over a lengthy sequence, most of the times the savepoint will be there. 
+ Puzzles are usually interesting to solve. 
+ You get three weapons and all three are useful.
+ You have a skip button to skip the cutscenes introducing the bosses. I would have considered a sin otherwise, so it was a bit of a required Pro but a Pro nonetheless!
+ Music is funky and very enthralling. 

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Too much slow-paced when you backtrack to find the remaining secrets.
- The tweak system (slightly similar to Hollow Knight charms but broken) is utterly useless. Chests only provides bonuses related to this tweak system and so you are not incentivized to explore around.
- With very few teleporting points, exploring past levels feel lengthy and laborious. 
- No real upgrades along the way.
- The story, though interesting, is a complete mess. Good luck to follow everything and make sense of all its threads. 
- A few sequences are quite poor. Many puzzles are basket-ball based (you have to throw a bomb in some hole). There is a whole sequence with an alternative character where you just have to slug your way through a corridor for entire minutes. 
- You don't have any control on the story. You are most of the time an observer more than an actor of it. Many things happen without you having any grasp on it. 
- The sidequests are under-developed, and mostly feel like an overlooked addition. I think there are two of them in total, drawn in the midst of the main story. You fulfill them more by chance than by purpose. 
- Some story components remain entirely unexplained (even one involving a boss). 
- The progression percentage is completely meaningless (I think it refers to the number of chests you find and tweaks you craft). 
- There is one area with chests you cannot return to. If you missed chests there, you will never be able to reach 100% completion. 
- There is a very lame puzzle sequence where you have to fall and reach some lever in mid-fall. If you fail, you have to take a ladder and restart everything, since the whole area is reset each time you get out of it. I had to redo the thing like twenty or thirty times before succeeding. This is the sort of moments which makes the game tedious at times. 
- One area is elevator-based. You have to backtrack multiple times to align the elevators correctly... I think it is an example of very poor and infuriating level design. 
- The end boss comes out of nowhere and feels a bit out of place. I would have liked an explanation of any sort. It's not very satisfying that the story ends with a disturbing feeling of floating puzzlement.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
To be honest, I was eager to finish the game because I grew tired of it before the end. And yet, I think it's impossible not to love it in some way. The main character is lovely, and most of her companions are too (even Royal). There are some great story moments, and yet the game is not a visual novel and some of these moments are completely intertwined within the game (as the Ivory remains room!!!) and are part of the gaming experience. However, I think that what makes the game shines are the boss fights. I used not to like boss fights because I find them too long or too difficult, but here they were a delight. Most were challenging and only a few felt too easy (but enjoyable nonetheless). The overall player-friendly attitude is most appreciated. Even though the exploration part is lacking, I think the game is still able to deliver an original, meaningful, and entertaining experience. 

I therefore recommend it warmly, unless you are expecting an exploration-based game. 

[h1]Additional remarks[/h1]

[b]Tweak system[/b]
Let's speak shortly about the tweak system. You can equip up to three tweaks (this number is fixed from the beginning of the game and will never increase) at savepoints. To get these tweaks, you need first to find their blueprint or something of the like, and second to craft them, using four kind of materials that you gather from the chests (the secrets of the game, usually hard to find, some of them involving a harder than usual puzzle, or just a more frustrating one). So far, I don't see any major flaw in this system.

The flaws are twofold. First, most of the tweaks are useless (for instance, breathing longer underwater. Maybe it's useful to find one super secret, but you can skip for the rest of the game) and they are redundant (I think I could equip my character with anything but these "breathing longer" tweaks). Since you can get only three of them, I wonder why such useless tweaks exist at all. Second, you loose these tweaks as you are sustaining damage (one tweak per two damage). You can refill them by killing enemies or destroying statues (a bit weird, I know). But it means that, during your adventure, you will spend most of the time without any active tweaks. 

[b]Exploration[/b]
By exploring the world, you get the crafting materials required for the tweaks. It means you can already forget about it as it won't bring you anything useful. I would have liked much better to find additional pieces of lore, story bits, or character backgrounds info. I think, had it been the case, I would have dig out ALL of these chests. But as it is, I stopped bothering finding them at some point unless they were obviously on my path. 

In some games, I find the secrets only for the sake of 100% completion (SteamWorld Dig 2 being the last example; artifacts are useless there). But here, the other problem is that exploring back the world is boring. Many secret areas are very hard to notice and you will have to go through every room multiple times to find them all. Plus, there are not very many shortcuts unfolding as you progress, which means you will have to redo the same sequences over and over. Given the slow-pace of the character movements, which is fine when you just follow the main game, this gets boring pretty quickly.

In the end, although I liked the world, the funky atmosphere, the character, the controls, the fighting, the platforming, exploring felt completely devoid of interest, and it contributes to my growing dislike of the game. Fortunately I gave up exploring and focused on the main story, and all was fine again. It's a bid sad, though, that a game about freedom and willpower forces you to such a constrained thread.

48200363.review:
I tried to like it, I really did. It was entertaining for the first 2-3 hours, and you can tell a lot of love went into this game, but it´s just too flawed to recommend, and I really hate having to say that. Quick breakdown:

- Graphics are nice, cute and vibrant, rather well animated. Nothing groundbreaking, but they do the job and some of the character design are cool.

-Sound is rather good too, the music is cool and the sound effects are Ok.

-The controls are responsive enough, and controlling the characters is easy.

Now, if I find the sound, graphics and controls acceptable, why can´t I recommend the game?  Well, to put it simply, the controls are OK, but what you have to do with them isn´t. It´s boring and derivative, the side missions are just fetch quests 

Main Quest: Hope you like searching for keys, ´cause boy are you gonna do it in this game! The levels are OK but they completely overstay their welcome in the most obnoxious way possible. Quick example: There´s a level where you go around a tower searching for keys and ways to unlock elevators to be able to get to the end, fighting the same "boss" multiple times in the process. When you think you´re finally out? Nope, for some reason the ventilation shaft you´re trying to use to get out requires 3 keys to open, so you have to backtrack to find 3 more keys before you can proceed. This is unnecessary padding, pure and simple.
Abilities are meh, just diferent ways to activate switches and open doors (By proximity, by charging a box and leaving it close to the switch, by charging  yourself and generating sparks next to a switch, by charging yourself and throwing a charged bomb near the switch...yawn). None of them add to the gameplay besides their door opening/switch enabling characteristics, and each is used so much it stops being fun. Pulling a lever is not a challenge, nor is it particularly compelling gameplay. 
Some puzzles are actually rather interestings...the first time through. There´s only so many times you can move boxes by throwing bombs close to them before it becomes a chore. 
The space between missions is filled with busy work...For example, after a certain point you´re in point A, you can´t proceed so you´re tasked with finding character X, who should be near a settlement B (previously visited area). You go to B, an NPC in a random house tells you "Oh no, he was here but he went to C (Other previously visited area)", you cross the entire area and the next one going west to find him in C, where he tells you to meet him in D (ANOTHER previously visited area). ALL of this without any new challenges, new ways to explore or stuff to find. HELL, as the areas are already explored most puzzles and pathways are already clear, you´re just walking through. Once you get to D, you have a small "boss fight" (More of a puzzle, really, and an easy one) and then it´s time to go back to A, to advance the story. Did any of this sound fun? No? It´s because it isn´t. 

Side missions: They are just fetch quests, you don´t even need to get through a harder area, a puzzle, a room that´s hard to traverse, nothing. You get Quest A, bring letter from X to Y, bring second letter from X, and then the reply from X to Y. In the example given both characters are in cities without even anything dangerous close by, you just talk to X, go to teleporter, talk to Y, go back, etc. but there´s other sidequests that require you to do something very similar, just during the middle of an area.

It´s a shame, because the characters, flawed as they are, are endearing, and the story is rather interesting, but after 8 or so hours of gamepaly I realized I had been bored for the last 3 or so. Sorry, but I wasn´t enjoing myself.

48179749.review:
Iconoclasts is an indie Metroidvania about faith, purpose, the challenges of helping people, and how many different things you can whack with your oversized, electrified wrench. 

The gameplay is fairly straightforward, especially for a Metroidvania. You run, shoot, platform, and wrench bolts. You can also have up to three "Tweaks" on your character, which confer various active or passive abilties. That brings me to my first problem with this game. The idea of crafting equippable bonuses for your character is fine, but your Tweak slots break when you take enough damage. They can be fixed by collecting these shards from enemies and background objects, but this still renders your character customization useless half the time. Furthermore, almost all of this game's optional exploration is focused on collecting materials for crafting more Tweaks. There's no upgrades for your health cap, and all the weapon upgrades are acquired at specific points in the story.

Speaking of the story, Iconoclasts tells the tale of a young mechanic named Robin. Ever the idealist, Robin uses her abilities to help her community. This brings her into conflict with the One Concern, a seemingly omnipresent theocracy that forces people into specific roles and oppresses anyone who isn't on their nice list. Some people get hurt, some slapfights ensue, and Robin soon finds herself going up against them. That's the premise, anyway. Not all is as it seems, and this story is filled with curveballs.

I won't give anything away. I do think the story is fine for the most part. There's plenty of moments that were genuinely upsetting or even heartrending. The villainous characters turn out to be surprisingly likeable and even a bit sympathetic despite their actions. The very end (as in, the last five minutes) is what bugs me. Without giving anything away, it ruined much of the built-up tension of the situation. It was just so bizarre and out of left-field that I can't really look at the rest of the game the same way. It's like the Dog Ending from Silent Hill 2.

Anyway, I think I consider the strongest aspect of this game to be the boss battles. They're varied enough that I almost always got excited whenever one began. They almost all play well, and almost all your failures actually feel like your own. A couple fights against a major antagonist towards the end, in particular, are just incredibly emotionally-charged and unforgettable. Luckily, there's a Boss Rush available after you beat the game.

Pros:
- Solid platforming and combat
- Great boss battles
- Solid story and characters, for the most part

Cons:
- Weak Metroidvania elements
- The ending

Verdict: I had fun with this game, and I'd recommend it if you're looking for a short, sweet action-platformer or just a good story. Sadly, I feel that the individual parts of the game are greater than the whole, if that makes sense. Iconoclasts has plenty of great pieces. It just doesn't put them together the way I wanted it to. I'm glad I played it. I don't know if I'd play it again, but I'm glad I played it.

48048785.review:
Let me preface my review by saying one thing: as a (mostly) one-man effort, Iconoclast is terrific. You only need to look at a random gameplay video or trailer while keeping in mind that what you see - the levels, the character designs, the story, the music, the coding - was made by one person, Joachim Sandberg, to realize how big of an accomplishment this is.

However. What I want to do is judge the game on its own merits, and not on external factors, no matter how impressive I might find them. I realize I might end up talking about the things I disliked more than the things I liked, so I'll be clear on this: despite its flaws, I enjoyed Iconoclasts. It's a solid game and it's worth playing. It’s just not the best game I played this year.

First of all: Iconoclasts might look like a metroidvania at first, but it's not. There's not much in the way of exploration and, even if you do unlock powerups that let you access new areas, the plot is going to lead you on a very linear path. There’s some platforming, but it’s rather sparse and not the focus of the game: that role is reserved for puzzles and combat.

The puzzles are relatively simple, with some exceptions. One thing about them that left me a bit iffy is that I was able to "solve" some of them in ways that I'm not 100% sure were intended: one of the puzzles towards the end of the game can be completely bypassed by clever use of the pink boxes in the room and the swap gun. Much in the same way, it happened a couple times in my playthrough that some obstacles that clearly required more brainpower than I had available at the moment could be surpassed by simply diving headfirst into them and using those few seconds of invincibility to reach the otherwise inaccessible area.

But Robin's wrench and stun gun are not going to be used only for puzzle-solving; there's a fair deal of combat in Iconoclasts, too. Generic enemies are varied enough, both design and mechanically wise: simply whacking or shooting an enemy often won't be enough to dissuade them from standing in your way. At the same time, though, I wouldn't say combat is one of the game's selling points; while it does its job decently enough, this is no Hollow Knight or Hyper Light Drifter. The same applies to bosses. Most of them have the tendency to feel a bit - for lack of a better word - gimmicky; there's a lot of "do this thing x times and you win", paired with relatively simple attack patterns, so some fights boil down to waiting until the stars align and you can mess their day real bad. It doesn't help that some bossfights require you to use Mina, a different character; this would be a good idea in theory, but Mina's shotgun is much clunkier than Robin's stun gun and it makes for some annoying gameplay moments.

I was also disappointed by the tweak system and, in conjunction with that, by the various treasure spread around the levels. The loot will always boil down to one out of four upgrade materials and, combined with the fact that upgrades for Robin don't feel like they matter much, you never really get a sense of wonder and excitement when you see a new chest; you more or less already know what's in there, and that it won't be impressive.

As far as the story goes, Iconoclasts is similar to Cave Story in vibe: both games start colorful and wacky and have cute characters but it doesn't take long before you come to the realization that the story is, in fact, pretty damn dark. However, while there are obvious differences in terms of plot, I think Cave Story executes his way better. While it starts off good, Iconoclasts seems to quickly develop a taste for the melodramatic, like it mistakes making everything and everyone as miserable as it could possibly be for how mature narration should look like. There's a ton of gruesome deaths and ugly, sad backstories or destinies for many of the side characters, and as a result it all ends up drowned in the tides of misery. When everything is a tragedy, nothing is.

(also, why does no one give a shit about the blue goo that takes over lifeforms and is literally everywhere? Not even a passing remark? A "hey what's this thing that looks like some elder god is corrupting our land and why is it here and how do we get rid of it?" No?)

The message about blind belief isn't exactly subtle either - City One's "pearly gates" are guarded by an old, bearded gatekeeper named Pete that decides who is deserving of entry, in case you're still unsure about what specifically the cult of Mother is a reference to - but I'd be lying if I said I cared much for it, and not due to personal beliefs. I'm not a religious person myself, but what Iconoclasts seems to try to say about the matter sounds an awful lot like a well-worded "believing in imaginary friends is bad don't do it" which I feel is too simple of an outlook on the theme of belief. But perhaps I'm wrong and I completely misunderstood what Joachim Sandberg was trying to say. Might very well be.

The ending is also very weird, and I'll leave it at that.

But despite all this, Iconoclasts is certainly not a game without its charms; the general design is very good, as well as animation quality; the gameplay, while it might not be a shining beacon, is still solid and varied enough to keep you entertained; the music is also pretty good and, while I might not be the biggest fan of the game's story, I still was interested in seeing where it would go. So all in all: a neat little game, worthy of your time if you're a fan of the genre.

48039484.review:
Ummmm.. did you ever play Cave Story? How about Metal Slug? Ooh, and Shadow Complex?! 

If you were to invent some kind of virtual blender and threw these 3 ingredients in, well... you'd probably get something grey and sticky... 

Iconoclasts! None of those name-drops are meant to be uncomplimentary, and they aren't! 

Look, this is a labour of love from one fellow - a, Joakim Sandberg - and what a love of labour he has. His inspirations are clear and evident, and his own personal touch shows through in almost every detail. And there are SO many details! Every biome is vibrant, and the enemy designs are - for the most part - inspired.

This is a typical core platformer in the "new" retro style, which means it needs a gimmick to keep its head above water. The gimmick here is the 'Wrench' that our hero wields, and the varied abilities that come with it. You can twist nuts to open doors and move platforms, bash enemies, scoot along ziplines and electrocute power-reliant puzzles.

The combat feels like Metal Slug "Lite". The hammering of your basic gun or the explosive power of your secondary are impactful and satisfying. Yet there are more elements at play here...

And it's... pretty fucking fun!

The story is, fantastic? I think. It bobs and weaves around it's core themes in a way that ISN'T bad, just difficult to follow. I found myself romanticized by the idea of a TECHNOLOGICALLY - ADVANCED world utterly inhibited - and yet, sustained by - it's RELIGION. It's a cool play on those themes, and I love the world Mr Sandberg has built. It's pixel art design belies a darker story that isn't ashamed of shying away from some pretty violent and dramatic moments. Some scenes really caught me by surprise; the nuance of storytelling in a game like this was unexpected and WELCOME. I'd put it on par with Cave Story, with a Tarantino skew.

I can't talk about the story without commenting on the characters though, and they're great. Bloody great, actually. Although there are a bevy of names to learn, and some will fall to the wayside... the core 8-10 that make up the core story are worth their weight in biscuits. Or Vegemite, if you're me.

You'll encounter many, um... encounters between said folk. They range from the benign to the world-ending, reality-suggesting and condom-checking. The characters are filled out well though, assuming you have the patience and the crack-addled mind to understand them. 

*However... the controls are not perfect, the story is convoluted and it overstays its welcome somewhat.

I experienced difficult platforming sections in which my command was not so much a command, by a bygone suggestion.

I encountered enemies that pissed me off so much I gave serious consideration to modelling them myself in a static environment, just so I could FUCK THEM UP, the CUNT WANKERS, FUCKING punch and kick the SHIT and FUCK the FUCK outta them!

About an hour before the end, I wanted it over with. The finale is satisfying, but I can't take back that hour.

These are quibbles in the face of the FULL, UNABASTED CREDIT that Joakim Sandberg deserves. I smashed through Iconclasts in 3 sittings and enjoyed, hmmm... about 90% of it. Good odds for any gamer :)

Make a game by yourself, I dare you.

48026355.review:
[h1] Review Start! [/h1]

Iconoclasts is an incredibly underappreciated game. While I personally wouldn’t call it a masterpiece, I do believe others probably would. I'm going to break this review into a few different segments, so that I can write about what I did like, and what I didn’t, both so that the reader can find the parts that they care about, and so that I can try to properly parse my feeling for this game, as i'm still trying to decide on how I feel.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

	This game is gorgeous. Just incredibly pretty. The character designs, while somewhat off-putting in the trailer, look wonderful in the 2D pixel art of the game. The background, enemies, npc’s, animations, everything, all of it just looks so good. Two thumbs way up.

	Having said that, I am a massive sucker 2D pixel art games, and am therefore pretty biased, so take that with a grain of salt.

[h1] Music & Sound [/h1]

	The music is fairly good. None of the tracks stand out to me as incredible, but all of them seem well composed, thematically appropriate for the places where they play, and overall add to the quality of the game, but not in a huge way.

The sound on the other hand is great! I... don’t really know anything about how sound effects are produced or chosen, but clearly developer Joakim Sandberg has a real talent for it. Unfortunately, the quality of the sound effects isn’t something that will cause games to fly off digital shelves, but if it was, then this game would be a bestseller.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

	The gameplay of Iconoclasts is probably where the game shines the brightest, though like with the point I made about graphics, I am a huge fan of metroidvania games, so keep that in mind.

	Now, while it [i] is [/i] a metroidvania, It doesn't really have very much backtracking to find collectibles or anything. There is [i] some [/i] of that, but it is very much optional, and even if you do backtrack, there isn't a great deal of collectibles to find anyway, and the rewards for doing so aren’t that great anyway. For some people, this is a plus, but I am the type of person who LOVES backtracking, so this was actually a negative for me.

	Having said that, the gameplay is still fantastic, if somewhat basic. You have a gun with infinite ammo that shoots low damage bullets, but shoots them almost as fast as you can press the button, as well as a few other modes for the gun that change the type of bullets you use. You also have a wrench that you can swing at enemies, though I personally used the gun for combat way more often. The wrench can also be used to grab and turn bolts in the environment, that then open doors or allow you swing off of them, spin gears to make platforms move, as well as do a few other things after you upgrade it during certain story segments. As I said, fairly basic.

	The basic-ness of the gameplay, however, becomes a huge advantage to the game, because of the spectacular level design. Almost every single room or screen in this game seems to have been painstakingly crafted to feel like either a breeze to get through or a fairly hard challenge, causing you to feel a sense of accomplishment whenever you finally make that jump accros the thorns that you failed at seven times, or finally kill the last enemy in a room that you've died in twice. Additionally, while you probably will die a few times, the level of difficulty is very fair, even at the higher levels, so with the possible exception of one specific segment just before the final boss, you never feel like smashing your keyboard or throwing your controller. (though keep in mind the gameplay seem much more fun with a controller, I switched to a controller fairly early on in the game and never looked back)

[h1] Story and Characters [/h1]

	And now we get to the interesting part (and the part that is going to be a [u] massive wall of text [/u], because I can’t figure out where to put a paragraph break in here). Normally, I would make these two seperate sections, but I feel I need to talk about them together in order to talk about them properly. Firstly, the characters are phenomenally well written, in the sense that the feel like actual real people, with realistic personalities, realistic motivations, and most importantly, realistic flaws and interpersonal relationships. When something bad happens in the story, the character react in ways that a lot of other, less well-written, video game characters just don’t; they collapse and cry, they scream, they mull over the bad thing, they come to the wrong conclusion, they lash out at those trying to help them, they grow as a character, but then like some real people do, regress that growth, possibly becoming worse. Additionally some of the characters seem to have flaws indicative of possible mental illness, or other things that people in our real world would probably go to therapy for, but there doesn’t seem to be therapists in this world. So the traumas and hang-ups these characters have have time to grow and fester, and by the end of the game (Significant spoilers)  [spoiler] when the world is literally ending, or at least on the cusp of ending, the characters are, for the most part, only able to think about themselves, and what they want, or what they think should happen. [/spoiler] This game is dark, very dark, but it is a nuanced darkness, that exists not for the sake of being dark, but because it is grounded in reality, albeit with a large helping of sci-fi and fantasy baked in. The game even has some fairly funny moments in it, showing that even when bad things are happening all the time, funny things can still happen, just not often.

	Now having said all that, there is one thing I should mention. I am personally very much biased when writing this review, though not in the way you might think. I understand this viewpoint is fairly uncommon, and a LOT of people disagree with it, perhaps rightly so, but in my opinion a story, no matter how well crafted can be almost completely ruined by its ending. I also think that the opposite is true, that a bad story can be saved by its ending, though I don't think that happens very often, and it also doesn't apply here. The reason I say this is that I didn’t like the ending of Iconoclasts. At all. I personally thought is was fairly rushed, left a huge amount of loose threads, kinda felt like it lost its narrative thread, and was overall just... bad. And because of my previously mentioned viewpoint, I came off of Iconoclasts sad, almost [i] bitter. [/i] [u] BUT [/u] because I know this about myself, I know I should look past this personal hang up when trying to review a game; I know I should try to be more objective. And looking at this game’s ending through a more objective lense, I think it's the kind of ending that would appeal to a lot of people, and is probably, objectively, good. And so that, in addition to all the other positives I mentioned above, is why I still recommend this game, even though I personally didn’t like it.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
	
	So that is my review of Iconoclasts. An incredibly fun-to-play game, that has a very dark narrative, with an ending that I personally don’t much like but I still feel is probably, objectively, good. I also love reading all of the discussions about the ending. Unfortunately, not nearly enough people have read this game for the discussion to be as lively and diverse as I would like, so please, please, if you have read this far into this review, PLEASE buy this game!

47984231.review:
An all-round excellent game. Unlike most Metroid-likes/Metroidvanias, there's less focus on power-ups changing mobility altogether (e.g. the double-jump is an entirely optional upgrade you get near the very end), instead focusing on enhanced puzzles and learning new mechanics. It's a really interesting challenge that makes you feel clever for figuring out how to "solve" a room or bossfight.

It's also a vast world despite rarely requiring you to backtrack, as you're introduced to new, unique areas at a fairly regular pace. (There are still optional collectibles and sidequests, though.)

The story is surprisingly cynical and dark for its cheerful aesthetic and frequent jokes, but encouraging all the same. Even if Robin seems to be out of her depth and everything's going awry, she can't be stopped from trying anyway. In Robin's words, "No, must save!"

47774833.review:
[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list]
    [*]The story and characters
    [*]The creative boss fights and wrench puzzles

[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]This game is not a normal metroidvania game that those looking for would like. The game is linear and with some backtracking mostly for optional stuff. The game is heavy on story and you will read A LOT, but you can skip it if you want.

    [*]I’ll start with the gameplay. The simple combat you have is using a normal laser, bomb/missle gun, a heavy laser/swap gun and your wrench to kill or stun enemies. You get these at certain points in the game and as well as upgrades to your wrench to electrify it. This is used mostly in traversal and puzzles, not combat though.

    [*]The game is overall very easy for those looking for a challenge unless you start the new game with one hit mode. The enemies and bosses you encounter are all unique in they look and attack patterns that each requires a different approach to killing them.  With some having to be avoided, stunned or more creative ways to get past them with tools acquired later.

    [*]The bosses are the best part of the game. You have so much creativity in the design of each one that I wish there was a boss rush mode to replay them, minus a few. The developer didn’t make them insanely hard which most people, even me expect when hearing about bosses in games. They aren’t that hard, just require a certain way to defeat with even the annoying or unexplained bosses were still creative like a stealth boss, tag teaming with your companions, and using your wrench that fits and sets the game apart with the design of these bosses

    [*]The game has chests you open for the “light Metroidvania” aspect that you get materials to craft passive abilities that you also find through various ways. This feels like an afterthought as it’s the only thing that makes this game from being just a straight linear game. Nothing wrong with that, but since it’s optional and not fully useful unless trying to 100% and find optional bosses. The abilities are useful, you can have 3 active. Each hit takes the abilities away until you get orbs to heal the slot from doing basic stuff, which in the world isn’t that bad, but during boss fights are worthless. So for me they felt like an afterthought or didn’t want them to be required to progress, which also makes since.

    [*]The story is interesting and I didn’t skip it, it’s a mixed bag on tone though as the game is very heavy on religious and philosophical ideas, which I find interesting. It will get serious and then undercut with an out of place joke or 4th wall breaking reference. The game can also just use a character to preach at times. It felt like totally going against what the character vibe is. This makes the characters not as consistent and makes the characters that are very one simple even more shallow. The 2 most interesting characters were enemy agents that one would preach but that was his character and it fit with who he was and the other was a female that had mixed emotions over what she was doing and hated life. The four main characters didn’t have the same level of depth and at times would get annoying.

    [*]The game does have one entire level and other areas that had elevators that would require so much backtracking to use these properly. Why they don’t have buttons to call elevators to the level your on is so stupid. That one entire level was annoying instead of interesting because of this. They can also not explain how to defeat certain bosses or what to even do.

    [*]Overall the game was a blast to play and seeing this world and its characters, the interesting religious story and showing the many facets of it along with interesting villains. The fact that one guy made all these interesting bosses to fight blows my mind. But even the few mistakes or inconsistency I can’t wait to see what he creates next.

 [/list]

47348861.review:
Just aced this 100% so I'll leave a review while it's still fresh. 

I'll start with the good and the great: 

Very unique setting, beautiful landscapes, colourful, well animated, great character designs, smooth and fast gameplay, cool over-the-top and flashy boss battles, no bugs, and (mostly) fantastic music. 
A welcome addition to the Metroidvania/side-scroller genre. Best played with a controller. 

But it's not without its flaws...

STORY: 
The story is the main problem I had. There was a lot of unnecessary dialogue. A lot. I say unnecessary because dialogue is supposed to flesh out the characters and the world. There is a lot of talk about Him, Mother, penance and ivory (the lifeblood of the planet), and that's about it. 
The best part of the story was the optional, secret sidequest; Fitzroy. That sidequest was far better then the entire main story. I enjoyed his sidestory (although an unnecessary pain to find), his character design, and his battle a lot. It should have been easier to find so more could enjoy it, or put into the main story. I actually started to feel something but it was all over before I even had the chance to.
Some things were left unanswered (like Royal) and I feel a bit let down with the pacing. The focus was too much on what didn't matter in the end.
The best parts were the Mendeleev boss and the rocket battle. The final boss doesn't even come anywhere near as epic as those. The final boss' final form was very random and felt out of place. The starworm was all that was needed. I suppose with the existence of the final form, the possibilities leave it open for a sequel should one be made. 

CHARACTERS: 
I felt nothing for the characters. Zero. Except for Elro, which was a lot of hate. He has to the most useless character I've experienced in a long while. I found myself hating him very early on in the game and even wishing death upon him come a certain point. A useless, annoying, whingy coward, and when you finally get to control him, the dude with the sword, he's so slow, and again, useless. 
The main character Robin, with whom you're supposed to sympathise, is the generic silent-type who contributes nothing to the story. She just nods. The other characters like Mina and Royal are pretty cool, but could have been fleshed out a lot more than they were. They were the most fleshed out though, which isn't saying much. 
Come the 10-hour mark I was saying "Shut the f*** up" to my screen as I had stopped caring for the characters. I just wanted to see where the plot was going at its snail-pace. 

CHARACTER DESIGN: 
All the sprites are very, very well and smoothly animated. The character designs are unique and original. 
The only problem I had was, again, with Elro. If you're going to design a character who isn't symmetrical, animate both sides instead of just flipping the image. His eyepatch and which way his hair is combed changes sides depending on which way he's facing. That and something happens to him later on (no spoilers) which proves my point even more. I see this a lot with pixel art and it annoys me very much.
Some of the coolest character designs aren't in the story for long, like Mendeleev, Grey, Fitzroy, and even some NPCs look cooler than some of the main cast. 

LEVEL DESIGN: 
The only level design I didn't like was under Mina's home. I got tired of looking at its plain-ness. All other levels though look stunning. They're colourful, well designed and laid out, enemy placement is great, hidden areas like a Metroidvania game should. Even the tweak that tells you if there's any hidden areas on-screen doesn't help with 100% of them, encouraging exploration. 
The puzzles though left something to be desired. Too easy. The tougher puzzles were optional but needed doing if going for 100% of the chests.

MUSIC:
The music is mostly great. The boss themes are rockin' and fast, the green, grassy areas are upbeat and make you feel happy to be alive, the desert music feels nostalgic for some reason, but some do get repetitive. Like under Mina's home. It ended up being muted while I looked for hidden chests. 

GAMEPLAY:
The controls are flawless. Robin handles flawlessly. Zero lag. Combat is always fresh. 
My only gripe is about high-jumping. 
I kept thinking throughout the game "Oh, I can't jump up there. There must be a double-jump or a high-jump power-up later" but then I could get up there by jumping and then firing my powered-up shot downward, propelling me upward. 
You get the double-jump too late in the game, and it's optional. You get it AFTER defeating a secret boss, which is only available just before the FINAL boss. The main story can be completed, the other secret boss, Fitzroy, can be defeated, and 100% of the chests can be found without it. It's pointless. This should be a standard power-up in the main story which then allows access to previously inaccessible areas. When I learned I could just shoot myself upward, I completely forgot about the thought of a double-jump or high-jump. When I eventually got it (unexpectedly, and 15 hours in of the 17 it took me to finish 100%), I never even used it. 

THINGS THAT NEED TO BE ADDED TO AN UPDATE OR FUTURE TITLE(S): 
- Custom map markers. Axiom Verge (another Metroidvania-type game) allows 2 per map. Still, that's not enough for maps of this size. I ended up screenshotting the maps, pasting them into MS Paint and circling areas so I would remember to come back later. I forgot to screenshot 1 place and never got to go back. Even though I have 100% completed the game, it's an unexplored area. I have no memory of where it is. I can't find it again. 
- More power-ups, or get them sooner. Gameplay became repetitive and stagnant between them. 

OVERALL:
All in all, props to the creator. The credits were very short so I assume he made this by himself, and in Construct 2 no less. Very good job. I envy your talent. Take the negative things I've said here, put them on a scale and weigh them against everything positive about the game, and the positive wins.
I would gladly pay for and play a sequel, IF the story is paced better and the dialogue is more focused on what's relevant and what matters. I see no issues with the RRP. Good price

[list]
[*]The characters, specifically their backstories and the way they interact with one another, are definitely my favorite part of Iconoclasts. I especially like the way they influence- and are influenced by- the game's world. Things rarely "just happen"- the events of the story really do feel like consequences of the characters' actions, which are, in turn, informed by their diverse personalities. This theme continues right up until the end where things get especially dramatic.
[*]The game looks beautiful: the environment is vibrant and varied, and the characters are pleasantly expressive. [strike]Oh, and they're hella cute, too.[/strike]
[*]The sound design (especially the soundtrack) definitely deserves a mention. Your ears will enjoy this experience.
[*]The boss fights are fun, although some might find them a bit too simplistic.
[/list]
Overall, this feels like a very [i]sincere[/i] game. The themes Joakim Sandberg explores make for a very genuine personal experience. He has every reason to be proud of the game he spent so many years creating.

46174341.review:
This is a Metroidvania title with decent gameplay (the bosses are notably excellent) and great story. 

The story is a mix of Final Fantasy 7 and the Hunger Games: an authoritarian government rules the world, which is nearing its end as the resources people exploit are the very thing keeping the planet alive. It is dark with a fair share of eldritch horror and lots of deaths (you heard correctly, this is not safe for children). It's also smart that a lot of character and world development occur during gameplay, either in the form of a boss fight or otherwise, since it's easy to make a dark setting but hard to make people care-and Iconoclasts most definitely made me care about its world. It also has one of the most exciting and crazy epilogues I've ever seen in a video game. My biggest complaint about the story is the dissonance between narrative and gameplay, as narratively speaking the bosses in the game are so powerful that you have no business standing a chance against them.

Gameplay-wise, Iconoclasts doesn't evolve over time as much as other metroidvania titles, since you don't get many new abilities. The crafting system also isn't very interesting, as you can only get passive stat upgrades-and niche stats too, even though the majority of the puzzle and combat in the game involves shooting, there is no upgrade available for your gun.
The gameplay shines during boss fights, which are quite frequent: around 20 over a 15 hour story. While their designs range from good to amazing, the way you beat them usually isn't very interesting (namely, by shooting them repeatedly, or by waiting for the weak point to come out and then shooting it repeatedly).

Overall, I would without a doubt recommend this game for its story. If you only care about getting a good metroidvania experience, Iconoclasts is functional but not great, but even if you don't care about story, the boss fights are another nice selling point as well.

46105534.review:
[h1]Robin is the name[/h1[

This game is a major labor of love that I have been waiting years for. When this came out at the beginning of this year, I had a  strong feeling that this was almost a harbinger of good, quality games. Well, it's almost December now, and boy oh boy was I on the mark. But enough of that, about the game.

This game is phenominal! The controls are tight and Joakim again shows his understanding of excellent controls for a fast and fluid game. New skills are quick to learn, but tough to master! And there are some clever uses of the protagonists main weapon. It is very much styled to play like a polished smooth metroidvania (do people still use that term?).

The graphics are in the same beautiful pixel art that one would expect from his previous work. What makes this game particularly more impressive than previous titles in his collection is not just the wonderful full artwork/animation but the larger, more expansive scale of the game's world which requires more artwork. Not only that, but the more mature theme and design gives for more expressive sprite work that really shines end-game.

If you have read any of my reviews before, you know how much I like to gush about multi-faceted plots and stories that make you think. That being said, there's a whole reddit about it ([url=http://www.hchoutofleftfield.com/2018/11/iconoclasts-is-one-of-best-games-of-year.html]This review is actually pretty good![/url]) but I will cover some of the things that really struck out to me:

-The fact that [spoiler]Robin's name is literally foreshadowing to the final boss.[/spoiler] This is one of those "it's right there the WHOLE TIME and nobody is aware.
-Robin being mute and the implications. [spoiler]The thoughts are that the tragedy which killed her dad affected her badly, but there's also hints of something happened between her and her father. Again, I could be reading into it, maybe Robin was angry he left? Maybe he was never there? We never get the full picture, which I honestly love.[/spoiler]
-[spoiler]The entire nightmare sequence. It perfectly encapsulates the theme of the game.[/spoiler]
-[spoiler]Agent Black. Anyone who played fully understands.[/spoiler]

This game is quite the trip and I urge people to play it. If you're a fan of metroidvania or games with well thought out and deep plots, this game is definitely for you!

Iconoclasts is a wonderful game.
Not only is this game a glorious throwback to the 90's with beautiful pixel art, tight no-nonsense platforming and an infectious chiptune soundtrack, but it manages to bring those ideas into the modern era with a gripping story, memorable characters and enough creative, thrilling boss fights to appease even the most hardened Dark Souls fan.
I could ramble for hours about the individual moments which made this my game of the year, but rather than bore you all with a wall of incomprehensible spoilers, I'll just say this: if you like gorgeously designed retro throwbacks, buy this game. If you like games with a cast of relatable heroes and imposing, deeply-layered villains, buy this game. If you like a spectacle without any of the nonsense getting in the way of the fun, buy this game. And hey, even if my paragraph of gushing hasn't won you over, do yourself a favour and take five minutes to check this game out - believe me when I say it's deserving of your time.

45922041.review:
Iconoclasts is a genre-fusing adventure that combines platforming, puzzles, metroidvania exploration, and impressive boss battles, tying these elements together with a story about the suffering that emerges when trying to change the world.

Iconoclasts casts the player in the role of silent protagonist, Robin: a young mechanic working illegally beneath the shadow of One Concern, a tyrannical and near-omnipresent theocracy. When her transgressions place her in the sights of One Concern's agents, she graduates from fixing old machines to trying to fix the world and society she inhabits.

Between story beats, you'll run and jump through pixel-art environments that are popping with color, using your wrench and your wits to bypass many small puzzles. Though these puzzles are rarely ever very challenging, they all feel impeccably designed, with just enough trickery to make them satisfying to solve. There are plenty of fodder enemies around too, but many of them are small puzzles as well, requiring you to figure out the right trick to bypassing them. However, Iconoclasts' real showstoppers are the bosses. The game has plenty of boss fights, most of them large, elaborate affairs with giant machines or grotesque monsters. But while the bosses are the highlights, every aspect of the gameplay feels exceptionally polished, thanks in part to great controls that feel responsive and even tactile, like the pleasant repetition of working Robin's wrench to open up a door or swing off a grapple point.

It is when the game returns to the story, though, that Iconoclasts really shines. Robin meets a colorful cast of friends and enemies who all have immediately compelling personalities. There's Mina, a pirate whose rebellious impulses are slowly alienating her from her loved ones. Elro, Robin's protective older brother who fears Robin will fall into the same pitfalls he stumbled into. Royal, a priviledged and sheltered elite who comes face to face with his own inadequacies. Even the villains are sympathetic and layered. All of them tie together into the game's core themes about how rebellion changes, harms, and even destroys those trying to effect change, and it's that thematic cohesion that really lets Iconoclasts' story shine.

In summary, Iconoclasts combines slick, polished, and varied gameplay with a powerful narrative bursting with wonderful characters and excellent writing. It's fun, cohesive, compelling, and I highly recommend it.

45588202.review:
A gorgeous game with a great soundtrack and fun, kinetic gameplay...most of the time.

This game really is a treat to look at and listen to. The level designs are fun, there's just enough exploration and customization to never get bored but never feel overwhelmed either. Honestly, I can't say enough good things about the main experience of playing this game.

However, there are a few hiccups. Especially in some of the later boss fights, Iconoclasts has trouble getting out of its own way. It throws a lot of ideas at you, and most of them are good, but the last quarter of the game or so feels less like Iconoclasts and more like a series of unpolished mini games starring the supporting cast. (eg, a boss fight that consists solely of slowly trudging to the right punctuated by attacking once every 15 or so seconds when you get close enough to the thing you're trudging towards.) There are also some issues with the dialogue that feel a bit like translation issues, which I wouldn't bother pointing out in most games, but given Iconoclasts's convoluted story they really do make a difference.

All in all, This is a fantastic game, really fun to play, and a joy to look at. Just don't be in too big a hurry to finish it, since it kind of falls apart at the end.

45575874.review:
Was interested by the game's artstyle so I picked it up to try it. At first the game was fine, and just fine, but the more I played, the more I disliked it. 

The gameplay is mediocre, enemies all have simple AND similar mechanics. In a fun bossfight, you would have to figure out the bosses' patterns and movements, but in Iconoclasts, boss fights are just another puzzle to figure out. None of the gameplay is really engaging, as your starter shot locks on, your groundpound also locks on, there's really no skill involved to play this game. The puzzles in this game were so frustrating; either they were super easy or super tedious (eg. the tower level). Those tedious levels made me lose my patience for the game, so at most parts I just ended up looking up a walkthrough (which I usually don't do unlesss I'm really stuck and tried everything I could do). Also, for being marketed as a metroidvania, the gameplay and area discovery is very much linear.

The storyline is boring, I am usually very invested in story rich games, but this one was just uninteresting and confusing. The story itself is all over the place, and tries too hard to be "deep" and different. Being a good artist does not make you a good writer, I understand that it takes time and effort to make a game like this by yourself, but it still does not excuse bad and boring writing.

Many elements of the game are also missing. For maps, you can only see the map for the area you're in, as there is no single world map you are able to see. Side quests are terribly designed, once you leave the person that gives you the side quest, you're not able to check the item/quest in your inventory for what you need to do again (you had to go back to the person to check what you need to do), so sidequests were basically forgotten through my playthrough.

Overall: This game has been mis-marketed as a metroidvania, but is actually just a long ass puzzle game with confusing writing and nice visuals.

45537173.review:
Iconoclasts is a Metroidvania 2D action adventure game created by Joakim Sandberg, a Swedish game developer who is famous for his Noitu Love series. This game has been in development for 8 years - since 2010. You may have noticed that Iconoclasts is inspired by the developer's previous game, Ivory Springs (2007). This means that the developer has been working on this title for a very long time. So the more you play this game, the more you'll be impressed by the developer's amazing work!

The world of Iconoclasts is dominated by a gigantic & wicked religious group called 'The One Concern' who worship space worms. Furthermore, they monopolize 'Ivory Fuel', a divine substance that is the source of the world and the power source of all living things. In this rough world, you play as Robin. She is an innocent girl who helps people as an unauthorized mechanic. But don't you worry. She has stun guns & wrenches as her trusty weapons. These weapons allow the player to solve various problems in the beautiful & cruel world of Iconoclasts.

In this game, players will encounter many puzzles that they'll have to solve by using their wrenches & stun guns. But the puzzles you will face never get tiresome. The more you play this game, the more you'll become immersed. This means that the puzzles of Iconoclasts are well designed. In addition, since combat and puzzles are not played separately, users will have a fresh experience throughout the game. Especially if you use the 'Tweak' system properly, your Robin will become even more special. The boss battles are also one of the most enjoyable aspects of this game. There are various methods needed to defeat each boss and with every win, you'll have a huge sense of accomplishment.

Iconoclasts has another charm you should not miss - the story & characters of the game. Aside from the puzzles and adventures, you will encounter various unique people on your journey. There are characters who are helping each other through all their suffering and characters who give up because of the frustrations of the world. By interacting with these people, you'll become more and more immersed in this game. Eventually you'll grow to understand this world and love the game.

If you want engaging storytelling, novel puzzles, and a Metroidvania-style action adventure game along with challenging boss battles, Iconoclast will definitely be a game worth playing. You don't want to miss the beautiful pixel art & exciting music. There are so many things to love that I may not have even found them all. I strongly recommend Iconoclasts!

45402260.review:
Ok, let me start this review by saying: You might enjoy this game! Chances are pretty high actually. Most people enjoy it. I did not. Just do not have the wrong expectations!

Iconoclasts IS NOT A METROIDVANIA. This game is a story-heavy puzzle-platformer and all the gimmicks, puzzles and bossfights seem to be hit-or-miss, really.

While most parts of Iconoclasts gameplay seem to be aimed at children, it's storyline is not. The story is getting pretty dark, pretty quickly and I really enjoyed it. There's some kind of Anime-vibe to it. One moment, everyone is joking around, next moment, shit is hitting the fan, arms are being ripped off and people explode. Iconoclast is really getting carried by it's bad guys. They are all awesome! But the german translation however, is not. If I had known how garbage it would be, I would have played it in english but what's done is done.

One example: A guy called Ash says: "Du hast mich weggegeben." What he probably said in english was: "You gave me away." So, he meant, his physical position was given away. But in german he pretty much says: "You gave me to somebody else." So, yeah, screw that. So many literal translations in the german version it's not even funny. It makes you think, you are reading an instruction manual instead of other peoples conversations.

Like I said before, the level- and puzzledesign can only be described as hit or miss. The level I enjoyed the most is called "The Tower." The only metroidvania-ish part of the game. What happens is, you lose your weapons and powerups and have to get them back, in a magical-tower-like environment. You need to understand how all the rooms are connected and drawing a map of the place in your mind also really helps. That was great! By far, the best part of the game.

Iconoclasts bosses are pretty good most of the time but only when the bossfights aren't puzzles with a healthbar. That happens way too often. Like, you know, the worst bosses in the Zelda-franchise also are more of a puzzle than an actual fight. "Use the item you found in this dungeon, to defeat the boss!" Would be pretty cool, if I hadn't used this item a million times before! In shitty, way too easy puzzles! And there are so many shitty puzzles. I only enjoyed maybe 20-30% of them.

Also playing on hard did not really spice the game up, either. The only times the difficulty gave me trouble, were in a few really cryptic boss-fights. I would have had trouble on any difficulty when I just did not understand what the game expects me to do. And that is exactly, what the game was going for in these fights! Make them like a puzzle, this is gonna be good. It might be good if you are a certain kind of player. I just dindn't really enjoy it. And uhm... why does Iconoclasts ask me to lower the difficulty every time I am reloading my save!? That doesn't make any sense at all!

45389557.review:
I have mixed feelings about Iconoclasts. I picked it up after watching a positive review where the combination of a plot about a young woman fighting against an auhtoritarian suystem and the bright, colorful presentation piqued my interest. I basically came into this expecting a fun adventure with some dark elements, which was not quite what i got. It's not really the fault of the game, but it affected my experience regardless.

I'm not much a gameplay guru, so I can't go into any depth about the gameplay. It was fun. There were some points that required some pretty precise timing that gave me some grief, and there were points where it took me way too long to figure out what i was supposed to be doing. Other than that, playing the game is fun. I kinda wish the 3rd weapon had been introduced earlier, since it's by far the most interesting one and opens up some neat opportunities for puzzle design, but that's a small thing.

Really the thing that killed this one for me is the story. It starts out fun enough, when some wacky supersoldiers show up to your house to execute you for working as a mechanic illegally but get distracted and allow you escape, and continues even more fun when the same wacky supersoldiers catch you hiding in your brother's house and proceed to murder his entire family. And that's only the start!

Dark plots are fine, really, but after several hours of everything being terrible and every person you encounter being either an asshole or on the fast road to murdertown, and sometimes both, it started to get a little hard to care about anything in the game. It doesn't help that the game is fairly long by indie rpg standards, so the journey to shitville feels like it's dragging on forever. I still haven't beat the final boss, and probably never will, because i just don't care enough about the world to drag myself through that whole pain in the ass fight to save it. The sheer level of cynicism emanating from this game is honestly mystifying, especially when paired with its presentation.

Said presentation is the high point of the game. The 8-bit graphics are beautiful, the animations are lively, the music is fun. While regular enemies are good to fight, it's the massive bosses with their threatening presence and over-the-top attacks that steal the show. They just feel like a massive threat and beating them feels like an accomplishment. Similarly, while most of the characters were, to me at least, completely unlikable,the way they're drawn and animated makes it hard not to be endeared by them at least a little. Even when half the lines they spout read like they came out of google translate.

The dialogue was the real low point of the game for me, even more than the hilariously bleak storyline. There's grammatical errors, confusing turns of phrase, thesaurus words showing up next to casual speech with no rhyme or reason. All the times i had to stop and reread a sentence to try and figure out what it was supposed to mean, or found myself mentally rewriting a line to sound more natural, added up until what is normally the part of a game I'm most excited about turned into a chore. And it's a real shame, because there's plenty of little jokes and personality-revealing lines that might've been great if translated by someone who can fluently speak the language.

I realise I've been going on about the flaws of this game more than its good points, and that's because I'm disappointed. I wanted to have fun playing this game, but all these little things gradually chipped away at my enjoyment until i just didn't care anymore. It's far too well made to give it a negative vote, and it's very likely that someone who's not as sensitive to these things as I am will have a great time playing this game.

45383774.review: This is a wonderful little metroidvania game that blends great platforming with combat mechanics, and some wonderful puzzles thrown around in there aswell. I like it.

45379707.review:
MAJOR SPOILERS BELOW:

This is a very good Metroidvania game. Both the story and the gameplay are top-notch. Still, there were a few weaknesses in the story and the gameplay that stop the game from being AMAZING.

Let's start with gameplay. It should be pointed out that most of the gameplay requires either platforming or solving puzzles. There's not that much "combat". Let's be clear, your character can attack. There's a melee attack and 3 different ranged attacks. However, the attacks are honestly just a "tool" for you to solve puzzles.
	• Melee attack: You will mostly use this to solve puzzles. You can also "parry" attacks of certain enemies of bosses by melee attacking at the right time, but you don't have to use this all that often. You will pretty much NEVER just normally melee attack because the ranged attacks always do more damage and are safer.
	• 1st ranged attack: You will use this to kill basic enemies and early game bosses. The basic enemies provide pretty much no challenge. Hell there's not even any incentive to kill them. You get no experience or loot drops, so it's a better idea to just jump past them if you can.
	• 2nd ranged attack: A "bomb" weapon that is used for a lot of puzzles.
	• 3rd ranged attack: Used for puzzles and defeating late game bosses.

So yea the game focuses on puzzles, platforming, and combat, in that order. Hell even most of the early bosses are just one big puzzle in the sense that once you figure out their pattern, the battles become easy as hell. However, I should point out that the late game bosses feel like proper "battles" in the sense that it's not just a matter of figuring out a pattern. Late game bosses have like 4-8 attacks and you have to react fast enough in order to dodge the attacks. I personally prefer combat so I enjoyed the late game bosses a lot more. Basic enemies are ALWAYS no challenge though :P.

In regards to the actual quality of the puzzles, platforming, and combat, they're all well done and varied. Everything is not too complicated/difficult, but not painstakingly easy either. There's also a lot of "tools" that you have in order to solve puzzles (in addition to your attacks) and you'll constantly be using multiple tools for a puzzle as well as using different sets of tools between puzzles. So the game constantly moves at a nice pace without ever becoming boring. 

One flaw with the gameplay though is the upgrade system. You can't level up in this game and you can't find loot to improve your stats (there are not stats). The only way to improve your character is by crafting and equipping "tweaks" of which you can equip 3 of. To do this, first you have to find the schematic for the tweak and then you have to find the materials in order to build it. First of all, most of the tweaks are very boring. They're like "Stop damage once" or "hold breath underwater longer" or " move slightly faster". Second of all, if you get hit once, your rightmost tweak gets disabled. This means that if you get hit 3 times, all your tweaks stop working. I think this was a really poor design decision. You can get hit randomly at any time while exploring and when facing bosses, so you'll be out like 1-2 tweaks constantly. For most of the game, I had "Double-Jump" and "Stop damage once" times 2 as my tweaks. I never changed my tweaks because….. Well the tweaks are really boring and that was usually the best setup :P. So yea the upgrade system was not engaging at all.

Now we come to the story. Essentially, this game has a main story focusing around the world and sort of the main character and 4 side stories focusing on 4 side characters. The main story is about how the world is ending and you have to save it. At the same time, the world is currently controlled by a religious organization called "One Concern" and the leaders of this organization are planning on taking rockets and leaving the planet. Not everyone knows about this within the organization, creating a lot of interesting interactions between characters. Also, this organization is very dark and you see some messed up shit. Overall, great main story. There are some unanswered questions and a "What the Fuck is Going On" type thing with the final boss, but overall I was engaged throughout my play time. The side stories are more hit and miss:
	• Mina: She has an over-bearing mother plus Mina is an adventurous type and so she wants to stay away from home most of the time. This causes her mother to feel abandoned making her become even more over-bearing and so a vicious cycle ensues. I liked this story because let's just say, I can understand :P
	• Elro: His father died because of the religious organization, and so he wanted to take down the organization down. He succeeds in killing one of the important members, but in turn his wife and daughter die. This causes him to get PTSD and a series of unfortunate events occur that cause him to lose an arm and a leg (literally) and make him very…. "withdrawn" from the world. Tragic story. Interesting.
	• Royal: He's supposed to be the successor of the leader of the religious organization. However, he's spoiled and kind of stupid so the religious organization eventually shuns him. While he may have his faults, he has the best of intentions at heart and so he helps your hero try to save the world. I felt a lot of pity for this guy and was really looking forward to his "redemption". Like, he's been constantly been called useless and told that he should just die  by some of his closest former friends and family. Really sad. UNFORTUNATELY, near the end of the game, YOUR CHARACTER has to sacrifice him in order to save herself. NO REDEMPTION. I really hated this. REALLY HATED THIS. This character deserved better.
	• Agent Black: She's one of the main "villains" and does messed up shit throughout the game. However, as you progress through the game you learn about why she's like this and you come to understand her. Basically, she's immortal and it is very difficult to kill her. Her existence is painful and she's tried to commit suicide multiple times. At some point she found someone important to her, but then she lost him and became even more bitter about the world. Now all that's left is her "duty" and she will give everything she has for that duty. Without a doubt, she is my favorite character in the entire game. Great villain. 

I have to give Kudos for how much emotion the developers were able to convey. There are no voice-overs in the game, but through animating the characters and there speech bubbles, it was as if I was watching scenes in real life. The developers did SUCH a great job in making me understand how the characters were feeling.

Overall, this is a great game. While I would've preferred more combat, a more engaging upgrade system, and for Royal to not get SCREWED OVER, I definitely enjoyed my time playing it :).

45011445.review:
Iconoclast as a game starts off strong and then petters out over about twelve hours. As a Metroidvania game, it has to compete with powerhouses that work with incredibly tight control schemes and minimalistic stories. As a Metroidvania, its pattern is well-defined: jump around, find hidden caches, blast enemies, and unlock a story. On all of these fronts, a succession of small flaws build up to undermine the game.

The platforming is alright, but not great. You jump around as usual, but there are a number of small repeated frustration points. For example, most jumping requires grabbing the ledge. This process requires a half second climbing animation. Not much, right? Except every. single. platform. seems to require this. The entire world is built to be just high enough to never properly clear. You won't unlock double jump until quite literally the end of the game, so enjoy hanging from the edge of platforms over and over...and over...

There are other control quirks as well. Why is it that you need 1.5 charges on the wrench to electrify instead of 1? Why is the hitbox on the pipe sections so narrow that you can miss it by jumping too close? Why does the down stomp require such pixel-perfect alignment? Why is Mina's shotgun so poorly controlled and require her to stand lock still? Why does the 8directional shot on the guns sometimes trigger and sometimes not? None of these sink the game, but they are annoyances that build over the game's playtime.

With other genres I would give these sorts of quirks a pass. Not with metroidvanias. This genre lives and dies by the details of its controls. 

Then there are the negative tropes. Did you want a prolonged stealth section where you have to crawl along? Have one! That not enough? How about a stealth boss section?! What about a section where you lose all your equipment? Great, have one! A boss battle while without most equipment? Have one! Invulnerable enemies in tight hallways to harass you? Have an entire gauntlet of them!

Like all Metroidvanias, the treasure hunting comes with a large dose of "Find the fake wall" and "find the hidden platform". While obnoxious, this is kind of expected, so I give that a wash. Just use a guide to find those last couple chests.

The story is incomprehensible. After finishing the game, I thought I had accidentally triggered a joke ending. No major plot points are resolved, none of the characters grow, and the artist apparently thinks this constitutes a deep story. The driver of the story is an angry, smelly pirate and your overbearing brother yelling the same damn thing at each other, over and over and over. This game subscribes to the avant garde version of story where you are dropped into a setting with no information, no explanations, and no resolution so that you can feel the same annoyance as trying to sort out your in-laws dinner plans over the phone.

Also, everyone with speaking lines is a giant dickbag. Just...just a giant dickbag. I was actively hoping for a full party wipe by the halfway mark of the game.

I'd rate Iconoclasts 4/10. Its not terrible, but it is competing with Momodora, Hollow Knight, and Metroid. Mediocre simply is not a passing grade in such a crowded and well established genre.

44938088.review:
Feels like Shantae with some Mario & Luigi sass and an increasingly dark tone.

Iconoclasts nails its aesthetic.  There is so much care and effort put into all of the animations and details that it's continually mind-boggling that the game is ~150 MB.  These are pixel graphics but every little thing is designed to have punch, even the dialogue boxes.  They got a lot out of very little.  As for the game, it's an excellent linear adventure-platformer.  There's a lot of variation in gameplay with a gripping story that keeps you continously invested without getting bored.  The controls are simple but fulfilling and the bosses are a lot of fun, if maybe a little easy.  Not every game needs to be hard though, and there's a lot to enjoy here while you sail through.

Unfortunately if you don't sail through, you'll find the metroidvania aspect of the game to be fairly weak.  The incentive for exploring off the beaten path is to get designs/materials to craft Tweaks which are small equippable powerups.  Unfortunately, most of the Tweaks are very weak and uninteresting, which removes most of the reward for finding these collectibles.  Making matters worse, backtracking is required for many of them, and backtracking in this game really sucks.  You eventually get a fast travel hub between zones, but you often have to backtrack to an area after you complete it to unlock it for that zone, and you can't ever warp back to the hub.  All this said, the bright side of how weak Tweaks are is that you can just ignore collecting the ones that aren't fun and not have to deal with this.

I've heard Iconoclasts described as a series of metroidvania vertical slices, which I think is a good summary of what does and doesn't work about the game.  Forget about backtracking, and you'll have a well-paced narrative with varied gameplay.  Get bogged down trying to 100% it, and you'll probably end up questioning whether it was worth your time.

The weaker side of this game would be it's story, that is inconsistent in quality. An excessive amount characters and plot threads with a spoonful too much melodrama turned me off to begin with. The cut scenes are also far too frequent and it harms the pace of the game. 
However, I did find myself getting more invested in it towards the end once I'd had the chance to properly sink into the world. But unfortunately (minor spoiler) the ending was awful. After such a strong build it's as if the creator gave up on the idea of writing a good climax and the game finishes with a cheap, lazy cop out.

Despite this the game still has more strengths than flaws and is worth the time and money.

44736474.review:
[b] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31067175/] If you enjoy this review please consider following my Curator page here [/url]. [/b]


I’ve always been immensely impressed when a game comes out that is, more or less, made by one person. When you look at games such as Braid, Dust: An Elysian Tale and Thomas Was Alone it’s abundantly clear that they were made with great care and have benefited from the personalized attention that only a game made by one person could provide. The dedication that it must take to make a game on your own is daunting, and something that I certainly respect. You can add Iconoclasts to that list as it took developer Joakim Sandberg nearly ten years to complete his project.

Sandberg’s efforts mostly pay off as he has created what I would call a Metroidvania-lite set in an interesting world. I use the term “lite” because while this has elements of the Metroidvania genre, like using new abilities to access previously unavailable areas, it’s incredibly linear. While you do have access to fast travel at some point, the game pushes you forward in the story at such a pace that it’s not really encouraged or even necessary to revisit old areas. There are no persistent upgrades and simply “tweaks” that provide buffs to your existing abilities. While I did not mind this approach, I could definitely see it off-putting to some expecting your traditional Metroidvania affair.

The combat here is perfectly competent, if not unspectacular. You have ranged and melee attacks, and while they work just fine, there is not much depth to the combat. Where the game does shine, however, is in the excellent puzzle design and inventive boss battles. You’ll probably spend more time solving puzzles than fighting and I found this to be a non-issue as the puzzles are rewarding and use your powers and abilities in quite a clever fashion. Despite the combat not being stellar, the boss battles were surprisingly unique and was one of the highlights of the game for me.

The music is also just a joy to listen to. Mostly filled with light and delightful tones, there’s some really great tracks here and never got old across my ten or so hours of playtime.

One thing that I was somewhat at odds with was the plot. While the world building is initially interesting, I found it to be a bit convoluted at times. The game tackles religious themes and allegories, which is no small undertaking. It mostly sticks the landing, but it can get lost in the weeds at times and I found you motivation to be doing something a bit muddled. That said, the cast of characters are pretty great with each person having a defined and unique personality.

Iconoclasts is immensely impressive, if even for the fact that it was made by one person. For it to be a better than average puzzle platformer is just icing on the cake for me. If some of my problems and concerns give you pause, I’d say wait for a sale to check out Iconoclasts. It’s a good game that I’m sure a lot of people will like.
