44693259.review:
It's rough on the edges, but it's an experience worth having, at least for the first few hours of gameplay. Wait for it to go on sale. I would prefer to mark this game as "informative" rather than "not recommended", but that option is only offered to curators AFAICT.

The gameplay is mostly solid, animations are lively, and the music really captures the mood of each area and boss battle. The controls are tight and responsive, though I don't really agree with the decision to cram 3 guns onto 1 button with a switcher button. The game was not hurting for buttons to use and almost every modern controller is going to have at least 6 buttons. Actually, it's just a little shy on using buttons in general. I guess that makes it substantially more accessible to 1-handed gamers like halfcoordinated (who is in the credits as a tester), but it would still be nice to have the option available as a 2-handed gamer. The curb cut effect is not helping here.

Minor spoilers ahead.

The game starts off strong, but drags on longer than is welcome. There are two bits of gameplay that absolutely destroy the pacing- a stealth section that is poorly explained, and a slow-paced crawl with an incapacitated Elro followed by a slow-paced boss battle that drags on far too long. Other than that, the powerups were fun and the exploration, while limited for this genre, was satisfying. It actually is pretty interesting how there are no upgrades to health maximum or number of tweak slots (unless they were just insanely well hidden), which is sort of a refreshing departure from the typical metroidvania.

Boss design wasn't particularly memorable. Nothing to write home about.

The story on the other hand... Honestly kind of terrible and hard to follow. Robin is just another silent protagonist with chronic hero syndrome, Mina is hot-headed and one-dimensional, Elro is a bland nihilist who sorta accidentally is badass sometimes, Royal is a whiny spoiled brat whose motives are inconsistent and who never has a chance to redeem himself. There are so many missed opportunities for story choices, only being offered meaningless choices that you just know won't actually affect anything substantial. I would describe the game's story as a bittersweet wandering plot, as it lacked a clear structure and had a murky and unsatisfying climax.

This game was almost a chore to finish due to the wandering plot and weak late game.

Konjak's distinct sprite style shines once again, and the gameplay--while not as fluid as Noitu Love 2's--is still quite fun.

Overall, a solid game, just wish that Konjak had left his agenda out of it.

44659207.review:
While the game looks amazing, the mechanics and overall design do not live up to the same level.

Iconoclasts is not clear with it's design. Game mechanics are usually shown by walking next to a sign, but many of the signs fail to convey clearly what the player is supposed to do. Am I supposed to just press and let go of a button, or keep the button pressed down? When should I do this, and what should happen? It isn't until you've most likely failed and messed around with the mechanic while taking damage that the true intent is discovered.

On top of this, you get three "tweaks" with bonuses to things like movement speed, melee attack power etc. but you'll lose one tweak if you take damage. To get back that tweak, you need to destroy enough enemies to repair said tweak. This mechanic combined with how many times you'll take damage because of the game slapping you for not reading a walkthrough, I don't feel challenged by an obstacle but rather punished for simply playing the game.

Puzzles are finicky with placements and timing, and doing damage to some enemies is more luck than skill. Bosses have mechanics that are not explicitly shown or even slightly nudged towards, and your supposed to notice something at the edge of a screen like a small lever or a button etc. while focusing on dodging incoming projectiles and eliminating spawned enemies. Few times I was left wondering where I needed to go to advance the story, and I simply stumbled upon the right place when scavenging for secrets.

Overall, playing Iconoclasts ended up being a frustrating experience, and it didn't show signs of improvement.

44642845.review:
The story and narrative in this game are kind of bafflingly good, and you can tell it was created by a single person with their own specific ideas rather than by a committee - it's a little opaque and a little strange and a little ecclectic, all in ways that add charm and interest. There are a surprisingly complex cast of characters with backstories and relationships and perspectives of their own, and the experience of discovering these characters and the world they live in was really fascinating, supported by expressive character art and dialog UI.

The initial setup of the world and the antagonists was unusually fascinating too, compared to the rote and cliché-filled narratives in most games; it did get a bit tropey by the end, and it dropped a few story threads that I would have liked to see through to the end (like the way cartography and engineering have been regulated and made nigh illegal), but overall it's a step above most game stories in terms of inventiveness and depth.

Mechanically, this was a decent puzzle-platformer, largely fun but occasionally a tiny bit frustrating when complex puzzles demand you do things that you've never been introduced to before. There are times when game mechanics are leveraged to convey narrative ideas, and those work really well. Some of the combat, especially the boss fights, felt like they would have been an awful pain on harder difficulty modes, but as I played on easy I had a pretty good time with them, treating them as slightly more annoying puzzles to figure out rather than frustrating Groundhog Day fights.

By the end of the game, I felt like there had been a good balance of puzzle-platforming and meaty story - these are some hours well-spent, and I highly recommend you give this a try.

I went into Iconoclasts expecting a Metroidvania; a big interconnected map that I'd traverse while collecting upgrades. It's... Not that. It's more of a puzzle platformer. The puzzles are generally clever, and there's hidden stuff to discover, and some upgrades to receive. But that hidden stuff isn't terribly useful (you really only need the Tweaks that negate damage) and what few upgrades you can get are received through the story.

Iconoclasts really shines in design, however. The story is fantastic, and by the end of the game, I was on the verge of tears. Joakim Sanberg has single-handedly crafted a genuinely fascinating world, with lots of wonderfully flawed characters. The art is fantastic throughout, and every bit of music is catchy. If you appreciate games that ooze style and emphasise plot, this is the game for you.

TL;DR: What this game is just 'okay' in terms of core gameplay, the writing more than makes up for that. Highly recommended. Should last you about 10 hours.

44396901.review:
I like to read a lot of negative reviews before I write anything about a game. If you read any negative reviews and the reviewer only played the game for a couple hours, I wouldn't pay any attention to it. In their defense the game does take a while to get interesting (story wise) so I get it. Personally I couldn’t bring myself to leave a skid mark on someone’s hard work without playing through at least a majority of the game. Also this game was made by a single person. 1 human made this game. Like by himself. It isn’t pure metroidvania but it’s similar. There is a lot of puzzle/platforming elements in this game that make is less of a metroidvania. It’s also on the linear side with some backtracking. 

I went into this game knowing almost nothing about it other than thinking it looked worth a play through. It appears to be all happy with cute characters and bright colors with upbeat music. I was expecting a game similar to the Shantae series. Ho-ly-shit this game gets pretty dark and fucked up. Don’t let a little kid play this. I think it’s appropriately rated as a T title but goddamn there are a few cut scenes where some violent shit happens and my jaw was on the floor while whispering “wtf???” After a couple hours you start to realize what’s going on in the world. A lot of the negative reviewers that finished the game say they hated the story. I enjoyed it a lot. I thought all the characters were unique and multi-layered. They all change throughout the story too. I felt empathetic and attached to them. The game doesn’t spoon feed the whole story to you. I was motivated to look up fan theories and more info on the lore. It’s pretty impressive for one man’s work. If you really want to understand and appreciate the game for what it is without looking up shit, start a new game+ and play through some of the beginning hours and things will start to click more than the first time. Little things like posters on walls, background images, narrative, and even the environment details seem to pop out and make sense giving you those “ah ha!” moments. I love when games have detail this well done.

There are some very light rpg elements here. You can explore and find items to add little perks like swinging your wrench longer, free hits, movement speed, etc., but none of them will break the game at all. You could play through the game without paying much mind to them if you really wanted.

I got it during the summer sale for like 70% off or something. Feels like I robbed someone for how great this game was. I think the $20.00 full price tag is very reasonable for how deep this story is.

TL:DR
Game made by 1 person over a long time
Extremely well-polished, loved all the boss fights
Game looks cute and happy but story gets quite dark and deep after a couple hours
Definitely get it if it’s on sale but it’s worth the full price tag IMO

44318725.review:
Unlike most people, I didn't really like this game all that much. I thought it was okay, and it is indeed a "good game," but it's not for me. I was promised a Metroidvania, and what I got was a relatively basic (gameplay-wise) action-puzzle-platformer with a dearth of the RPG elements I really wanted. I don't know why they went the route they did with the Tweak system (you can get up to a max of three buffs that one of breaks every time you take damage, and the buffs themselves are relatively minor) instead of just having a normal sort of upgrade/level system, but I still wish they hadn't. When going into the game, I expected to be unlocking new weapons and abilities left and right, but was disappointed when I discovered only two other weapons in the whole game (one of which you only unlock close to the end) and that the character's moveset is more-or-less static aside from a scant couple wrench upgrades that aren't really useful in battle or movement aside from a couple pre-determined areas and feel clunky to use. Give me a double jump, give me a dash; just give me anything, please, and design the game around that.

The real appeal of the game lies in two points: it's visuals and its world. The art style is gorgeous, and the game's graphical abilities are more than enough to accurately get it across to you, The world is all thematically consistent, and it doesn't just do things for the sake of doing them. The fact that the three most basic shapes (triangles, circles, and squares) are all used in abundance integrates well with the nature of the game's world that you eventually find out about.

Unfortunately, however, I felt like the game's writing really betrayed any potential that the world and story had to be great. All the characters felt stiff to me, the dialogue felt confusing and vague at times, and by the end of the story, the only one I actually cared about at all was Robin (mostly because she didn't have any dialogue to tarnish the character I imagined her to have), though I also liked Royal (a character that does a heel-face turn and helps you out) to an extent. The characters all seem to get angry over things that aren't well-communicated or don't have a lot of build-up, and they're all frustratingly bull-headed for no good reason (or, if it is a good reason, it's, again, not well-communicated or built up to; characters just sort of seem to do things because the plot demands it). I know this was a game made by one man, but it'd be twice the game it currently is if he had hired a more experienced writer who knew what he was doing (no offense intended, but that's the truth of my feelings).

I really did want to like this game, but I don't. It's just not for me. Don't let anyone tell you it belongs in the same category as SotN, Axiom Verge, Metroid, Hollow Knight, Rabi-Ribi, or any other Metroidvania. If that's what you're buying this for, you'll be nothing but disappointed.

I pulled the trigger on buying Iconoclasts on a whim. I'm glad I did.

Not knowing what to expect outside of a "metroidvania" type game, I quickly became enamored by the Characters, the music, the atmosphere, and the story.

The story isn't flawless, and I have one complaint, but otherwise, I haven't become obsessed with an "IP" like this in a long time. 

After my first playthrough, I was ACHING for more, DLC, Comics, more cutscenes, ANYTHING.

I'm not sure if I'll get it, but I really love this game.

There are some interesting parallels to the real world that I appreciate, in regards to society.

44104225.review:
This game is terrible at communicating to the player.

It's never a good sign when I have to check steam forums and reddit for how to beat half the enemies, and not just the bosses. I've run into a couple baseline enemies that just do not communicate clearly to the player their weak points. If the enemies are invunerable against everything but one specific type of attack, then you need to clearly communicate to the player what is expected of them. If it fires a handful of projectiles at me, and I need to knock a specific one back at it, then make it a different colour to the others. If I need to hit these specific points in a boss battle (this switch, that crank, those gears, that glowing spot) in a specific sequence then have each part change visuals as it becomes relavent, don't just have them all flash and move about.

I have honestly given up; you get an ability to use the wrench to ride along glowing rails, and I reached a part which required me to ride a rail over a spiked floor with enemies that spit poison gas up at you as you approach. The enemies are invunerable to your guns, you have to stomp on their heads; but then you land in the spikes and get hurt, assuming you even managed to hit them through the poison gas (which you can't). You can't ride past them as they spit at your approach, so it's not a timing puzzle, there's no apparent brake for the rail grinding (the game at least has tutorial signposts as each mechanic is required, at first, so I'm pretty sure there isn't a brake), there is no other direction to go instead, and there's nothing about that suggests any method to get past them (oh, and this is about 5 mins from the nearest save point, so that right there is a rage quit moment)

I give up. I am done with this game. Even if I either find out how to beat this challenge, there'll just be another one right after it, another platforming challenge, new basic enemy or boss fight with no idea what I'm expected to do to deal with it.

I played this mostly on the Switch version, I never really got into it on Steam.

44079633.review:
Usually when I write a review, I try to say as much as possible, and it's probably not really worth it. I want to go over every aspect rather than focus on the things that stood out for me, but I'm not good at it. For Iconoclasts, I'd love nothing more than to unpack how you shouldn't underestimate the 'cute' pixel graphics. People die in the first 30 minutes (if you're slow) and there's no magic 'resurrection' story gimmick in the game. A guy loses an arm and the main characters spend no small amount of time trying to find 'Mother' who supposedly has the power to fix it-- only to find out she can't. I'd want to spend some time talking about how the music is so on-point it's creepy. It's so good it's downloadable (oh look, DLC, *click*). And of course, we shan't forget the simple fact of how amazing this game is for being made by ONE guy. It truly is a joy to experience.

I think the thing that 'holds it back' if I were to pinpoint something, is the fact that the story is delivered 100% by text. Even in 'my time' I knew people, friends, acquaintances, who wouldn't bother to read things they were presented, so they skip everything or mash A until it goes away (oh, that rhymed, hah!). I'm the one loser who just eats it up, because I seek meaning in the world around me rather than ride it like it's some kind of tide. But for those who actually do bother to read it, it's GOOD. Someone on the forums described the story as 'akin to a Greek tragedy,' and I feel this is pretty accurate.... for not having any kind of literature degree.

Oh wow, I've already said more than I meant to. So alright, let's wrap this up. The simplest and best way to describe this game is as follows:

Heir apparent to Super Metroid.

If this means something to you, just buy this game already. You absolutely will not regret it.

43997421.review:
Bought on a whim since I thought it looked pretty charming and fun! What I got was exactly that and more. The characters and general design are endearing to a point where I found myself heavily invested in everyone whether I hated their guts due to them being a well-constructed bad dude or hoping for nothing but success for the heroes. Everyone has their flaws as people and it consistently makes each character feel realistic for the setting and situation they're set to. Music being great is a huge plus!

The gameplay being a very metroidvania style but the upgrades are unique to this game. You acquire 4 different crafting parts that you assemble different modifiers to upgrade your character. They act as buffs (speed, wrench power, free damage negation, increased water breathing, etc) until you take damage and they can be regenerated as long as you do some puzzle solving or damage enemies. It's neat as each upgrade is applied to basically first, second and third hits you take... kinda sets you to strategize which buffs you want on the last hit so you can keep running faster or dodging for longer.

I highly recommend this game if you're looking for a nifty Metroidvania that does things a little differently! I'm definitely looking forward to whatever is done next by Joakim Sandberg!!

I'm not sure if I can properly articulate how much I love this game. I have never been so attached to the characters of a platformer, and the developer's rendition of Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata during the (not-so-)final boss sent chills down my spine. For the plot, dialogue, subtle humor, and characters alone, this game is a diamond in the rough.

As a metroidvania, I suppose it's slightly below par, but only because the game doesn't really encourage using any of the tweaks you unlock. Beyond that, the side quests were amusing, the map layout and quick-travel system were really well thought out, and the puzzles and boss patterns were clever. The tower was certainly my favorite area. And for all the complaints I'm reading about the game being too easy, I have to wonder if they beat challenge mode on 100%.

One warning I'll give - although the avatars may be cute, the ending of the game is rather harrowing. It's nice to say this isn't a game for the weak-minded.

43729769.review:
This is one of the best games I've ever played, full stop.

I'm not sure if there was anything I disliked about the game at all, to be honest. Beautiful pixel art graphics, amazing soundtrack, engaging story (and it gets pretty darn dark!) great level design... I think what needs to be stressed the most is the gameplay, tho. Everything feels so fluid. You can spend so long in the first area just messing with the mechanics, because they're just so fun. That's not even to mention the boss fights, which are easily the game's strongest points, in a game full of already strong points. Every single one uses the new and old mechanics given in creative ways. Never did I feel like i got hit by a cheapshot on any boss. The only encounters that really frustrated me was the Blocker boss (conveniently in the screenshots of the game above), which I felt was a bit too finicky with how you fight it. And with another boss (which is spoilers), it wasn't quite clear how to get them down to the ground after stunning them. But with how many bosses the game has, there's bound to be a couple not quite up to speed, and it's stunning how creative and different they all are.

What also gets me is how the method to defeating bosses is something to be inferred by the player. Sometimes, it gives hints if you go without dealing damage long enough, but it's never outright said what to do, and it's not like a hint box pops up either - it comes entirely from character dialogue. 

Although i am gushing a bit here, I will say that the game's not too hard. It's more of a puzzle platformer game, with less focus on combat. This doesn't bother me personally, though.

I can't recommend it enough.

43682981.review:
Iconoclasts is a challenging (and sometimes challenged) jump and puzzle with some metroidvania tendencies. There are the occasional jump and run sequences but largely it is not about 'making that perfect jump sequence' but more about figuring out where you want to go. Excellent controls help.

Some boss fights contain a bit much screen-kill and are a tad hard to read for me but YMMV.

There are a few sequences where you don't play the same character. They are short and few but make you appreciate getting back your powerful main character again.

The world is rather linear. Sure you can go back looking for that previously unreachable pickup but there is little harm in not doing so.

The story is told in monologues by every one else and excellent body language of the protagonist. The mute, pantomiming heroine makes it look like a game for a younger audience but a lot of the story and events are mature enough.

43672291.review:
What an amazing hidden gem this turned out to be. Gorgeous anime-style pixel art serves as the base for a cooky, unique world built by the game's creator. It's a great example of a singular vision that is fully excuted - amazingly held together by a lone developer over the course of many years.

Others have called this a Metroidvania and it certainly is - but the way the story is presented and its overall feel is much more like a classic JRPG. Lots of characters with their own stories and motives, with the player character at the heart of it all in a very endearing way.

It's linear with some backtracking, and the platforming and combat all feel great in your hands. But it's all in the service of telling a quirky story about a strange planet, its moons, and the competing ways of life and their [spoiler]techno-magic space-worm god-machine[/spoiler].

Highly recommended.

43669817.review:
TL;DR: Iconoclasts, despite its handful of shortcomings, is a fantastic experience and is worth the asking price and more. If this type of game is at all interesting to you, it is without a doubt worth picking up.

EDIT: Steam seems to have not counted most of my playtime. I've played this game through and done some postgame content for a total of about 18 hours.


[u]Story:[/u]

    The story of this game is mixed. Many of the characters are pretty archetypal, but all of them were executed well enough that I personally didn't mind.  Dialogue is well written, and all characters have some level of nuance and moral ambiguity with the way they interact with others and fit into the world.

    The plot is interesting enough, if a little cliche. Theocratic dystopia with questionable ideas, impending doom, etc. There's a surprising amount of levity despite the dark premise. There's also quite a few references to LGBT stuff that actually manage to add to the story and worldbuilding. (Take note other game devs) Surprisingly, Iconoclasts does fantastic job at balancing levity through cutesy humor with some incredibly dark themes and moments. 

    Quite a bit of the plot, specifically around the middle of the game, is delivered quite messily, with a handful of concepts brought up without ever getting properly followed up. I feel like this game would benefit greatly from optional collectable bits of flavor text to flesh things out a little more.

    In spite of all this, the story manages to build a compelling world and has a ton of powerful moments. Much of the story is told partially through missable visuals and gameplay sequences, which is a huge plus as far as I'm concerned. Overall, the story is saved from slightly-above-mediocrity by a handful of fantastic stand out moments, and some pretty solid humor throughout.


[u]Presentation:[/u]

    Not a lot to say here, just look at the gameplay trailers. It's consistently great. One small thing I'd like to point out is that, despite the 16-bit style, this game runs in HD. Most animations are allowed to subtly break the pixel grid, which makes everything feel just a tiny bit smoother. There are also a handful of more advanced graphical effects in use, such as screen space refraction in some sections and subtle use of bloom throughout. The soundtrack is also great, although it would benefit from a few more unique tracks. 


[u]Gameplay:[/u]

    Iconoclasts is a puzzle-platformer first and foremost. The puzzle-platformer label is usually applied to puzzle games with platforming elements. This is not the case with Iconoclasts. The puzzles, and the actual platforming, are both treated as equally important. Both are decent on their own, but the game is at its best when it combines both seamlessly; which, thankfully, is most of the game. 

    There is also a somewhat heavy focus on combat. For the most part, combat is an extension of the platforming, puzzles, or both. All of these converge together to make some of the best and most creative boss battles I've ever played - many of which are also simultaneously well-executed story sequences. 

    Each major area introduces one or two new elements used throughout the area, and sparingly throughout the rest of the game world. These are used expertly, most memorably the many variants of the bolts, in platforming bits, puzzles, and even boss fights. The best uses of these elements are in some of the games optional puzzle rooms, which combine different elements in really interesting and novel ways. My biggest gripe with this is that there are criminally few of these more complex and difficult puzzles. What was there was fantastic; but I finished the game feeling there was a lot more that could have been done with the mechanics its introduced.

   There are metroidvania elements throughout. These are well done, but mainly used as a way to gate complexity and keep things manageable. There are also bits where metroidvania elements are used to promote exploration, but this is in no way the main focus.

   Collectibles are materials or blueprints, which let the player craft different tweaks - small buffs that can be equipped to one of three slots. This system isn't particularly complex, but offers some compelling choices. What's more useful: Increased melee damage, immunity to one attack, or slightly easier parries and charges? Of course, it depends on the player. The one exception to this is the 'dodger' tweak which gives you a dodge roll and is unambiguously the best tweak. It's also the hardest to get, so this is fine by me; others may take issue though. Tweaks will be deactivated one at a time upon taking a hit, and can be reactivated by destroying enemies or objects. Tweaks always deactivate in the same order so there's some strategy involved in slot selection. The tweak system adds an incentive to collect the already rewarding collectables, and a reason to avoid damage, even if ample health and regen is available.


[u]Conclusion:[/u]

I find numeric ratings to be overly general, but if I had to give one to Iconoclasts it would be a 9 out of 10. Considering how ambitious it is, and the handful of areas it falls short, that should say something about how amazing this game can get at it's high moments. It should also say something that my most substantial complaints about this game are essentially that there isn't more of it. It may not be perfect, but for an ambitious $20 indie game, made by one person nonetheless, Iconoclasts is truly incredible, and without a doubt worth playing.

43556421.review:
This metroidvania is simultaneously amazing in a lot of respects and a good amount of missed potential. The game itself is gorgeous, the colour palettes of each area, the themes and the aniamations while not always fluid are polished and natural looking. Level design is a bit 'meh', it's not awful, but there are parts that rely on hidden passages with minimal indication, bosses that rely on multiple attempts to divine what method of attack works at a certain stage and a lot of unnecessary backtracking. Difficulty isn't really that high, I played the 'harder' difficulty and it never took more than a few goes. The quest tracking is minimal and doesn't let you track any side quests (I also never found out of there was a point to side quests as there wasn't any reward) and loot is reserved for one time boosts. Progression is more linked to your "Zelda" tool procurement through the story than to loot.

Easily the strongest part of this game for me was the world building and story which is not usually a marking point for metroidvanias in my experience, this isn't to say it's a masterclass in writing but you can tell the sheer amount of effort that was put into just the story as it progresses. The main character legitimately had me gushing over how cute she was through the entirety of the game, for a pixely metroidvania I never thought I'd want to spend so much time crawling and listening to the *patpatpat* of the animation. Despite being mostly silent the MC has a bit more character than your standard silent MC, you are offered some dialogue options through the game (which I'm not sure change the result) but it definitely lends to colouring the MC in. Suffice to say I loved her design.

This leads me to my last point, the other characters. All the characters are very unique and contain their own personality really well, they are not always the deepest or complex characters but that's hardly necessary in a metroidvania. Within the game you are offered a few stages where you can play as two other characters and therein lies my gripe about missed potential. Every named character feels like they could be a playable character at some point and it makes me incredibly salty that I have a less than 5 stages to work with these creations. I hope they do more in another game or DLC with these characters as I feel it would really be a shame to waste all the love that was put into writing these characters whether it's a backstory instalment or a tribute to the character designs. 

In conclusion, while the gameplay is a bit 'meh' and could use a better progression system, the game's strong point lies in the world building and characters. The fact you're able to play some of the other characters in certain stages leaves the game as a giant tease for me and I hope they are working on something to flesh them out whether directly or as a tribute to the character designs. Gets an 8/10 on my arbitrary rating scale with the potential for ~8.5 if they worked on the above.

43519213.review:
Iconoclasts is a worthy addition to the library of anyone who enjoys exploration- and/or puzzle-based platformer games. Its minor flaws are overshadowed by its classic platformer gameplay, vibrant and expressive pixel graphics, and good soundtrack.

Metroidvania purists may not find perfect satisfaction with Iconoclasts. It follows a primarily linear progression with bits of narrative and dialog interspersed. However, it does indeed have a large, persistent world with exploration enabled by item and ability upgrades.

The game can be a bit long-winded in exposition, and some of the dialog is a little awkward at times.

Iconoclasts fairly nailed its difficulty level. Standard is occasionally challenging without being frustrating, harder is slightly more difficult with seemingly-fewer health pickups and more enemies. If you’re feeling particularly masochistic, there is an unlockable challenge difficulty where you die in one hit.

Expect a play-through to take 5-10 hours, with more for total completion.

The bottom line:
I solidly recommend Iconoclasts for fans of old-school platformers and look forward to the next game by its developer.

This one can easily win any awards even Game of The Year.

OK, so it's the background of the game, now I will tell you why I'm begging you to buy at least 2 copies of this game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]Have you ever play Metroid on Gameboy Advance ? Megaman Zero on Gameboy Advance ? Kirby on Gameboy Advance ? If you played one of those games I will describe it in one sentence: This game can stand among those legends. If you haven't, you don't need to worry I will tell you. This game is a 2D Pixel Platformer packed with actions, puzzles, bosses, secrets, choice matters (Yes, you hear me right, choice MATTERS). Each feature deserves it own description, so ... here we go, it's gonna long, LOL !
[h1]Action[/h1]This aspect feel mostly like Megaman Zero, where you shoot, slash, jump, grab, use gadgets to defeat enemies, unlock new paths or explore secrets, fight bosses ... It won't get bored because it combine action and puzzle very well ! The more you play the more you want to play.

Don't worry, it is challenge indeed but it is not frustrated, plus the levels is well designed so that you can enjoy while solving the puzzle.
[h1]Bosses[/h1]You will definitely love this one, I swear. The Bosses are many and various, each boss fight is something to remember ! And just like what I said with the puzzle, it is challenge indeed but it is not frustrated.
[h1]Choice matters[/h1]The game does has choice matters which add up to the replay value of the game.

[h1]Story[/h1]Story is deep, interesting and twisted. 43408473.review:
The [b]main[/b] reason I bought this game was because it promised to be a Metroidvania that leans more towards the Metroid part then the Castlevania part in Metroidvania. Few Metroidvanias have you run around and jump'n [i]shoot...[/i] most are melee based.
The second reason was... because I [b]really like[/b] the style of the pixelart it has and the gameplay somewhat reminds me of the likes of Gunstar Heroes and Mischief Makers.

However... Iconoclasts is a [i]very[/i] Linear game. It doesn't lets you [i]off the leash[/i] at all.
It starts out with a small story-dump, then it lets you roam free in a small, curated area where in reality you can go to two places; a dead-end with crafting materials and the exit continuing on your way in the story. You get each tool at certain story beats, also there are not all that many enemies to fight in those exploration areas, they mostly consist of puzzles.
Most Bosses are in the same vein a mostly "know how to beat", you need to figure out a gimmick and once you know it it is borderline trivial to beat most bosses. There [i]are[/i] a few bosses that are more traditional in the sense that you have to analyse their attack patterns and then have the skill to evade them.

The [b] reason [/b] for me to downvote Iconoclasts is that it is a [b] Puzzle Platformer [/b] first and Mainly. I was expecting a [b] Action Adventure [/b] where you are free to explore, roam around in a world left to your devices. After all it [i]wrongly[/i] states "Metroidvania" as one of the tags.

For me Iconoclasts is a Fun little Puzzle Platformer at best, with a story that entertains pretty well, gorgeous pixelart and a nice sound track.

43395159.review: Good metroid gameplay, fairly long (10 hours for my first playthrough), and an interesting plot that won't be for everyone but I enjoyed. If you like well developed characters, religious themes, space worms, and cynicism you should pick this up. There's a few irritating gimmick boss fights that I didn't love in the middle third.

43381176.review:
The game has great art, it toys with a lot of Metroidvania cliches in interesting ways, and the general setting and plot are fun apocalyptic stuff. Some of the characters are interesting and there are a lot of funny cutscenes. Unfortunately, all of that is punctuation on gameplay that feels like a best hits collection of bad Playstation era puzzle minigames.

Iconoclasts wants to feel like a Metroidvania where, instead of shooting/stabbing baddies until they die, you use nonstandard or creative methods to deal with encounters. That's fine and in keeping with the theme (you're a mechanic with a mediocre stun gun, not Samus), but it relies on an assumption that the mechanics are solid, and the game is consistent about conveying to you what kinds of interactions are valid on the various objects and enemies. Neither of those statements are true.

In terms of making its expectations clear, the game is abysmal. Sometimes you're told something can be parried with an animation, sometimes you get the animation once, sometimes you don't get it at all. Some enemies that look fixed to terrain can be detached from their mounts, but other enemies with the same aesthetic in the same area are inexplicably immune. One recurring miniboss is immune to some attacks in one fight but not in another, and nothing changes about them or the environment that would explain why. Sidekicks are frequently a nuissance, showing up in fights where they don't meaningfull contribute anything except visual noise, and then appear later as critical elements of other fights. For a game with so much effort put into the sprite art, it desperately needs much of that art removed or streamlined to restore some sanity to what's actually hapening.

Once you've figured out what the rules are for any given scenario, you're mostly just going through motions. The gimmicks are 90% of an encounter, and once you've deciphered what the gimmick is, there's nothing else to it. This would be bearable (in the sense that replaying a puzzle game you're already overly familiar with is boring, but not offensively so), but the general mechanical looseness makes it feel like a chore. You might entiely know what to do to clear something, but will take a couple hits because you forgot the exact way a given ability or weapon was finnicky.

Ten hours later, I feel like I should have watched a Let's Play while playing Metroid on another monitor with the sound off. Learn from my mistakes, save yourself this dire fate.

43360273.review: El juego me atrajó por el tipo de gráficos que tenía y me atrapó por la diversa jugabilidad que se puede tener con el personaje principal. El soundtrack es buenísimo y la historia es bastante interesante, recomendadísimo si quieres jugar un juego al estilo megaman. Lo único que no me gustó es el hecho de que no se pueden utilizar los demás de personajes (y yo creía que sí se podría), salvo en unas ocasiones, del resto súper bien todo.

43341932.review: Top notch animations, tight controls, a killer soundtrack, and some amazing boss fights.  Well worth the money.

43333247.review:
It’s got a great art style and animation but Iconoclasts has far too much of an emphasis on story for me.

Besides the opening areas, Iconoclasts is litter with tiresomely long interruptions from the story. Over time, this slowly degraded my connection to the world and its inhabitants. Every significant character is either consistently angry, wildly angsty, or obnoxiously preachy. So many conservations boil down arguments over religious beliefs, lengthy exposition, or incessantly highlighting character flaws. These increasingly occur throughout the game to a point where it’s hard to through hallways without a quick pause for a chat. My version of Robin became more and more dissonant from the rest of the cast. She just idly watches others argue or gets preached to while standing there quietly, waiting to go fix everyone’s problems. They’re label as party characters hardly suits them as they only follow you around arguing or show up as set pieces in boss fights. [spoiler]The rare opportunity to play as Mina was a nice mix-up. Elro’s one showcase as a ‘rock-paper-scissor’ boss fight was a disappointment [/spoiler].


There’s a fantastic moment of ‘show don’t tell’ when [spoiler]you come across skeletons bathed in ivory underneath a room full of chambers[/spoiler]. However, any eeriness is lost on a prior exposition dump explaining exactly what you’re seeing. If it was even preferable to include, it may have been a better choice to add that lecture after having seen that room, since it would’ve piqued your curiosity. Correspondingly, you even find the character who gave you that exposition in the next room.

Iconoclasts feels desperate to have deep lore and feel the need to put much of it front in center. There’s an expectation to be acutely invested in the world and its societies. Having that world building for those interested is fantastic, but respectfully placing it off to the side can add length for the curious and convenience for the indifferent. 

Why not convey the thoroughly religious world through visiting countless monasteries full of lore. Perhaps give the player the [i]choice[/i] to talk to characters on their own time to learn more about them. The game already does this well with townsfolk, a personal favorite being [spoiler]the man on the ground weary from working so hard to get his child into the great city[/spoiler].



Iconoclasts feels small. I know it’s not mandatory, and even effective, for a game to not follow the trends of its genre but Iconoclast’s secrets and upgrades are severely lacking. 

There are only three significant upgrades which serve up some great puzzles and combat variety. There only downfall is their overuse. Because they’re so limited in quantity, puzzles lack variety in the long term and become incredibly straightforward with familiarity.

Moronically, I didn’t realize that tweaks were equippable for a portion of the game. However, that wasn’t that big of a problem. The wide majority are useless and, unless yet again I’ve misunderstood things, there are only three slots to use, making a large host of tweaks pointless. Tweaks in general also do very little. The only one I’d suggest is the tweak that lets you spin the wrench for longer, since it clears up how awkward it is to have the spin the wrench twice to charge it.
This is a personal preference, but I’m not a fan of the negative feedback loops or leveling down for upgrades, so the tweak system further lost its ground with me. Taking damage and losing an upgrade feels counter intuitive. Iconoclasts isn’t this severe, but it revokes the assistance you had when you need it the most. It may be similar in nature to, say, a Mario mushroom, but you don’t actively work for those. Luckily, Iconoclasts’ tweaks are so menial that this doesn’t become a concern outside of that wrench-spinning convenience.

Tweaks are created by crafting with materials that are found in optional secret chests. Several material are required for each tweak and you don’t know what tweak is going to be in a chest. The majority of materials will only let you create repeats of the simpler tweaks. I only found myself going after chests when it was convenient and for the sake of the puzzle. Due to the randomness and uselessness of materials, there was no reason to backtrack or explore, substantially neglecting a critical feature that Iconoclast pushes for.

Since there are no permeant survival improvements, the sense of long term improvement and accomplishment, a metroidvania genre essential, is utterly neglected. This also means that the final boss is just as much of a chump as the first boss you face.

There are only a few areas. The opening two were wonderful and loop around themselves well and are completely uninterrupted. My first impressions of Iconoclasts was nothing but positive. As the plot sets in, it becomes harder to spend time in the meat of the experience which itself slowly loses complexity.  Getting one of the few power-ups breathes new life temporarily but these few occasions aren’t enough to fill up the deserts between them

Bosses can are hit or miss. Combat in Iconoclasts is one of its stronger attributes yet most of the bosses choose to instead offer unique gimmicks that make for a few clever ‘thinking-on-your-feet’ puzzles. The skill focused or smaller ‘unlock the weakpoint’ encounters were really well executed. Several other fights tried out either dull or confusing ideas or are were about passive survival. Disappointingly, I found myself still succeeding in the more disorienting boss fights, bypassing an potentially rewarding situation.



I always feel the need to apologize after producing reviews like. The length and critical tone of this post means nothing against the insanely hard working developers whose long-term devotion to projects like this is something I look up to.

I know it’s always easier to list the problems with something since they are citable examples and the moments stick out more prevalently. The ‘reviews’ I toss together act as a way to practice writing and reflection while treating games as more than a consumable medium. It’s my personal way to divulge my thoughts on an intriguing subject since I have few people around me that might care about or relate to. Experiences where I find disconnects offer insight into my personal preferences and help me accumulate information that might help me build my own project one day.

I’d like to place more emphasis on my outstanding time at the beginning of Iconoclasts and the effort that went into the graphics, which were what had initially drawn me the game. Those who do connect with the story will likely find Iconoclasts to be far more substantial.

43288521.review:
Iconoclasts is a metroidvania with heavy story elements. If that last bit sounds just as appealing as having butterknifes in your eyes, you are in the same boat I was in. Unfortunately for me, an indie game called Night in the Woods absolutely ruined story-emphazied  games for me because there was absolutely no gameplay and only complete waste of 9 hours. Thankfully, I cannot say the same for Joakim Sangberg's "Iconoclasts". Not only is the story set in an incredibly unique and rich world that feels as original as it is colorful, but being a metroidvania, it has a whole lot of gameplay on calcium-rich story skeleton. Heres the easy pro-con list.
PROS:
() Sprite Work - I know, another indie with pixel art, whoopdeedoo, what next, am I going to get another broke college kids art potfoilio? Ok sure, its not exactly a unique style but the ANIMATION is fucking insane. Just to fast travel from one point to another the character will go through about 10 animations in a 10 second period of time. Its unbeilevable.
() Story - Yeah, its a tough thing to write in a videogame when half of the market is out playing EA sports games anually and the other half sticks the same games that get the most views on Twitch. Thankfully, I think Konjak did a great job making the world and characters feel pretty authentic. Each character has their own motivations and the world has enough problems to make players strive to fix them. 
() Music - Its not the MOST amazing stuff I've heard in an OST, but it certainly fits the bill quite nicely and sets atmosphere with ease, although I partly wish it could decide if it wants to be chiptune or not. 
() Theming - I know that I can very easily HATE it when games smack you with the skillet of "Oh hey wow we have real world messages, let us poke holes in the fourth wall so you can feel InSpIiIIiiiReD!!" Thank god Konjak was subtle in implementation, cause that was my big concern going into the game. For example, there is a bit of an LGBT(etc.) message in there, but I didnt really catch it until after I beat the game, but looking back Im able to feel a little stupid for not seeing it earlier on. 
() Humour - Not much more to say, the game never misses a joke.
() Tone - Its fun exterior hides a pretty dark plot, which Im down for, seeing as how the game doesnt go MEGA EDGY.
() Puzzles - For me, all of them hit that perfect balance of challenge and accomplishment. The only things I had to look up was hidden walls. 
() Variety - the end experience feels completely different from the start. 
() Combat - Is good. Is not great, but is good. 
() Authentic Indie Experience: No I dont mean this in a stupid Hipster way, but this game was made by ONE PERSON. ONE PERSON. Holy Flying FUCK! Ya gotta give a men credit where credit is due. 
CONS:
() Difficulty - No, its not that its too hard to or too easy, but the game gives yet another main menu difficulty select option that just ruins everything as it gives the player absolutely no context of what is easy and what is hard, which can a destroy a players experience before the game has even begun. 
() Length - Its a really Short game. It took me like 10-12 hours to beat without 100% completion, and 100%ing only took 15.5 hours. Because of pretty much only that reason I feel like Asking for 20 bucks is a bit much. A full price game wouldnt even give you a dollar "back" per hour. I reccomend getting this on sale. -15% was enough for me, although I should say that this is definetly a quality over quantity game. 
() No neat cutscenes - Yeah this is as nitpick as it gets, but the trailer had really good cutscenes that the game just never uses. I guess thats the cost of 1 person development. 
() Achievements - There really arent that many, and in 15 hours I had 91% completion, which is a bummer, but it brought my average game completion up so I guess I cant complain too much. 

Well there you have it! As per usual, the cons are mostly nitpicks that couldnt be changed without a decent amount of work put into them (except maybe acheivements). If you see it on sale once more, I'd reccommend picking it up without a doubt! Great Presentation, Surprising Story, Strong Themes, Sense of Humour, Wonderful pacing, and amazing puzzles. It might not be super long, but I'd easily pay $5 bucks per hour for later half of the game. This definetly mends some of story concerns I had going in.
Yet again Metroidvanias prove their dominance.

43281604.review: Tries too hard to have an interesting story, and fails. Has boring, one-dimension characters. Not even a Let's Play; you want as little time invested in this tryhard as possible. 43265868.review: I have yet to even beat this game and my mind keeps being drawn to it when away from my computer.  The world that was built is lush and vibrant with not only color yet also life.  The Characters at this point all feel real and like someone you could run into on the street or through random hapinstance. 43263407.review:
I’m going to do something that I don’t usually like to do here: I’m going to refrain from going too in-depth. The reason for that is a simple but possibly unexpected one: I don’t want to spoil the game’s story.

I’ll summarise by saying this: It’s very good. Seriously, I’m not usually one to praise a game for it’s story mostly because I rarely care about them beyond the surface level context, but the game’s pacing, character arcs, worldbuilding, and overall narrative is unexpectedly captivating.

The pacing is probably it’s biggest achievement. It starts off pretty innocuous and typical for games of it’s ilk, but slowly and methodically over the course of the game builds up the tension and intrigue, before eventually catapulting into a jaw dropping finale that by the end will have gone so far off the deep end you’ll have to ask yourself   “WHAT GAME AM I EVEN PLAYING ANYMORE!?"

The gameplay, while pretty solid, is a bit less noteworthy. It can be a little obtuse at times: there were a few cases where I got completely stumped and had to look up a strategy or tip, and finding secrets is a bit more of a challenge than I’d really like. But overall I enjoyed it and it served its purpose well enough: It’s focus on puzzles more than on combat is a refreshing change of pace, it’s bosses are both visually spectacular and challenging fights in their own right, and the overall challenge of the game ramps up appropriately to reinforce the context of the game’s story. It’s an amazingly polished experience, I can definitely say that the nearly a decade amount of work Sandburg put into this absolutely paid off.

I went into this game expecting something fun, challenging, and scratching that metroid Itch and while I can’t say that my expectations were fully met, I certainly would never say that I left the game feeling disappointed. If you’re like me and just want something fun to play, I do still recommend this game. Just be aware that it will go places you would never expect; and that most certainly is not a bad thing.

43260091.review: A good puzzle-platformer with a great story and presentation. Owlboy is an apt comparison.

43256200.review:
SOME SPOILERS, NOTHING TOO MAJOR REALLY
This game is alright, and the review will be broken into STORY, CHARACTERS, COMBAT, and BOSSES.
STORY - The story is actually pretty good, or at least engaging enough to keep you playing. The contrasting artificial and natural is nice and helps show the player what faction is in charge of what place. At first I thought the whole game was just going to be stylized blocks, but finding the first natural plants really helped show that the stylized block areas aren't natural. The story is about a young mechanic, while being a mechanic is punishable by death, and a war between two different religions. After playing through the game, I found a lot of questions were simply never answered. Why is being a mechanic illegal? Why can't the two factions simple talk to each other, they clearly have two different origins! What on earth is that twist at the end?

Beating the game took me about nine hours, which I'd say is a decent length for its price. However...

CHARACTERS - While most of the characters are fun and charming, none of them seem to be the ones who travel with you. While you are off doing a cool adventure, having fun twisting bolts and the like, most of your companions just want to scream at each other. It's cool to have a character who, without their presence, the quest would be doomed to failure, but's another thing to have everyone except you be useless because they can't, and don't try to, get alone. Most of this seems to come from Elro, who is the main character's brother. He is the worst. The game always seems to go out of its way to show Elro in a cynical, uncooperative, unproductive, whiney, controling jerk, which is weird when by the end of the game you get to play as Elro for awhile and he's super powerful. Everyone else has to clear their own bossfight and they all use guns and stage hazards, but Elro is missing one arm, missing one eye, walks really slowly, and has a broken sword for a weapon. So what does Elro do? He walks up to his boss fight and stabs it to death. 
Another person who is really annoying is Mina, a pirate girl with a powerful shotgun. While Elro is cynical, Mina is grating and unbelivably hostile to nearly everyone you meet. Also, out of all the people screaming at each other Mina is determined to scream the loudest, regardless of what going on. More about her later, as there are a few parts of the game where you get to play as Mina.

COMBAT - For the most part, combat is okay. You can only aim your gun in four directions, up, down, left, right, but if you get close to an enemy there is a sort of lock on feature that lets you just shot them instead of having to worry about aiming. This, by itself, would be fine but there is a second combat mechanic that functions something like Cave Story. In Cave Story, killing enemies powers up your weapons and taking damage powers down your weapons. In Iconoclasts, instead of powering up your weapon killing enemies fills up your Tweak gauge. Tweaks are small changes that you can equip, and you can equip up too three at a time, but most of them are so minor that I didn't really care about them. The other thing that made me not care the tweaks is that taking a single hit, from anything, deactivates a tweak. Killing an enemy, or completing a puzzle, gives you about a third of a gauge. This results in having plenty of health, but one or no tweaks active, which means you tend not to rely on tweaks because of how rarely you actually have them. To make this just a bit worse, saving fully heals you but does not fill tweak gauges.

You do get more weapons, like you would in any other metroidvania, but they never felt better than the starting gun. The reason for this is because every other gun overheats as you use it, but the starting gun can be fired as fast as you can mash the button. This makes the other guns feel more like tools for solving a puzzle, not weapons you want to use in combat. There's also a charge mechanic, but it's not useful. A normal charge mechanic has you wait to charge up to deal more damage and after the charged shot is fired you can immediatly go back to normal shooting. In Iconoclasts, you wait to charge up to deal more damage, fire the shot, then you have to wait again for an overhear gauge to empty. In the time it takes for you to charge, fire, and cool down you could be doing more damage with regular shooting.

Then there's playing as Mina. This is awful. Every movement option or tweak you have normally, Mina doesn't have and she doesn't have anything to replace it with. This adds to not relying on tweaks because you learn that if the game switchs you to a different character then you don't have any tweaks. The biggest problem Mina has is her shotgun. Normally, you just auto aim at enemies, but Mina's shotgun does not work like that. Instead, whenever you want Mina to fire the gun she has to stop moving, a targetting line appears, then you aim by pressing up or down, then after firing Mina can't move again until she completes a reloading animation. Compare all those steps to playing as anyone other than Mina. Normally, if you want to fire your gun you just press the button and do it. Mina removes the fun, fast paced combat in favor of a really clunky gun.

BOSSES - The bosses were... fine. They aren't really a challenge once you figure out their gimmick, but a number of times I died to a boss, looked up how to beat the boss, and was certain I had already tried what the video was doing. The reason I looked up how to beat a boss was because on my first try I was certain I had tried everything, but nothing worked. Sometimes this was so bad that I thought the game was just broken. There are also some bosses that are just plain annoying. Near the end you fight a boss whose is gimmick the room is filling up with a deadly neurotoxin, slowly killing you,  and the bosses strategy is seriously to just stall for time.

CONCLUSION - Yeah, the game is alright. For all I grip about the game does have its moments, but it's not so good that I want to get 100% in the game.

43255946.review:
Iconoclasts was alright... as far as the game is concerned that's about all I can say, since there's no option between yes and no for recommending it I'd have to give it a yes as I generally enjoyed the 8.5 hours I got out of my playthrough.

For those who don't want to read the entire thing 
TL;DR
-Generally good gameplay
-Good levels and boss fights
-Great character/ world building
-Gorgeous art and soundtrack

-Pointless Tweak System
-Story completely loses the plot halfway
-Pacing gets atrocious

Overall I'd give it a 7/10 

Not particularly great but just alright, recommended only at a discount.

The Good Stuff:

The art is blooming fantastic, everything is brightly and vibrantly colored to fit the mood of the area, without ever being too over saturated, all the NPC's and enemies are delightfully animated and full of life and the bosses are all unique and a wonder to fight, Robin in particular is so fluid and expressive with all of her animations which can change depending on her environment, and there's small details all throughout the game.

The music is also bloody good, wouldn't say it's one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard but it does have some solid bangers in there. (In particular Blockrock, Shard Wastelands and Machines were my favorites)

Character dialogue and building is strong and charming throughout the entire game, and consistently was the main driving force of the story, which sad to say really drops the ball around the midpoint of the game. (Thats for in a minute though)

Gameplay:

While it's somewhat toted as a Metroidvania it's more of a very linear platformed with the occasional side path or something you'll have to come back later with a new ability, though it's only ever for optional materials. You'll have a wrench which you can use for some basic melee attacks, a stun gun which renders melee attacking completely pointless except for when absolutely needed and later on 2 different forms of firing the stun gun for combat and puzzle solving.

The wrench is instead primarily used as a puzzle solver/ mobility tool, allowing you to grapple onto certain screws to swing yourself across gaps and eventually use zipline systems, it's relatively simple but allows for some clever a-ha! moments throughout the game with some of it's puzzles which are generally fairly simple in concept and execution but they don't overstay their welcome and are mostly quite fun.

Now I mentioned materials earlier, those are used to craft Tweaks which are used for the Tweak system and to put it bluntly... It's kinda entirely pointless.

You can have 3 tweaks attached at the same time, whenever you take damage the tweak furthest to the right is destroyed and becomes inactive until you fill it with enough crystal.... things, gotten from performing certain tasks, collecting things or just killing enemies. Kinda like how Cave Story handles it's weapon level systems.

Sounds fine so far, only issue is all of the tweaks are only minor stat boosts, which at best are somewhat useful (aka the +speed or Free Hit Absorbtion tweaks) and at worst are completely ineffective and make the whole system feel moot. (For example there are some for holding breath longer, there's no area in the entire game where you would need to hold your breath that much longer and the timer is already plenty generous)

As a result of the tweaks feeling useless, finding materials and new recipes for new tweaks quickly gets unfulfilling as you continue to get extra Breath Holding and Wrench damage ups, knowing full well they will never actively help you in-game.

Something I find particularly egregious is that around 2-3 hours into the game you gain the ability to charge your wrench by holding the attack button to spin it up, however the issue is it'll stop spinning before it reaches max charge which you can't get unless you charge it another time which eats up atleast another second EVERY time you need a full charge.
Now there's tweaks to elongate the time you can spin for and you only need 1 equipped to make it a charge but the fact your ability to charge the wrench is deliberately crippled unless you waste atleast 1/3 of your slots just felt aggravating, especially when puzzles revolved around charging up and de-charging the wrench.

Combat is also fairly bland, decent enemy variety in the beginning but after long enough (especially late game) you just end up fighting the same 4-5 troopers who all can generally just be gunned down. Or you can just run past any enemy you can because there's nothing to gain from fighting enemies unless they are blocking your only path with no way around, there's no rewards for killing enemies except for tweak energy and health (only drops when low on health though), both of which you lose from fighting them so might as well just make a B-line straight past them entirely.

Bosses are generally quite fun and are fine for the most part but sometimes they are just egregious with not telling or showing what you need to do to actually kill or attack them. Just for example there's a boss who attacks you with a sword around 3-4 hours in roughly who you need to parry the attacks of with your wrench, problem being is that you're never made aware of the fact you could even parry a melee attack nor the cues for what is parry-able (I only figured it out from reading up on how to actually beat the guy) and what isn't and to top it all off his character design as a very solid sewer grate looking thing on his head so you think 'oh might need to stomp him to stun him', nope just gets you instantly sliced and receive damage.

And to spoil something real quick that boss fight? [spoiler]No idea what his identity was, no idea what his allegiance was, no idea what even his bloody name was, he gets possessed for another fight shortly after saving you from certain death and dumping you in a cave, then he just dies via drowning by getting stuck under a rock and that's it for his story. He never gets brought up again and is never addressed why he decided to attack you in the tower and then save you from it.[/spoiler]

And unfortunately this is pretty much how the entire story goes, it starts off really strong, getting a setting going, getting the villians and allies set up, some good world building, some lore, then halfway through the game it just kinda gives up [spoiler]the Big Bad Mother set up as some god like deity being bestowed by the gods just makes a giant cat out of rocks and then dies as easily as any agent, General Chrome survives an anti-Ivory injection given by ONE OF THEIR OWN TROOPERS for no real reason and then gets injected by the same Injection later by Elor and then dies from that for no reason, no real questions raised throughout the entire thing are answered and turns out entire thing happens because of Bird Aliens who ride space ships that look like worms, tries to take the Ivory off the planet i guess until you kill him and then his space ship kills him and..... that's it every one lives happily ever after, never mind that there're still leaders and troopers for the White Goo Scientologists who don't have any reason to stop what they're doing and actively are still out there, never mind the fact there are hundreds if not thousands dead from rioting and genocide via Scientologists, nah everythings cool now and I guess Robin's Daddy Issues(?!?) are resolved? If not for that I have no idea what the point was behind that scene when robin gets mind fucked by the space sperm ship.[/spoiler]

All that being said that wouldn't be necessarily the worst thing (Yeah I know Hur Dur, story in a platformer), except around halfway into the game it gets incredibly story focused with the dungeons and puzzles slowly getting replaced with straight corridor combat sequences with previous enemies and increasingly simple puzzles with increasingly easy and confusing bosses with long winded story cutscenes gradually taking up more and more and more of the actual play time.

43242760.review:
Iconoclasts is an interesting, medium sized game that doesn't outstay its welcome and never drops the charm.

Ultimately, this game is a creative game that appeals to creatives. An absolutely atypical setting sets it aside from all other games of its genre and others. If I were in the habit of scoring the different creative aspects of the game out of the usual 10, I would probably give out:

Setting: 9
Plot: 7.5
Characters: 6
Music: 9.5
Art: 8

No distinct goal from the beginning stops the plot from being overly interesting, and changing goalposts result in a few "Well now what" moments. Ultimately, the story is about the planet, rather than the characters or their direct motivations, so if a good setting is enough for you to put money down, then it's a win/win for you. I am a sucker for dying planet stories. The characters though, either don't get enough time to shine or become somewhat predictable (and there's one point late in the story where you're introduced to a large number of characters at once and it's kinda jarring).

Calling Iconoclasts a Metroidvania is an... interesting label, to say the least. It certainly has a Metroid style map, and you can get items to craft upgrades... But you can only equip 3, for the entire game. So once you've got your loadout, each pickup becomes merely a fun puzzle or completionist's habit, rather than to inherently power yourself up.

A similarity that comes to mind is Owlboy; a rather linear game that upgrades only very few times, but plenty of things remain collectible around the world for those willing to probe at it. However, if your money was on the line and you had to pick Owlboy or Iconoclasts, my suggestion would be Iconoclasts all the way.

Either way you slice it, it's a great game with fantastic music that doesn't stray into "Okay bored now skipping all the upgrades" like I did with other recent Metroidvanias like Guacamelee and... actual Metroid. A great weekend game if you're into the genre, or looking to get into it. Gets pretty dark a couple times though; don't buy it for tiny children.

42987279.review:
One of the best Metroidvanias I have played, this has been directly inspired by Metroid Fusion. The game starts out all vibrant and cheerful but turns into a dark and dramatic story that questions mankind. Iconoclasts is a sci-fi tale ruled by a religious government who call themselves "The One Concern" whose main goal is to harvest Ivory fuel and anyone who goes against their wishes will face a religious execution known as "Penance". 

The gameplay is fantastic and has every recipe that makes a good Metroidvania/Platformer. The pixel art and animation is top notch, the environments are extremely detailed providing you with enough action as you use your arsenal to solve all the intricate puzzles. The boss battles are unique and fun without being cookie cutter predictable. I love how the game keeps throwing something new and strange so you never feel bored although there is a bit of back tracking involved. 

You will meet a diverse set of characters and they are a likeble bunch including the antagonists. In fact one of my favorite character is one of the primary villains that you frequently face named Agent Black. The soundtrack was pleasant while I can't say it's very memorable but certain tracks did stand out from the rest. 

This is certainly the best game I have played so far this year and If you like compelling storylines, great boss battles, intricate puzzles, exploration and good music to go with it, then Iconoclasts deserves to be played multiple times.

42791296.review:
[h1] The 'Eh?' Heard Around the World [/h1]

(Warning; spoilers ahead. Prepare yourself)

Have you played a game called Iconoclasts? If not, be prepared to be get thoroughly confused by this review, because I'm about to mention a lot of things that don't make sense.

In a world where Ivory is the rarest material, and Fate decides everything, young Robin wishes to become a mechanical wizard. Fixing things, screwing bolts, that sort of stuff. Unforunately, she'll not get the chance, and instead have to fight monsters and members of the One Concern, the mild threat of the Earth, as well as The Starworm (This game's God).

The catch with this game is that as you do, you begin getting roped into hundreds of different things that you shouldn't. There's a youtube channel called Gellot who did every boss fight in this game, and I highly suggest you go watch it if you don't feel like going through meager gameplay with absolutely stunning backgrounds and difficult puzzles.

The issue is, as much as I enjoyed the game, I stopped enjoying myself around the sixth hour.

That's right. The SIXTH hour. My time is one of the fastest blind runs of the game, and that's not a joke. I can honestly admit that the final boss of the game, [spoiler]The Starworm and the strange bird person that comes out of it for some reason[/spoiler] is actually less final than the boss that came before it. The game is stunning, visually, but nowadays a visual game with thin gameplay is harder to enjoy than it should. The puzzles seem overally tedious at points, despite having very unique mechanical structure (The electrical grenades, for example), but they're not used past the place they get introduced.

Don't get it twisted, by the way; I still enjoyed myself. I've not had a better experience with a metroidvania, and with the release of CrossCode approaching it got me hyped to play it, but I do need to emphasise the fact that you'll be playing a game with less game than I feel it deserved.

So, still here? Still not convinced about whether you should buy or not? Good, my complaints can now begin much worse.

What the hell was that final boss? I feel so bogged out by the concept that I couldn't enjoy the anticlimatic ending that came after it. Funnily enough, as stated above, the pennultimate boss was the boss I enjoyed the most, because not only did it utilise all the tools you picked up, it was absolutely terrifying in concept. I wish I could play it again without having to go through everything again.

Because, as stated above, this game is EIGHT HOURS LONG. That's without all the sidequests and collectables getting in the way. I didn't do any of them, as I kinda gave up looking for them after the first one took me thirty minutes to try and do, only for it to glitch out and have no importance to the story.

So, overall, for all its kinks and mysteries, as well as hard-to-enjoy gameplay, odd puzzling....

7/10?

Fortunately for Iconoclasts, I found myself continously dragged back inside the world. The characters were easy to love, and the villians were easy to hate. I found myself wanting to help Robin more and more as she traversed the lands, fighting to see her brother and friends again. I genuinely felt sorry for Royal, a character who only wanted to help Robin, after he [spoiler]ended up getting turned essentially braindead by The Starworm and begged Robin to leave him for dead[/spoiler] during the final act. Elro's tragic backstory and constant abuse, Mina's family woes; I watched it all and wanted to help them at every twist and turn.

So, if you really want to, I'm down to recommend the game. However, just stay aware that the game's gonna take a while to beat, and it's up to you if it's because of the sidequests or the difficult areas.

42712081.review:
A gorgeous, story-driven, non-conventional Metroidvania game that was made with 8+ years of love and care from a single person who poured so much of his heart and soul into developing it can go a long way...and you can definitely tell that this kind of love and care shines through. While typically open-world and non-linear like most Metroidvania games, Iconoclasts's story carefully weaves itself together to intermingle with the gameplay so that neither of them clash, encouraging players to engage with the world while seeing where the story would take them next as they collected as much missing loot as possible. [spoiler] I also found the "give the world one last chance" arc to be a nice touch as it helped to wrap up some loose ends while proving that despite the current situation being grim, there was still a glimmer of hope in saving it. [/spoiler] And speaking of gameplay, I was pretty amazed at how forgiving the checkpoint system was. For instance, if you died to a boss, you would only wind up at the pre-boss cutscene; whereas dying outside of boss battles would only take you back to the start of the room [spoiler] (or the start of the area, in the case of the final area, which is beyond unforgiving). [/spoiler] The tweaks were also quite the helpful bonus, although I will admit I did find myself keeping at least one Iron Heart all the way through to the end (my personal favourite tweak is Meditation, in case you were wondering).

The characters in the game are also pretty neat, especially the main ones. Seriously, how can you deny the cuteness of Robin saying her name by using a pictorial bubble of the bird she was named after? My personal favourite overall character, however, definitely has to be Agent Black, and for a good reason. She's just so sassy and down-to-earth, and her speech near the end was certainly one of the most heart-breaking moments in the game. At least by the end, her soul has managed to find peace (rest well, Madelyn Binoche). Mina and Royal are definitely a close second for me, especially Mina, who was a lot of fun to ally with and play as. The only two characters I didn't like were Elro and Mother, the former for his hypocrisy near the end and the latter for only getting around .5 seconds of screen time (ngl, all she does is attack you with a giant cat and then dies afterward).

Perhaps the main highlight for me are the boss fights. Every fight felt more different and unique than the last, and the bosses themselves are also some of the most non-conventional that I've fought thus far. Furthermore, each boss has their own unique set of attacks so even repeat bosses wouldn't feel so boring. Some of the bosses are pretty challenging, but in a good way, and will occasionally provide you with health pickups in case you ever got yourself in a pinch.

Of course, not every game is perfect, and Iconoclasts is no execption to this rule. Here are a couple of things that I nitpicked while playing through the game:
- I REALLY wish you didn't fight the Silver Watchman in random rooms. I remember getting unlucky both times because the rooms I ended up in had me cornered
- We didn't get much information on what those blue eye things were, though my theory is that they're a parasitic species that are attracted to whatever (or whoever) has Ivory inside of them. [spoiler] This could explain why they were so quick to latch onto Agent Black and (possibly) the Silver Watchman [/spoiler]
- Just a minor one on my end, but I was slightly disappointed that Royal didn't get his own playable segment. I know that the reason for this is due to him not having any weapons on his person save for his psychic powers, but still
[spoiler] - The alien bird guy. 'Nuff said [/spoiler]

Overall, a great game and one that definitely deserves my crown of "Favourite Indie Game of All-Time"! ! would DEFINITELY recommend picking up this game!
