42482759.review:
This is actually one of the best games I've played in a long time.  I'm a big fan of Metroidvania-type platform-shooters (and as a result, I've played a pretty decent amount of them, I think), and this one manages to get a lot of things right and do justice to the genre while really standing on its own, both stylistically and with regards to gameplay.  Controls are tight and well-tuned (if a tad unforgiving at times--but that's fine, I don't like my games to hold my hand), combat is fun and often fast-paced, and there are lots of great, frantic boss fights.  I do see some people in the reviews complaining that they didn't know what to do in certain parts (primarily boss fights), but that's kind of the point of the game--it rewards trial and error and expects that you'll need to take a few tries of finding out what does and does not work and building on that (and I'm totally fine with that because--again--I don't like games to just hold my hand).  The game has a very strong puzzle element to it which is really refreshing in the genre.  This one had me scratching my head a few times but with just a little bit of patience I was able figure each part out.  If you really get stuck, there are plenty of YouTube playthrough videos out there to help (I'll admit, I had to consult those once or twice, but it ended up being something obvious that I had overlooked).  Another thing this game manages to get right is backtracking.  In a lot of games like this, you have to backtrack a lot; while there is some backtracking in this game, it's not overboard by any means (unless you're going for 100% completion, and even then it really isn't too bad at all), and even when I was backtracking I didn't find myself getting bored or anything.  For those who dare to go for a 100% completion, be prepared for some VERY tough (but fun) boss battles.  The secret boss fights are ridiculously fast-paced; an absolute treat for any fan of the genre.  Regarding difficulty, while I can't speak for the normal mode (because I didn't play it), I can say that the "harder" mode had a great challenge level that kept me on my toes through the entire game.  Finally, I have to remark that this game has a really great aesthetic style; the art, music, and story are very well done and fit together nicely.  I rather like how each character is quite flawed and jam-packed with emotional baggage and trauma, just as you'd expect (unless you've lived your entire life in some kind of Stepford community).

Overall, I very much enjoyed this game and heartily recommend it, especially to fans of the genre.

42394274.review:
I love this game. It's not perfect, it's got its flaws, but I really love it. 

Start off to say, this game's main strengths are its art and its story. The animations are realy fluid and springy and cute and really well done, and everything is bright and colorful and happy. We'll get to story in a bit. 

Personally, the gameplay isn't quite as amazing as I would have liked, but that's A-OK. It's a puzzle platformer which usually is a genre that leaves a lot to be desired on its own, so I don't fault it. Generally the puzzles themselves were fun and not too annoying (other than the elevators in the tower stage!!! I hated those, but it wasn't a huge deal.) The bosses are mostly just figure out what to do and then ya know, just do it. It's acceptable! There are "tweaks" but they're not really.... too amazing. Again, eh, it's whatever. 

Only con I'd have to say is the side quests were really just kind of not good. I don't have anything good to say about them. They're very lose, the rewards are not great, the writing for them seems tacked on and a bit lazy, and the gameplay just sort of ends up being "go here, and then go back" and repeat 3 times. At the very least, they're just side quests and because the rewards are so bad, you really do not ever need to do them. Bit of a shame still. 

Anyway, the thing that really clicked for me more than anything was the story. I really loved it. I know a lot of people complain that tonally its all over the place, and honestly? It really is. The tone goes mental. But I love that about it. It keeps you on your toes, and when the serious stuff really goes down it feels a little jarring, yeah, but then it also really sticks with you. It felt very real and I guess "organic" you could say. 

The worldbuilding is really done a lot better than you'd expect. In so little words and so few actions, you're thrust onto this strange planet with all sorts of strange customs and religions and you kind of just accept it easily. Sometimes things can get a little confusing because of this, but overall I really like it better this way than years and years of dialogue explaining that there's TWO MOONS and wHY IS ONE BROKEN and HERE IS WHAT THE CONCERN DOES EXACTLy and what not. It really hooked me into this place and I wanted to really know what made the place tick and why it went down. 

My favorite thing would have to be the characters, though. I love them. They're all very "real" again. Sure, they have weird super powers, are very extremely exaggerated, but they come from a place I think everyone should be able to understand. Everyone's got faults and stuff that they don't like, and some are more faulted than others (YOU KNOW WHO I AM TALKING ABOUT) but the writing never excuses what they do and tries to say oh they're a great person really. Yeah, again, you could easily say its pretty amateur and I think on some levels it is, but again, I couldn't explain it, it just felt really good. You could tell the developer really put their heart and soul into this and tried their best and I respect that. I love the characters at their bests and at their worsts. 

Thing I like was that this game was able to make me laugh and make me feel generally pretty sad at times too. It was often unexpected, but that was kind of what made it special. The story and the characters stick with you even when the game is over and leave you wanting more. 

If you're looking for a game for JUST platforming, I don't think this is gonna be for you. Gameplay is acceptable, but nothing outstanding. Grab Celeste for the opposite of this. Decent story, but much better platforming. This game is meant for a good story with some decent platforming. 

And again, it is not without its flaws.  I loved it either way and think it's worth the price of 20 myself, thanks bye

42378211.review: I honestly enjoy this game quite a bit, fun gameplay, interesting story, a good look, I really have fun playing it.

42375315.review: Cookie cutter Metroidvania platformer with tons of tedious backtracking + Another tiresome dissertation on religion from someone who watched the first half of Fight Club once and memorized the Fifth Edition Monster Manual and now considers themself a master of spirit and universe = One big No Thank You.

42370205.review: I bought the game having heard of the notoriously long dev cycle, but was dissapointed. The more I played, the less interlinked the story felt-- the more drudging it became to get through. It was really fun in the beginning, but as it progressed I couldn't keep interest. I felt the same way about Owlboy, tbh. I think there's a lack of tone maintenance when you spend so long on a game like this. I don't blame the dev, though as life and food on the table do take precedence, and hope they have an easier time on their next project with the takeaways from Iconoclasts.
